column2: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 26. -- Senator F.M. Cockreli of Missouri, who is visiting here, said to-day concerning his proposed appointment on the Isthmian Commission:

BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- The session of the Reichstag, which opens on Tuesday, is likely to be of uncommon interest. The Socialists have full magazines for assaulting the Government on the new Military bill, the relations with Russia, and the German Southwest African war.

Because of the protest registered against R. Todd of the New West Side Athletic Club in the senior cross-country championship of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union last Thursday a meeting of the Registration Committee was held to pass upon the case. John Steil, Chairman, presented evidence which caused the committee to agree that Todd remained under his original suspension.

The steamer Finance, owned by the Panama Railroad Company, having lost her rudder at sea, necessitating a tow part way up from the Isthmus, after she had left her passengers and cargo at Savannah, got afire at the Erie Basin in Brooklyn last evening. The damage to her was $20,000.

BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- Ruggiero Leoncavallo is superintending by invitation of Emperor William the rehearsals of his new opera, "Roland of Berlin," which Emperor William commissioned him to compose six years ago. It will be produced Dec. 12 at the Royal Opera.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 26. -- As a result of the prolonged agitation on the part of the hotel men, backed up by the local and State health authorities, Atlantic City is to have a model sewerage system. Months ago a representative committee of hotel proprietors represented to the sewerage company that the local system was not all that it should be.

NAT GOODWIN, after a brief essay at Shakespearean comedy, has returned to modern, evening-clothes comedy again. To-morrow evening he will appear at the Knickerbocker Theatre in "The Usurper," a comedy drama by I.N. Morris, an American playright. Mr. Morris wrote two other plays, "Jim Bludsoe" and "The Primrose Path," but neither of them attained the success that has so far followed "The Usurper."

A solution of the amusing episode in Prussia, where a Cabinet crisis is threatened by the interest which the Minister of Education has taken in a certain horse of unusual intelligence, might be found in giving this important place to Hans, the educated Orloff stallion, if Dr. STUDT is compelled to resign it.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26. -- A football game that possessed unusual elements of Interest was played here this afternoon in the World Fair Stadium. It was the first football contest ever held in America between Indian students from two Government institutions -- the Carlisle Indian School of Pennsylvania and the Haskell Indian School of Kansas.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 26. -- The drought in Kentucky is unprecedented in the history of the Weather Bureau and human beings as well as stock are suffering all over the State. In the eastern sections inland from the rivers water is being sold to farmers at the rate of 75 cents a barrel.

Two points against football as at present carried on are made by Dr. DRAPER, Superintendent of Public Instruction in this State, that deserve the careful consideration of all authorities in college and school. One is the pursuit of large gate receipts, the other the tendency of students to gamble on university contests.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 26. -- Dimple, declared by the stable td win, captured the Vestal Stakes handily at the Benning track to-day. Marjoram, coupled in betting with Dimple was second, about a length and a half in front of Ruby Hempstead. Ogress, the favorite, well ridden by Mr. Taylor, won the Hunters' Champion Steeplechase.
WHERE does all the dirt and debris from the subway go?

Preparations were completed yesterday for the second annual convention of the Citizens' Industrial Association, and the first to be held in this city, which will begin in the Hotel Astor on Tuesday and continue through Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Notwithstanding the speculation that has been indulged in since the election regarding the attitude of the President toward tariff revision at the approaching session of Congress, there is good reason for the belief that no reference will be made in the annual message to that subject.

PARIS, Nov. 26. -- According to private but trustworthy correspondence from Warsaw the recent riots in the capital of Russian Poland, organized by the Polish Socialist Party as a protest against the recruiting for the war, were much more sanguinary than has been reported.

There is one statement in the letter of Mr. Cowles in this morning's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES which ought to be repeated in a more prominent form because it is so much to the advantage of the public. That sentence is:

RECENTLY Edwin Hawley, President of the Minneapolis and St. Louis and Iowa Central Railroads, accompanied by his partner, F.H. Davis, Treasurer, and Vice President and Treasurer, respectively of the two roads just mentioned, went rest to inspect these and other railroad properties in which they are either the controlling factors or are heavily interested.

Through his policy of allotment of space in the new Hall of Records to various city and county departments, president Charles V. Fornes of the Board of Aldermen, who was designated by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment ms Chairman of a subcommittee to arrange this allotment, has stirred up a small tempest.

DOBBS FERRY, Nov. 26. -- The police of Dobbs Ferry and Hastings had a battle with three burglars who were caught coming out of the country house of Henry Sidenberg, a New York manufacturer, just across the Dobbs Ferry line, early to-day, and as a result one of the burglars was shot through the back and will die, and another was captured.

THE sister of Mrs. Alfred Vanderbilt, and who was Miss Elizabeth French, daughter of the late Francis Ormonde French, married a decidedly lucky younger son in the present Lord Cheylesmore. He was Lieut. Col. Herbert Francis Eaton when Miss French became his bride.
Any manager would have been agitated under the circumstances.

I DON'T see why all you fellows are after me." said Simeon Ford, boniface, raconteur, and general all-round after-dinner humorist, as he calmly surveyed the nine hundred and ninety-ninth man who had asked him if it were really true that he had decided to make no more speeches in public. "I'm not the least bit interesting. Never have been."

IN SOUVENIR of his recent trip to Europe one sees in Mr. Carroll Beckwith's atelier at the Sherwood a large copy of one of Tiepolo's ceilings in which the Serpent of Old Nile is seen landing from a galley, clad in the voluminous gown of the Venetian lady of Tiepolo's time, and "throwing her come-hether" over Mark Antony with much majesty and grace.

NEW YORK is becoming a close follower of Paris as a "dining-out" metropolis, a fact which needs but the proof of a glance into the representative restaurants of Fifth Avenue and Broadway any evening between the hours of 6 and 8:30.

The Gas Engine and Power Company and Charles L. Seabury Co. are about to make a number of improvements and alterations in the hull, machinery department, and cabin plan of the yacht Edithia, owned by J.H. Hanan of New York.

-- Reasonable curiosity is expressed by The Montgomery (Ala.) Advertiser as to the exact meaning of the statement, recently made in behalf of the President and apparently by direct inspiration from him, that all he asked from the South was that the negro should have there the same fair chance as anybody else.

SALONIKA, Nov. 26. -- The Bulgarian revolutionary movement has recently assumed such alarming proportions that the Sultan is sending Nazir Pasha to Salonika as special envoy with instructions to take all the measures necessary to suppress the Bulgarian movement by the quickest possible methods.

One of the most interesting and complete railroad reports ever published was that of the Southern Pacific Company, which was given out last week. Besides containing most detailed information regarding the operation of the company -- it offers many novel and unusual features, for instance, a series of charts showing the development of the property since 1883.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 26. -- Two men were caught yesterday afternoon attempting to enter Naumkeag, the country residence of Ambassador Choate, at Stockbridge. One, stationed as a lookout, escaped, and the other, William C. Morris, who had entered the building through a window, was captured near Stockbridge by a Deputy Sheriff.

MONDAY night brought one of the most brilliant premieres the opera has ever seen in New York, and the parterre boxes were more the "glittering horseshoe" than ever, for the display of jewels was quite wonderful, and the lights, differently arranged this year from ever before, brought out the glitter of the gems and the tints of the frocks to the best advantage.

THE last month of the year finds us with a number of interesting events, and our evening study of the stars is still a possibility, although possibly more enjoyable when looking at them through the window pane than standing exposed to some of our chilling northwesters.

GAZING from his office windows on the twenty-third floor of the Park Row Building, the Man Who Runs the Subway was intently watching the curious vines of smoke entwining and almost overshadowing the Erie Railway shops in Jersey City.

The time is fast approaching when the long-suffering motorman will again be called upon to face the storms of Winter without protection. In blinding snowstorms, with the thermometer often below the freezing point, he stands on the front platform absolutely unprotected from the gales of Winter weather.

The second week of opera at the Metropolitan Opera House will be marked by events of importance. To-morrow evening, after many delays in preceding seasons, occasioned by difficulties in composing casts and arranging indispensable rehearsals, Ponchielli's master work, "La Gioconda," will be produced with new scenery and costumes.

THE opera of "La Gioconda," by Amilcare Ponchielli, to be produced at the Metropolitan Opera House to-morrow evening, will bring before this public a work much spoken of in discussions of the contemporary Italian School of opera, but not familiar to many people from actual performance.

Postmaster Winfield Scott Vandewater of Cedarhurst, L.I., was carving the Thanksgiving turkey at the family board on Thursday, when his son, Percy C. Vandewater, walked in, with a blushing young woman clinging to his arm, and announced to his surprised parents that she was his bride, and that they had been married for more than a year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26. -- Samuel Gompers was practically unanimously re-elected President of the American Federation of Labor to-day. One delegate, Victor Berger, of Milwaukee, a leader of the Socialistic element in the convention, voted in the negative and asked that his vote be so recorded. Secretary Frank Morrison and Treasurer John B. Lennon were also unanimously chosen to serve another term.

LONDON, Nov. 17. THE Irish are threatened with another grievance. If the British Government is not misjudged in the prevailing expectation it intends to adjust the irregularities of representation in the House of Commons.

THE complicated department stores become, the more does the average man fear and distrust them. Shopping is a pure delight with the average woman. For the opposite sex it is filled with unknown and altogether undesirable terrors.

That a gambler who had been shot and mortally wounded by another gambler should doggedly refuse to identify and accuse his assailant, and that the assailant, on his part, when brought to the bedside of his dying victim, should refuse to take his hand -- these things seem to ordinary men and women almost incredible.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- The presence in the city of nearly all the delegates of the annual convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union gave unusual significance as well as uncommon fervor to to-day's celebration of World's Temperance Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- An engineer in the service of the Panama Commission has written a letter to a friend in this city, complaining of the methods of the commission in dealing with men who have been taken from this country to work on the canal. The writer was formerly employed by the old Panama Company and on the Nicaragua survey in 1899.

VIENNA, Nov. 27. -- Socialists to the number of 10,000 to-day made a demonstration against the Government before the residences of Premier von Korber and other Ministers, and then tried to invade the Town Hall.
TOKIO, Nov. 27. -- The two principal political parties have issued manifestoes unanimously in favor of ample supplies to carry on the war to the end.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28. -- Promptly on schedule time the special train carrying President Roosevelt, his wife and daughter, and the members of his party, departed from the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, where it had been parked since the arrival of the Presidential party Saturday morning, for Washington at 12:01 this morning.

New Jersey has a small productive industry in gamecock raising quite thriving till lately, but now set about with some difficulties. It is much to the credit of a Bloomfield fowl raiser that giving his days and nights to the vigil he has traced the danger to its source, and probably put it in the way of being guarded against in the future.
TOKIO, Nov. 27. -- An unofficial telegram from Port Arthur states that the Japanese began a general attack last night.

British economists continue to "view with alarm" the steady inflow of alien immigration into England. Perhaps there is more reason for this than our economists would have to deplore a like condition of affairs on this side of the Atlantic. The capacity of the British nation to assimilate such immigration is distinctly limited, and whatever the immigrant may in course of time become, nothing is more certain than that he will not become an Englishman.

The citizen of New York will need to develop a hitherto neglected sense -- that of absolute direction. Perhaps he will have to learn to "feel the north," or in some other way be able to take his bearings and steer himself in the direction in which he desires to go. Subway experience renders this necessary if he would avoid the bewilderment of being "turned round" every time he emerges from it.

By far the most illuminating of the comments that have come from Russia itself upon the revolutionary programme elicited by the Minister of the Interior from the Presidents of the Zemstvos, and by them submitted to the Czar in person, on his own invitation, is that of M. SOUVERIN, the veteran editor of the Novoe Vremya, published yesterday as an Associated Press dispatch from St. Petersburg.

One workman was killed and four others were badly injured in an explosion in the generating house of the Consolidated Gas Company's plant in West Forty-fourth Street between Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues yesterday morning. Great sheets of flame shot out from the windows on Forty-fourth Street and from those on Eleventh Avenue, terrifying passers-by, many of whom were thrown from their feet.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The Foreign Office has issued the following translation of the declaration signed at St. Petersburg by Sir Charles Hardinge, the British Ambassador, and Count Lamsdorff, the Russian Foreign Minister:
LONDON, Monday, Nov. 28. -- Sir A. Conan Doyle, in a letter to The Times, asks if there is no law to touch the men who, it is alleged, ran the torpedo boat Caroline to Libau, adding:
LONDON, Monday, Nov. 28. -- The Daily Telegraph's correspondent at Che-Foo hears that many of Admiral Togo's vessels are being docked and repaired, in preparation for eventualities.

With Governor-Chairman Odell spending Sunday in Newburg and the rest of the Odell organization away from the Fifth Avenue Hotel Senator Platt talked last night about the Senatorship and the Postmastership.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The recent announcement of a proposed new form of currency for Mexico lends especial interest to some figures just compiled by the Bureau of Statistics regarding the commerce between the United States and Mexico.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 27. -- It is announced that the Guggenheim Exploration Company, which is a branch of the American Smelting and Refining Company, has abandoned its lease of the famous Descubudora mine, situated in the Hermillas District of Mexico. The Guggenheim Exploration Company has been operating this property for the last four months and has shipped a quantity of high-grade copper ore to the Agus Calientes Smelter.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- It was asserted here to-day that Lorenz F. Loree, formerly President of the Rock Island system, is to be at the head of the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway Company. This statement was made by one of Mr. Loree's intimate friends in this city when it became known that Speyer Brothers of New York and London have virtually completed plans to finance this big railroad system.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27. -- The navy's football team of eleven weary players and substitutes returned to Annapolis to-night from Philadelphia, where they were yesterday defeated by the eleven of West Point, and for the first time in several years succeeded in getting into the academy inclosure without being discovered and subjected to the customary ride on their comrades' shoulders.

Mrs. Caroline Jeannette, proprietress of the Strathmore Hotel, at 11 East Thirsty-second Street, reported to the police of the West Thirtieth Street Station last night that diamonds valued at $5,000 had disappeared from her hotel. She said that they were the property of a guest, Mrs. Frederick H. Benedict, daughter of the late Frederic R. Coudert and daughter-in-law of E.C. Benedict, the banker.

Magistrate Whitman departed from his usual custom of refusing to comment on cases brought before him when Detective Martin Keogh of the West Twentieth Street Station arraigned John F. Botens, thirty-three years old, a bartender of 351 Eighth Avenue, in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Nov. 27. -- Miss Maud Arnold, a slip of a girl weighing scarcely ninety pounds, and giving her age as seventeen, spent last night on Cameron's Cone in company with her brother, Stanley Arnold, two years her junior, and Harold Maurer, two years older. All reside in Chicago, the Arnolds being children of B. Arnold of 4,713 Kimbark Avenue.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Foreign Minister Lansdowne has written a letter to the Chambers of Shipping, Chambers of Commerce, and other similar bodies giving further warning with reference to British colliers and the Russian Baltic Squadron, and explaining that British owners chartering their vessels for such purposes as following the Russian fleet with coal and supplies might render themselves liable to proceedings under the Foreign Enlistment act, the applicable sections of which he quotes.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- A Washington dispatch to The Tribune says:

The position taken by Count Cassini, in the statement recently issued by him, declaring that Russia will fight until she conquers, is calculated to occasion serious reflections in the mind of every student of political history and political morals. I do not hesitate to say that this position is untenable from both points of view.

The first productions under the auspices of the Progressive Stage Society, an organization designed for "interesting the masses in the teachings and the art of the great dramatists by producing modern social dramas of progressive tendencies," took place yesterday afternoon at the Carnegie Lyceum.

While the open-air activity in automobiling for this part of the country practically came to a close for the present year with the hill-climbing contest at Eagle Rock on Thanksgiving Day, the months of December and January will possess many features of interest for lovers of the sport. On Thursday, Dec. 15, the time will expire for receiving entries for the Gordon Bennett Cup race, which will be held next June in France.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union, mainly through whose efforts Congress was induced to abolish the canteen from the army, has a strong opponent in the Woman's Army and Navy League, an organization composed largely of wives, widows, and daughters of officers of the regular army and navy.

Coroner Scholer decided yesttrday to admit "Big Frank" Felton, charged with killing Guy Roche, the gambler, to bail, but later reversed his decision and remanded the prisoner back to the Tombs until to-day.
Outlines of the wonderful defensive works the Japanese have had to encounter before Port Arthur are shown n the above map.

Policeman Gleason saw smoke coming out of the entrance to the butcher's store of Adolph Zigar on the ground floor of the big sixteen-family tenement building at 5 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street late last night. Gleason shouted and then ran up the stairs.

One man and eight horses were burned to death, three large stables and a carriage factory were destroyed, another large stable damaged badly, and half a dozen other buildings scorched in a fire early yesterday morning in Flushing, Queens Borough. At one time the entire business section of Flushing was threatened.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- Samuel Davenport Morton, who said he lived at 161 Rector Street, New York City, was arrested at Christ Church at the conclusion of the morning service to-day. Morton is seventy-six years of age and of very dignified appearance. As he left his pew he fell to the floor, his muscles twitching, and sank into unconsciousness.
LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The Times, in its financial supplement, to-morrow will say:

Leo Cohen of 50 Morningside Avenue, who has been serving as a juror, and Herbert L Kamber, a lawyer at 99 Nassau Street, were locked up at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon charged with offering to bribe a jury in Part XIII. of the Trial Term of the Supreme Court. Warrants for their arrest were issued by Magistrate Olmsted. Both protested their innocence.
TOKIO, Nov. 27. -- Discussing the war and the domestic, financial, and political conditions of Japan on the eve of the assembling of the Diet. Premier Katsura said:

PANAMA, Nov. 27. -- Secretary of War Taft and party arrived at Colon this morning on board the United States cruiser Columbia. Mr. Taft was received on shore by Vice President Arosemana and other Panama officials, Gen. Davis, commander of the canal zone, and Minister Barrett.
MELBOURNE, Oct. 21. -- There is no cessation in the agitation against the branch of the Tobacco Trust which now controls practically every wholesale and retail house in Australia.

Secretary of War Taft's plan to reduce the duty on tobacco from the Philippines to 25 per cent. of the Dingley rates, which he has announced he will push to the utmost of his ability at the coming session of Congress, has aroused the domestic trade. Resolutions have been passed by organizations of growers, cigar manufacturers, and the cigarmakers' unions, and they may unite in order to retain counsel to oppose Secretary Taft's project.

BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- Infuriated by the unwillingness of the Polish troops to leave their wives and children, the Russian authorities at Kutno, a town on the Polish frontier, have treated the people in a manner almost incredibly cruel.
ST. PETERSBURG, Monday, Nov. 28. -- Gen. Kuropatkin, in a dispatch received yesterday, said:

Andrew J. Curtin, employed in the Brooklyn Navy Yard and living at 341 East Nineteenth Street, was thrown, out of a light rig, which he said belonged to Deputy Police Commissioner Lindsley, at Forty-second Street and Third Avenue last night. The horse had been frightened by a passing elevated train.

Israel Zangwill, the author and playwright, addressed the annual meeting of the Emanu-El Sisterhood of Personal Service at the organization's home at 318-320 East Eighty-second Street yesterday. The small room where he spoke was crowded uncomfortably.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 27. -- Adjt. Gen. Scott to-day received a message from Sheriff Stein of Franklin County, requesting that two additional companies of soldiers be sent to Zeigler.

PORTSMOUTH, England, Nov. 28. -- Two launches belonging to the British torpedo schoolship Vernon were engaged in an instructional course of sweeping the harbor for mines when an explosion occurred, caused by an unsuccessful effort to fire a countermining charge.

BENNING, D.C., Nov. 28. -- Only one favorite -- Gamara, at odds on -- won in the six events at the Benning race course to-day. King Pepper, at 15 to 1, in the handicap for three-year-olds, won handily, while Cloten, the favorite in a big field, barely succeeded in landing place money from Mamie Worth. The largest field of the day was in the fourth race, in which nineteen two-year-olds were entered.

BOSTON, Nov. 28. -- Herbert D. Newton of Brookline, who has sued Mrs. Cassie Chadwick of Cleveland, Ohio, for $190,800, is a well-to-do Boston business man. Concerning the action against Mrs. Chadwick, he says that suit has been brought in the Common Pleas Court at Cleveland, Ohio, to recover upon loans made to Mrs. Chadwick for which promised payments had not been made when due.

The many recent failures of brokerage houses trading on the Consolidated Exchange have caused so much comment that President Randolph of that Exchange gave out a statement yesterday in which he outlined the position of the Exchange. He said in part:

In a decision written by Judge Somerville, the Board of General Appraisers sustained a protest by the Commercial Cable Company yesterday. The company imported a number of telegraph instruments to New York, for which entry was made on April 10 on a pro forma invoice. In that invoice the importers estimated the value of the merchandise at u342.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The insurance correspondent of The Times will say that the Japanese comments on the sale of British coal for the use of Russia are likely to mislead persons not aware that the British traders have been strictly impartial in selling their wares to both Russia and Japan, and are actually doing the larger business in contraband goods with Japan.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 28. -- Failing in an attempt to get $100,000 from the Canadian Pacific and Canadian Northern Railways by blackmail, an organized gang of desperadoes, it is believed, are fulfilling their threats to wreck trains. Several wrecks have occurred recently in the Canadian Northwest, and others have been frustrated.

Ms. Margaret Keeler, thirty-six years old, whose husband is a delivery man hired by a department store, was found murdered in the Keelers' flat at One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and Park Avenue yesterday afternoon. She had been beaten to death, apparently, with a big iron bolt which was left in the flat. The police are sure that the murderer was a man to whom Mrs. Keeler had given food several times recently.

-- From several quarters comes critical comment upon the precautions that were taken to insure the President's personal safety during his trip to and from St. Louis and while he remained there. It seems to be a fact that measures quite as elaborate as were deemed judicious in this instance were never resorted to before, and it is to this elaboration that objection is made, sometimes seriously and sometimes in derision.
PARIS, Nov. 28. -- The Chamber of Deputies to-day began the debate on Finance Minister Rouvier's bill establishing an income tax.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- While the investigations of trusts conducted by the Department of Commerce are made with the utmost secrecy, it is practically admitted that the petroleum industry is now the subject of inquiry. The assertion is made that this is the only action being taken at present that involves the Standard Oil Company.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 28. -- Gen. Sakharoff to-day telegraphs as follows:
BRAZIL, Ind., Nov. 28. -- While the pilot engine preceding President Roosevelt's special train was passing a lonely place near Brazil to-day, four men threw stones, breaking several windows.

RYE, Nov. 28. -- After being held up, robbed of his money and clothes, and left for dead on the frozen highway, Andrew Taylor, a farm hand of Sound Beach, Conn., is now insane in the Rye lockup. When Taylor was found early this morning he was nearly dead, and had to be assisted to Police Headquarters.

At a meeting of the City Committee of the Citizens' Union last night, a definite decision was reached that the Union would take part in the next municipal campaign. The meeting was largely attended. R. Fulton Cutting presided, and after an exchange of views on the political prospects for next Fall, the following address to the people was adopted:

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 28. -- As a result of the efforts of the better class of Italians in and around Carbondale to rid their colony of the members of a lawless gang who have been committing many outrages, a street battle occurred at that place to-night which was attended with the loss of one life and the serious injury of a second man.
Thomas W. Lawson issued in Boston last night a statement of which the following is a part:

With money touching 4 per cent., no news developments which could be interpreted as extraordinarily favorable, and enough "warning notes" to frighten grown-up men, to say nothing of the "children of the street," the stock market continued its bull career yesterday. There was some slight irregularity, but on the whole stocks were strong.

On charges of shoplifting four persons, three women and a man, were locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Station yesterday afternoon after being arrested in a department store in Sixth Avenue. The first to be brought to the station house were a woman and her daughter, and the other woman and the man were brought in a few minutes later.

Brig. Gen. Alfred Cutler Barnes, Vice President of the American Book Company, who was State Inspector of Rifle Practice under Gov. Cornell, Colonel of the Thirteenth Regiment, and later Colonel of the Twenty-third Regiment, died yesterday morning at his home, 114 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, after an illness of less than four days. Pneumonia was the cause of his death.

Trouble has arisen over the reported sale of the Tontine Building, a ten-story structure at Wall and Water Streets. The Unity Realty Company has begun a suit in the Supreme Court, based upon a contract made for the sale of the property. The contract, it is alleged, was executed with the Tontine Company a month ago, and the amount of real estate involved is valued at more than $1,000,000.

The estimated deficit in the revenues of the German Empire is over $73,000,000, some 114 per cent. greater than that of last year. The extraordinary expenses connected with the war in Southwest Africa account for only one-sixth of the increased deficit. The remainder is due to steadily advancing military and naval expenses and to the inelasticity of the revenues.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 28. -- John Most, the anarchist of New York, was arrested last night after a fruitless effort to hold a meeting here, and is still a prisoner. For ten days St. Louis detectives have watched Most. He was to have made a speech at National Hall, 1,022 Franklin Avenue, on Sunday afternoon a week ago, but the police prohibited it in view of the approaching visit of the President.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The case known as the Fayerweather will case was decided by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in favor of the colleges. The case involves bequests of about $3,500,000 made to twenty different colleges by the late Danied B. Fayerweather of New York.

That suit to recover for damages to the city's property by the advertising signs in the Subway shall be brought at once against the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and all others responsible and steps taken for an injunction is the prayer of the Municipal Art Society in a memorial presented to Mayor McClellan.

Will Russia and Japan ultimately join hands in the Orient and take joint control of that vast, rich, undeveloped and mysterious region of the globe? According to the "indiscretions" of a Russian diplomatist reported in our London dispatches, this is what Russia contemplates and what Japan is supposed to be capable of.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 28. -- Sensational developments in the suit brought by Herbert B. Newton of Brookline, Mass., against Mrs. Cassie Chadwick of this city for almost $200,000 are coming.

In a consideration of "Sapho," which served for another display of Gabrielle Rejane's virtuosity at the Lyric Theatre last night, one naturally recalls at the outset the famous -- or had one better say the notorious? -- staircase scene which in the version played by Olga Nethersole at Wallack's some years ago became the subject of widespread comment.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28. -- Gen. Jacob S. Coxey of Mount Vernon, once leader of the "Commonweal" army, filed to-day a personal petition in bankruptcy in the United States court. His liabilities are given as $287,000. His assets consist of 2,560 shares of stock in the Coxey Steel and Silica Sand Company, and an unsecured note for $11,000.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 28. -- The special train bearing President Roosevelt to Washington from St. Louis arrived in Pittsburg to-night at 8:30 and departed ten minutes later. A large and enthusiastic crowd was present at the Union Station, and cheer after cheer greeted the President when he appeared on the platform of the rear car. Mr. Roosevelt said:

Popular interest in the Old Glory horse auction in Madison Square Garden continued unabated yesterday when the big sale entered its seventh day, and through the three regular sessions of selling, morning, afternoon, and evening, all the arena seats on the Twenty-sixth Street side of the hall were filled by spectators and buyers.

Fowls, fluffed and feathered like a lady costumed for the opera, and of high degree, who could look with pride upon a polished incubator and call it "Mother," clucked a welcome last night at the annual show of the Association of Poultry and Pet Stock Breeders. The show is held in the Herald Square Exhibition Hall, Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway.

According to the alliterative word-painter, "Tody" Hamilton, a "concordat" has been arranged between the managers of the James A. Bailey and the Ringling Brothers circuses. "Tody" is authority for the statement that this is purely and simply "a gentlemen's agreement." The statement concerning the important move says:
BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- On the Boerse to-day prices in most of the departments were firm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Treasury Department is a law breaker, according to the District Commissioners, who have been hot on its trail for several months and hlve kept it under close surveillance. The Treasury Department not only proclaims its innocence but is inclined to be irritated at the proceedings of the Commissioners' detectives, and is disposed to complain that it is being hounded.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 28. -- Gov. Vardaman has pulled a veritable hornets' nest down about his ears by his discourteous reply to a telegram from David R. Francis of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition conveying to him the kind remarks made by President Roosevelt concerning the Mississippi Building and the exhibits of this State at the Exposition.

Wallace Downey, one of the members of the shipbuilding firm of Townsend Downey, which built the Kaiser's yacht the Meteor, has announced that he is going to try the plan of running the yard on a sort of co-operative plan. Profits are to be divided among workmen as well as the heads of the firm.

The President is due back in Washington this morning, after a long series of brief meetings with his fellow-citizens and a considerable number of opportunities to talk and be talked with. Throughout his hasty journey he has borne himself with his usual hearty good humor toward all and undoubtedly has strengthened the feeling of liking for him which was so emphatically expressed at the election.

There are reason and intemperance in all things, and it seems to me that some well-meaning people have gone beyond what is reasonable in denouncing all advertising in the Subway. They might as well do it as regards the streets, or the newspapers, or the magazines, or spaces in the street cars. Proper advertisements are not objectionable, and, indeed, are entertaining -- much more so than blank spaces.

ALBANY, Nov. 28. -- Joseph F. White, for ten years orderly in the State Treasurer's office, is under arrest here charged with killing Mrs. Josephine Russell, a widow, this afternoon. Jealousy is said to have been the cause.

PANAMA, Nov. 28. -- The first conference having for its purpose the adjustment of the questions in dispute between the United States and Panama was held this morning. There were present Secretary of War Taft, President Amador, Ricardo Arias, a member of the Panama Fiscal Commission, and Gen. Guardia, the Panaman Minister of War.
The official election returns from Kansas given in to-day's Times are an interesting study. Comparing them with the Kansas Presidential vote in 1900, we find:

We owe an acknowledgment and an explanation to the President of Columbia University. At the dinner given to Mr. MORLEY by the Lotos Club, Dr. BUTLER complained of the provincialism of the New York press, which calls itself metropolitan, in that it did not take sufficient account of things happening in other parts of our common country because they did not have the advantage of happening in New York.

The Nan Patterson case must be tried all over again. The two weeks spent in securing the jury and hearing the prosecution's presentation of a portion of its evidence were wasted. Monday a second start will be made, and, judging from the rate of progress achieved in the first trial, the interested parties may hold themselves fortunate if a verdict is reached before the Christmas holidays.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Secretary of War Taft discusses a variety of topics in an entertaining way in his annual report, just made public. For the military establishment proper the Secretary submits an estimate of $72,700,000 for 1906, as against $77,700,000 for 1905. As to the reduction, he says that the heads of departments have fallen into the habit of making their estimates large, with the idea that Congress would cut them anyway.

DENVER, Nov. 28 -- Another woman, Mrs. Rosa Snyder, was arrested to-day on warrants charging her with buying votes at the late election. Lizzie Cummings and other women have made affidavits that Mrs. Snyder gave them $5 each to vote the Republican ticket. Mrs. Snyder is a complainant in one of the cases against Democrats arrested on warrants charging conspiracy to intimidate voters.

The Health Department steamboat Franklin Edson was taking a scarlet fever patient up the East River to North Brother Island yesterday when, as the boat was near the south end of Blackwell's Island, she had to swing around quickly to dodge a big float. When she tried to turn in again her rudder chains snapped and the steamboat went upon the rocks near the island.
I was very much interested in your editorial of to-day entitled "Reciprocity and Annexation, and believe your readers might possibly be interested by comments upon it from a different point of view.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day affirmed an opinion of the Supreme Court of Missouri limiting an interest charge under the National banking law.

Dr. Peter Hughes of' 469 Bedford Avenue, Williamsburg, was riding past the apartment house at 574 Bedford Avenue yesterday afternoon when Mrs. Mortimer D. Metcalfe thrust her head from the window of her apartment and shouted to the doctor to catch a thief who had just left the Metcalfe apartment with his pockets bulging with booty.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- After an illness of about two weeks the Rev. Dr. William M. Paxton, who was lately President of the Faculty of Princeton Theological Seminary, died at his home in Library Place this morning. His death was caused by a paralytic stroke which he suffered directly after the Yale-Princeton football game, on Nov. 12.

It is plain that the contest for the restoration of the "canteen feature" of the army post exchange must shortly again be brought up before Congress for decision. It is so clearly a contest in behalf of the temperance, the morality, the discipline, and the contentment of the United States Army.

The admirable handling of the audience during a causeless alarm of fire in the Harlem Opera House on Saturday afternoon is an object lesson which theatrical managers generally would do well to take to heart. The moment the hysterical woman in the gallery called "Fire!" -- because, forsooth, she heard the noise of department apparatus in the street -- every employe of the house went to his place and did exactly the right thing.

It is plain that the contest for the restoration of the "canteen feature" of the army post exchange must shortly again be brought up before Congress for decision. It is so clearly a contest in behalf of the temperance, the morality, the discipline, and the contentment of the United States Army.

A well-dressed woman who said she was Mrs. Caroline Hobart of Jersey City Heights was arrested outside a department store in Twenty-third Street yesterday afternoon by Detective Eva Peyser on a charge of stealing two brooches valued at $15.50.

The Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest by F.W. Myers Co. of Plattsburg, N.Y., claiming free duty for concentrated copper ore. The ore had been assessed at 20 per cent. as a non-enumerated manufactured article. It is held that the concentration of the ore, while removing some of the impurities, still leaves it copper ore, which is provided for in the free list.

BENNING. D.C., Nov. 29. -- Favorites won three of the six races at the Benning course to-day. The steeplechase was taken in a driving finish by Woden, a 12 to 1 shot, which reduced the track record for two miles and a half from 5:08 to 5:07. Cousin Jess established the former record three years ago. Australina had an easy victory over the big field that started in the first race.

Baron Alphonse Rothschild, head of the French branch of that famous family of financiers, who is now on a visit to this city, was the guest last evening at a dinner given by August Belmont. The Baron is understood to be in this country for an inspection of the Subway system, in the financing of which his firm is reported to be interested through Mr. Belmont's connection with the Interborough Company and the construction company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The appointment of a representative of this Government on the tribunal which is to examine into the firing upon the British trawlers by the Baltic fleet and a report from Attorney General Moody that he had decided against the legality of the guessing contests in newspapers and magazines and held them to be illegal were considered at a meeting of the Cabinet after President Roosevelt's return this morning.

Charles Teshlin of 357 East Thirty-eighth Street, a chauffeur employed by Charles E. Smith, a dealer in antiques, living at 135 East Thirtieth Street, is believed to be dying at the Presbyterian Hospital from injuries received in a smash-up on the East Drive in Central Park last night between the touring car he was driving and a three-seated surrey belonging to Frank Cohn of 52 East One Hundredth Street.

Controller Grout has begun a controversy with other city officials, in connection with the excavation work for the tunnel and station of the Pennsylvania Railroad, which may hamper the excavating contractors, the New York Contracting and Trucking Company, of which Charles F. Murphy's brother, John J. Murphy, is President.

The cotton market suffered a severe break yesterday, and the worst that has occurred since the days of the Sully regime. From the high prices of Monday the decline measured from 50 to 55 points, the latter in the May option, which was most seriously affected. The result was that cotton, in the case of the November option, which declined to 8.91, for the first time in three years sold below 9 cents.

That Mrs. Chadwick is staying at the Holland House in this city was made clear late last night when a rumor reached the Tenderloin police to the effect that she had committed suicide in her apartments there.

After being delayed nearly two hours at Quarantine, owing to the fact that the Hamburg-American liner Bluecher had got there first, the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm II, arrived at her pier in Hoboken late yesterday afternoon. While at Quarantine there occurred an accident that resulted in the fatal injury of one and the injury of three others of the steerage passengers.

MIDDLETOWN, Nov. 29. -- E.H. Harriman has just added a choice tract of land to his estate of 3,000 acres at Arden, Orange County, by the purchase of the adjoining dairy farm of the late Isaac H. Thompson, located in the town of Monroe and comprising about 200 acres.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Elverton R. Chapman, Jr., aged twenty-three, of New York City, committed suicide last night at the Carlton Hotel here by throwing himself from the third floor landing to the vestibule. His skull was crushed, one arm was shattered, and there were other injuries, from which he died within a few minutes.

-- It is very probably true, as Mr. F.B. THURBER gently intimated in the letter we printed yesterday, that more than a few of the people who are now exclaiming angrily over the Subway advertisements as barbarous blemishes on the artistic decorations of the stations, make their moan in the hope of proving an aesthetic sensitiveness of which they really haven't a trace.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The final hearing by the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the matter of the complaint of William R. Hearst against the coal carrying roads was begun here to-day.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 29. -- When Mrs. Chadwick married Dr. L.S. Chadwick, in 1896, she was Mrs. C.L. Hoover, a West Side woman and a reputed widow. After her marriage she went to live at the family home of the Chadwicks on Euclid Avenue, in the most aristocratic part of the city. She has her own automobile and carriages and a retinue of servants.

ALBANY, Nov. 29. -- By a decision of the Court of Appeals to-day, the Interurban and the Brooklyn Rapid Transit systems of street railways will be required to give transfers to points on any of two lines which they operate in the City of New York.

Admiral BARKER'S report that "the Navy is to be congratulated that the department has remained firm in excluding wine and beer from the canteens of ships" doubtless expresses the sentiments of the great majority of naval officers. The present condition of things is a great change from the old times when "grog" was a constituent of the ration of every navy.

Pastor WAGNER -- he is Dr. WAGNER now, but the more familiar term seems to fit him better -- returns to his beloved France to-morrow. He leaves behind him a remarkable number of friends who have learned during his stay what an extraordinarily lovable man he is, and the impression he has made on the thousands he has addressed in all parts of the country, if less in degree, has been of the same kind.

After several weeks of uncertainty and an inability to bring all of the legal billiard organizations into harmony the dead-lock has been broken by a compromise, and the National amateur championship tournament will be played at the Chicago Athletic Association. This is the first time in the history of playing a National championship that the event has been held outside of New York and Brooklyn.

We are confronted, in the case of the woman PATTERSON, accused of murder, with an absurd but not unusual consequence of the actual administration of the august institution of trial by jury. It seems that a juror who had already had two strokes of paralysis, had another as soon as he was impaneled, and is evidently unfit to try the case.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- William Loeb, Jr., secretary to the President, to-day issued an official statement denying that President Roosevelt's children had cruelly treated the Thanksgiving turkey sent to the President by Mr. Vose of Rhode Island. In the statement Mr. Loeb says:
WINSTED, Conn., Nov. 29. -- Beginning Dec. 1 the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company will assume the lease of the Dutchess County Railroad and operate it as part of its system.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 29. -- The properties of the Great Eastern and National Clay Manufacturing Companies at South River, which recently went into bankruptcy, were sold this afternoon by the receivers, J.K. Rice of this city and Otto T. Bannard, President of the New York Security and Trust Company.

Breeding stock made up the greater part of the 125 trotters and pacers that passed through the sales ring at the "Old Glory" horse auction in Madison Square Garden yesterday, but nevertheless the high average of the offering was maintained straight through, and at the close of the selling last night $44,600 had been added to the total of the sale, bringing the amount of the sale to date up to $417,235.

That the owners of winning harness racers received liberal treatment at the hands of track managers during the year is shown by the money they won at the eleven big trotting meetings. Throughout the nine Grand Circuit meets and the special racing events at Lexington and Memphis there were no less than $286,425 distributed among horsemen.

The most interesting question before the people of this country is, not where President ROOSEVELT now stands in regard to tariff revision, but where he will stand after the 4th of March next. Unless all the signs and portents are at fault, the President has had it in mind to urge upon Congress and upon the country some amendments of the Dingley act.

CHE-FOO, Nov. 29. -- Chinese and Japanese advices received here to-day, while not beyond question, indicate the practical certainty that another general assault on Port Arthur began on Nov. 24 and was continuing Nov. 27.

President Woodrow Wilson of Princeton University, speaking as a guest at the third annual banquet of The Virginians, held last night in the Astor Gallery at the Waldorf-Astoria, called for the South to get rid of the radical element of the Democratic Party and rehabilitate that party on good old-fashioned lines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Speaker Cannon visited the Capitol to-day and talked regarding tariff revision with characteristic frankness and bluntness. He evidently does not expect that any movement will be made at the approaching session to disturb existing conditions. When questioned on this point he said:

BOSTON, Nov. 29. -- Herbert D. Newton of Brookline, the plaintiff in the suit against Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick, refused to-night to discuss the case in any phase, but referred inquirers to his counsel, Percy W. Carver.

MOUNT VERNON, Nov. 29. -- Mrs. William Taylor of Stamford, Conn., went to the harbor in front of the Larchmont Yacht Club this afternoon for the purpose of donning a diving suit and going to the bottom of the harbor on a "dare." Mrs. Taylor is the wife of an engineer employed by Peter J. Kane, the contractor who is laying a sewer in the harbor, and she is a fairly heavy woman.

Directors of corporations who pay dividends in preferred stock out of capital instead of net earnings were scored roundly yesterday by Justice Clarke in a decision in the Supreme Court, the Justice holding that the Directors of the American Malting Company did this, and ruling that each of them is liable individually for the amount so paid out.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 30. -- According to a Tokio dispatch to The Standard there is an unofficial rumor that the Japanese have hauled large calibre guns to the top of 203-Metre Hill, from where their fire has a sweep of the whole harbor.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 29. -- Dr. Albert E. Payne has placed his father and mother in charge of his home here, put his practice, one of the best in Riverhead, in charge of other physicians, and is now on his way across the country, acting as escort to his wife, who is on her way to South Dakota to obtain a divorce from him.

Just before adjournment last evening Justice Gaynor in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn committed to jail for perjury James Corcoran of Manhattan and William H. Larowe, one of Corcoran's witnesses. Corcoran was suing the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company for $10,000. He alleged that on Dec. 2, 1902, he was injured by a car at Grand and Havemeyer Streets, Brooklyn, and that his left ankle had been made practically useless.

The Broadway-Reliance Realty Company, of which Henry Hellman is President, has bought from the Marsh estate, through William P. Mangam, the plot of fifteen lots, including the entire block front on the west side of Amsterdam Avenue, between Ninety-fourth and Ninety-fifth Streets, and extending 182 feet in depth on the former and 193 feet on the latter.

The market yesterday continued the irregular path which it has been pursuing for a week or more. The underlying tone was firm, but the price movement were irregular. New York Central, which had been strong on the day before, advanced to new high prices. At one time it sold at 141 1/4, and it finally closed at very near the top for a net advance of 2 7/8 points.

BENTON, Ill., Nov. 29. -- The mining war at Zeigler reached its height last night, when the town was fired upon from sundown to daylight. It is estimated that no less than 500 shots were fired at the town.

The "open shop" idea was explained and unionism severely criticised at the second convention of the Citizens' Industrial Association of America, which began yesterday forenoon in the Hotel Astor. The Socialists also came in for left-handed compliments by some of the speakers; including President D.M. Parry of the association.

While Joseph Ferone, twenty-four years old, of 200 East Forty-fourth Street, was being tried by a jury before Recorder Goff in Part II., General Sessions, on a charge of murdering his wife, Lawrence Ferone, his sixteen-year-old brother, was put on trial before Judge Foster in Part I., General Sessions, on a burglary charge.
Magistrate Hogan gave out a statement yesterday attacking Superintendent of Elections Morgan. As to alleged naturalization frauds, the Magistrate said:

When the President of the Citizens' Union is asked by newspaper reporters to give his views upon the possibility of an indorsement of the Tammany Mayoralty ticket by the Union, it is evident that our local politics have entered upon an entirely new stage. At the meeting of the City Committee of the Citizens' Union on Monday evening it was stated that the Union's attitude in the next Mayoralty campaign will be defined next April.

ALBANY, Nov. 29. -- By a decision to-day in the action of the People ex rel. Cossey, appellant, vs. Controller Grout of New York, the Court of Appeals declared unconstitutional Chapter 415 of the Laws of 1897, (the labor law,) which prohibits a contractor from employing his men more than eight hours a day on city, county, or State work.

TRENTON, Nov. 29. -- Hundreds of copies of a letter signed by William J. Lea have been mailed to prominent citizens here from Station H, New York City. In the letter, which charges that his Phoenix Iron Works were "stolen" from him, and that he was unlawfully "imprisoned" in the State Insane Asylum, he says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Belgium is among the nations which have not yet accepted the invitations sent by the United States to all the signatory powers to The Hague Convention to sign with this Government arbitration treaties similar to the Anglo-French treaty.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 29. -- Within a few hours Cleveland expects to see disclosures in the Chadwick mystery that will rival in their startling details the famous Humbert case that not long ago astounded Europe.

PARIS, Nov. 29. -- M. Bos, Reporter in the Chamber of Deputies of this year's Admiralty budget, prefaces a detailed account of the French Navy by an interesting comparison of that navy and the navies of the world.

Charges were openly made in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday that H.J. Bebro, who says that his chosen mission is to get from sanitariums persons wrongfully committed, had been a convict and that he had in his pay many trained nurses who had been discharged from private hospitals, and who gave him family secrets that might be of value.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- The will of Edward L. Wentz, the young Philadelphian who was mysteriously slain in the mountains of West Virginia a year ago, was filed to-day at the office of the Register of Wills. The bulk of the estate, valued at $500,000, is devised in trust for the benefit of the testator's fiancee, Cornelia Brookmire of St. Louis, Mo.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 29. -- According to information which has reached the War Office here, Field Marshal Oyama's strength is much smaller than heretofore believed, tending to confirm the theory that a large force has been withdrawn to assist in storming Port Arthur.

An editorial in THE TIMES of Nov. 28 points out the obvious evils that have arisen in connection with intercollegiate football, and concludes that, in order to eliminate these evils the game itself must be discontinued. But there are many persons who see these evils as clearly as you do, and yet feel that the game has good features that should not be lost in a general abolition.

When a National election is more than three weeks back in history it is a difficult thing to work up post-election enthusiasm, but there was plenty to go around among the 600 and odd diners who attended the Roosevelt-Fairbanks-Higgins-Bruce jubilee dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

After more than two hours of heated discussion between Controller Grout and Alderman McCall the Sinking Fund Commission yesterday laid aside for one week the application of the New York Central Railroad to divert its tracks in Twelfth Avenue so that the Pennsylvania Railroad could get possession of the Thirty-second Street pier for the purpose of expediting its tunnel and station work.

Thousands of commuters and other travelers over the main line of the New York Central Railroad were delayed for hours when at 4:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon the brick barge "Three J's" tried to pass through the Cromwell's Creek draw, and stuck fast on the bottom on a falling tide.

TOKIO, Nov. 30. -- The Emperor formally opened the second war Diet to-day. He rode through the crowded streets in a state coach escorted by a troop of lancers and accompanied by the Crown Prince, his staff, and some members of the imperial household, to the House of Parliament, where both houses were assembled in the Chamber of Representatives.

If ex-Gov. Frank S. Black announces himself a candidate to succeed Senator Depew there will be two other candidates in the field, according to the declaration yesterday of those close to Mr. Depew. It was said that Timothy L. Woodruff would be one of the candidates and that the other would come from the Western part of the State.

The eighth and most expensive annual dinner of the Rockefeller Bible Class was held at the Hotel Majestic last evening. In 1903 members of the class paid $1 a plate. Last night's dinner cost $1.25 a plate, with Turkish cigarettes, a cigar apiece, and an illustrated cartoon talk thrown in. No fewer than 253 men, young and old, were present.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 30. -- An enterprising stranger visited East Orange to-day and did a rushing business with the school children in the Elmwood district. At recess time he unfolded his plan to a crowd of wondering young folks. For old rubbers, rubber boots, and rubber goods he would give jewels of fabulous value, absolutely free.

Wallace Downey of the Townsend Downey Shipbuilding Company and President of the New York Metal Trades Association gave the delegates to the convention of the Citizens' Industrial Alliance in the Hotel Astor yesterday some points as to the progress of the open shop idea in this city. He spoke at the last session of the convention.

BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- Since January, 1901, Mrs. Dagmar Baagoe of New York, wife of Frederick Baagoe, a chemist of that city, and daughter of Gen. Christensen of Brooklyn, has been an inmate of a private sanitarium in Worcester, having been committed as insane at the alleged instigation of her husband.

DUQUOIN, Ill., Nov. 30. -- It became known here to-day that three weeks ago Joseph Leiter was indicted on three counts on the charge of bringing armed men into the State, contrary to recently passed statutes. Although the indictment was returned Nov. 12, no attempt has been made to serve the capias or to arrest Leiter, because State's Attorney Scott, who will retire to-morrow, wishes to leave the case over to his successor.

BENNING, D.C., Nov. 30. -- Go Between, the speedy three-year-old gelding who broke the record in capturing the Washington Cup on Thanksgiving Day, to-day as a 1-to-2 favorite won the Fifth Benning Special and lowered the track record of 2:40 for a mile and a half, made by Rochester four years ago, to 2:37 3-5.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Rear Admiral Charles Henry Davis has been chosen by the President, after consultation with Secretaries Hay and Morton, to be a member of the international tribunal which is to investigate the firing upon the British trawling fleet in the North Sea by the Baltic fleet under Admiral Rojestvensky.

The claim is made on behalf of Senator DEPEW that he has pledges to vote for his re-election of seventy-six members of the Legislature, or five more than the majority of the caucus which is necessary to secure that re-election.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 30. -- With reference to the discovery of alluvial gold in Fern Spruit, Rhodesia, I understand that the Chartered Company's engineer will arrive in Cape Town next week and will proceed at once to inspect the locality.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Senator Hale of Maine, whose recently published interview in opposition to tariff revision attracted widespread attention, had an extended conference with the President to-day. It is understood that the subject discussed was the tariff. When he came out of the White House Mr. Hale said he was quite sure that there would be no tariff revision either at this session on during that of the Fifty-ninth Congress.

For the alleged use of his influence on behalf of Mortimer L. Schiff, who was arrested the other day charged with over-speeding his automobile. Police Inspector Richard Walsh has been officially reprimanded by Commissioner McAdoo. This is the first action of the kind on the part of Mr. McAdoo since he became the head of the Police Department.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 30. -- One man holds the key to the Chadwick mystery. He may talk to-morrow when the case comes up for a hearing in the court here on a motion for a receiver to take charge of the securities Mrs. Chadwick is said to have.

A number of old paintings and engravings of famous race horses that formerly belonged to the late Col. S.D. Bruce, well known to horse lovers and for many years editor of Turf, Field and Farm, drew a large number of bidders last night to the Anderson auction rooms, 5 West Twenty-ninth Street, where the entire library of the late horseman was disposed of.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Nov. 30. -- The official canvass of the vote of Utah was completed to-day. The vote for President on each Electoral ticket was as follows: Roosevelt, 62,444; Parker, 33,413; Debs, 5,767. No other candidate for President was voted for.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Russia is unwilling to join the powers in a second peace conference at The Hague until her war with Japan is ended.

A definite acceptance of the arrangement entered into between the attorneys for Mrs. Chadwick and Henry D. Newton of Boston was made at a midnight conference held at the Park Avenue Hotel last night. Present were Mr. Newton and his Boston counsel, Mr. Carver, and Mr. Ryall. They announced that they had perfect confidence in the ability of Mrs. Chadwick to meet their claims.

As one who has devoted a large part of his life to the study of art, I feel impelled to say that "The Comparative Art Exhibition" now being displayed in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, in Fifty-seventh Street, is the most important and the most interesting art exhibition ever held in the United States.

The Directors of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company yesterday declared a dividend of 3 per cent. on the company's stock, payable Jan. 3 next to holders of record on Dec. 10. This is the second dividend declared by the company, and with the first, amounting to 2 per cent., paid in July last, makes a total of 5 per cent. for the present year.

Recalling his own misfortune in having come into the leadership of the Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association simultaneously with a reform administration of the city, Fritz Lindinger, now an ex-President of the organization, said last night that District Attorney Jerome was the only member of that administration who had treated the liquor dealers fairly.

Emanuel Tannenbaum, who lives at 345 West Seventy-first Street, brought down a thief with a pistol shot in his back yard yesterday morning, and the occupants of several handsome four-story dwellings in the same block hope that what they describe as a reign of terror caused by the frequent visitations of burglars is at an end.

We remarked yesterday morning that the public interest in the issue raised by Senator HALE'S scantily respectful declaration on tariff revision would centre in the attitude of the President. Something like an official response to the semi-challenge of the Maine Senator is contained in the Washington dispatches of The Tribune, sent from that city on the day that Senator HALE issued his manifesto.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Nov. 30. -- A heap of powdered bituminous coal containing not less than 100 tons is on fire in one of the largest buildings of the plant of the Edison Cement Company at New Village. The fire is an exceedingly dangerous one to handle. It is worse than useless to throw water on the burning coal, as the water causes it to throw off more gases.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 30. -- The Rev. Dr. William T. Manning, Vicar of St. Agnes's Chapel, Trinity Parish, New York City, was to-day elected Bishop of the newly organized Protestant Episcopal diocese of Harrisburg.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Secretary Morton announced to-day that he will take up and decide the whole question of titles in the navy. This means the final disposition of a question that has caused more heart burning and bad feeling than any other issue of its size. The old quarrel between the line and staff figures in it, and also the resentment of fighting officers over the giving of high titles to bureau chiefs.

New proceedings will be taken in the next few days by Corporation Counsel Delany against the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company to compel an accounting to the city and the recovery of some $5,000,000 held to be due from the Subway combination. The papers in the action have been prepared and are ready for service on the officials of the Subway company, which is merely a subsidiary corporation of the Consolidated Gas Company.
