George R. Read Co. have sold for Jackson Stern 10 and 12 East Forty-first Street, two four-story dwellings, each 20.10 by 102.6. The same brokers have also sold for Mrs. Elizabeth K. Stillman, mother of James Stillman, the abutting property at 7 East Fortieth Street, a four-story dwelling on lot 25 by 96.

Mr. D.M. PARRY, Prsident of the Citizens' Industrial Alliance, in his speech at the meeting of that body on Monday, made a very clear distinction between a legal right and a moral right in the case of a strike by union workmen against the employment of those not in affiliation with them.

TELLURIDE, Col., Nov. 30. -- The District Miners' Association, in session at Ouray, has called off the strike in this district, which began Sept. 1, 1903. President Charles H. Moyer of the Western Federation of Miners has made the following statement concerning the action of the miners' association:

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 30. -- At a conference of members of the Kansas Legislature here to-day it was decided to push a bill making pipe lines common carriers. This is a movement in opposition to the Standard Oil Company, which has a monopoly of the Kansas field.

-- Though himself a versifier, and credited by some with being a poet of a sort, Pension Commissioner WARE has deemed it expedient, now that he is about to exchange the miseries of office for the joys -- comparative -- of legal practice, to put himself straight with those who may have occa sion to consider the wisdom of buying his services.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 30. -- The statement that Russia is concentrating troops on the Afghan frontier is denied. Nevertheless it is undoubtedly true that Russia is watching with some misgivings the British plans for the reorganization and increase of the Indian Army as well as the dispatch of a deputation to Persia.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Peter Nissen is believed to have been either smothered or frozen to death in his rolling balloon Fool Killer, in which he started for a trip across the lake yesterday.

The annual "Old Glory" auction sale of harness bred horses, held by the Fasig-Tipton Company in Madison Square Garden, came to a close last night, with a total realized by the sales that was second only to one auction held by the company, the aggregate sum of the sales for the nine days reaching $447,775 for 987 head.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- In the Prussian Diet to-day Herr Moeller, Minister of Commerce and Industry, spoke of the trust question as it exists in the United States, and warned Germany against copying the American system.

Hundreds of Japanese gathered at the Twenty-third Street station of the Pennsylvania Railroad yesterday afternoon to give welcome in a thousand-throated "Banzail" to Prince Sadanaru Fushimi, the head of one of the four royal families of Japan, and a brother, by adoption, of the present Mikado. Many who were not Japanese were present, and everybody cheered.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 30. -- Announcement is made here to-day that, beginning to-morrow, a large advance in the price of wire products will go into effect. No official figures are at hand, but the advance will be between $2 and $4 per ton.

In your issue of to-day is an article on United States Steel earnings which shows an "extremely satisfactory" condition of the business. Yet you quote "a leading official of the Steel Corporation" as saying, "we hear reports that within two years the common stock will be on a stable dividend-paying basis."

The Court of Appeals has practically wiped out the law forbidding contractors for public work to employ their men for more than eight hours a day. But the decision does not leave it very clear how or why the law is unconstitutional.
LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The Times's Paris correspondent sends a summary of a document purporting to be an account of a secret conference recently held in Paris by Russian reformers and revolutionaries.

It was announced the other day that the Government and the importers are in a fair way to procure from the Supreme Court a final decision determining the value of the Indian rupee as used in invoices of dutiable merchandise. Between the importers and the Secretary of the Treasury there has been a long contention over the rupee, and much litigation has resulted.

The announcement that Commissioner GARFIELD of the Bureau of Corporations is about to resume the investigation of the Beef Trust is not likely to send a thrill of apprehension along the nerves of those connected with the packing interest. It is more than doubtful whether any such combination as is forbidden by law exists between the several corporations which control the meat business of this country.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Mrs. Naomi Duncombe Ring, whose elopement on Sept. 10 caused a sensation at Mount Vernon, has begun a suit in the Supreme Court to set aside the deeds of $30,000 worth of property which she gave to her husband, Patrick J. Ring, immediately after their marriage.

The Sully creditors accomplished what had been considered the impossible yesterday and agreed. The hearing before Referee MacGrane Coxe was one of harmony, induced by a pronounced general desire to get something out of the estate at an early date.

A strong syndicate, headed by Charles W. Morse and backing a construction company of which John B. McDonald is President, it was learned yesterday, has taken up the New York and Port Chester railway enterprise and will appeal direct to the Legislature at the coming session to get the franchise put through which the Aldermen last Spring denied to the Port Chester Company.

Among our great merchants of the olden time of New York City were the Waltons. The first of the name was Robert Walton, a counsellor, to the Earl of Belmont. He had his shipyards then and as late as 1728. The Walton house was 828 Pearl (formerly 68 Queens) Street, and had a garden that reached to the East River.

The Oratorio Society marked a notable event in its history last evening by producing for the third time Brahms's "German Requiem." It was, if the author of the programme notes is correct in his enumeration, the fifth performance that has been given in New York.

Prince Sadanaru Fushimi took his first real good look at New York yesterday, when he drove down from the St. Regis to the Chamber of Commerce, where he was the guest of honor at a luncheon. In the afternoon, accompanied by two members of his suite, he visited Tiffany's, in Union Square.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- Vice President-elect Charles W. Fairbanks and John D. Long, ex-Secretary of the Navy and ex-Governor, discussed the protective tariff at the dinner of the Home Market Club to-night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- If an agreement just entered into by the trunk lines in the Central and Western Freight Association is firmly maintained, there will hereafter be no more cutting of freight rates, paying of rebates, or granting of concessions of any kind to shippers. The agreement covers both import and domestic traffic east and west bound.

Business men who received their mail through Post Office Station U at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Third Street are rejoicing in the arrest of Herman Fronkers, twenty-five years old, of 43 West One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, a distributing clerk in that sub-station. Fronkers is frantic with grief because it means that he will in all probability never see his old mother again, to whom he is devotedly attached.

In a collision between an uptown Subway train of five cars and a short train of "work cars" at One Hundred and Forty-second Street and Lenox Avenue last night one man was injured, two cars were damaged badly, fifty passengers were brought to the verge of a panic, and a gasoline lamp or tank on the work train caught fire, causing much smoke in the tunnel and resulting in the sounding of a fire alarm.

The tender by Mr. WILLIAM BARCLAY PARSONS of his resignation as Chief Engineer of the Rapid Transit Commission was prompted by considerations alike creditable to himself and advantageous to his business interests. His professional position is assured, and it is distasteful to him to be considered a fixture in the office which he has filled with such distinguished ability and with which his reputation is so closely connected.

BENNING, D.C., Dec. 1. -- Arsenal, in the first race, was the only favorite that won here today. In the second race Winchester, at 15 to 1, beat Calmness and Chimney Sweep, and in the fourth race Delphie easily won from Dazzle, the favorite. Walter Cleary and Imperialist were the choices of the talent in the steeplechase, but Gascar, at 8 to 1, was first, neither of the favorites getting a place.

STEVENSVILLE, Mich., Dec. 1. -- Peter Nissen, who started across Lake Michigan Tuesday night in his curious boat called the "Fool Killer," was found dead on the beach two miles and a half west of here to-day. He is supposed to have been washed ashore during the night.
TOKIO, Dec. 1. -- Field Marshal Oyama reports as follows:

The stock market had its usual Thursday afternoon reaction yesterday. Close observers of the market have noticed for some weeks that whenever prices showed a tendency to hesitate around 1 o'clock on a Thursday the market was sure to sell off at the end. Almost invariably, also, the market has continued reactionary Friday morning, with a tendency to harden and a final rally in the late afternoon.

DUQUOIN, Ill., Dec. 1. -- According to Sheriff Stein another attack was made on Zeigler last night. Firing began at the pumping station two miles north of Zeigler, and spread back to the mining town, where Stein said at least 300 shots were fired. The machine guns, as usual, responded promptly.

TOKIO, Dec. 1. -- Gen. Nogi's telegram announcing the storming and capture of 203-Meter Hill is received with great satisfaction by the Japanese people. It revives the hope of the early capture of Port Arthur.

There is something ridiculous to the verge of intolerableness in the fact that a brick barge, making its slow and devious way along the Harlem River in tow of a tugboat, should be able to paralyze for some hours the movement of the population of the second city in the world.

Improving trade conditions are indicated by the report of failures for the past month which show a large decrease as compared with last year. Dun's Review in its issue of Dec. 3 will say on the subject:

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- Edgar Speyer has won a warm place for himself in the hearts of the British people by his action in making good the losses caused by the failure of the Needham Market Penny Savings Bank. The London newspapers to-day comment appreciatively on his well-timed and graceful beneficence. The Pall Mall Gazette says:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Many Senators and Representatives were at the White House to-day to extend congratulations to the President, several Democrats being among the callers.

Evidently the President has made a mistake in his treatment of The Boston Herald. That journal undoubtedly exercised too little editorial discretion in printing a story that the President's children had chased about the White House grounds, and otherwise maltreated, a votive turkey sent from Rhode Island to furnish the President's Thanksgiving dinner, while the President "looked on and laughed" at the tortures of the bird thus foredoomed to make a Rooseveltian holiday.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 1. -- The inauguration of Gen. Porfirio Diaz as President of Mexico for the seventh time and of Don Ramon Corral as First Vice President took place to-day in the hall of the Chamber of Deputies.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- A burglar was caught hiding behind the furnace in the home of C.G. Nichols in the Post Road late last night by the cook, who had gone down Stairs to put some coal on the furnace. The burglar's eyes attracted her attention. She grabbed the man by the throat and shouted for help.

Despite the fact that the manager of the store in which she was arrested asked to withdraw the charge of shoplifting against her, Magistrate Whitman in Jefferson Market Court yesterday held the woman known as Mrs. Hobart in $300 bail for trial. The prisoner had been taken in a department store in Twenty-third Street several days ago.

Carrying out his expressed purpose of resigning his commission as chief engineer of the Rapid Transit Commission as soon as trains were running through the Subway, Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons sent to the board yesterday a letter tendering that resignation, and while not setting a date for its acceptance, suggesting the end of the present year as a fitting time.

-- With an obstinacy that might be described with equal accuracy, perhaps, either as Bostonian or theological, The Watchman clings to its archaic belief that animals know in the Fall whether the coming Winter is to be mild or severe and proportion their houses and their coats to emergencies and necessities still months away.

While not taking common ground with Sir Edward Clarke, the British Solicitor General, in his recent criticism of the change in designation of American diplomatic and Consular representatives abroad, many local lawyers are finding fault with the substitution of "American" for "United States" before the title.

The astonishing story of the financial operations by which a woman not in business and not known to be possessed of tangible assets was able to borrow like a sovereign State and to obtain from at least one bank with a reputation for conservatism loans of four times its capital stock will be read with amazement by thoughtful people.

With only Justice Bartlett dissenting, the Justices of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, sitting in Brooklyn, decided yesterday that a contract to maintain the "closed shop" was illegal. In the opinion, written by Presiding Justice Hirschberg, a contract, entered into between the firm of Morris Cohn Sons and the Protective Coat Tailors and Pressers' Local Union 55 of the United Garment Workers of America is illegal and contrary to public policy.

As soon as the horse sale in the Madison Square Garden was concluded on Wednesday evening an army of workmen began to prepare the building for the six-day bicycle races. The greater part of Wednesday night was required to remove the earth which had formed the surface of the sales ring, and early yesterday morning the carpenters began the erection of the bicycle track.
Magistrate Pool said yesterday, in the Yorkville Court, that if persons desired their servants to keep sober they should not keep liquor in their houses and subject the help to temptation.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1. -- "We wanted to do something that nobody else had done and we wanted to see the exposition from the top of Festival Hall, so we decided to climb up on the dome. We got a splendid view, and while we were pretty badly scared, especially coming down, I don't think we were ever in any real danger."

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 1. -- The control of the New York and Ottawa Railroad passed to the New York Central to-day, the road having been purchased at a price in the neighborhood of $2,000,000. The sale will not be officially announced until Dec. 22, and in the meantime officials of the road are uncommunicative.
TOKIO, Dec. 1. -- The House of Peers has adopted the following resolution:

There has been so much exaggeration of the facts about child labor in the Southern States that even the intelligent linotype in THE TIMES office must have thought that the figures given by me lately to Mr. Stevenson were too small. The figures published, however, in the last paragraph of the excellent article on the child labor problem in Sunday's issue are so startling as to call for some correction.

Fancy mice, rats, cavies, and rabbits, including a few high-class exhibits of hares, proved the important magnet yesterday at the show of the Association of Poultry and Pet Stock Breeders in the Herald Square Exhibition Hall, Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway. Among the women who several years ago made pets of the cold and snaky chameleons, oddly marked and colored mice and rats are becoming popular as pets.

What Senator McCarren termed "the annual love feast" of the Democratic organization of Kings County was held last night in the Imperial Cafe, at Red Hook Lane and Fulton Street. The meeting was preliminary to the meeting of the General Committee next Tuesday to organize for 1905. Last night's session was held behind closed doors.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 1. -- The records in the office of the Marriage License Clerk show that Dr. Leroy S. Chadwick in applying for a license to marry Cassie Hoover, now the Mrs. Chadwick whose financial troubles are engaging the attention of the country, signed his name "Leroy Schadwick" to the petition for a license.
BUFFALO, Dec. 1. -- As culmination of efforts to secure control of the German-American Bank a run was started this afternoon on the bank and $400,000 was withdrawn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The long-expected effort to amend the present law taxing oleomargarine has made its appearance. Representative Boutelle of Illinois has framed a bill to make the tax uniform by imposing 4 cents a pound on the product, whether colored or not. At present there is a tax of 10 cents a pound on colored and one-quarter of a cent on uncolored oleo.

BEVERLY, N.J., Dec. 1. -- William Waterhouse Bray, forty-five years old, of New York, said to be a broker, who recently married Mrs. Catherine Krim of South Beverly, was arrested there to-day on the charge of bigamy. It is alleged that he has a wife living in New York, where he maintains a handsome home.

From noon to night yesterday Governor-Chairman Odell held conferences with the leaders of the Legislature and Republican county leaders of prominence on the subject of the United States Senatorship, with the result that the fight between Senator Depew and ex-Gov. Black can now be said to be fairly on.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 2. -- The Daily Telegraph's correspondent at St. Petersburg asserts that he has unimpeachable evidence that Russia is reckoning on the necessity of making a lasting peace with Japan by means of an offensive and defensive alliance.

Patrick Lennon, a fireman, of Engine Company No. 158, who was injured in the fire that destroyed the Court House in Long Island City last Saturday, died in St. John's Hospital early yesterday morning.

PARIS, Dec. 1. -- Deputy Jaures, the Socialist leader, has telegraphed a challenge to a duel to Paul Deroulede, who has been in political exile since his participation in the plot to overthrow the Government.

The second performance of "Parsifal," given yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House, was notable for several things. One of them was the fact that the audience was the smallest that has yet attended any of the representations given there. Another was the appearance of Miss Olive Fremstad as Kundry for the first time, and of Mr. Journet as Gurnemanz, also for the first time.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 1. -- The War Office here is not yet prepared to accept the report that the Japanese before Port Arthur have taken 203 Meter Hill, but if it is true the War Office admits that the capture is a desperate blow for the gallant defenders of the fortress.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 1. -- Directors of the Citizens' National Bank at Oberlin held a meeting this afternon in the office of the Vice President. They discussed a telegram that President Beckwith said he had received from Pittsburg stating that some one representing Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick would be in Oberlin next Thursday to settle the claims against her. They were not very optimistic.

ALBANY Dec. 1. -- Florence Fairview Weiland has often posed as a champion of labor. She started a working girls' home in Albany, which was of short duration. Then she went to New York and started a similar home, which also failed. Later she returned to Albany and established in East Greenbush what she called "The Health School of Mental Science."

ALBANY, Dec. 1. -- Attorney General Cunneen to-day granted F. Gustav Kindlund pemission to begin an action to test the title to office of certain Trustees of the Westminster Presbyterian Church of Twenty-third Street, New York City.

Having convinced the lawyers on the other side that she was able and willing to pay her debts within a few days, Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick of Cleveland went out for a long drive yesterday afternoon. She remained away from her Holland House apartments from 2 until 5 o'clock. That she visited one bank is known positively.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 1. -- Much interest was manifested in the first day's sale of thoroughbreds by the Fasig-Tipton Company to-day. Many prominent horsemen were present and fair prices were received. The feature was the disposal of the horses belonging to Douglas H. Grant of England. They were shipped here four weeks ago. The best sales were:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1. -- With appropriate and impressive ceremonies the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, which was opened on April 30 last, was formally declared closed to-day. Mayor Wells had made the day a city holiday, and business was largely suspended for hours, while many thousands of the city's population journeyed to the Exposition Grounds to attend the closing ceremonies.
BENNING, Dec. 1. -- Following are the entries for to-morrow's races on the Benning track:

A number of essays by Hamilton Wright Mabie, which once appeared serially in magazine form, are gathered in "Nature and Culture." (New York: Dodd, Mead Co. Pp. 226. $2.) The illustrations consist of woodcut heart and tail pieces and reproductions in photogravure, executed by Rudolf Eichemeyer, Jr.

The Charity Organization Society asks aid for deserving persons as follows: $6 monthly for a delicate widow with four children and an old mother to support; $60 to pay rent for an Italian widow with two young children and an aged mother; $100 to help support an intelligent woman and her four young children for one year.

The situation depicted in "Baccarat" is at once the most painful and the most repulsive that life has to offer. In this, story it is brought about by the weakness rather than the wickedness of a woman, and the motif of the novel is to show how it is met by the great souled man who has the misfortune to be her husband.

THE fine critical ability credited to Sidney Lee was never more conspicuously in evidence than in his "Great Englishmen of the Sixteenth Century." Some of our readers who were fortunate in hearing Mr. Lee's lectures in this country must have been struck with the clearness of his views upon the subjects which he has now been treating.
ROME, Dec. 2. -Several delegations of ecclesiastics have arrived in Italy to represent the United States at the jubilee of the Immaculate Conception.

Under the title "Mme. du Barry" the author of "Mme. Recamier and Her Friends" and "Mme. de Montespan," H. Noel Williams has given a sketch of an other French lady's life, illustrated with reproductions of famous portraits (New York: Charles Scribner's Sons; Pp 410; $7.50.)

THE Story of Anglo-Saxon Institutions," by the Hon. Sidney C. Tapp, is one of the books which every American citizen should read. In the brief space of 245 pages it gives an account of the struggles of democracy against imperialism, from the time when our ancestors were plain, unvarnished savages, down to this glorious era when we have achieved civilization -- a civilization which looks best to those who do not look too closely.
Concerning trade conditions Dun's Review says:

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- It appears from a letter written to The Times by A.F. Yarrow of Yarrow Co. that the British Admiralty was informed on Sept. 24 of the sale of the torpedo boat destroyer Caroline to "Mr. Sinnett," the man who took her from the Thames to Libau and turned her over to Russia.

DUQUOIN, Ill., Dec. 2. -- Guards at the Dyle blockhouse, half way between the town of Zeigler and the pumping station, which are more than two miles apart, were driven to cover shortly after midnight by an attack from the woods, in which about fifty shots were fired. An attack was also made on the pumping station, which was answered promptly by the guards and Deputy Marshals guarding the plant.

You will, I am sure, forgive an all-the-year-around reader and one who would swear by your paper for calling attention to the question in last Saturday's BOOK REVIEW, why a tailor is called a ninth part of a man. As a young man I read in an English paper or magazine, in 1871, this version:

Ida M. Tarbell, known through her "Life of Lincoln" and "Life of Napoleon," is the author of a book which McClure, Phillips Co. have published. The material which comprises the book appeared serially in McClure's Magazine, but much has been added to it. "The History of the Standard Oil Company" is based on documentary evidence. In her preface Miss Tarbell writes:

The Fleming H. Revell Company reports that "Doctor Luke of the Labrador," by Norman Duncan, issued only three weeks ago, is in its second edition. The same company states that within a year 75,000 copies have been sold of two religious books by S.D. Gordon -- "Quiet Talks on Prayer" and "Quiet Talks on Power."

BY the publication of this book there hangs a romantic tale. The complete manuscript of it was stolen in 1901 and has not been returned. Consequently Dr. Rolfe has been put to the depressing and heroic task of rewriting it.

Harry J. Bebro, who has been trying to obtain the release of Miss Mabel Spang from Dr. Bond's sanitarium at Yonkers, was arrested late yesterday afternoon by Detective Sergeant Samuel Price of the District Attorney's office.

" Alternating Current Engineering" (Van Nostrand) is the title of a textbook written for the use of those self-taught young men, or even college graduates, who are not familiar with the intricacies of the calculus. The author, E.B. Raymond, belongs to the testing department of the General Electric Company of Schenectady.
ROME, Dec. 2. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Signori Brunialti and Barzilai interpellated the Government on the subject of the recent anti-Italian disturbances at Innsbruck, Austria.

LONDON, Dec. 2, 1904. -- The publishers' Fall season is practically closed, and not many important volumes are likely to be published before the new year opens. Publishers and booksellers are said to be well satisfied with the trade for the last three months.

Spain is the country of picturesque attitudes and fantastic notions of honor. At least in fiction it is. For which reason Don Q., the brigand, "one of the world's greatest and most blameless men," is a Spaniard. The chronicles of this singular character have already entertained many in Pearson's Magazine; collected into a book, they will doubtless entertain many more.

ONE of the most attractive of the books for the wee people this year is "The Happy Heart Family," written and illustrated in colors by Virginia Gerson, (Fox, Duffield Co., $1.) It is a thin, square book, with a cover in a soft tone of red, and in the centre a picture of Mother and Father Heart and all three little Hearts out for a ramble.

Although your space is necessarily limited, a more extensive answer to the inquiry of R.L. Baker of Alexandria, Va., would be interesting because it involves real practical philosophy touching human happiness. The question asked was: "What was Solon's happiness'?" and Shakespeare is quoted. You reply by saying the great poet referred to the "famous interview between Solon and Croesus. When the latter asked the sage who was the happiest man he had ever seen.

The State courts will be called upon to settle the ownership of a five-dollar gold piece, which has been vexing the customs authorities of this port for the last two months, and of which they finally washed their hands yesterday, without having been able to solve the problem.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 2. -- Jacques Krakauer, a dealer in linens, of New York, filed a petition in involuntary bankruptcy against Mrs. Chadwick in the Federal Court here to-day. Krakauer declares that $600 is due him from Mrs. Chadwick. The names of George Couch, a liveryman of this city, and H.F. Potter, a merchant, were also signed to the petition, on claims of $300 and $200, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- That either Theodore P. Gilman or William R. Willcox -- probably Gilman -- will be Postmaster of New York, and that John A. Merritt will be Postmaster of Washington, are the results of an hour's conference between Senator Platt and the President at the White House to-night. Both results are entirely satisfactory to Senator Platt and were contended for by him.

In various wrappers of painted silk and decorated rice paper the latest work of the famous Japanese novelist, Gensai Murai, has come to us from Japan, (Tokio: Hochi Shimbun.) As is stated in a biographical introduction, the novel, which is entitled "Hana, a Daughter of Japan," was especially written for translation into English.

On the 8th inst. the bill entitled "An act for preventing the adulteration or misbranding of foods or drugs and for regulating traffic therein, and for other purposes" (H.R., 6,295) comes before the United States Senate for consideration. Its fate will determine in how far that body is dominated by a lobby of whisky rectifiers, proprietors of patent medicines, manufacturers of adulterated foods and beverages, and promoters of profitable drug trade frauds.

" Flower Fables and Fancies," by N. Hudson Moore, is a little volume printed on decorated paper, and attractively illustrated in tint. (New York: Frederick A, Stories Company; Pp. 192; $1.) It deals with violets; tulips, daffodils, crocuses, lilies, chrysanthemums, roses, and lilacs. The first flower that appears in the Spring is the snowdrop, the "fair maid of February," as it is called.

How a youngster, between boy and man, came out from London to America to hunt among the savages for the granddaughter of certain benefactors of his who had been stolen by the Indians and carried off into the woods years before -- that's the stirring theme of the story before us.

This is to be a few words, only, on a time-honored subject. The utility of books as Christmas presents used to be the theme of a regular annual article in the newspapers which recognized literature as a field of news and subject of comment. Nowadays the phrase "books as gifts" has become hackneyed.

I would like to inquire if there is any law in this city relative to the soliciting on the streets by dealers in second-hand clothing. I live on the west side of the city, and scarcely a day passes in which I am not accosted by one or more of these individuals, who are sometimes so importunate as to make one lose his temper.

Acting on the suggestion of Mayor McClellan, the Board of Estimate yesterday decided to revive the Burr-Hering-Freeman engineering commission, named by Mayor Low to report on a comprehensive plan for increasing the water supply of Greater New York, in order that the commission might pass upon an amended report and plan submitted to the board by Chief Engineer Birdsall of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

The total amount realized from the two days' sale of pictures in the ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria, which ended last night, was $89,790. There were 159 paintings from the collections of the late George B. Blanchard and Mrs. C. Le Roy Stewart As on the previous evening, the bidding began last night in small figures and ended at the highest price.

This is a nice, cheerful little love story about a gallant English gentleman and a saucy French girl. The English gentleman, it is true, went to Canada for no good purpose, since war was in the land, and he fell into the hands of the French girl, niece of the Governor himself, who, fortunately for him, was not a hard jailer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Senator Elkins of West Virginia, who conferred with the President to-day about the work Congress will take up, said he thought there would be important legislation very soon in regard to inter-State commerce. He is Chairman of the committee having that in charge, and it was among the matters which came up at his conference with the President.

The seventh edition of William Elliot Griffis's "Corea: The Hermit Nation," (New York: Charles Scribner's Sons; Pp. 502; $2.50) is revised and enlarged, giving an account of historical events up to and including part of the present year. Its reappearance is undoubtedly due to the troubles in the East.

" Impressionist Painting: Its Genesis and Development," by Wynford Dewhurst, (Scribner's,) $9, contains illustrations of impressionistic work not without their technical value for the art student. Both in selection and in manufacture the plates which accompany Mr. Dewhurst's admirably printed book are about as fine specimens as we have yet seen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The forecaster at Boston has been instructed by the Secretary of Agriculture through Capt. Willis L. Moore, the head of the Weather Bureau, to deliver no forecasts or information to the Boston Herald. When Capt. Moore was asked to-night if this report was true, he replied that it was.

In a Graeco-Roman wrestling match to a finish, contested before 4,000 spectators in Sulzer's Harlem River Casino, One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Second Avenue, last night, H.H. Egeberg announced as the Danish champion, defeated John Piening, "the Butcher Boy," of New York, two falls in three, of a furious struggle for the mastery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Representative Littauer of New York talked State politics with the President to-day, and was informed, as was Gov. Odell at the latter's recent conference with Mr. Roosevelt, that there would be no White House interference in the Senatorial fight either for or against Senator Depew.

The latest publications in the series of Life Stories for Young People are "The Maid of Orleans," "William Tell," "Mozart," and "Beethoven." (Chicago: A.C. McClurg Co. 60 cents each.) The different books of this series are translated from the German by George P. Upton. In the first-mentioned volume, the history of Joan of Arc is treated.

Arthur Vaughan Abbott, C.E., is the author of a series of six books with the general title "Telephony," (New York: The McGraw Company; $6; each, $1.50.) "The Sub-station," the fifth volume in the series, has just appeared. The others are entitled "Location of the Central Office," "Construction of Underground Conduits," "Construction of Cable Plant," "Construction of Aerial Lines," and the last one will probably treat of the construction of the switchboard.

The ferryboat Paunpeck of the Hoboken Ferry Line between Twenty-third Street, Manhattan, and Fourteenth Street, Hoboken, was run into last evening on her 6:30 trip from Twenty-third Street by a Hudson River boat, believed to be the William C. Redfield, and twenty persons injured, one seriously.

Charles F. Murphy signalized his return to Tammany Hall yesterday for the first time since his vacation by declaring that he favored the renomination of Mayor McClellan and by predicting that the Mayor would not only be renominated, but would be re-elected.

Despite his efforts to avoid becoming entangled in the Senatorship fight, Governor-elect Higgins now finds that influential leaders are waiting for him to signify his choice. From inside sources it was learned yesterday that Speaker Nixon, George W. Aldridge, and Superintendent of Insurance Hendricks have decided to steer their course by whatever chart Governor-elect Higgins now decides upon.

The annual exhibition of books and objects of art at Bonaventure's Galleries, opposite the Waldorf, is particularly strong this year in eighteenth century books, illustrated by some of the most celebrated artists and in covers designed by world-famous artist binders. The gems of the collection, which includes some embroidered bindings and miniature books as well as fancy leather work, are described in a small brochure which may be had on application.

-- Another of Boston's religious weeklies, The Christian Register, has taken up the old yarns about the ability of animals to foresee, or at least to prepare for, severe weather months ahead, and the sound common sense of its remarks on the subject is refreshing after the sticky sentimentality with which The Watchman covered all the facts from sight.

The market experienced a decided change of form yesterday. Instead of a continuance of Thursday's softness and irregularity, as had seemed likely, the opening was good and the close better. Our own market offered nothing like the twenty-point rise in two days in Lehigh Coal and Navigation in Philadelphia, but this was recognized as a New York operation, although located elsewhere.
In the opening chapter of a new book which the Macmillan Company is issuing entitled "The Rat," which is included in the Series of Animal Autobiographies, one reads:

G P. PUTNAM'S SONS have undertaken to publish a volume of love letters addressed to Victor Hugo by his lifelong friend, Juliette Drouet, during his exile into the islands of Guernsey and Jersey, 1850 to 1869. These letters were discovered by Henry Wellington Wack, the well-known authority on the Congo Free State, and will be published by the Putnams, with an introduction by Francois Coppee, with a title as yet to be decided upon.

The dead body of a girl about nineteen years old was found with a towel knotted about her neck lying near a bed post to which the towel was tied in a room in the Mott Haven Hotel, at One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street and Park Avenue early last night.

A book of essays by the late Professor of Political Economy in Harvard University, Charles Franklin Dunbar, is coming from the Macmillan Company press. It is entitled "Economic Essays" and is edited by O.M.W. Sprague, Assistant Professor of Economics at Harvard, and contains an introduction by F.W. Taussig, Professor of Economics at the same university. The introduction is a kind of biographical sketch of Prof. Dunbar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Director of the Mint, in his annual report, shows that the output of the coinage mints at Philadelphia, San Francisco, and New Orleans, which were in operation throughout the fiscal year, was the largest on record.

WHEN Mr. Ben Greet revealed the wealth of our elder religious drama by his production of the tragic morality "Everyman," we pointed out that in the so-called Second Shepherds nativity play of the Towneley cycle of mysteries there was an equally excellent example of comedy, and that it only waited adequate presentation on the stage to take its place in the repertory of the humbler masterpieces of our National drama.

BENNING, D.C., Dec. 2. -- The talent was badly disappointed at the result of to-day's races. The favorites were beaten in every event except the third, in which Bohemia, at 4 to 5, won. The greatest surprise was in the last race, when James F. and Marjoram, in the order named, defeated Ostrich, the hot first choice, in a four-horse race.

The time of this story is the Administration of Andrew Jackson, and the place Detroit, just at that time being transformed from a French village into an American town. The central figure is a pretty French girl called Marie Beaucocur, whom many men wooed, but two particularly loved.

The idea has been frequently expressed lately that we are just at the opening of a period of general book buying. A few generations of free education are beginning to have their effect, and the multitude has become dimly aware of the printed book. The Boston Transcript's communicative "publisher," from whose periodical revelations we have already made a quotation or two, has discovered this fact anew and newly promulgated it.

" Certaine Sonnets" in its present edition is similar in size and style to the volumes of Petrarch and Ronsard by the same publishers, although the minor points in the manner of their treatment have been changed in order to coincide more nearly with the features of Elizabethan printing.

TOKIO, Dec 2. -- It is reported here that the Russians have attempted to retake Two Hundred and Three Meter Hill. They assembled a strong force and assaulted the position, but were repulsed with heavy loss.

This compilation, designed to promote the finer influences of war, such virtueas patriotism, obedience, courage -- not the wild lust of battle -- consists of descriptions of many battles in many parts of the world. The present volume is concerned only with campaigns between 1816 and 1860.

The hero is a little Irish boy lacking a hand, but all there in the matter of courage, cheerfulness, and freckles.

You deserve the greatest praise for your splendid editorial on football this morning. It should be remembered that brutality is not manliness, but cowardice. There is hardly a great football game without some injury to one or more of the players, which frequently seriously disfigures or disables the young man for life, and sometimes proves fatal.

If the sterner brand of Calvinism is no longer fashionable in cities, indeed finds existence almost impossible in such places, there are yet regions of the Canadian Northwest where a parson with the blood of the Covenanters in him is at a premium. This is the story of such a parson, by name Hamish MacGregor, called on account of his tow head, Shock.

The theory suggested in these columns yesterday morning -- namely, that a weak closing on a Thursday would these days be followed by a rise and a strong finish on Friday worked out its salvation in practice yesterday. The market opened with some hesitancy, but, gathering strength as the hours passed on, closed with a small boon.

With but a single dissenting vote the Board of Estimate went on record yesterday in favor of a municipal electric lighting plant, and Corporation Counsel Delany was directed to prepare an amendment to the charter carrying the necessary power, to be presented to the coming session of the Legislature.

INTERESTING as have been all of Mr. Anthony Hope Hawkins's clever stories, and confidently as one always opens one of them when in search of forgetfulness of the daily grind of humdrum happenings and humdrum people, it seems certain that most of the readers of his "Double Harness" will open their eyes a little in surprise at the decided step forward on his part which it undoubtedly marks.

Prof. A.H. Espenshade of the Pennsylvania State College has expanded his lecture notes into a volume called "Essentials of Composition and Rhetoric," (Boston: D.C. Heath Co.) As a result he has produced a work valuable from a practical rather than a literary point of view; his explanations of the principles of composition we couched in terms plain to a high school pupil.

" Old Florence and Modern Tuscany," which will bear E.P. Dutton Co.'s imprint, is a sketch of the Tuscan peasants. The book may be thought by many to overestimate them, but the author, Janet Ross, has lived among them for thirty-four years, and she states that in no other country more than in Italy is the golden rule, "Do as you would be done by," more carefully followed.

It seems that the Japanese on "203-Meter Hill" are "inexpugnable" to Russian assaults. The desperation of the assaults by which the Russians have endeavored to retake this position corresponds to the desperation which the Japanese have shown in assaulting it. And quite naturally.

Considerable ado was made in the Street yesterday over the announcement that the National City Bank had arranged to import $500,000 in gold from Paris. In some quarters the inference seemed to be drawn that the announcement meant that the exchange market had suddenly shifted from the gold-export to the gold-import point and that the engagement was probably the first of a series of such transactions.

Paris is indeed the ideal city for the novelist, and Alexandre Dumas adored it. From the stones of Paris have been built up many a lordly volume. Francis Miltoun in his "Duma's Paris" has constructed a historical and topographical work abounding in reminiscences of the supreme maker of romances.

This is a book of epigrams, a beautiful English girl, and brigands. The scene, as the title hints, is in Sicily -- the Sicily which, in spite of all the years between, is still in the author's eyes somewhat, in the pretty English girl's eyes altogether, the Sicily of Theocritus. However, you are to understand the girl-is-no-blue-stocking.

Mr. Sandys's book is one of a classification now somewhat numerous. He has interwoven a variety of information about fishing, hunting, and camping in the Northwest, with a sort of skeleton story. "Sportsman Joe" is a boy, the son of a New York stock broker, who has grown up rather thin and pale.

To say that admirers of Stevenson will find the dress of this new "Edinburgh" worthy of the contents is to say much in little. A severely plain binding of dark blue buckram, with paper, print, and format all that a modest taste could wish for; the illustrations, drawings of corners of the old town and new by T. Hamilton Crawford. W.E. Lockhart, and Sam Bough -- sixteen of them, all charming.

Some of the men who worked so earnestly and vigorously many weary years to secure an international copyright law fear that the droll remarks of Mr. Howells in the December Harper's, concerning the unsatisfactory results of that law, may be misconstrued by the American public, and especially by its legislators. A bill is now pending for the strengthening of the copyright act in the matter of better protection of the works of Continental authors.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- Among the resolutions reported and adopted to-day by the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union was the following:

In a two volume work the Macmillan Company is issuing "The Literature of the French Renaissance," by A.A. Tilley, fellow and lecturer of King's College, Cambridge. The first volume opens with the accession of Francis I. and closes with the death of Du Bellay. The second volume begins with Tyard and his poetry, and closes with Malherbe, containing in addition a conclusion and four appendices.

BUFFALO, Nov. 2. -- The action of the President and Directors of the German-American Bank of Buffalo in promptly making public all the details of the dissension among its stockholders and officers which started a run on the bank had the effect of reassuring the public, and to-day the withdrawals were only about $150,000 above the normal amount.

Armed with a big revolver and his pockets full of ammunition, Garabel Krykorian, an Armenian, yesterday gave battle to the police reserves of the Bedford Avenue Station, Williamsburg, and was killed after he had shot the helmet from the head of one of the opposing force and a bullet from his revolver had clipped the tip from the ear of another.

THESE five volumes compose the first installment of the co-operative history of the United States which was first planned by a committee of the American Historical Association in 1901-1902, but the execution of which it was deemed best to leave to private enterprise. Prof. Albert Bushnell Hart then undertook the task of editing the volumes, securing the most eminent specialists in the country as his co-workers.

Mother Goose has been utilized as a basis for the making of a "Folk-Lore Primer" by Eulalle Osgood Grover. (Chicago: Atkinson, Menazer Grover; 30 cents.) The old-fashioned "See the dog! It is a black dog. I do not fear dogs" of our own school days is gone; the children of to-day are served with tales from their beloved Mother Goose.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 3. -- The possibility of Russia trying to send her Black Sea fleet to the Far East strongly engages the attention of England, in view of the complications which would result if such an attempt were made.

It would not surprise us to be informed that the writer of these essays stood in a pulpit every Sunday morning and that these essays are so many of his sermons that have been diminished of their texts. Conviction on these counts would work no corruption of their blood. If these were sermons in their first intent they were very different from the ordinary run of sermons.

For the use of commercial high schools, business colleges, , the Macmillan Company is issuing a "Commercial Series,'' edited by Prof. C.A. Herrick, Director of the School of Commerce, Philadelphia Central High School. Of the seven books ready or announced for the near future, the editor is also the author of two, "The Meaning and Practice of Commercial Education" and the "History of Commerce," the latter still in preparation.

BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- The appointment at Cleveland to-day of a receiver for the property of Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick took the local attorneys for Herbert B. Newton, who is suing Mrs. Chadwick for the recovery of a large loan, by surprise, and resulted in the hasty departure of Percy W. Carver for New York at midnight to-night. As he took the train he said:
