Mr. Barrett Wendell's volume, "The Temper of the Seventeenth Century in English Literature," is calculated, at least by its title, to arrest attention. Because the historical fact so clearly is that there was no "temper," but only a contradiction of tempers in the English literature of that period.

Boehm Coon have sold to Adolph Lewisohn the five-story building, with stores, at 538 and 540 Fifth Avenue, on plot 50.5 by 100. L.J. Phillips Co. were the brokers in the transaction. The property is on the west side of the avenue, 50 feet south of Forty-fifth Street, the ground being part of what was formerly the site of the Church of the Divine Paternity.

When Mrs. Thomas Wiberley of 239 East One Hundred and Tenth Street engaged Mary White to preside over her kitchen on Wednesday she believed that she had solved the servant girl problem, as far as her own household was concerned. She realized her mistake, however, on Thursday morning when she discovered that Mary had disappeared in the night with silverware, cut-glass, and clothing worth $300.

It is a curious situation that is set out for the consideration of the State Department by the New York lawyers as to the recent change in the official designations of the Consuls sent to other lands by the Government of the United States, whose stationery is now stamped, by the direction of the State Department, "American Consulate."

Thomas L. Higginson, retired banker and member of the Board of Education, began suit yesterday for $5,000 damages against Detective Edward O'Neil of the East Fifty-first Street Station for an alleged insult to which his sixteen-year-old son, James J. Higginson, and himself were subjected on Nov. 22. The incident took place on Madison Avenue, near Fiftieth Street.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- The Cornell football team to-night elected its Captain for next year, and the choice fell to J.H. Costello, right tackle on this year's eleven. Although out of condition during the past season, because of an injured knee, Costello is one of the strongest linesmen Cornell has ever had, and in his first two years on the team played a great game.

TO-MORROW "Arbitration and The Hague Court," by Hon. John W. Foster, will be in all the bookshops. It is written in a cheerfully hopeful spirit, and it abounds in curious details, among which not the least curious is the admission that the compulsory use of French in The Hague Tribunal would debar the majority of American lawyers, "and would" discourage the "resort by American States to the Court."

Gov. Odell's staff gave a dinner at the University Club last night to Adjt. Gen. Nelson H. Henry. Gov. 0dell was present, and made an address, and a silver loving cup was presented to the Adjutant General. Lieut. Col. Charles H. Sherrill made the presentation speech. Among other things in his address to the staff, Gov. Odell said:

Pigeons raced from the Poultry Show at the Herald Square Exhibition Hall, Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway, yesterday, to Lakewood, N.J., and broke the record for the distance by three minutes. Two teams of four pigeons each were in the competition, one team the property of Carl Wentzien and the other the property of John Price.

Take advantage of your chance to save money. Visit us to-day; we will convince you that you have a REAL OPPORTUNITY NOW. Try on the overcoats, note the style of them -- loose, long, broad-shouldered garments, measuring 52 inches in length, with snug-fitting silk velvet collars, some with silk lining -- you will surely buy one.

A man who left behind him two "jimmies," or chisels, and $5,000 worth of furs, all done up in a bundle, in the building at 4 West Fourteenth Street, last night, either jumped or fell from the skylight of the third floor through a second skylight to the ground and received a fracture of the left leg. He was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital a prisoner on a charge of burglary.

AMID the seeming confusion of our mysterious world," observed Nathaniel Hawthorne in his delineation of Wakefield, "individuals are so nicely adjusted to a system, and systems to one another and to a whole, that, by stepping aside for a moment, a man exposes himself to a fearful risk of losing his place forever. Like Wakefield, he may become, as it were, the Outcast of the Universe."

" Danny" Maher, the most successful of the American jockeys who rode through the turf year just ended in England, was a passenger on the White Star Line steamship Cedric, which reached New York yesterday. Maher was accompanied by his valet, John Rowe, and no other American horseman was on the ship.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 2. -- With the confirmation of the news that the Japanese have occupied 203-Meter Hill and the report that the Russians unsuccessfully attempted its recapture, officials at the War Office are beginning to prepare themselves for the inevitable.

There is practical worth in Mr. Dyer's book. He was for ten years at the head of the Tokio Engineering College. The education given there to the Japanese youth was of inestimable value. The problem was how best to take full advantage of all that is good in Western civilization while retaining the characteristics of Japan and bringing them into organic harmony with those of other nations.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., Dec. 2. -- John Sharp Williams, Democratic leader in the House of Representatives, in a speech here to-night outlined a policy of passive resistance by the South in the event of the Republican Party reducing representation in the Southern States and refusing to make the same reduction in the North, East, and West.

" We commonly speak of the working Men's College as having been founded by Frederick Denison Maurice. And the assumption is substantially a true one," writes the Rev. J. Llewellyn Davies, in the volume which the Macmillan Company is issuing under the title "The Working Men's College, 1854-1904." "But the scheme of the college," he continues, "did not, as a matter of fact, issue independently from Maurice's mind.

" Browning and Meredith," (Boston: The Poet-Lore Company: Pp. 55; $1,) by Mary Winchester Abbott, shows the points of similarity between the two writers. In a comparison between the authors she says: "The development of the soul is the one thing worth study, according to Browning; and Meredith declares his subject matter to be the 'soul wind-beaten but ascending.'

G.P. Putnam's Sons are publishing this week Guy Wetmore Carryl's "Garden of Years." It is believed that had Mr. Carryl belonged to an earlier generation he would be known principally as a poet. At least so states E. Clarence Stedman in his preface. The lyric tendency was strong in him, for when a mere boy he wrote a poem on the death of a child which proves this leaning.

It is the aim of the Wampum Library of American Literature to include a series of volumes, each of which deals with the progress of a special literary species, showing the development of this in the United States, and setting forth chronologically specimens from the works of American authors. The selections of each volume are taken particularly from the writings of deceased authors.

At the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday Mayor MCCLELLAN gave evidence of his usual practical good sense in dealing with large municipal problems. A report was offered from the office of the Commissioner of Water, Gas, and Electricity embodying a plan for the increase of the water supply of New York.

Mr. Ade has collected into a little book another bunch of his "fables" in the vernacular of Chicago. As usual some of his vernacular expressions are not without a rude eloquence; as usual, also, Mr. Ade is not without his flashes of insight into the bourgeois breast, if we may be pardoned the expression.
ST. PETERSBURG, Saturday Dec. 3. -- 8 A.M. -- A special despatch received here from Mukden says:

Allow me and many other young Russians to thank you most heartily for your editorial in to-day's issue of your most esteemed and valuable paper, as well as for many other articles concerning the reforms which are taking place now in our dear, poor Russia. One must he born in Russia, live there, go through a Russian high school in order to be able to appreciate the importance of what is going on there.

The year's highest prices were made last week once more, despite reactionary intervals. Many will hold that the stronger portion of the week is characteristic of the current market, and there are bears who contend that the receding prices are the more typical and appropriate of what we are to expect.

Dennis Harrington, who is six feet three and weighs sixteen stone, got on a Ninth Avenue elevated train at Christopher Street early last night and began quietly to ask passengers if they wanted to fight. Nobody paid much attention to him, and he made his way from car to car repeating the request until Twenty-third Street was reached.
HARBIN, Dec. 3. -- Lieut. Gen. Gripenberg, Commander of the Second Manchurian Army, arrived here this evening.

The Jersey City officials and officers of the Erie Railroad had a meeting yesterday afternon to consider the closing of Barnum Street, and Superintendent Stewart of the railroad disclosed the Erie's $8,000,000 improvement project for which the vacation of Barnum Street is necessary.

ROME, Doc. 3. -- It is officially announced that King Victor Emmanuel has conferred the Great Cordon of Saints Mauritius and Lazarus on J. Pierpont Morgan in recognition of Italy's gratitude for the return by Mr. Morgan to the Italian Government of the famous cope which was stolen from the Cathedral of Ascoli in 1902, and subsequently purchased by Mr. Morgan.

BY the aid of an ordinary telephone magnet the telephone has become a storehouse for, as well as a transmitter of, the human voice. This has been made possible by Ella E. Ries of New York City, an electrical engineer and inventor of international fame. Mr. Ries, among his many other achievements, has become a recognized authority in telephony, and this, his latest invention, is called the telephonograph.

IF it were possible for the atmosphere of the Children's Court, at Eleventh Street and Third Avenue, to resolve itself into luminous expression, the words that probably would blaze forth upon the wall would be:

Will you allow a few words from a plain man who has recently been with the United States Army in the field? I speak through your paper because you take an intelligent, humane interest in army matters.

All but four buildings in the little village of Westbury, L.I., were burned down late yesterday afternoon for lack of water. Seven buildings and two windmills were destroyed. The chief of the local fire department summoned fire departments of adjacent places, but when they arrived all that was left for them to do was to bewail the lack of water and to philosophize on what they would have done if they had had an opportunity.

MRS. WISEWAYS, bting overjoyed at the meeting with Mrs. Ingenue, cast about for some form of entertainment which should tend to the latter lady's enjoyment. The matinee was the readiest suggestion, and Mrs. Wiseways asked as to the preference Mrs. Ingenue had in current plays.
It is remarkable what a change can be made in a family by a simple rearrangement of food.

It was a very remarkable tribute that Lord ROSEBERY paid to the late Lord SALISBURY in the debating hall of the Oxford Union Society. During the whole of Lord ROSEBERY'S career in the lifetime of Lord SALISBURY the former was in open and often in rather bitter opposition to the latter.

It is not surprising that Russians should now be agitating the possibility of sending through the Dardanelles their squadron of the Black Sea, to join and reinforce their squadron of the Baltic which left its home waters so many weeks ago, doing some unintended and incidental execution by the way in the North Sea.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Julius F. Biederman, constable, was shot and killed this afternoon while attempting to remove a slot machine from a saloon kept by Joseph Brunner, at Western Avenue and James Street.

The roll of membership of the new Building Trades Board was announced at a largely attended meeting of delegates from thirty-four unions yesterday, sit which steps were taken for a permanent organization. The new body takes in not only the unions in the Building Trades Alliance, but also all unions under the arbitration agreement with the exception of the bricklayers' unions, whose constitution prevents them from joining general organizations.

The question as to whether a foreigner can go through bankruptcy has been raised for the first time in this city in the case of Joseph Gerald de Polo of 208 West Eightieth Street, who filed a petition in bankruptcy on Nov. 2, 1903, with liabilities $57,307 and assets $1,500, a quarter interest in real estate in the United States of Colombia.

MISS BAYLOR was in journalism. Not very deeply, as she admitted herself, but she had a small position on an afternoon paper, and with this, together with the occasional sale of a special article for a Sunday paper and an anecdote or a little sketch for a weekly, she just managed to keep her head above water.

BERLIN, Dec. 3. -- Six million fewer bottles of champagne were drunk in Germany during the first six months of the fiscal year, from April to September, and 800,000,000 fewer cigars were smoked than in the corresponding period last year.

BROCKTON, Mass., Dec. 3. -- Lieut. Gen. Nelson A. Miles has accepted an appointed as Adjutant General on the staff of Governor-elect William L. Douglas. This was made known to-night by Mr. Douglas in the following statement:
TWO months at home -- well, I'm lucky if I spend six weeks of the year there."

Hangers-on about Police Headquarters rubbed their eyes yesterday afternoon when a wagon load of waste paper, blazing twenty feet in the air, drawn by a frenzied horse and driven by a terrified driver, went hurriedly down Mulberry Street.

Aided by the indorsements of several Justices of the Supreme Court, of a majority of the County Judges of the State, and some of the Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States, efforts will be made by lawyers of this city at the coming session of the Legislature to have constitutional amendments passed to change the jury system of the State.

GENEVA, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- After working for thirteen years at the plant of the Phillips Clark Stove Company for from $2 to $2.25 a day, George McCullough finds himself one of thirteen heirs to an estate valued at $325,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- An order has gone out from the White House nullifying the original order by which all executive departments were instructed to give no news to The Boston Herald, because it had printed a story about the President's sons chasing a turkey. The new order permits routine news to go to that newspaper, but does not remove the prohibition as to news of any other character.

THE interest in the revival of Ponchielli's "La Gioconda" makes it probable that the opera will be an attractive item in the Winter's repertory. A performance that is so well presented by so many of Mr. Conried's best singers is, ipso facto, almost assured of success at the outset.

OFFICIALLY it is known as the graduate course for Naval Constructors in the department of naval architecture of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Theoretically it is only a branch of a private educational institution. In reality it is the school established by Uncle Sam himself for the rearing of those who are to plan and build his floating ocean fortresses.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 3. -- A high officer of the General Staff who is intimately familiar with the fortifications of Port Arthur insists that the importance of the capture of 203-Meter Hill has been overestimated.

The cornerstone of the central building of the Rockefeller Institute, at Sixty-fifth Street and Avenue A, was laid yesterday afternoon. John D. Rockefeller, who made the donation which provided for the construction and support of the institute, was not present.

T was in what has been called the power house of the Stock Exchange, in a basement on New Street, at the crowded cocktail hour just preceding the exodus homeward from the financial distrlct, the other afternoon, that Jacob Field met a gentleman who had borrowed a hunded dollars from him many months before, and had since broken many promises to pay.
The drowsy Winter calm of things at the Coney Island Police Station was broken yesterday afternoon by a wild-eyed man, who rushed in and announced excitedly:

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 3, -- The town of Darien is stirred over a lawsuit which is soon to come to trial. The defendant is John W. Emmens, who is employed at the New York Custom House. The plaintiff is a boarding house keeper of Darien.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- A strong effort is being made to end the terrorism under which members of Congress have long labored at the hands of the various postal organizations. President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Wynne have at the request of Congressmen who allege that they have been "held up" by the Rural Letter Carriers' Association caused an investigation to be made.

NEW YORK, in passing Paris and overhauling London as with seven-league boots in the race for the blue ribbon now worn by the English metropolis as the largest city on earth, is rapidly eclipsing both of them as a capital of luxury. This is perhaps best illustrated by the increasing number of New York clubmen and the corresponding growth of the club as an item of paramount importance in metropolitan social and business life.

Packed from the topmost gallery to the aisles of the arena seats with shrieking enthusiasts, Madison Square Garden was opened for the annual week of bicycle racing last night, a special programme of amateur and professional contests being decided preliminary to the beginning of the six days' team race immediately after midnight to-night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Preliminary returns to the Chief of the Bureau of Statistics Department of Agriculture, show a total production of cotton in the United States in the year 1904-05 of 12,162,000 bales. Round bales have been included in this estimate and reduced to their equivalent in square bales.

Pad news from Southwest Africa continues to keep German opinion in a state i of irritation with the Colonial Office; Judging by the past, the reinforcements which have arrived on the coast, finding it very difficult to land, will soon discover that it is almost impossible to operate effectively when at last ashore.

Athletes of Company E won the Nesbitt trophy, emblematic of the athletic supremacy of the Seventh Regiment, at the forty-sixth games of the organization, held at the armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue, last night, with a score of 26 points, defeating Company H, the former holders of the cup and title, by the narrow margin of 1 1/2 points, Company H. scoring 24 1/2 points.

If it was the purpose of Mme. Rejane to reconcile us to her absence, she accomplished, it by putting in for her last matinee and evening performances at the Lyric Dumas's sentimental romance of an impossible courtesan, "La Dame aux Camelias."

LONDON, Nov. 9. IT COSTS enormously to be Lord Mayor of London. It's a sort of tradition that 10,000 is about as little as will suffice to cover the expenses of a decent observance of the customs his lordship may not ignore, and that one who spends lavishly is apt to make a very large hole in 20,000.

KINGSTON, Dec. 3. -- George Adams of Saugerties is suing his wife, Kate Adams, in the Supreme Court in Ulster County for four rings valued at $87.50, which he gave her before marriage. The husband alleges that he gave her the four rings upon condition that she would become his wife, and would live with him and render the duties of a good and faithful wife during her lifetime.

The annual estimate of the Department of Agriculture of the cotton crop fixing the total at 12,162,000 bales naturally threw the cotton market into confusion. It so far exceeded the estimates which have been accepted in the market as a basis for recent trading that a break of from 30 to 50 points was to have been expected.

Magistrate Ommen, sitting in the West Side Police Court, yesterday criticised some phases of union activity. The case is one against "John Doe," in which Harry Love of West New Brighton, S.I., has sought to show that he is a victim of a conspiracy of the Wall Paper Manufacturers' Association and the National Print Cutters' Association, which ruined a business of $72,000 a year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- The armored cruiser Tennessee was launched to-day at the yards of the William Cramp Sons' Shipbuilding Company in the presence of distinguished guests from the State for which the vessel is named and a number of navy and army officials. The party from Tennessee included Gov. Frazier, his staff, Mrs. Frazier, and sixteen-year-old Miss Annie Keith Frazier, who was sponsor for the ship.

FOR the last five years frequenters of Central Park in the afternoon have undoubtedly seen a tall, thin, aged man whose sole business or care in life seemed to be the feeding of the squirrels. Central Park, however, is a big place, and even though you may have seen this aged man once or twice you possibly have not seen him so often that you marked anything particularly interesting about him.

CLEMENT B. ASBURY, who sits behind the arbitrage rail for John H. Davis Co., for which exercise he is commonly reported as getting a higher salary than the Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, says that, a recent statement in this column to the contrary notwithstanding, he has not had a puncture in his automobile for three months.

MUKDEN, Dec. 3. -- All day yesterday Russian siege guns bombarded villages occupied by the Japanese to the east of the railroad, and early this morning to the west of the railroad Don Cossacks routed the Japanese south of Lidiatoun and captured eight guns.

PARIS, Dec. 8. -- Cardinal Perraud, one of the foremost figures in the French hierarchy and a member of the Academy, has written a letter strongly approving of the American system of the independence of Church and State, indicating that the American system offers a basis for a reorganization of the French system when the forthcoming separation of Church and State in France is accomplished.

Yesterday's break in cotton is even more important than its reflection in renewed buoyancy on the stock market. It is always the expected, or what ought to be expected, which is most surprising. Here we have known for months that the acreage was unequaled, that the growing season was good, and the picking season unsurpassable, and yet only very few are not surprised at what was plainly forecasted by every element of the calculation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- William R. Willcox will be nominated on Tuesday for Postmaster of New York, to fill the vacancy made by the death of Cornelius Van Cott, This announcement was made at the White House to-day.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 3. -- J. Madison James, a farmer, of Kelleytown, near Darlington, recently an inmate of an insane asylum, shot and killed his wife last night and to-day killed her brother, R. Sydney Kelley.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- There were numerous callers at the White House to-day, most of whom were Members of Congress and Republicans who thought the President desired to hear their views on tariff and other public questions. The callers were so numerous that none had opportunity to discuss these questions, and few even got a chance to express an opinion.

PORTLAND, Ore. Dec. 3. -- The land fraud trial came to an abrupt close to-day. The defense occupied but seventeen minutes, and then only to present explanations in behalf of two of their counsel. The defense apparently base their hopes on an argument to the jury, and if that fails, on a reversal of judgment at the hands of an appellant tribunal on a question of law.

WHEN you go into a bookshop at this time of the year the array of new novels is apt to make you dizzy, even before the man behind the counter has begun to advise you which of them to read. When that amiable young gentleman has done you are dazed; you wonder how he managed to wade through such a vastness of print.

ST. LOUIS, Dee. 3. -- A further investigation by the police and the Jefferson Guards strengthens their belief that the fire on the Pike this morning, which totally destroyed the Streets of Rome and Quo Vadis and partly destroyed Fair Japan, on the Bowery, and Old St. Louis, was of incendiary origin.

UNTIL the electric railroad between New Haven and Wallingford, Conn., was completed last week, it never had been possible to make a continuous trolley trip from New York to Boston. People had told of trolleying all the way, but the fact was that they had to cross a long gap by steam railroad or in carriages.

HELSINGFORS, Dec. 3. -- An order has been issued by Emperor Nicholas that, as the statutes of the Finnish Diet require members to participate in its deliberations, all expelled persons who have been elected Deputies or who are heads of hereditary noble houses shall be permitted to return and attend the Diet until the session closes.

An evidence of the fact that the President is carefully considering the demand for a revision of the tariff became public yesterday when it was learned that Secretary of the Treasury Shaw paid a flying visit to New York last Wednesday expressly to consult the tariff experts on the Board of United States General Appraisers on the revision of certain schedules.

The people of the country who have seen in the Congressional career of Mr. JOHN SHARP WILLIAMS of Mississippi evidence of unusual soberness of judgment and acute political sense will be sorely disappointed, we think, by his speech at Spartanburg, S.C., on Friday evening, of which we published the chief portion yesterday morning.

By no means the least sincere, tribute to the decision of Justice Clarke last week in the American Malting suit was the announcement the day after the judgment of a million-odd dollars against ex-Director Curtiss was handed down that an effort would be made in the next Legislature to repel or modify the law holding Directors responsible for dividends paid out of capital.

For several years I have had the privilege of appealing through your columns on behalf of our Christmas fund for helping the destitute wives and children of men in prison. In speaking once more of this need, I have the assurance that the message will reach many whose interest is already deeply aroused, and who will be glad to hear of the success of our last Winter's mission in these poor homes.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Lolita Armour, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Ogden Armour, will return next week to Chicago. She has been under the care of Dr. Lorenz in Vienna for several months.

The police yesterday arrested Frank Furlong, the youth suspected of having murdered his aunt, Mrs. Margaret Keeler, in her apartments at 82 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street last Monday. According to Inspector McClusky of the Central Office, Furlong has confessed that he committed the murder, saying that he did it because his aunt refused to give him money.
LONDON, Dec. 3. -- Stocks have done fairly well this week in spite of circumstances that tended to heaviness and lower price levels.

THAT awe-inspiring, that awful Nance O'Neil! Her Magda and her Hedda Gabler, with their crude and cold naturalism, amply explained why her late progress round the earth left behind in the heavens no dust-fires of blazing splendor. Star she may be, but comet never!

THE most-talked-of man in private life to-day is unquestionably Thomas W. Lawson of Boston, not because of his dollars -- others have as many, still others have vastly more -- but because glimpses caught here and there of his fearfully strenuous life show it rich in human qualities.

New Yorkers who were not able to take the trip to St. Louis to seethe World's Fair are to have the chance to see many of the exhibits at a little World's Fair to be held at the Madison Square Garden for two weeks beginning Dec. 17. This is to be held under the auspices of the New York Art Exposition Company, of which W. de Wagstafe is the general director.

Mrs. Colin Powys Campbell, who up to Monday was Miss Nancy Carver Leiter, is a marked contrast in type to her unmarried sister, Miss Daisy Leiter, and to her married sister, Lady Curzon. She is not a beauty as is her elder sister, Lady Curzon, nor is she of the odd and rather bizarre type of her younger sister, Daisy, whose coloring is of the gypsy order minus the red cheeks.

THE debutantes have had a busy time since last Thursday, and the programme this week shows that there will be no change in the social fixtures of the first part of December. Nearly all the Autumn weddings are over, and there are only yet a few of much importance to come before Lent -- which, by the way, is late this year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- J. Edward Addicks has avoided trial in the case brought against him by George Wharton Pepper, receiver for the Bay State Gas Company, to obtain an accounting of $75,000,000 worth of stock, by giving back a large part of the stock and depositing security for the payment of about $45,000 for shares that he could not return.

DUQUOIN, Ill., Dec. 3. -- From investigations made by staff correspondents of St. Louis newspapers, it would appear that the sensational stories of war that for some time have been emanating from the Leiter mines in the town of Zeigler have little foundation in fact.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 3. -- Gen. Madison J. Drake has written a letter to C.H.K. Halsey, President of the New Jersey Committee of the Revolutionary Monument Association, suggesting that the historic cannon owned by the Veteran Zouaves be mounted in front of the new Union County Court House next June, on the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the battle of Elizabethtown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goelet of New York arrived in Washington to-day to be the guests of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, who gave a dinner in their honor this evening. Mrs. Goelet, who was formerly Miss Elsie Whelen of Philadelphia, is a close friend of Miss Alice Roosevelt, the latter having been one of the bridesmaids at the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. Goelet at Wayne, Penn., last June.

The President is to be congratulated upon the happy issue from his perplexities in the matter of the New York Post Office that has been gained by his appointment of Mr. WILLCOX. When Mayor Low made Mr. WILLCOX Park Commissioner for Manhattan and Richmond, the appointment was a complete surprise.

The story of Minnie Shapiro was told in the Supreme Court before Justice Clarke yesterday. Parts of it she told herself. Others told the court pieces of it. They told how she had lived happily with her parents, plain folks who had saved enough to buy real estate, give her a good home, and provide her with an education.

William H. Van Guilder, a real estate broker of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., who claims an interest in the West End Casino, on West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, went there yesterday with eleven men to assert himself. His claim has been disputed by the two men who are running the place, Walter Adee and Frank Archibald.
I LOOKED at Hopkins; Hopkins looked at me. There was a smirk on Hopkins's lip and a self-satisfied smile in Hopkins's eye. But in me these things were not. I was filled with a nameless terror.

EACH season brings on wedding of importance, one that from the social position or the bride and bridegroom and the brilliancy of the function leads all others. For the present New York season this wedding was that on Tuesday of Miss Eleanor Jay, only daughter of Col. William Jay, and Arthur Iselin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Iselin.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 3. -- The directory of living graduates of Yale, made public to-day, shows that 12,665 graduates of the university are alive, the leading departments, being the academic, with 7,025; the scientific, with 2,823; the theological, with 849, and the law school, with 1,371. Occupations are given of 96 per cent. of the graduates, divided as to vocations as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Secretary Taft has apparently succeeded in adjusting the delicate questions which took him to Panama. His report of the outcome of his negotiations with the Panaman Government was received by President Roosevelt today. After a careful perusal of the report the President gave his approval of all the agreements made.

When Daniel J. Sully was bulling cotton last Spring one of his favorite arguments was that he was educating spinners and the public generally to a permanent fifteen-cent basis for that staple. At that time conservative men in the cotton trade prophecied that, Mr. Sully to the contrary notwithstanding, there would be a tremendous crop grown during the next season and that cotton would again return to lower levels.

THIS has probably been the banner year in American steeplechasing. More progressiveness has been shown, better horses have been running, both as regards quality and equine value, many more races have been run, and while the fences have been made more difficult, the number of falls has decreased.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 3. -- A party of Judges, bankers, railroad officials, and politicians of New York and Baltimore played golf on a sleet-sprinkled course in the face of a raw northeast wind to-day, and dined this evening at the Belvedere Hotel as the guests of William A. Marburg. Vaudeville performers from New York gave an entertainment during the dinner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Senator Alger of Michigan went to the White House in a hurry to-day to investigate a report that the President was going to appoint a Michigan man to be Assistant Secretary of the Navy without having previously consulted the two Senators from that State or notified them of his intention.

Those who have been looking for evidences of a broader market and of a better demand for improved properties have again had much to encourage them in the business of the last week. The general Bronx and Washington Heights aspect of daily reports is still predominant, but there have also been signs pointing in the direction of a gradual revival of interest in other directions.

NOW boys, come back with the goods." Acting Captain Mott of the Harbor Police watched his men stow themselves away in a black-painted naphtha launch and cautiously feel their way through the fog out of the square little stone dock that adjoins Pier A at the Battery.

ON June 20, 1870, half a hundred representative cotton men, all of them New Yorkers, met in a room on Pearl Street, and the New York Cotton Exchange, the first the world had known, was born. The initiation fee paid by the original members was $200, at which figure it remained until the organization was fairly launched.

Columbia University and the Hockey Club of New York opened the season of competitions last night by a spirited match at the St. Nicholas Rink, Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue. The Hockey Club players were decidedly superior to the Columbia men, and won handily by 13 goals to 2.

The French liner Touraine, from Havre, and the Cunarder Etruria, from Liverpool, both of which were due at New York early yesterday morning, were both delayed by the prevailing heavy weather on the Atlantic. La Touraine was sighted late yesterday afternoon and should be at her pier in the East River early this morning. The Etruria was sighted last night, and will probably be at her pier this morning soon after the Etruria reaches hers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- The National Woman's Christian Temperance Union today closed its annual convention after reaffirming its faith in the beneficence of the anti-canteen law and pledging itself to defend the measure against all efforts to have it repealed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Aroused to action by the urgent necessity of employment for convicts in the State penal institutions, the Illinois State Prison Board to-day authorized the printing of 20,000 circulars, which will be sent to the executives of every municipality in the State giving the information that the penal institutions are ready to supply products of every description for which requisition is made.

HOLDEN, Mo., Dec. 3. -- Missouri Pacific passenger train No. 1, west-bound from St. Louis to Kansas City, due here at 4 o'clock this afternoon, was wrecked at the water works bridge, two miles east of here.

At least one art student reached Paris lately from this side of the Atlantic who found that romance all ready which ought to meet the novice but rarely does. Miss Malone of Columbia, S.C., had been but a few days in France when she lost on a train between Dieppe and Paris a portfolio full of the pictures she had brought with her as samples of her skill.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 3. -- Sensational disclosures were made in the Supreme Court to-day in the trial of the six election officials of Ward 5, Precinct 9, who are charged with contempt. George King, a handwriting expert, said that 57 of the ballots in the box had been written by ten different persons.

ALTHOUGH every one knows that the price at which a picture is held means a good many other things beside its value as a work of art, it is difficult to avoid receiving a certain impression on learning that an old canvas, upon which some painter long dead and gone brushed his pigments with a master hand, represents an investment of more than $100,000.

UNCLE SAM, in his democratic manner of taking things -- and Princes --for granted, has as yet hardly awakened to the very unique distinction being accorded to him as the host of Gen. H.I.H. Prince Sadanari Fushimi, who, since his arrival in San Francisco on Nov. 9 and here last Wednesday, has been busily practicing the strenuous life after the heart and preaching of President Roosevelt.

One of the most important decisions affecting the steel industry was that rendered last week by the arbitrator in the dispute regarding the distribution of percentages among the members of the Steel Rail Association. This association, which is composed of the United States Steel Corporation, the Lackawanna Steel Company, the Pennsylvania Steel Company, the Cambria Steel Company, and the Maryland Steel Company, has for its object the maintenance of the price of steel rails.

IT was a very tired-looking woman, bundled in warm furs, that stepped off the express from Toronto, a night or two ago, chatted with friends for a few moments on the platform of the Grand Central Station, and then hurried away to a train for a quiet suburb about thirty miles from New York, where she is to rest until her official public reception in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening.

PLAINFIELD, Dec. 3. -- "Mayor Bill" Smith of New Market, brother of the late Mrs. Charles L. Fair, has failed in business. New Market's "Mayor" and Andrew Wilson of this city, trading as the Plainfield Auto Garage Company, have asked the Court of Chancery to appoint a receiver for the concern, alleging that they are hopelessly involved.
I SHALL be delighted to have you join us at dinner to-morrow at 6 o'clock. Our mutual friend Miss -- will be of the party. Please let me know if you can come. Yours sincerely, Mrs. John Brown."

PANAMA, Dec. 3. -- Approval was received from Washington this afternoon by Secretary of War Taft to conclude the agreement reached by him and officials of the Panama Government looking to the settlement of points in dispute regarding the government of the canal zone. The text of the agreement will be made public Monday.

CHICAGO, Dec, 4. -- 'Vhether there is to _boa flight among the different Joekey clubs'throughout the liddle rest and South will be decided To-morrow wheri the Board of Stewards of the 'V'estern Jockey Club meets here in annual session. Although there are many questions to be decided, a clash over racing dates will be the -ital issues.

Although not indorsed by the Board of Health, the Interborough Company has seen fit to publish Prof. Chandler's report in the pamphlet "Subway Air pure as in Your Own Home." This action was ill-advised, because the evidence thus far secured by chemical analysis and general observation clearly does not bear out the conclusion drawn from it.
LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The Times in its financial supplement to-morrow will say:

Off to a rolling start, and carrying a sprinting pace from the crack of the pistol that sent the riders off on their long contest, the annual six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden was begun at 12:07 o'clock this morning in splendidly spectacular style before the hugest crowd that ever attended such a contest in the great hall.

W. Emlen Roosevelt, cousin of the President, at the head of a bucket brigade composed of the servants of his household, succeeded in controlling a fire which started in the pantry of his home, 804 Fifth Avenue, at an early hour yesterday morning until the arrival of a fire engine from headquarters.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Governor-elect Frank W. Higgins is not doing anything just now, he says, which might be construed as "meddling" in the struggle for the United States Senatorship between Chauncey M. Depew and Frank S. Black, but the Governor-elect stated plainly last night at the Iroquois that while he was not interfering at the present time, he had not mortgaged his future action.

Once more the stock market has left a somewhat critical position behind it with results agreeable to all but the bears, and everybody is happiest when the bears are sulkiest. The exports of gold threatened the stability of the advance, but the averages are left at their highest by a week's movement in which among the stocks which moved so much as a point 107 advanced, and 27 declined.

PRINCETON, Dec. 4. -- Princeton enthusiasts are looking forward to the Winter sport with increasing interest, and discussing the prospects of the basket ball, hockey, and track teams, which seem to be brighter than usual this year. The first game of basket ball will be played next Saturday with Fordham College, and Capt. Vanderbilt is rapidly getting his men in shape for the contest.

That the Subway station at Seventy-second Street was a blunder is now conceded by those who made it and those who permitted it. That it "must go" is the conclusion of all who have given the matter consideration.

The annual conference of the appraisers of merchandise at the various ports of the United States will begin at the Appraisers' Stores in this city to-day. The custom of holding the annual conferences was started by Daniel Manning when he was Secretary of the Treasury under President Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Exports of manufactures in the calendar year 1904 will not only exceed the highest figures of any earlier year, but may probably pass the $500,000,000 line, as against $434,000,000 in the high-record year, the fiscal year 1900; $151,000,000 in 1890, $103,000,000 in 1880, $68,000,000 in 1870, and $40,000,000 in 1860.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- That immigration to the United States decreased materially during the last fiscal year, and that the moral, intellectual, and physical qualifications of the immigrants admitted to this country during the past year are higher than ever heretofore have been chronicled, is asserted in the annual report of Frank P. Sargent, Commissioner General of Immigration, which was made public to-day.

MOUNT VERNON, Dec. 4. -- While Mrs. Dudley S. Valentine, wife of Alderman Valentine of the Seventh Ward, Yonkers, was out walking this afternoon with her children, she discovered the body of a baby girl that had been choked to death, and was lying in a clump of bushes in Belmont Park near the Empire City Race Track.

Water Commissioner Oakley and Controller Grout gave out statements last night with reference to the signing of lighting contracts by Mr. Oakley last week. Commissioner Oakley's statement was given out at the Pensacola Club, his district organization headquarters, while the Controller's statement was issued from his residence on Carroll Street in Brooklyn.

The decision of the New York Central management to equip its Harlem Branch with electrical apparatus for train propulsion as quickly as possible, instead of waiting a year as was first intended, is due to the rapid growth of its suburban traffic. Like considerations have influenced the Lackawanna management to enterprise in the same direction; also that of the Long Island Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The third session of the Fifty-eighth Congress will assemble at noon to-morrow.

The correspondent who, in a letter printed in a recent issue, expresses "some astonishment" at the statement in these columns a few days before that the fertilizing value in sewage is not great enough to warrant its recovery, since it would not repay the cost, makes the very usual mistake of confusing irrigation with fertilization.

The Rev. S.D. McConnell of All Souls' Church, in his regular Sunday afternoon sermon yesterday, said that no worse conditions of conduct of man toward man were possible than existed here at home. The only relief from "our bane of bad manners,'' he declared, was to get out of New York.

PANAMA, Dec. 4. -- The differences between the United States and Panama which made necessary the visit of Secretary of War Taft to the Isthmus were settled to-day by the issuance of an executive order signed by Secretary Taft for President Roosevelt and assented to in a letter by President Amador of Panama.

So acute in some religious bodies has become the dearth of ministers, and so few are the young men that are entering the seminaries with intent to study for the ministry that active steps are being taken by prominent religious educators to determine if a solution for the problem cannot be found. John R. Mott, head of the Student Volunteer Movement, is said to be behind this effort.

ROME, Dec. 4. -- The infant Crown Prince of Italy was baptized at the Quirinal today. The weather was showery, but this did not prevent a great crowd gathering at the Palace to witness the passage of the carriages with their distinguished occupants.

Recent official tests of the Amethyst, of the British naval establishment, have given remarkable results as establishing the economy and value of the steam turbine for ship propulsion. Compared with ships of the same class, the Amethyst showed an advantage of 1.29 miles an hour in speed, this gain having been secured with easier steaming of boilers, equal weight of machinery, no vibration, and a net saving of 10 per cent. in coal burned.

Mrs. Sadie Everett, an actress living in the Hotel Gerard, in West Forty-fourth Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Breen in the West Side Court yesterday on a charge of larceny, but was promptly discharged. She had been accused Saturday night by Mrs. Adele Jackson, also of the Gerard, of stealing a pocketbook containing $60.38.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 4. -- Two arrests as a result of the so-called Chadwick affair were made to-night. President C.T. Beckwith and Cashier A.B. Spear of the Citizens National Bank of Oberlin, which suspended because Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick could not repay notes for over $240,000, were taken into custody charged with violation of the Federal banking laws.

TOKIO, Dec. 4. -- Unofficial details of the capture of High Hill (203-Meter Hill) at Port Arthur show that the struggle began at 1 P.M. on Nov. 27, when the besiegers concentrated the fire of their heavy guns on the parapets of Red Hill, 300 meters south of High Hill.

The Janitors Society of New York, at a mass meeting held last night in Golden Rule Hall, 125 Rivington Street, voted unanimously to defy the orders of Dr. Woodbury, Commissioner of the Street Cleaning Department, and will, commencing to-day, refuse absolutely to sort the garbage and refuse of the tenements over which its members rule.

A minor chord sobered the merrymaking of Chinatown last night. "Mokago Pete" was no more, and it was only fit there should be mourning, for he was as good a friend as Chinamen in need ever had in this land of foreign devils.

BERLIN, Nov. 22. -- Crowds of people who thronged the busy crossing where the Friedrichstrasse and Unter den Linden Intersect were treated to-day to a sensation. A young, slenderly built fellow was noticed to take off his hat, look round in all directions, and then suddenly to stand on his head in the middle of the street, not, using his hands to balance him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Praise of President Roosevelt as a keen naval observer finds conspicuous place in the first report of Secretary of the Navy Paul Morton to the President, made public to-day. He declares that opinions delivered by Mr. Roosevelt years ago have been borne out by the conflicts of the Japanese and Russian fleets.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- A proposed change in rules, equivalent shippers allege to an advance in freight rates of $250,000,000 a year, will be investigated by the Inter-State Commerce Commission, beginning to-morrow morning.

The most significant feature of the tariff revision agitation which is going on at Washington with increased liveliness as the Congressmen gather there is the heat manifested by the extreme protectionists. It looks as if they were good deal frightened at the strength of the sentiment for revision which is shown and a good deal concerned at the way in which the President is likely to take it.

The American home and its principles, springing from a former agricultural life, are arraigned by Prof. SIMON N. PATTEN in The Independent of Dec. 1, for their effect of discouraging marriage under present changed industrial conditions. Men used to be glad to marry young, he says, as wives were an economic help.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 4. -- The keel for the new fifty-two-rater which is being built at the Herreshoff shops for racing abroad next year was successfully cast last week. The shape of the lower part of the casting is curved fairly from aft to forward instead of being in nearly a straight line as most of the Herreshoff racing boats of that size have been.

The story of the attempt of the mail carriers' organization to secure legislation for its members by "holding up" Congressmen is by no means a novel one in Washington. There has been a pretty steadily growing tendency to this sort of thing for a number of years, and though the department may undertake its suppression in earnest, as it certainly should, it will be found not an easy matter to handle.

Two Second Avenue elevated trains, running over the Subway extension viaduct that is connected with the elevated line at One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, collided at 9:30 o'clock last night at One Hundred and Seventy-fifth Street and the Southern Boulevard, just opposite the Union Railway's West Farms power house, and two blocks south of the viaduct's One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street station.

Lucy Blugus of 156 First Street, Jersey City, was arrested late Saturday night, charged with a series of petty robberies. She is only fifteen years old, but would readily pass for twenty or twenty-two. There are four complaints against her.

Many of the horses which figured prominently in the "Old Glory" sale at Madison Square Garden were seen on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning. Only one or two of the newcomers, however, made any showing, the most note-worthy being the bay trotting gelding Baron De Shay, 2:08 1/2, which was purchased by Andrew Phillips.

The open shop convention of the Citizens Industrial Association stirred up the organizations in the Central Federated Union yesterday which .are preparing to combat the advocacy of the open shop in New York.

BELLEVILLE, N. J., Dec. 4. -- A self-appointed court of justice has been conducting star chamber proceedings in the woods near here the last two or three days, and automobilists who happen to pass by have been obliged to contribute generously to its support by giving up twenty-five-dollar fines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Cabinet places are not often given as rewards of merit. Still rarer is the case of a Cabinet office given as a reward of merit to a man whose merit consisted in his hunting out graft in the department of which he is made the head. This it is which gives interest to the presence in president Roosevelt's Cabinet of Postmaster General Wynne.

ROME, Dec. 4. -- Archbishop Farley of New York was to-day appointed by Pope Pius to the dignity of Assistant to the Pontifical Throne, which permits the Archbishop to sit with the College of Patriarchs and Archbishops and to assist at functions presided over by the Pope.

Earl lltzwilltam of Rotherham, Yorkshire, England, one of the largest landholders in England and Ireland, the Fitzwilliam estates totaling 115,000 acres, arrived here yesterday on the Cunarder Etruria. Lord Fitzwtlllam is a traveler of note, a veteran of the South African war, and One of the Trustees of the Ascot Grand Stand Fund.

At the newspaper offices along Park Row last night a lengthy typewritten paper was left anonymously, describing a scheme for expediting the transportation of foreign mails by carrying them on fast trains between the Central Post Office in this city and Montauk Point, L.I., the terminal at the New York end to run under the East River.

The opinion of the press of the country generally as to the order of the President limiting the news to be given by the officials of the Government to The Herald of Boston, on account of an untrue and offensive story published by that paper, is that the publication by the paper was inexcusable and that the action of the President is a serious error.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The arrival of a St. Petersburg dispatch stating that the Russian Naval Headquarters Staff announce that the Aurora of the Baltic fleet was struck by Russian shells in the affair of the Dogger Bank astonishes nobody.
Sometimes milk does not agree with children or adults. The same thing is true of other articles of food. What agrees with one sometimes does not agree with others.

Despite the fact that comparatively little aid was vouchsafed him by those to whom was intrusted the difficult task of adequately representing his tragedy, the "Judith of Bethulia" of Thomas Bailey Aldrich stood revealed last night as a work of large poetic inspiration, conveyed in convincing and impressive dramatic form.

Borough president Littleton of Brooklyn declared yesterday that Controller Grout was bound by law to declare void the twenty-six lighting contracts entered into by Commissioner Oakley in behalf of the city.
De Selding Brothers and E.A. Treadwell have sold for Mrs. Althea Rudd Ward the property 29 Frankfort Street, a six-story building on plot 29.9 by 102.9 by 23.9 by 103.8.

So far as designating the leading batsman of the American League for the season of 1904 was concerned, the official averages, which were authorized to be promulgate yesterday, were not necessary. All statisticians placed Napoleon "Larry" Lajoie of the Cleveland Club, who was Captain of that team, but who has been elevated to the position of manager next year, far above any other player in the League.

In a decision written by Judge Somerville, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by Gillespie Brothers Co. of New York against the assessment of duty on a watch claimed to be of American manufacture and a sample returned from abroad. Judge Somerville overruled the protest because the Treasury regulations as to proof of identity had not been complied with.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.-- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day affirmed the order of the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas dismissing a writ of habeas corpus in the extradition case of Charles F. Dodge, wanted in New York on the charge of perjury in a divorce proceeding to which he was a party.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- With the announcement of a second arrest in the Cadwalder safe robbery case, the members of that family have begun to wonder how many persons have been living for the last three years at the expense of that family strong box. The police say that three families have, and wonder at the Cadwalder's a little for not finding it out before.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- The sensational confession of President C.T. Beckwith of the failed Citizens' National Bank of Oberlin, Ohio, regarding the bank's transactions with Mrs. C.L. Chadwick, was read over the telephone to-night to Edwin T. McKnight of the law firm of Eaton, McKnight Carver, who brought the suit for Herbert D. Newton against Mrs. Chadwick for the recovery of $190,800.

Gov. Odell definitely disposed last night of any aspirations which Democratic lawyers may have had to succeed to the places on the Supreme Court made vacant by the resignation of Justice Edgar M. Cullen of the Second Department, now Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, and of Justice D Cady Herrick of the Third Department, who resigned to become the Democratic candidate for Governor.

GENOA, Italy, Dec. 5. -- The German collier Irmgard Horn, which was chartered by the Russians and accompanied Admiral Voeikersam's division of the Russian second Pacific Squadron through the Suez Canal and was going to the Island of Perim, Straits of Bab-el-Mandeb, suddenly received counter orders and has arrived here.

America has one automobile entry assured for the international Gordon Bennett Cup races that will be held in France next year. Definite news was received yesterday by Secretary S.M. Butler of the Automobile Club of America that a check for $600, the required entry fee, would be sent this week to comply with all the conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The assembling of Congress was marked by those scenes which have become familiar by oft repe-which have become familiar by frequent repetition. There were the usual throngs of fashionably gowned women in the balconies and the great masses of flowers on desks of favorite members.

" Brother Jacques," Miss Annie Russell's new vehicle, is mainly written by Henry Bernstein, who was responsible for the original of her melancholy and distasteful piece of last year. "The Younger Mrs. Parling," but it is of a wholly different order. It is remarkable, in fact, as being the reverse of what is usually called French.

-- One of the Swiss cantons, Zurich, is about to try, according to report, the experiment, decidedly more interesting than hopeful, of creating a medical service fund by taxing every citizen 86 cents a year and with this money employing something like fifty physicians, who will respond to all calls without further remuneration.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- Herr Bebel, the Socialist leader, analyzed the Budget in the Reichstag to-day. Secretary of the Treasury von Stengel, he said, had sketched on Saturday the deplorable financial situation of the empire in terms so true that he regretted the French custom could not be followed and the speech be posted throughout the country as a Ministerial declaration of the position into which the country had been drawn by the Government's policies.

Another Shakespearean revival, following close on the heels of the short but successful engagement of Mr. Sothern and Miss Marlowe, was effected last night at the Princess Theatre by Robert B. Mantell. The play chosen for Mr. Mantell's reappearance in New York, after an absence of years, was "Richard III.," in which he is reported to have had much success in the West.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 5. -- A Wells-Fargo express car on an Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe overland passenger train, west-bound, was entered early to-day somewhere between Needles and Daggett, and Evan O. Roberts, express messenger, was shot and probably fatally wounded. The way safe was rifled, but the main safe, said to contain $200,000 in pension money, was not robbed, officials say.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- William R. Wilcox's nomination of postmaster of New York will be sent to the Senate to-morrow. He was here for a few hours to-day with Wm. D. Murphy, President of the Union League Club, and both called on the President and the Postmaster General.

William H. Maxwell, City Superintendent of Schools, was defeated yesterday in the Supreme Court, in an action brought against him by the Normal College graduates, the court holding that a Normal College graduate is entitled to a license to teach in the public schools, notwithstanding Mr. Maxwell's contention to the contrary.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5. -- Ogontz, Kleinwood, and Merry Acrobat were the beaten favorites to-day. The weather was cloudy and the track heavy. Judge Himes and Joe Lesser were both well backed and each made a show of his field. Merry Acrobat's defeat was a blow to the talent. Summary:

The plaza at the intersection of Broadway, Twenty-third Street, and Fifth Avenue, which John W. Gates has described as the "city switch yard," where the three lines of street cars mix it up with vehicles innumerable and unfortunate pedestrians, became safe yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- The reports that France has given adhesion to Russian overtures for a modification of the Treaty of Paris so as to permit the Black Sea fleet to pass through the Dardanelles are officially denied. The authorities here say that no such application has been made, and that at present there is no indication of any modification of the treaty.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- The story published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, tending to impugn the authenticity of the Velasquez portrait recently purchased by the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, has set art critics here in a ferment.

If it is possible to take the leaders of the local building trades seriously, and assume that they mean what they say, it looks as if they had laboriously walked in a circle, and after maintaining all Summer and until the present time a profitless conflict with the employers, had come back to the starting point.

Criticisms of the Comparative Exhibition of Native and Foreign Art, which will close next Sunday at the Fine Arts in West Fifty-seventh Street have revolved rather tiresomely round the question of the adjective "Comparative," a matter of the smallest importance in view of the fact that by general consent the pictures are with few exceptions so fine that no one can afford to stay away.

Detectives from three cities in three different States who had been hunting John E. Callahan, an alleged baggage thief, over the whole long line of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad for two weary months, saw him simultaneously at the Grand Central Station on Sunday, and made a rush for him.

The decisions of the Admiralty Court at St. Petersburg, overruling the decisions of the prize court at Vladivostok, tend to redeem the reputation of Russian jurisprudence. In the lowest view, they show a Russian consciousness that Russia may at some time be a neutral, and that, in that case, to hold her to the doctrine of her executive departments during this war might work her grievous injury.

The dozen or more families who occupy the houses on the north side of East Thirty-fourth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, had a burglar scare, followed by a hunt over the roofs by several Tenderloin detectives, between 11 o'clock and midnight last night.

It is awkward, confoundedly awkward, for an Administration which has turned a forbidding and hostile countenance upon all Trusts to find itself actually a party to the most flagrant contract in restraint of trade ever drawn by Trust attorneys. The tripartite contract or agreement between the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, the Panama Railroad Company, and the transcontinental railroads, is absolutely shameless in its open defiance of law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Attention is drawn to the large fees received by the United States District Attorney for the Southern District of New York in the annual report of Attorney General Moody. Recommendation is made that a fixed salary be given to this official.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 5. -- An official statement issued from naval headquarters gives Vice Admiral Rojestvensky's latest account of the Dogger Bank affair and explains how the Baltic fleet fired on its own ships. The statement is as follows:

The right to criticise Gov. ODELL for any use he may make of his power to elect a Senator of the United States has been forfeited, it seems to us, by the members of the Republican Party, of other parties, and of no party, who voted for Republican candidates for the Senate and Assembly.

ROME, Dec. 5. -- The Pope this morning held a consistory for the Beatification of Blessed Gerardo Maiella and Blessed Alessandro Sauli, one of the chief functions of the celebration of the golden jubilee of the proclamation of the dogma of the Immaculate Conception.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 5. -- Mirza Riza Khan, former Persian Minister to Russia and present Ambassador from Persia to Constantinople, and his suite, constituting a deputation from the Shah of Persia to the Czar, have arrived in St. Petersburg.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The doxology has been discarded at the University of Chicago. The faculty has agreed with the students that the college songs do more to breed a true religious and college spirit than the chanting of the doxology, and to-day at all chapel services in the junior college the college song, "Alma Mater," was substituted for the doxology.

Fire losses in Manhattan, Bronx and Richmond showed a lower average loss per fire during the first nine months of the current year, although the total fire loss is greater than that of the year before, according to figures which Fire Marshal Peter Seery had prepared for the information of Mayor McClellan in his coming annual message.

BUFFALO, Dec. 5. -- As a result of the run started last week, the doors of the German Bank were closed to-day by order of Frederick D. Kilburn, State Superintendent of Banks, and the run on the German-American Bank was renewed. It was also announced that Richard Emory, who had been President of both institutions, had resigned from the German-American Bank.

While Pierre Bertel, an employe in the Standard automobile garage in West Thirty-ninth Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, directly opposite the stage entrance of the Metropolitan Opera House, was working about an automobile on the lower floor of the place yesterday about one o'clock, somebody dropped a cigarette stub into a pool of gasoline that had gathered near the car.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5. -- Richard Emory is a nephew of T. Edward Hambleton of the banking house of Hambleton Co. Mr. Emory was at one time identified with the Baltimore Traction Company. He later took charge of the Street Railway at Nashville, and then went to Ohio to look after interurban properties bought by New England capitalists.

TOKIO, Dec. 5. -- Popular sentiment regarding the question of assistance which neutral powers are giving to the vessels of the Russian second Pacific Squadron, which heretofore has been repressed, is now growing more acute, and prominent newspapers are voicing the demand for determined action by the Japanese Government.

Is the negro race to be gradually driven from the Southern States? This is not exactly, in form, the question which Mr. WILLIAM GARROTT BROWN places before us in his most interesting article on "The White Peril" in The North American Review, but it is the question his article leads a reader to ask.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 5. -- One of the greatest undertakings in connection with the double-tracking of the Highland Division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad from Stormville, N.Y., east toward Hawleyville, will be the filling in of the right of way across a valley 1,500 feet long at Towners, N.Y., over which the present track is carried on a wooden viaduct.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 5. -- The Federal authorities have determined to probe the case of Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick to the very bottom. They have taken steps to serve subpoenas on Andrew Carnegie and on Mrs. Chadwick. Subpoenas will also be served on other persons who are believed to know something about this strange affair.

MUKDEN, Dee. 5. -- There is a persistent rumor that the force of Japanese sent to turn Gen. Rennenkampff's flank has been repulsed with great loss. The story is not yet officially confirmed, but details are given with great circumstaniality.

A long reach was made backward into the past at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening when Donizetti's opera "Lucrezia Borgia" was revived. Whatever plausibility of excuse may have been found for the resuscitation in recent years of half a dozen other neglected operas of the older Italian list there is very little for this.
That famous English public school, Eton, wants a ghost. That is, of course, if the students and masters agree with the editor of the Eton College Chronicle, who sets forth the case as follows:

The second trial of Nan Patterson, accused of the murder of Caesar Young, began yesterday morning in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, Justice Vernon M. Davis presiding. Before the hour for adjournment arrived twenty talesmen from the special panel of 200 had been examined, and three jurors chosen.

A man who the Austro-Hungarian Consulate here believes is Dr. Franz Papp of Budapest, Hungary, who is wanted in his home city for the alleged theft of about $23,000 worth of jewels, was brought to this city from Norfolk. Va., Saturday to be sent back to Hungary to face his accusers.

Just before daylight yesterday, when the tide was coming in, ferry hands at the Pennsylvania's Twenty-third Street pier heard cries for help coming apparently from the water. A search revealed nothing, but all the time the cries could be heard, though they were growing weaker.

If there is anything upon which speculative opinion has been agreed for a long time, it is that a reaction has been overdue. It having arrived yesterday, everybody was much surprised, and with common accord there was casting about for a scapegoat. The general news of the day was not chargeable.

PANAMA, Dec. 6. -- A supplemental agreement signed this morning by War Secretary Taft and President Amador and Foreign Minister Guardia provides that after Dec. 12 no cargoes can be landed at the canal ports except on presenting a Panaman Consular invoice from the port of shipment.

After the curtain of the third act last night at the Lyric, in response to a good deal of persistent applause, Mr. Hackett made a little speech. He said that his present welcome to his old home was warmer than in many years, and he added, with a touch of real modesty, that he hoped it was sincere.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 6. -- The election of Supreme Court Justice William E. Werner to the Court of Appeals will be followed shortly by his resignation from the lower court. The vacancy, it is stated, will be filled by the appointment by the Governor for one year of Nathaniel Foote of the law firm of Foote, Perkins Havens of Rochester.

ALBANY, Dec. 6. -- The Board of Railroad Commissioners has decided indefinitely to postpone consideration of the application of the New York and Port Chester Railroad Company for the increase of its capital stock from $250,000 to $15,000,000, and issue of bonds, hearing on which had been set down for to-day.
HENDAYE, France, Dec. 6. -- M. Deroulede and M. Jaures, the Socialist leader in the Chamber of Deputies, fought a duel with pistols here this morning.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 6. -- Three boys, Harold and Herbert Jackson and Leo Cruse, had a startling experience last night, and as a result Harold, who is thirteen years old and the elder of the Jackson brothers, is confined to his home at 29 Chapel Street, Orange, suffering from severe injuries which will leave their mark on him for life.

The Salvation Army tendered a rousing reception to its new Commander in this country, Miss Eva Booth, at a meeting last night in Carnegie Hall, where the fourth daughter of Gen. William Booth was officially welcomed by many of the Army's members and staff.

Removing Augustus T. Gillender as referee in the case of McKenzie against McKenzie, Justice Gildersleeve in the Supreme Court yesterday appointed Edward G. Whittaker to take testimony. Referee Gillender is now in a sanitarium at Greenwich, Conn., and was removed on the ground of mental incapacity.

ALBANY, Dec. 6. -- By a decision of the Court of Appeals to-day in the case of the people against Bootman and another, the State loses its last chance to recover over $1,000,000 penalties for alleged violation of the game laws.
TOKIO, Dec. 6. -- The Port Arthur besiegers report as follows:

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6. -- Halcyon Days, Brooklyn, and Tom Shelley were the beaten favorites to-day. Vouch was cowded out in the first race and pulled up. Lucy Young could not shoulder her impost in the heavy going, and the best she could do was third in the ruck. Gregor K. might have won his race, but reared up and became entangled in the barrier at the start. Weather cloudy, track heavy.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- The course of prices in the local market to-day was clearly foreshadowed before trading began, owing to the announcement that the Earle deal with the New York, New Haven and Hartford interests was off. Lehigh Navigation, which closed yesterday at 124, opened at 111, with the next sale at 113.

There is cold comfort in the President's message for the earnest and insistent seekers after subsidies for the mercantile marine. He barely mentions the subject, and in an entirely perfunctory manner.

The trial of Policeman Arthur J. Mallon of the West Sixty-eighth Street Station for shooting and killing young Robert Brennan of 17 Forsyth Street early on the morning of May 8 last in front of 17 Bowery began in earnest before Recorder Goff in General Sessions yesterday, when William O'Brien of 71 Washington Street was put on the witness stand.
I have read with much interest your note on a clock that "will run for 2,000 years without even a single winding up to start with." This looks very much like perpetual motion.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6. -- Three favorites, two second choices, and an outsider in the betting were the winners at Ascot to-day. There was a big crowd in attendance, the day being designated "Ladies' Day." E. Walsh carried off the jockey honors, winning two races, finishing second in one, and third in another. Summary:

The St. Nicholas Society of New York, in celebrating its annual dinner last night at Delmonico's, made it rather a celebration in honor of their fellow-member President Roosevelt. George G. De Witt, President of the society, presided behind the old weather vane of the New Amsterdam City Hall.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- The Transcript to-night, referring to the investigation of the authenticity of the Art Museum's new Velasquez, says:...

Official figures of the vote at the last election in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx were given out yesterday by the Board of County Canvassers. Notwithstanding the large number of split ballots cast, out of a total of 369,495 ballots for all candidates, only 62 were defective, 1,112 blank, and 2,920 Void because of being returned by voters who had mismarked them but had not asked for new ballots.
