So far has the work of construction of the Rapid Transit tunnel under the Harlem River advanced that workmen have begun laying the rails for the use of trains. Both tunnels are practically completed, and construction crews pass freely under the river while at their work of cleaning and making the tunnel ready for use.

Never in the history of the city's charitable institutions have there been so many unemployed men to care for as at present, and some surprising figures compiled by the authorities at Bellevue Hospital and at the Municipal Lodging House indicate an appalling situation for the Winter.

The suspension of Joseph Connah was announced on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Mr. Connah was what is known as a floor broker, doing business for other firms on the two-dollar commission basis. He had desk room at the office of H. Knickerbocker Co., at 25 Broad Street.

Scott Hudson of Lexington, Ky., acting as the spokesman of a committee of the Professional Drivers' Association of America, made the rather sensational statement to the members of the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association at their annual meeting at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday, that every large stable containing stake horses finished the season of 1904 at a loss.

I cannot, in the interest of scientific accuracy, let pass unchallenged the conclusions displayed in your columns regarding the time in which the Subway tunnel may be expected to become quite filled with debris and dust.
BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- In the Reichstag to-day Herr Liebermann von Sonnenberg (Conservative) expressed regret at the enthusiasm of the Germans for Japan. He said race consciousness should be awakened.

Supported by her son and a maid, and walking as if she was very weak, Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick suddenly left the Holland House at 10:10 o'clock last night and entered a closed carriage in waiting before the Fifth Avenue entrance. With her two companions silo Was taken at a rapid pace to the Hew Amsterdam Hotel, at Twenty-first Street and Fourth Avenue, where she now occupies a suite of rooms on the fifth floor.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Summonses were issued to-day to the purchasers of the turbine boat Caroline, which was recently taken to Russia by Mr. Burke Roche.

If you told any man in Engine Company No. 76 that Joe, the big buckskin horse that has pulled on the nigh side of the engine for several months, didn't lose his life yesterday just because of his noble and successful effort to save three children from death, you would soon have to apologize or fight.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 6. -- Unless Secretary Iri Reynolds of the Wade Park Banking Company wants to stand in contempt of the United States Court he can remain silent no longer with regard to the exact nature of the $5,000,000 worth of securities which it is said the bank got from Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The Admiralty will issue next Saturday for publication on Monday a statement of its new scheme for the distribution of the vessels of the British Navy.

To-morrow is the fiftieth anniversary of the promulgation by Pope Plus IX, of the dogma of the Immaculate Conception of the Blessed Virgin Mary. Special preparations have been made for the anniversary in practically every Catholic church in the country. The celebration has a local interest in that the feast of the Immaculate Conception is the patronal feast of the Catholic Church in the United States.

The clergy of Trinity Church announced yesterday that under no circumstances will divorced persons be married by any of the clergy of that Episcopal parish, nor will such marriages be permitted either in the church at Wall Street and Broadway or in any one of the parish's eight chapels. The announcement was as follows:

The President's message leaves the tariff revision agitation where it was before the message was written. The only allusion to the matter is in the very general terms employed in the opening passage of the message.

The mosaic and encaustic tile layers, the chief factor in holding up work in building since the lock-out by the Building Trades Employers' Association, broke away yesterday and stampeded back to work unconditionally on the terms of the employers. The Tile Layers' Union, together with the Plasterers' Society, which is still out, succeeded in effectively holding back the completion of hundreds of buildings.

It is expected that the investigations by the Federal Commission into the requirements which it is necessary shall be imposed upon excursion steamers in the matters of construction and equipment will lead to the passage by Congress during the short session of a more stringent law than has hitherto been enacted.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- "We may see in this message the words of Police Constable Roosevelt of the International Police," says The Daily Chronicle in an editorial article this morning, the sentence concentrating the aspect of the message of the President of the United States which most forcibly presents itself to that journal.
The H.E. Hayes Company has sold for George W. Stetson to an investor 2,189, 2,191, and 2,193 Broadway, between Seventy-seventh and Seventy-eighth Streets, five-story flats on plot 60.6 by 100.

" There are laws regulating about everything except advertising in the street of a city, and that runs wild," was the keynote of the architects' side of "The abuses and restriction of public advertising," the subject considered at the December dinner of the Architectural League of New York last evening.

ST. PETERSBURG, Wednesday, Dec. 7. -- Although the War Office and the Admiralty are still without direct news from Port Arthur, confidence in the ability of the fortress to hold out continues to be expressed.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 6. -- Upon the statement of Simon Buttner of Schenectady, who is under arrest here charged with grand larceny, Chief of Police Wright asserts that he has evidence of a gigantic swindle involving hundreds of thousands of dollars.

After displaying considerable strength nearly all day, the market suffered a bad break in the last hour yesterday. Active stocks sold off two points and thereabouts, and though there was a slight recovery just before the close the last prices were very nearly the lowest for the day. The Street was inclined to assign a number of causes for the break.

Fire Marshal Beers of Brooklyn was notified last night of an attempt to burn a three-story frame tenement house at 61 Whipple Street, Williamsburg. Rags saturated with kerosene had been placed under the cellar stairs and a match applied, and at the same time a large quantity of oil had been poured over the cellar stairs and about the walls.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Francis F. Oldham, representing the office of the Controller of the Currency in the Chadwick case, returned to Washington to-night from New York. Mr. Oldham will make a report to Controller Ridgly to-morrow.

-- One can safely pretend to wonder -- if one carefully conceals the fact that the wonder is not quite all pretense -- why it is that the authorities of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts are so much disturbed by the rumor that a picture for which, believing it to be the work of VELASQUEZ, they recently paid something less than $51,000, was really painted by another man, name unknown.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- A large batch of nominations were sent to the Senate by the President to-day, many of them recess appointments, which included four Cabinet positions as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Gov. Pennypacker enlivened the proceedings of the Senate to-day in a manner both quaint and original. The occasion was the swearing in of the two new Senators, ex-Attorney General Knox, who fills the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Quay, and ex-Gov. Murray Crane, who succeeds the late Senator Hoar.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6. -- A dispatch from Vladivostok says that a steamer which has just arrived there from Shanghai reports that the Japanese armored cruiser Azuma has been blown up and sunk by a mine.

Mr. ROOSEVELT, in a very brief and not entirely clear passage of his message -- which seems to have suffered somewhat from the hands of the transcriber -- calls the attention of Congress "especially" to some very important principles connected with the currency. He says:

One lap between the leaders and the last trailers, after two days of riding, the international six days' team bicycle race in Madison Square Garden progressed in the most prosaic possible manner last night and early this morning. The very closeness of the contest to date has shut out many of the features that made the races of other years popular with the public.

The new disposition of British men-of-war to be announced by the orders of the Admiralty, as our cable dispatches have informed us, comprises a "unique compliment" to this country by leaving out altogether the western coast of the North Atlantic and the eastern coast of the North Pacific, in other words, the coasts of the United States, from the "stations" of the British Navy.
The Treasury of the United States is in some measure in the happy condition of a nation without annals. Mr. SHAW in his annual report finds little of special interest to dwell upon.

The term of railroad mortgage bonds is, on the average, about fifty years. Between the date of issue and the date of redemption of such a railroad bond twelve Presidential elections would take place, twelve Administrations would come and go, and conceivably the Inter-State Commerce Commission might be twelve times reconstituted by new appointments all around.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- That there should be Federal supervision of trust companies is suggested by Secretary of the Treasury Shaw in his annual report to Congress. In support of his view Mr. Shaw points to the relatively large growth of such institutions than of National banks, and to the corresponding menace they may become unless conservatively managed.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Although the British Government departments concerned with Central Asia affect to disbelieve the reports of large movements of Russian troops on the Afghan border, those in close touch with the Ameer's kingdom are inclined to credit the news.

After the unexpectedly successful run of "David Garrick," Sir Charles Wyndham changed the bill last night at the Lyceum, putting on "Mrs. Gorringe's Necklace," a comedy-melodrama, as one may call it, by Hubert Henry Davies, the young playwright in whose "Cousin Kate" Miss Ethel Barrymore was so popular here last year.

It Was estimated yesterday by the Customs officials here that $2,000,000 has been saved to the Government in refunds by its victory over the importers of sugar in the decision in the "sugar test case," handed down by the United States Supreme Court on Monday. The decision is considered the most important in Customs law since that upholding the constitutionality of the Dingley act.

Police Commissioner McAdoo, through his Secretary, William Howell, announced yesterday afternoon that Inspector Richard Walsh had been transferred from the Fourth Inspection District, which includes the "Tenderloin," to the Third Inspection District, which takes in the upper east side, and that Inspector William W. McLaughlin would go from the Third District to the Fourth. Secretary Howell said when he made the announcement:

Consecration services were held yesterday morning in the chapel of the Incarnation, 240 East Thirty-first Street, which with the ground is the gift of Edward Severin Clark, who built it as a memorial to his father, Alfred Corning Clark. It represents an investment of more than $100,000.
The clergy of Trinity have taken a rather startling step in announcing their intention not to remarry any divorced person, not even any innocent party divorced for the cause of adultery.

"Too much gas never did anybody any good," was the comment of Governor-Chairman Odell last evening on the statement of Charles F. Murphy, the Tammany leader, yesterday, that Mayor McClellan would be helped rather than hurt by the gas question. Referring to the issue likely to be raised in the next municipal campaign by reason of the gas contracts made by Commissioner Oakley, Mr. Murphy said:

With a contract to carry 50,000 tons of the 250,000 annual foreign tonnage of the International Harvester Company of America, the greatest manufacturer of agricultural implements in the world, the Street Steamship Company has been incorporated in New Jersey with $240,000 capital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations for Postmasters in New York: Frederick B. Powell, Amityville; Charles J. Sweet, Black River; Annie Larrabee, Oyster Bay; George A. McKinnon, Sidney; James W. Welch, Hamilton. He also nominated Lieut. Col. Clinton B. Sears, Corps of Engineers, for member of the Mississippi River Commission.

Ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant has bought the Libbey Castle at the northerly end of Washington Heights and will make it his residence. Besides the famous old mansion, ex-Mayor Grant's purchase includes a large plot, about 115 lots, measuring 350 by 750 feet, running through from Broadway to Fort Washington Avenue, and a smaller plot, directly opposite the Castle, running through from Fort Washington Avenue to the Boulevard Lafayette.

Wall Street and the stock market had a lively experience yesterday. Under the lead of Amalgamated Copper the stock market broke and stocks dropped violently. The cause of it all -- on this the Street seemed agreed -- was the campaign conducted by Thomas W. Lawson, author, broker, and manipulator.

Inquiry at the various lodging houses, charitable and semi-charitable institutions yesterday confirmed the statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES that the army of unemployed in the city was greater than ever known. So far no organized plan has been set on foot to relieve the destitution, and the various institutions are doing the best they can with the means at their command.
I have read with interest your comments on the recommendation of the President that the Inter-State Commerce Commission be clothed with increased powers.

Possibly the estimate from Tokio that the Russians have already lost 3,000 men in trying to retake "203-Meter Hill" is excessive, as St. Petersburg declares that it is. But evidently that number of men, even out of a garrison of 20,000 or less, would not be an extravagant price for the possession of the hill.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- The hearing of the question of the railroads placing in eperation a new "uniform bill of lading," against which thousands of shippers are complaining, has been continued until Thursday, Dec. 15, at Washington, by the members of the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association had a busy day at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday, but the proceedings were not of so important or interesting a character as the seemingly successful efforts of the Professional Drivers' Association of America to change the rules of the entry to stake events and to limit the field of starters in a race.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The police arrested this afternoon, on application of E.M. Block, a pawnbroker of this city. President Richard Emory, Cashier Paul Warner, and Assistant Cashier William P. Luedeke of the suspended German Bank on a charge of grand larceny in the second degree.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7, -- Lord of the Valley, which was run up to $1,200 after his race and sold to W.M. Walker, and Extol were the only winning favorites to-day. Judge Himes's defeat in the handicap was a blow to the talent Dusky was run up to $900 and sold to W.M. Walker, Bishop Poole was run up to $800 and bought by R.E Watkins. The weather was clear and the track lumpy. Summary:

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 8. -- According to a St. Petersburg dispatch to The Daily Mail the Emperor yesterday decreed the dispatch of a third squadron to the Far East, comprising the battleships Paul I. and Slava, which will be completed as speedily as possible; five older battleships, five cruisers, and forty torpedo boat destroyers.

As she lay ill in her apartment at the Hotel Breslin, to which she went yesterday afternoon, and while seven Federal officials stood grouped around her bed, Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick was arrested last night by United States Marshal William Henkel on a warrant issued at the instigation of the authorities in Cleveland.

Hugh McLaughlin, ex-Register of Kings County, and for many years the "boss" of the Brooklyn Democracy, known by his followers as the "Sage of Willoughby Street," died shortly after eleven o'clock last night at his home, 163 Remsen Street. The cause of his death, after a superficial examination, was said to be heart disease.

What came near being a serious ending of a wrestling bout occurred last night during the contests for the championships in the annual event of the Church Athletic League in St. Bartholomew's Gymnasium, 209 East Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Department of Justice has begun proceedings against the Tobacco Trust through the appointment of A.E. Garner, a lawyer of Springfield, Tenn., as a special Assistant Attorney General to investigate the tobacco trade.

-- Among the few matters of human interest upon which the President failed to touch in his message was not that of the proper method of dealing with crime "that takes the shape of brutality and cruelty against the weak," and, with the self-confidence which is among his admirable characteristics, he declared that these criminals "need a special form of punishment."

MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 7. -- The Vermont House of Representatives this afternoon refused to pass to a third reading a bill to commute to life imprisonment the sentence imposed upon Mrs. Mary M. Rogers, who was convicted of murdering her husband and sentenced to be hanged. The vote was 91 in favor of the bill and 139 against.

After a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company yesterday it was announced that Contractor John B. McDonald had tendered his resignation from the directorate both of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company, and that it had been unanimously accepted. James H. Hyde, Vice President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, was elected a Director of both corporations to fill the vacancies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- President Roosevelt now has under consideration the application made on behalf of Mrs. Phyllis Dodge for remission of the forfeiture and the restoration to her of the jewels aggregating in value $63,927 brought to this country by her about five years ago and seized and confiscated by the customs officers at New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Secretary Hitchcock of the Department of the Interior to-day made public his report for the fiscal year ended June 30 last. The report deals at length with the pension system. It says that at the end of the year the total number of pensioners on the rolls was 994,762, a net loss of 1,783.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 7. -- It was with a great sigh of relief that United States District Attorney Sullivan learned of Mrs. Chadwick's arrest.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- Thomas W. Lawson of Boston has been made defendant in legal proceedings brought by George Wharton Pepper of this city, who, acting as receiver of the Bay State Gas Company, has been investigating the affairs of that corporation.
Readers of the Hearst newspapers find the message in many things an old acquaintance. Many of the ideas put forward by the President have been pressed in these papers for years.

According to information obtained in Wall Street yesterday, representatives of one of the leading railroad systems in the country sent a protest to President Roosevelt when they learned what his message would contain on the subject of the increase of the powers of the Inter-State Commerce Commission.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7. -- A personal encounter was narrowly averted to-day between United States Senator McLaurin of Mississippi and Judge Enochs, who was presiding in a murder trial at Brandon, Miss.
William A. White Sons have sold for Harry M. Austin the southeast corner of Broadway and Sixty-seventh Street a plot 70 by 68, with old buildings. The buyer will improve the property.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7, -- The Board of Appeals of the American Trotting Association to-day began hearing evidence in a long list of cases. Only verbal testimony was heard, all affidavits and written statements being placed on file. These affidavits will be thoroughly examined before decisions are made.

VIENNA, Dec. 7. -- The Government is about to send a squadron from Pola to Turkish waters to support a demand the Austrian Ambassador presented to the Porte for the dismissal and punishment within three days of the officials responsible for the recent forcible detention of Austrian mails at Scutari.
TOKIO, Dec. 8. -- The commander of the naval battery on Two Hundred and Three Meter Hill at Port Arthur, reporting at 2:30 P.M. to-day, says:

The flags on the Public buildings in Brooklyn were ordered at half-mast yesterday by Borough President Littleton because of the death of Hugh McLaughlin late on Wednesday night. The McLaughlin home, at 163 Remsen Street, was the Mecca of men who hold high places in the borough, many of whom owed their advancement in life to Mr. McLaughlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- At the night session of the convention of the Civil Service Reform League President Gilman delivered his annual address. An address prepared by Carl Schurz, who was unable to be present because of an attack of bronchitis, was read, and the annual report of the council was made by Charles J. Bonaparte of Baltimore.

The Charles Bathgate Beck property in the Bronx, a tract of nearly 400 lots in the section bounded by One Hundred and seventieth Street, Prospect Avenue, Boston load, One Hundred and Seventy-third Street, and Bryant Street, has been bought by the Central Realty Bond and Trust Company for $1,200,000. J. Clarence Davies was the broker in the deal.

The President's remarks about the army in his message will command the concurrence of all students of the subject. The President is quite in the right in taking credit to himself, and necessarily to Secretary ROOT, for reducing the army to the statutory minimum. To demand a further reduction would have been to make a demand that was not sane or safe.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8. -- The local police have arrested ten men in this city in connection with the attempted bank robbery at Mount Airy, Md., last night. Four of the prisoners were located by Police Captain Gittings in a house on East Monument Street, early in the afternoon. The others were arrested later in the day in the northeastern section of the city.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8. -- Mrs. S.M. York of this city, who says that she is a sister of Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick, and whom Mrs. Chadwick declares is not her sister, made a statement to-day. She said:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- Manning C. Palmer, President of the American Exchange National Bank, which is in the hands of Receiver J.W. Schofield, representing the Controller of the Currency, was placed under arrest at his home this evening by Federal officers representing the Federal Court at Utica. He was taken to Utica to-night to appear before Judge Ray to-morrow morning.

The game of local politics will seem emptier and less interesting without "BOSS" MCLAUGHLIN. He wielded a good deal of power in his day, and his day was a long one. The Kings County delegation, which was almost uniformly in his hands, was a force to be reckoned with.

H. Hier Davies, who at the time of the last international yacht races was the manager of the Lipton tea offices in this city, and who looked after the guests on board the Lipton steam yacht Erin, has retained E.B. Whitney as counsel in a suit in this city against Sir Thomas for unpaid expenses and for defamation of character. For his services Mr. Davies wants $5,000.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 8. -- Rev. Charles A. Eaton, the pastor of the Euclid Avenue Baptist Church of Cleveland of which John Rockefeller is the leading member, is the man who made it possible for Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick to become acquainted with Herbert B. Newton, the banker, of Brookline, Mass.

Seldom has the audience of the Boston Symphony Orchestra been so stirred as last evening at the second evening concert of the season. The third symphony of Brahms was the first incitement to the unwonted enthusiasm -- music of supreme beauty marvelously played, with the fresh and buoyant spirit, the poetry and romantic mood reproduced as by an immediate contact with the composer's purpose.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association entered upon the third and what proved to be the last day of the annual meeting at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday, and after an executive session lasting at least five hours a final adjournment was taken until next May. It was stated that a total of 160 cases were on the docket, but decisions were rendered in only a small proportion of that number.

Almost daily children are run over and killed or badly maimed. Between trucks, delivery wagons, electric cars, automobiles, ambulances, and fire apparatus, a New York street is scarcely safer as a playground for infants than a railroad terminal. Adults adapt themselves to changing conditions.

It has not often happened that two great armies have gone into Winter quarters under the conditions which now obtain in the neighborhood of Mukden. For the Russian and Japanese armies are technically "in contact" all along the lines, and are likely to remain so until the weather allows of the resumption of active operations.
At the December meeting of the Union League Club last night the Committee on Political Reform introduced the following resolution which was passed unanimously:

The President in effect says that the States should be left to deal with the problems arising in the conflicts of labor and capital, quite free from Federal interference. Of course he recognizes that a duty would be created if the authority of the Federal courts were defied, the transit of the mails interrupted or inter-State commerce interfered with.

In summing up in the case of Policeman Arthur J. Mallon of the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station, on trial before Recorder Goff for killing Robert Brennan, a waiter, Assistant District Attorney Train yesterday charged the police with hampering the prosecution and failing to get witnesses against Mallon because he was a policeman.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 8. -- Yorkshire Lad, which won the second race by a head in a drive, was the only successful favorite to-day. While at the post for the first race Nervator bolted into the inside fence, unseated Jockey Nicol, and ran a mile and a quarter before stopping. Nicol was only slightly injured, and the horse escaped unhurt. Summary:

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- George H. Ketcham of Toledo, Ohio, was found not guilty of establishing a fraudulent record (1:59 3/4) for his trotting stallion Cresceus at the Wichita, Kan., track, on Oct. 19, 1903, after a hearing of the case before the Board of Appeals of the American Trotting Association here to-night.

PARIS, Dec. 8. -- In the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon the Government escaped defeat by two votes, 276 to 274, on a resolution inviting the Government to refer to the Superior Council of Judges -- the cases of those magistrates who have been guilty of making secret investigations.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 8. -- The Grand Jury which was in session at Elyria, Lorain County, investigating the Chadwick case to-day, adjourned until Saturday, after voting to indict the woman on a charge of obtaining money under false pretences.

What has been popularly and somewhat inaccurately termed the "Lawson panic" culminated yesterday morning when Amalgamated Copper, against which the guns of the queer Boston financier have been directed for three days past, went down with a rush from the opening price of 68@67 and hit 58 1/2 just before noon.

The jury which is to try Nan Patterson was completed yesterday afternoon. Assistant District Attorney Rand opened his case, and to-day at noon the taking of testimony will be commenced for the second time. Before the jury was completed, and when perhaps half a dozen talesmen had been examined, Mr. Rand asked Justice Davis to make a special investigation as to the fitness of John D. Benedict, Juror No. 11.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8. -- The regular meeting of the Board of Trustees of the University was held this afternoon, and it was announced afterward that Prof. Charles A. Young had resigned as Professor of Astronomy, to take effect next June. Mr. Young has been professor in Princeton since 1877, and he will be retired with the title of Emeritus.

There was a panic in prices upon the Stock Exchange yesterday, but it lacked all the other characteristics of panics which make them dreadful. Countless pyramids crumbled, and many who were making profits in their minds are now realizing losses in their pockets. But it is strictly their affair.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The President is continuing his efforts to gain from consultation with Senators and Members of Congress a basis for deciding what shall be done with the tariff if any action is to be taken in the near future.
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Money was in quiet demand in the market to-day and supplies were plentiful.

When eight hours of frantic search had failed to reveal a bondsman willing to put up $30,000 for Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick, she was locked up in the Tombs at 9:02 o'clock last night. She had been arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields early in the day, and her bail fixed at $15,000. Under the law it is necessary that the bondsman qualify for twice that amount.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- George H. Earle, Jr., of this city, who has been negotiating for the purchase of the stock of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company for a price said to be $52,000,000, to-day made a reply to a statement by C.S. Mellen, President of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, in which the latter denied that his company had had any negotiations for the purchase of the Lehigh Navigation Company.

A petition in bankruptcy was filed yesterday against Thomas N. McCauley, formerly President of the International Mercantile Agency at 346 Broadway, which failed in August last, and who disappeared in September and has not since been heard of, by James Robinson of Montreal, a creditor, for $15,000, on two notes which were indorsed by Mr. McCauley.

LONDON, FRIDAY, Dec. 9. -- The Daily Telegraph's correspondent before Port Arthur telegraphs that all the Russian battleships and cruisers, together with the gunboats Giliak and Fusadneck, have been sunk or destroyed, and that only the torpedo-boat destroyers remain intact.

Is District Attorney JEROME cheated of his triumph by the conviction of CANFIELD on his own confession? Mr. JEROME said, after the constitutionality of the law regarding the testimony of witnesses against common gamblers was affirmed, that he would put CANFIELD in jail. CANFIELD pleads guilty and gets off with a fine of $1,000. Persons who take the narrow and short view might say that the gambler had baffled the District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- William Barret Ridgely, Controller of the Currency, in his annual report recommends that power to engage in foreign and international banking business be given to National banks of large capital. He says:

Electric light charges against the city will be reduced approximately 40 per cent. by the establishment of a competing company to charge the city $90 per arc light, if a strong group of capitalists are able to carry through plans which they now have under way. This would mean a reduction of $750,000 a year in this item of the city's expenses.

A surface examination of the figures of the Presidential vote in Manhattan and the Bronx, now officially declared, might lead to erroneous conclusions. Mr. ROOSEVELT received 155,055 votes, against 153,033 for Mr. McKINLEY in 1900, a Republican gain of 2,022. Judge PARKER received 189,688 votes, compared with 181,799 cast for Mr. BRYAN in 1900, a Democratic gain of 7,887.

THE subject of the third volume in the series called "The American Nation," edited by Prof. Albert Bushnell Hart, is "Spain in America." It is the work of Prof. E.G. Bourne of Yale, probably the first authority in the country on this subject.

Chairman Dunn and Commissioner Dickey of the State Railroad Commission yesterday heard the petition of the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad Company for permission to mortgage its property and franchises for $10,000,000. This, it was stated, would be a consolidated second mortgage, bearing 4 per cent. interest and payable Jan. 1, 1955, to be financed by the Mercantile Trust Company.

A volume which will appear shortly from the press of E.P. Dutton Co. entitled "The Monk of Llanthony" is written by the Baroness de Bertouch. The contents, which give a clue to the scope of the volume, are: "A Sower Went out to Sow," "A Little Child Shall Lead Them," "And the Child Grew," "Feed My Sheep," "What Manner of Man Is This?"

This is the season for the exhibition of finely bound books, rare old editions, and incunabula generally. Some beautiful specimens have been on exhibition at the rooms of Mr. Ernest Dressel North, 18 East Twenty-third Street, to-day being the last of the six days' show. Lovers of first editions have found many treasures there, some in the original covers, now faded and rubbed, but the real old leather, and many more beautifully rebound.

The season's output of art books includes several items in which utility and industry are combined with artistic expression. There have just come to hand a rug book, one on furniture, another on interior decoration, and two separate works on lace. "The Oriental Rug," by Marry Churchill Ripley, (New York: Frederick A. Stokes Company; $3,) although not as elaborate as some of its predecessors dealing with the same subject.

TENNYSON'S "DEATH OF THE OLD YEAR." -- My attention has been called by Mr. R.C. Heron Maxwell to the following variant of Tennyson's "Death of the Old Year," which he recently came across in an old volume of The World of Fashion, (January-December, 1633):
In last Saturday's issue is printed, under the above caption, a letter from Mr. John Dean as to the origin of that phrase.

The latest additions to the Country Handbook Series, which John Lane is issuing, are "The Kennel Handbook," by G.F. Davies, and "The Gun Room," by Alexander Innes Shand. The former tells of the origin of the domesticated dog, and bow different species should be cared for. The volume is illustrated with photographs of notable animals.

WERE it not for the fact that Miss Kellor's book has what may be termed a "happy ending" in which are given suggestions for the correction of the evils she has pointed out, those interested in the securing of help from employment agencies might regret having read it, on the plea that where ignorance is comparative bliss it would be folly to be wise.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- Acting by day as superintendent in the printing department of a local manufacturing company and at night the part of a charitable highwayman is said to have been the career of Edward B. Clark, now under arrest. According to his confession, he has played the varied role for a year. He has admitted being implicated m several hold-ups which have puzzled the police.

After seven years of trying to make life easier for the sailor man ashore, one year being spent as manager of the sailor's boarding house conducted under the direction of the Protestant Episcopal Mission at 52 Market Street, Frank Hughes, known to all tars in this port, has resigned. After Tuesday next Mr. Hughes will seek other fields of endeavor.

" The Bertrams," by Anthony Trollope, and "The Three Clerks," by the same author, are being added to John Lane's New Pocket Library Series under the editorship of Algar Thorold. In writing of "The Bertrams" the editor says:

The present number of THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW, being given over to holiday books, suggests the inquiry: What, specifically and by way of distinction, is a holiday book? The publishers in their way, and the reviewers in theirs, answer it according to their several appreciations and from their several points of view.

In the days when the Ohio country was a wilderness tradition tells of a singular man who wandered through it everywhere planting fruit trees. The man was known as Johnny Applessed, and, at one time at least, was touched in hid head. The Rev. Dr. Hillis, in making this eccentric the hero of a novel, has, of course, recast the tradition to fit the exigencies of his religious romance.

Daniel J. O'Reilly, of counsel for Nan Patterson, on trial for the murder of Caesar Young, yesterday was called to the stand by Assistant District Attorney Rand and asked if he knew J. Morgan Smith, the missing brother-in-law of the defendant. Mr. O'Reilly also was asked if he knew Mrs. Smith, Miss Patterson's sister, and J. Randolph Patterson, her father.

That the fast French liner La Lorraine failed to arrive yesterday, the first time in months that this vessel has not docked on Friday, is a good indication of the stormy weather at sea. The liner was not reported from any of the observation points along the coast up to a late hour last night. The Cunarder Lucania, which sometimes makes port on Friday, also failed to arrive.
That the gas contracts made by Commissioner Oakley are to become an important political issue was indicated in a statement issued last evening by R. Fulton Cutting, President of the Citizens' Union.

LONDON, Dec. 9, 1904. -- The Macmillan Company will publish next week a book on Shakespearian tragedy by Prof. Brodley of Oxford University, which submits to close analysis "Hamlet," "Othello," "King Lear," and "Macbeth" in an endeavor to show that they have common form of structure up to a certain point.
BOSTON, Dec. 9. -- Orders were received at the Charlestown Navy Yard to-day to have the battleships Maine and Missouri, now under repair there, ready for sailing at the earliest possible date.

NEW ROCHELLE, Dec. 9. -- A choir rehearsal which was being held in the parish house of Trinity Episcopal Church under the direction of the rector, the Rev. Charles F. Canedy, ended suddenly this evening in a fire drill. While the rehearsal was on, one of the choir boys stepped into an adjoining chapel and found, the large curtains at the doorway ablaze.

The Western Union Telegraph Company has bought from Daniel Lord, 16 Dey Street, a five-story building on lot 25 by 77.3. This property adjoins the company's other holdings which now extend a distance of 234 feet from the Broadway corner. The adjoining parcel, 14 Dey Street, 25 by 75, was bought last year from Kalman Haas, for $120,000.

In the literary partition of England, wherein the pilgrim may discover tracts definitely and indissolubly dedicated to Dickens, to Tennyson, to Ingoldsby, and many another, no province has been so thoroughly annexed or so effectively occupied as that associated with the Wessex novels written by Mr. Thomas Hardy.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- Receivers were appointed by Judge Davis in Common Pleas Court to-day for the Neafie Levy Ship and Engine Building Company of this city on application of the S.B. Vrooman Company, Limited, of this city, which concern furnished lumber to the company. Tim receivers are John Grange, a retired banker, and Sommers N. Smith, Vice President and General Manager of the Neafie Levy Company.

The existence of "unjust conditions" due to the tariff and affecting injuriously the "condition of manufactures" is practically admitted by the resolution of the Union League Club adopted on Thursday evening. If there was any doubt of the existence of such conditions the League is the last organization to "earnestly request Congress to investigate the question."

MAJOR L.L. Seaman, author of "From Tokio Through Manchuria with the Japanese," which bears the imprint of D. Appleton Co., has returned to this city after having had an interview with President Roosevelt in Washington, concerning feeding troops in war time.
HEADQUARTERS OF THE JAPANESE THIRD ARMY, BEFORE PORT ARTHUR, Nov. 28, (Via Tien-Tsin, Dec. 9.) -- The general assault on Port Arthur, which began at noon Nov. 26, is still in progress.

Heinrich Jasmirgott, a Babenberger Duke, in 1142 built himself a burg, or castle, where Vienna now stands. Within the walls of his castle he founded a little church and named it St. Stephan. In 1147 the church was consecrated. St. Stephan's has been one of the most famous cathedrals, and is the centre of ancient and modern Vienna.

Joseph S. Ames, Director of the Physical Laboratory in the Johns Hopkins University, is the author of a "Text Book of General Physics" for high schools and colleges. (American Book Company.) It was begun as a revision of his "Theory of Physics," but has developed into a wholly new book. It is divided into the following sections: Mechanics and properties of matter, heat, vibrations and waves, sound, light, magnetism, and electricity.

Sept. 9 last was the fourteenth anniversary of the death of Dr. Liddon. In 1890 John Octavius Johnston, M.A., was selected to write a life of the Canon of St. Paul's Cathedral, and at the time everything seemed to point to the fact that he would soon have plenty of spare moments to start it.

The wit of the people, their quaint environment, and the historic sites and scenes of the larger landscape have afforded the literary inspiration for many travelers in Ireland, and books on this subject are numerous. Just now we have a two-volume well-illustrated work called "Romantic Ireland."

For the first time this season a "double bill" was given at the Metropolitan Opera House, in which the sharpest contrast was presented that Italian opera can afford, the contrast between Donizetti's "Don Pasquale" and Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana," an exemplification of the extreme to which the composers of Italy have gone in the last half century or so.

Cross was dismissed from the department. This reduction, according to the opinion, may be made provided the Board of Aldermen and the Board of Estimate and Apportionment refuse Mr. McAdoo the seventeenth Inspector.

Diane Lahautiere, by Capt. Robert Channing, United States Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- At the final session of the National Civil Service Reform League to-day President Roosevelt was severely criticised for the exemptions in the service through executive order made by him during the past three years. Nelson S. Spencer, ex-member of the Municipal Civil Service Commission of New York City, made a direct attack on the course pursued by the President, which was loudly applauded by many of the civil service reformers present.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 10. -- The Daily Telegraph's Tien-Tsin correspondent reports that Gen. Oku, after a three days' artillery engagement last Sunday, drove the Russians out of the small lofty Island of Gushan, in the river.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- In the Reichstag to-day Herr von Vollmar, Socialist, at the conclusion of a long speech sharply arraigning Chancellor von Bulow for his alleged overfriendly attitude toward Russia, discussed Emperor William's telegrams, referring specifically to the one sent to President Roosevelt.

When James Smith, twenty years old, who said he lived at 268 West Carlisle Street, New Haven, was arraigned before Magistrate Crane, in the Harlem Court, yesterday on the charge of attempting suicide, he said that he had been discouraged, out of work, and penniless, and if released would be good.

The "Constables' Guide" (Albany: Matthew Bender,) is a small book of 100 pages compiled by Melvin T. Bender and Harold J. Hinman of the Albany bar, containing in brief paragraphs taken from the General Sessions Laws, the Codes of Civil and Criminal Procedure, digests of decisions, all the points likely to affect a constable nicely arranged under appropriate headings and properly indexed and credited.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Dec. 9. -- The torpedo boats built at the Ramsay shipyard in this city by Lewis Nixon, for the Russian Government, will leave here tomorrow. Nine of them have been taken apart and loaded on a barge, to be towed to New York and shipped as merchandise on a trans-Atlantic liner.

This afternoon the last "5 o'clock tea" will be held at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, when Mrs. John Jacob Astor and other ladies will preside at the tables. W.A. Dutt, author of "Highways and Byways in East Anglia," and "The Norfolk Broads," has written another book entitled, "The King's Homeland," which is being issued by the Macmillan Company. H. Rider Haggard has written an introduction to the volume, which deals with Sandringham and North West Norfolk.

" War Ships" is a textbook on the construction, protection, stability, turning, , of war vessels. (Longmans; $3.) Edward L. Attwood, the author, is a lecturer in naval architecture at the Royal Naval College, Greenwich, and author of a textbook on theoretical naval architecture.

WITH the season's usual number of works on subjects pertaining to the fine arts, such as biographies of painters and sculptors, expositions of their style, descriptions of their galleries, and critical examination of their art, we have this year a number of publications which, while frankly of the holiday order, emphasize as never before the tendency on the part of publishers to give permanency and stability to what otherwise would be merely ephemerally beautiful.

Granting the faintest suspicion that the art of impressing characters on paper was of Eastern origin, lithography is entirely and exclusively Western. The discovery of lithography by Alois Senefelder in 1796 was purely accidental. Where Senefelder showed his genius was in following up his discovery.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 9. -- Shot through the body with the contents of both barrels of his gun while hunting to-day, Henry Mortimer Brooks of New York lies in Pittsborough at the point of death, and no hopes for his recovery are held out by the physicians who are striving to save his life.

" Chronique du Regne de Charles IX.'' is the only historical novel Prosper Merimee ever wrote. In the study of history he used to say only the anecdotes interested him; his favorite books were the chatty old memoirs of the sixteenth century. He had read so many of these and of the contemporary pamphlets that when he wanted to make extracts from his reading this book resulted.

Henry Holt Co. will publish next week a new psychology by James Rowland Argell cf the University of Chicago. The book, while of a solid and constructive scholarship, will be somewhat of a departure in the way of didactic psychology, the author's purpose being to supply a manual that shall be of special use to students of philosophy and makers of education.

In the new popular and unillustrated edition of "William Shakespeare, Poet, Dramatist, and Man" (New York: The Macmillan Company; Pp. 345; $1) the author, Hamilton Wright Mabie, has written another preface. He remarks that the appearance of this fourth edition of Shakespeare within two years may be attributed to the increasing interest in the greatest writer of our language.
COLLEGE stories are among the most popular in the books for girls, and "Janet's College Career" is one of the best of these. It is by Amy E. Blanchard, illustrated, (George W. Jacobs Co.; $1.25.)

" Old Fashioned's" letter concerning "The Eagle's Shadow" interested me greatly, but that of "E.H.B." filled me with joy, for it went straight to the root of a matter which has perplexed me of late not a little. About six weeks ago I read this book in question, and read it with enthusiasm. Here at last a certain type of American girl had gotten into a book.

Macgrane Coxe, referee in bankruptcy, who has had charge of the bankruptcy case of Daniel J. Sully Co., cotton brokers, of 43 Exchange Place, filed his report yesterday, making an allowance to the receivers of the firm, Henry W. Taft and David H. Miller, and to Boothby Baldwin, the attorneys for the receivers.

Last February, when the terrible blow was dealt at Port Arthur, many declared it was a "thunderbolt from a clear sky." One reads, however, in "The Russo-Japanese War," by Thomas Cowen, which will be issued by Longmans, Green Co., that the clouds had been gathering for fifty long years, and looked so threatening during the last ten that there should have been no surprise at all when the bolt came.

Frederick Starr has translated and compiled "Readings from Modern Mexican Authors," (Chicago: Open Court Company.) He has taken twenty-nine of the best-known among them, given a picture and a brief biographical sketch of each, and a translation of some selection from their writings. Mr. Starr has imposed upon himself several limitations; his authors are all still alive, save two who died since he began this book.

The "Scientific American Reference Book" is compiled from the answers to readers' questions made by that periodical. (Munn Co., $1.50.) The compilers, Albert A. Hopkins and A. Russell Bond, have added an index that makes the book invaluable. Its 500 pages are printed in rather small type and contain an astonishing amount of information.
You published a very characteristic letter in your columns last Saturday -- that signed "Old Fashioned," in regard to Mr. James Branch Cabell's "Eagle's Shadow."

We think we may say that each number of THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW is worth several times more than it costs judged by comparison with like publications in different forms. We may therefore be pardoned for calling attention to the number published this morning, since its forty-eight pages contain, in addition to the ample provision of current matter for the week, a very large amount of special matter adapted to the season.

The Eragny Press is issuing a number of rare books, which are limited to an edition of fifty in America. These books are designed by Lucien and Esther Pissarro, and printed by them at their own press, Hammersmith, England. The latest volume of this press is being issued by John Lane. It deals with the poems of S.T. Coleridge.

Although Bishop Potter, the President of the organization, failed to attend the benefit performance of the Actors' Church Alliance at the New York Theatre yesterday afternoon, those who were interested in the affair expressed themselves as entirely satisfied with the result. The Rev. Walter Bentley explained to inquirers that the Bishop had bought a box, but was obliged to be absent from the city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Walter C. Hamm, American Consul at Hull, England, reports profitable results from municipal control of public utilities.

It cannot be said that these papers of Miss McCracken's, written originally for The Outlook, are all the subject calls for. The writer is something of a sentimentalist, and one cannot avoid the suspicion that she is apt to see as "distinctly American" the things which are merely "nice."

It is somewhat curious that the Italians, surrounded as they have always been by the influences of Greek and Roman plastic art, should have taken up the art of medal-making rather late in the period of the Renaissance, and even then hardly with distinction. Even to-day the work of Italians makes a poor showing when compared with that done by the medal sculptors of Paris and Vienna, or even of Berlin and London.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE THIRD JAPANESE ARMY, BEFORE PORT ARTHUR, VIA FU-SAN, Dec. 9. -- On the night of Nov. 26 the Japanese established infantry trenches inside the parapets of the two Erh-Lung and the North Keek-Wan forts, but on the following day they were compelled to retire beyond the moats.

A collection of studies of the present situation in the Balkans and the responsibilities of the different countries of Europe on this account will be issued by E.P. Dutton Co. under the title "The Macedonian Question." The volume is the work of many writers, and is edited by Luigi Villari.

Mr. Gerald H. Knight's letter which was printed in the Sunday issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES is one of the most forcible arguments I have ever read against the abolishment of the canteen, and one which should appeal to every one outside of the fanatical religious people who have done incalculable harm by their well-meaning lunacy.

A young man there once was who was very fond of music. One Summer he sought the seclusion of his ancestral acres, and there, all unexpected he stumbled across a most unusually rich contralto, singing hymns and love songs in the forest. He held his breath and waited, and presently the lovely tones died into quivering silence.

PELHAM, Dec. 9. -- Valuable wedding presents belonging to Mrs. Ida Hill Lyon, wife of David Lyon of North Pelham, have been stolen twice within six months. Mrs. Lyon was formerly a teacher in the Chester Hill School at Mount Vernon. She is one of the officers of the Women's Christian Temperance Union.

A "New History of England" will be brought out in six volumes by G.P. Putnant's Sons. C.W.C. Oman, author of "The Art of War in the Middle Ages" and "A History of the Peninsular War," will be the general editor. The work will treat of the history of England from the earliest times down to the year 1815.

MANDELL CREIGHTON, who was Bishop of London, was born in Carlisle in 1843. The Bishop's wife tells the story of her husband's life, and prints the many letters addressed to him. Creighton's father was a decorator and joiner, and seems to have been a man of stern will and determination.

M. Linn Bruce, Lieutenant Governor-elect, was a guest at the annual dinner of the Wesleyan University Club at the Hotel Savoy last night and made a speech on "The Collegian in Politics." In the course of his remarks -- an appeal to college men to take active part in politics and a warning against working for political preferment -- he referred to the Republican victory, sayings:

In your to-day's very able editorial entitled "How It Would Work," and discussing the President's recommendation that the Inter-State Commerce Commission be given power to fix freight rates, you say that the pervading vice of the plan is "that he proposes to substitute the artificial law of the statute book for the natural law of the business world."

WHEN Messrs. L.C. Page Co. bought The Literary World, a few years ago, it had an admirable reputation and the respect of a small but select circle of readers, who accepted its judgment as always honest, almost always just, and invariably expressed with care.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 9. -- Capt. Clado's campaign in the Novoe Vremya against the Admiralty, and in favor of sending out the Black Sea fleet irrespective of treaty considerations, has had a sensational sequel. The Captain was arrested this evening.

Mrs. Herbert L. Pratt, daughter-in-law of the late Charles Pratt, the Standard Oil man, was injured yesterday in an accident in which her brougham was struck by a Second Avenue electric car at Twenty-third Street. The brougham was wrecked. Mrs. Pratt was thrown down inside the splintered vehicle with such force as to cut her side severely.

It is well agreed upon by writers of fiction and those who work in the deeper department of literature that a novel must tell a good story. It must contain within its pages an exciting narrative, otherwise the book will fail to be read. Hence the public in its search of something vivid, forgets the classic in the book store, and seeks the novel, which consequently sells so rapidly.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 9. -- The indictment upon which Sasoneff, the assassin of Minister of the Interior de Plehve, and Sikorifsky, his accomplice, will be tried on Dec. 13 is a formidable document, reciting the history of the assassination plot and details of the crime, and revealing for the first time interesting facts about the accused and confessions made by them.

L.P. Gratacap of the American Museum of Natural History has republished his "Geology of the City of New York," (Brentano's.) Though intended "for use in schools, institutes, and classes," the book will interest any one who cares at all about the great changes affecting the whole appearance of our city, changes that in barely a year's time often alter the character of an entire neighborhood.

NOBODY having read "Marse Chan" may accuse Mr. Thomas Nelson Page of negrophobia. Of late years he has written, however, more about the problem of the actual black man, and less of the sentimental and picturesque sides of the old-time darky now so nearly extinct.

President ROOSEVELT spoke briefly but with emphasis in regard to the question of corruption in National elections. He recommends to Congress the passage of a law that "should go as far as under the Constitution it is possible to go, and should include severe penalties against him who gives or receives a bribe intended to influence his act or opinion as an elector."

The market after a slight hesitation at the opening yesterday, turned strong and closed very near the top, with general advances of a point and more over the close of Thursday. This is exactly what conservative interests had predicted it would do when the break began on Wednesday morning.

A LAND that has given us equal to a third of its present population and has contributed so materially as Sweden to develop the greatness and the fame of the United States ought to be known here as it is described in this book, one of the series on "Our European Neighbors," which has done so much to make us acquainted with other countries that annually add half a million to our population.

Policeman Arthur J. Mallon of the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station was convicted yesterday of manslaughter in the first degree by a jury before Recorder Goff in General Sessions. The case has been under way for three days. The jury was out two hours.

The people of New York like their Subway very much. It grows in their favor, and their use of it will rapidly increase, we think, up to the limit of its capacity. Now that the mechanism, including the human part of it, has become as it were lubricated by wont and practice, the service is speedy and subject to few delays.

A LARGE part of the uncommonly interesting review we publish this week of a remarkable book, "The Story of My Struggles," by Prof. Arminius Vambery, the Hungarian Orientalist, is devoted to those chapters treating of his youth and young manhood, and especially his early experiences in Turkey and the East.

A decision of considerable importance to all importers, because it lays down some rules as to the nature of the evidence required in making a claim for abatement of duty on merchandise damaged or spoiled on the voyage of importation, was handed down yesterday by the Board of United States General Appraisers.

I happened to pick up yesterday a book which has been very little heralded, but which seems to me by far the best novel I have read this season, and I have read many of them -- which is. indeed, in my opinion, one of the best detective stories in the language -- "The Marathon Mystery," by Mr. Burton E. Stevenson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The first real struggle of the session began to-day in the room of the House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce. It is over the proposition to give the Inter-State Commerce Commission authority over railroad rates.

Patrolman Slattery of the West Thirtieth Street Station, one of the tallest policemen of the Broadway squad, made the mistake last night of trying to stop an automobile by catching hold of it, and got the run of his life for a block.

The edition of Dante Gabriel Rossetti's poems which, with an introduction by the poet's brother, William M. Rossetti, was brought out in London in 1886, is now being reproduced in this country, probably from the original plates, as an addition to the Gladstone Edition of Poets. (New York: Thomas Y. Crowell Co. Pp. 349. 75 cents.)

It is a little difficult to discover the specialty of the Specialist, who appears to have quite a wide range of discuses under treatment. He is a French physician of world-wide fame and Ebernethian manners, who takes the pose of caring for his patients as "cases" only, but who really possesses a heart of rare tenderness and generosity.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9. -- An examination of the package of "securities" belonging to Mrs. Chadwick and held by Iri Reynolds, cashier of the Wade Park Bink, has revealed the fact, it is reported here to-night, that the stocks and bonds on which the woman borrowed vast sums, instead, of being worth $5,000,000, as alleged, are not worth a penny.

ALL books are gift books at this time of year, although some have a more distinctive holiday garb than others. With each succeeding season the tendency has been more marked to reissue, with new editors and new illustrators, works that have become classics rather than, as during the vogue of the Christmas "annuals," to present new texts of doubtful merit merely as the vehicle for fancy illustration and extravagant binding, also of doubtful merit.

LEAVES from the Diary of Henry Greville," edited by the Countess of Strafford, has just been published in London. It is full of entertaining anecdotes of distinguished men and women of the Victorian era. Greville was as familiar with artists, actors, and musicians as he was with statesmen and authors.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 9. -- A solution of the method of treating spotted fever cases, which, should it prove to be successful, will be a great aid to the medical profession, is announced by Dr. Arthur J. Wolff, bacteriologist of the Hartford Board of Health. Dr. Wolff believes that the antitoxin of spotted fever is found in the diphtheria germ.

BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 9. -- The Foreign Office is in receipt of a telegram from the Argentine Minister at Asuncion stating that the Government of Paraguay has accepted the peace conditions of the revolutionists subject to the nomination of Juan B. Gauna for President.

Henry Edward Watts, one of the comparatively few English students of Cervantes, who have formed a sort of cult by themselves, died lately. He was expected to have much to say in the forthcoming modest celebration in England of the three hundredth anniversary of the publication of "Don Quixote." This occurs early in January. Presumably, though there may be no "Cervantists" in this country, something will be done here to mark an anniversary so interesting.

" The History of Ancient Wethersfield, Conn.," which will shortly be issued in two volumes by the Grafton Press, was started by the late Judge Samuel Adams. At his death the work was taken up by Dr. Henry R. Stiles, who will be recalled as the author of "The History of Ancient Windsor, Conn."

August Niemann's book has provoked much comment, and THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW has already had something to say about it. As a novel it hardly counts; as an indication of how some people in Germany look at things; as, in some sort, a warning to Great Britain of possible joints in her armor of defense, the story has undoubted value.
HELSINGFORS, Dec. 9. -- The Emperor's message on the opening of the Finnish Diet to-day was as follows.

In the new edition which the Macmillan Company is bringing out of "The Holy Roman Empire," by James Eryce, D.C.L., a number of changes have been made. The work first appeared forty years ago, and in the intervening period the knowledge concerning mediaeval history has been so greatly increased that the writer thought it advisable to enlarge his book, now nearly half a century old.

TOKIO, Dec. 9. -- In disabling the Russian fleet at Port Arthur, precluding the possibility of its being able to reinforce the Russian Second Pacific Squadron, the Japanese have accomplished the main object of the desperate assaults against the fortress which they have been making for the past three months.

The fact that the exports of manufactures from this country during the calendar year 1904 win exceed those of any previous year and are likely to pass the $500,000,000 line will be hailed with joy by the "stand-patters" as conclusive evidence that a protective tariff does not restrict the development of our export trade in manufactures.

The unfaltering progress of the physical sciences, always able to make sure of the ground behind them as they advance, has given rise in some quarters to the idea that a similar steady course of progress might be in store for the mental sciences proper, as well as for such quasi-mental sciences as economics, if they were, without more ado, to adopt with little variation the methods of physics.

From the presses of the Macmillan Company a translation from the Italian of Augusto Righi is appearing under the title, "Modern Theory of Physical Phenomena," by Augustus Trowbridge, Professor of Mathematical Physics in the University of Wisconsin. To this translation Prof. Righi has added a preface, in which he says:

Often an instructor in Latin finds it difficult to get a text book which will suit those pupils who have completed the study of some first-year Latin books but as yet are not advanced enough for Latin composition. This trouble has been met and overcome by Mather A. Abbott, master in Groton School, Mass., in his book entitled "A First Latin Writer."

The keynote of Leonida Montedonico's life was tragety writ in large capitals. But in spite of this the book has its cheerful moments. There Is Lady Carnifex, a light-headed little woman with a good heart, and there is Sir Rufus, her husband, a county land owner, devoted to Lady Carnifex and to his pigs, and there is Rufus the younger, thoughtful, egotistical, and delicate, and Geoffry, a younger son, big, manly, handsome, and cheerful.

That David B. Hill will fulfill his promise to retire from the leadership of the Democratic State organization on Jan. 1, and furthermore that he will designate William F. Sheehan as his successor, were the declarations made last night by a Democrat high in the councils of the organization.

In your editorial remarks in issue Dec. 3 on the "opening of a period of general book buying," you mention a publisher who says he would like to see the book trade placed on as sensible and practicable a basis as the shoe trade, and you say that will be the case when the general public learns that good books are as essential to its well being as good shoes.

A volume dealing with the history of dress in this country from the time of the earliest settlements down to the year 1809 will shortly be issued by George W. Jacobs Co., and is entitled "Historic Dress in America." It is the work of Elizabeth McClellan, with illustrations by Sophie B. Steel.

IF any man, said Justice Keeling as he was about to sentence John Bunyan to three months in gaol, "have received the gift of tinkering as thou hast done, let him follow his tinkering," That was near the end of the year 1660, and Bunyan had been caught preaching at an unauthorized "conventicle."

Twelve years ago a book on missionary work appeared under the title, "Encyclopedia of Missions." In the course of these years the changes which have taken place in missionary work render this volume lacking in many important points. For this reason a "New Encyclopedia of Missions" is being issued under the auspices of the Bureau of Missions.

EVEN to-day, when so many of his period and faith have lost the power to move us, the name of John Ruskin awakens an indefinable emotion of allegiance. Those who have had bitter reason to regret their submission to his valiant leadership in the study of art still recognize the power for good in his ebullient energy and enthusiasm.

Some reviewers have impugned the historical accuracy of "Black Friday." One says "the meeting of the gold conspirators the night before Black Friday occurred, not at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, as stated in Mr. Isham's book, but in the old Erie Railroad Building on Eighth Avenue, now the Grand Opera House."

DAPPLETON CO. will publish shortly after the holidays a story of Chicago life entitled. "Fire of Spring." It is by Margaret Horton Potter, author of "The Flame Gatherers." The same house also has in preparation for publication about the middle of January "The Life and Correspondence of John Duke, Lord Coleridge, Lord Chief Justice of England," edited by Ernest Hartley Coleridge.

This is a very pleasant story of four girls from the ages of eleven to fourteen, who played at housekeeping in a deserted cottage, and whose little experiment brought about an unexpected and happy event. The maidens had neighbors kind and unkind, and even a lodger. They had various adventures, merry and grievous, but sunshine predominates, and all ends well.

THE debutantes have made their bows and are now out in society. The first Junior Cotillion has been danced, and there remains little to chronicle until several of the large private dances shall have taken place. To use a Wall Street expression, there will be quite a slump this week in entertaining.

THE optimism which characterizes the declarations of the parents of Lolita Armour as to the completeness of the cure of the congenital dislocation of both hips as the result of the treatment to which she has been subjected is not shared by specialists in orthopedic surgery.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 10. -- As a result of the unsuccessful attempts of Grand Duke Sergius, uncle of the Emperor, and Governor General of Moscow, and M. Muravieff, the Minister of Justice, to block the Liberal movement, both are reported to have resigned.

THE second-hand automobile has now become a recognizes article of commerce, and in addition to those sold at all the regular salesrooms where new machines are dealt in, there have recently been established several places exclusively devoted to the sale of secondhand machines.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Replying to an influential deputation to-day, headed by Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, who represented the necessity for the co-operation of all parts of the empire in the maintenance of the navy, Premier Balfour gave the heartiest approval of the objects of the deputation and emphasized the responsibility of the colonies to aid the motherland in carrying out the common duties of the empire.

In a sprint of less than a half minute's duration last night, alter 142 hours of riding in Madison Square Garden, E.F. Root earned a signal victory over Johan Stol. In an extra race of one mile, to decide a tie between the two leading teams, while the air quivered with the cheers of 12,000 spectators gathered in the big hall to see the finish of the six days' bicycle race.

The testimony of the late HENRY JAMES as to the impression made on him by RALPH WALDO EMERSON which appears in the December Atlantic contains far more that is favorable to the sage of Concord than the writer intended. It reminds one of legends of apostles and saints in which the lips of opponents framed to attack and refute the elect of GOD are forced by some inner power to applaud.

President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard, during a lecture on the subject "Education in a Republic," which he delivered before the Schoolmasters' Association in the University Building. Washington Square, yesterday, asserted that the real proof of education was the possession of will power, such as was developed in freedom.

THERE is one public market in New York City where enough food is bought between dusk and midnight every Saturday to sustain hundreds of families until the next Saturday comes around that is never interfered with, to any appreciable extent, by the exactions of the food trusts.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Lulu McLaughlin, who disappeared from her home here on June 15, 1903, was brought back to the city to-day by Detective Sergeant Cordally, who found her in Manorville, in the Catskill Mountains. The girl is now fourteen years of age.

I have been a constant reader of your paper. I have had occasion to differ from you on many questions; but through all those differences I have constantly maintained that your editorial manners were above reproach. Against a news item, as such, a mere reader can have no just cause for complaint.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Civil Service Commission makes announcement that another batch of examinations will be made for positions with the Panama Canal Commission on Jan. 8. These positions include places with salaries varying from $250 to $75 per month. It is announced that each applicant must submit with his application an unmounted photograph of himself of recent date.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 10. -- With the opening of the packages of alleged securities that were in the possession of Iri Reynolds of the Wade Park Banking Company and the disclosures that these packages contained $17,046,000 in bogus Carnegie and other paper the Chadwick bubble has burst.

Rome, Nov. 24, 1904. THE Consistory held in the Vatican last week was noteworthy for a vigorous allocution of the Pope on the estrangement between the French Government and the Holy See, and for the extraordinary number of Bishops appointed -- more than 130 for all parts of the world. There were twenty-seven Cardinals present and many prelates from East and West, among whom were several Americans.

In November 36 National banking associations were chartered, 7 associations placed, in voluntary liquidation, and 4 in the charge of receivers, making a net increase of 25, the number of existing associations on Nov. 30, 1904, being 5,520, with authorized capital of $784,821,335; bonds on deposit as security for circulation, $431,075,840; circulation secured by bonds, $427,947,505, and by deposit of lawful money, $32,781,570.

In the course of a discussion before the Rapid Transit Commission at a recent meeting, at which a number of experts were present by invitation, some interesting facts were brought out relative to the capacity of the Subway which are valuable as a basis of future discussions of the extension of the system.

With the nomination of the officers to be elected at the annual meeting early in the new year of the United States Golf Association, and the prospect of an early report from the special committee to consider methods whereby the associate and allied clubs may be placed on a more equal basis in the management of the affairs of the association, interest in the outlook of the coming year has been considerably revived.

After suffering for more than three months as the result of burns sustained by 1 in while at work on the viaduct extension of the Subway to West Farms, Hugh Ford, an electrician's helper died yesterday at the Lebanon Hospital as the result of lead poisoning, due to a dressing employed there in a last effort to cure his hurts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The first dinner of the Gridiron Club for the season was given at the Arlington Hotel to-night. The recent election afforded the club, which is composed of Washington correspondents, an opportunity to make mirth at the expense of both the successful and the defeated parties, prominent representatives of both being present to enjoy the quips and burlesques.

To the individual who on Thursday morning last saw his 10-point margin in Amalgamated Copper or in one of the few other issues which bore the brunt of that day's decline in the stock market wiped out, doubtless the situation seemed about as much one of panic as could well be imagined.

Dog owners of the Bronx are looking forward with pleasurable anticipation to the first dog show of that borough, to be held by the Bronx Kennel Club at Zeltner's Morrisania Park, One Hundred and Seventieth Street and Third Avenue, Dec. 20 to 23, inclusive. Over 250 entries, representing some 200 dogs, had been received when the entries formally closed last week, assuring the success of the exhibition.

B. Altman Co. announced yesterday their plans for erecting a new store building on the east side of Fifth Avenue, from Thirty-fourth to Thirtyfifth Streets, to which they will remove their business, now at Sixth Avenue and Nineteenth Street. It is understood that work upon the new sturcture will be begun soon after the first of the year.

The Great Central Railway, whose main line runs from London to Liverpool via Nottingham, has taken the initiative in substituting a large and durable style of freight car for the relatively small and frail kind which is now in general use on British railways. One of the new cars has just been finished for the Great Central Company, and the others to be built will be of the same size and character.

The general outlook in copper continues to be-pretty strong, despite the vagaries of the speculative market, the occasional depressed attitude of which was misleading. The sharp fluctuations which followed upon the sustained rise were not surprising, and the copious liquidation of profits has left the market in a less overweighted condition.

Last week we had the annual Governmental reports, and seldom have they been more interesting or received less attention. There was the President's message, which emphasized almost everything the Republican platform omitted, and raised new issues of which much will be heard later on.

Is there really something about the gas business that benumbs the human senses, including the variety called common, leaving only the pocket sense active? The behavior of the gentlemen responsible for the management of the corporations engaged in supplying gas and electric light to the City of New York indicates that gas does exercise this mysterious and subduing power.

THE greatest book in the world is very naturally called by a word which means merely "the book," since by comparison there is no other record of mankind's hopes and fears, crimes and heroism, grandeur and meanness which may be classed with the Bible.

JUST about now there is a lot of hysteria regarding the leading jockeys of 1904, and much capital is made out of the fact that Hildebrand heads the list with 164 wins in 748 races. What of it? Even though one earnest inquirer states that "this total of mounts nearly approaches that of the elder Reiff in 1896, whose record is the largest for this country."

The storm, which was central over West Virginia yesterday morning, moved up along the coast during the afternoon and was central over Nantucket last night. Up to 10 o'clock last night two inches of snow had fallen in this city, according to the official record at the Weather Bureau.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10. -The Preliminary Derby, a six-furlong handicap for two-year-olds, the most important stake of the meeting thus far, was won easily by an Eastern colt, W.H. Snyder . Company's Trapper. There were twelve acceptances, but only ten went to the post. Trapper, backed from 5 to 2 to twos, was a decided favorite. King's Trophy, at sixes, was a second choice, with Saladin and Viperine, both at sevens, next.
TOCIO. Dec. lO. -- The following announeeen was made fom imperial headquarters to-day:

TOKIO, Nov. 8. -- An interesting story of the great struggle between Japan and Russia lies in a long-established personal friendship between Gen Terauchi, Minister of War of Japan, and Gen. Kuropatkin, Commander in Chief of the Russian armies in Manchuria.

LONDON, Nov. 21. THE King of Portugal, after spending a week at Windsor, partaking of that discriminating and delightful hospitality for which King Edward and his amiable spouse are celebrated, is reported to have said he never before in all his life had had so much real pleasure crowded into one week.
SANTA CLAUS? No? Yes? New York really has a new one this Christmas.

Sir OLIVER LODGE is a gentleman whom it is the habit of intelligent people to take quite seriously.
