The announcement that he has devised and reduced to successful operation an apparatus which dispels fogs at sea is naturally one of unusual interest. It accomplishes its purpose by driving currents of electricity at a very high voltage through barbed wires into the fog-filled atmosphere.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 10. -- Mrs. Chadwick got between $750,000 and $800,000 out of Pittsburg residents before she thought of wider fields. This is known to the business men of Pittsburg and not denied by the victims when they feel that they are among friends. The names of those who were caught on bad paper making "loans" to the woman would create astonishment if made public.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 10. -- Fuller details of the confessions of President C.T Beckwith of the wrecked Citizens' National Bank of Oberlin were obtained here to-night. The confession, which is now in possession of the Federal authorities, is a story concerning the monumental transactions of Mrs. Chadwick that taxed the credibility of the few who heard it, but documentary proof compelled belief.

The famous old Gilsey House, at Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street, for more than thirty years the temporary home of visitors from all over the United States and distinguished guests from abroad and a New York landmark, closed its doors to the public last night at 8:30 o'clock, after having dismissed the 180 guests gathered under its roof.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The burning question of the hour among the members of the Inaugural Committee is whether or not Gov. Vardaman of Mississippi shall be invited to the inauguration. It has always been customary to invite the Governors of the different States to inaugurations, but the Vardaman question seems to have put a new face on the matter.
FORT EDWARD, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- The coldest weather of this Winter came last night. Early to-day 12 degrees below were registered at Whitehall and 10 below at Sandy Hill.

With the assertion that "high crime is more frequent in this country than anywhere else in the world, except Sicily," Andrew D. White, ex-President of Cornell University and ex-Ambassador to Germany, at once fixed the attention of the members of the League for Political Education who had assembled yesterday to hear him speak on "Evolution vs. Revolution in Politics."

It was learned yesterday that friends of Senator Depew in the Legislature are considering the advisability of their remaining out of the Republican caucus in the event of their being convinced when the Legislature assembles that Mr. Depew cannot obtain a majority of the Republican members.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 10. -- But for the presence of mind of Miss Jane Caskey of this city, three women and two children might have been seriously hurt in a runaway to-day. They were in a hotel omnibus in charge of Driver Charles J. Sayre.

PARIS, Nov. 22. -- Yesterday a well-known Wall Street lawyer, W.H. Norledge, walked into Bostock's Hippodrome, in the Boulevard de Clichy, and asked the great lion trainer if he had in his employ an Englishman named Caldwell. "Yes," said Mr. Bostock, and he sent for the man, an alert, well-set-up, well-educated Britishner, who, before taking elephant training, had served as a cavalry officer with Kitchener in the Soudan and was with "Bobs" in the Transvaal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Before a large gathering of physicians, including some from other cities, Dr. Howard Percy Deady of Liberty, N. Y., to-night delivered a lecture on outdoor treatment for tuberculosis.

THIS talk about art in our theatres is all nonsense." Nat Goodwin, himself an artist of very exceptional attainments, made the observation, sitting up in bed, with a couple of pillows for support and a cigarette for solace. "The people in New York don't go to the theatre for art," he said. "They simply want to laugh."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- One of the first results of the investigation into the political activity of postal employes is likely to be the dismissal from the service of President Keller of the National Association of Letter Carriers. It is reported that this will come in a few days.

THERE is a lost Pleiad -- but the Pleiades can be discovered without the aid of a Lick telescope every Sunday night. Stars are supposed to twinkle, but the Pleiades of New York eat, drink, and make merry, and let Monday take care of itself. That might stand for their motto, though it never has appeared in print in precisely that shape.

As a result of official investigations which Controller Grout been making into the bills and expenditures of the Police Department he let it be known yesterday that he believes Commissioner McAdoo's assertion that the "lid is down" in New York to be incorrect. Personal investigations by the Controller have led him to tell his friends that certain forms of vice and crime are being openly flaunted about the city, entirely unrestrained by the Police Department.
BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- "The horse Hans does not think, but at the same time there is no trickery on the part of his trainer."

The announcement of the plans of B. Altman Co. for erecting a great store building at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, referred to in more detail in another column will easily take rank among the most important events of recent years, having bearing upon the city's real estate growth and development.

A NICE little pig of silver resting upon a silver standard is one of the latest ornaments for milady's dressing table. It is an animal of the porcupine order, and the quills are the pretty scarf, lace, and fancy pins of various kinds which occupy an important place in every woman's wardrobe.

Whenever Wall Street is confronted with a sudden rise or a sudden drop in the price of the securities in which it is interested it makes an attempt to explain the situation, and in doing this it passes over the technical conditions of the market when made the movement in either direction possible.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 10. -- For the entertainment of her guests, Mrs. George J. Gould planned a court tennis tournament this week, and among those who played were James Henry Smith, T. Suffern Tailer, Robert Howard Russell, Mr. Gould, and Kingdon and Jay Gould. A silver loving cup presented by Mrs. Gould. is the trophy for which the players are contesting.

BOST0N, Dec. 10. -- Because of many alleged interviews in which he has been misquoted. Herbert B. Newton gave out to-day a full account of his dealings with Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick. Mr. Newton related his story primarily to dispose of the allegations which have been attributed to him, in which he has been made to blame his attorneys for introducing him to Mrs. Chadwick.

A good deal of discussion has been excited by the fact that an enterprising reporter in Washington spent a day on the streets of that city offering silver dollars for sale at 25 cents each, and that between the hours of 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. only three were sold, although they were freely offered to thousands of persons.
TOKIO, Dec. 10. -- The commander of the Japanese naval guns at Port Arthur reported at 9 o'clock last night as follows:

" The Berlin money market," writes a correspondent from that city. "shows a tendency toward easier conditions. Rates are declining, notwithstanding the approach of the monthly settlement. Private discount has fallen below 4 per cent. for the first time since the official rate was raised six weeks ago.
HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 10. -- Earl Grey, the new Governor General of Canada, landed here to-day from the steamer Parisian, which had lain at Quarantine during the night.

THE large exhibition of portraits, drawing and painting from life, general and applied design, wood carving, hammered metal, and tooled leather made by the Pratt Institute of Brooklyn at the St. Louis World's Fair has secured for the school of fine arts of that institute a Grand Prize.

To some of his old-time friends and political lieutenants who called at the Hoffman House last night to confer with him David B. Hill, the Democratic State leader, reiterated his intention to lay down the burden of leadership on Jan. 1. Those to whom Mr. Hill repeated his declaration of intention to retire were National Committeeman Norman E. Mack, John B. Stanchfield, Elliot Danforth, and William Lindsay, formerly Senator from Kentucky.

To multiply causes of divorce in these days when great church organizations erect their mitred fronts to frown upon it altogether seems out of time and keeping and lends a new tangle to a perplexity which is probably as old as marriage, or at least as the last quarter of the first honeymoon.

TWO of the quaintest and most becoming chapeaux possible for their pretty, handsome blonde faces are worn by Miss Rosamond Street and Miss Anita Sands respectively, and both are pale and blue or blue and White. Miss Street's chapeaux is a Directoire poke in white trimmed with pale-blue ribbon and pale-blue ostrich tips.

THE late Max Muller of Oxford University, accompanied by a friend, an engineer, was one day surveying the docks and warehouses at Liverpool, They were looking for the Superintendent of one of the docks to glean some information from him. At the office on the pier they met a man of the most pronounced blonde type of feature.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- President Roosevelt has decided not to call an extra session in the Spring to consider the question of tariff revision or for any other purpose. That is as far as his decision has gone. The talk of an extra session in the Fall is still going on, and the President is understood to be still considering it.

It developed at a hearing at the Tombs Court yesterday that George E. Fisher, a banker at 37 Wall Street, and living at the Plaza Hotel, who was arrested on Friday afternoon, charged with grand larceny, got into trouble through a note which in connection with T. Ashby Blythe, the complainant in the case; Peter B. Corr, Tracy W. Pratt, Ernest C. Brower, and David B. King, they had given to the Southern Textile Company.

WHEN Lillian Russell was dining with some of her professional friends the other evening she told a story about an eccentric friend of hers. This old lady had an aversion to paying calls. She went about once a year, but never got out of her carriage. She would send her coachman up the steps and make him stick a card under the door.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- As President of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, representative Bartholdt of Missouri to-day brought to the attention of Secretary Hay the resolution adopted by the Union at St. Louis on Sept. 13 urging the powers which signed The Hague treaty of arbitration to intervene in order to stop the war between Russia and Japan.

STAND on a Sixth Avenue or Broadway sidewalk and watch the crowds flow in and out of any big department store. Plunge into that flood of holiday shoppers to be swept through the great doors, caught in the eddy just inside and whirled off into any of the secondary currents of the stream, and one might fairly think his identity altogether lost.

In your issue of Dec. 1 on your editorial page you state that although there have been several decisions in the Indian rupee question, Secretary Shaw awaits the decision of the Supreme Court before he will allow the drawback claimed by importers.

In what may be termed a small blizzard, with the snow falling fast and of a blinding character and a howling wind from west by north, seven members of the Crescent Athletic Club's trap-shooting contingent and a few guests had good sport under the unfavorable conditions at Bay Ridge yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 10. -- A leading naval authority expresses the belief that the Japanese, after defeating the Russian Second Pacific Squadron, will send a Japanese squadron to European waters over the route that Admiral Rojestvensky's squadron has traveled.

ORANGE, Dec. 10. -- Wesley Lindabury's Leghorn hen is in the public eye again, and poultry farmers in and around Fairmount are much mystified at her chameleon-like proclivity for changing color. Last Summer she was white; now she is brown. This particular hen is five years old, and for the past two years has been the chief attraction of the neighbors at the Lindabury hennery.

BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- Dr. Carl Stumpf, Professor of Psychology at the University of Berlin and a member of the Royal Academy of Science, and two colleagues, Dr. C. von Hornbostel and Dr. O. Pfungst, have ended months of experiments with Herr von Osten's horse Hans.
DON'T mind him; he's only a chicken gambler."
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Money was in quiet demand and fairly abundant in the market to-day. Discounts were firm in view of the prospect of dearer money.

Accompanying Thursday's advance in the rate for call money to 5 per cent, reports were current of the calling of considerable amount of loans by the banks. That the supply of available funds despite the calls was ample was evidenced by the manner in which the call rate on Friday declined to 2 per cent.

Referring to the letter of "A.C.B" in to-day's TIMES, quoting the case of a motorist who admitted sixteen previous arrests, and was fined only $50, upon which he bases a plea for new laws, so that imprisonment should be the penalty for repeated offenses, permit me to subjoin the text of the present law.

THE nuptials of Miss Edith Devereux Clapp and the Count Rene du Temple de Rougemont of France drew a large and fashionable crowd on Tuesday afternoon to the Church of St. Francis Xavier, and the beauty of the frocks seen thereat rivaled those of the previous Tuesday at the marriage of Miss Eleonor Jay and Arthur Iselin.

Princeton and the Wadderers played a tie gameof hockey last night at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, West Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue. The score, after some exciting playing, was 2 goals for each side. The rival teams then played an extra five minutes in an effort to determine a winner, but no goal was made, and then the match was called off.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10. -- The main attraction at Oakland to-day was the Family Club Handicap. In addition to $1,000 added by the new California Jockey Club, the Family Club of San Francisco presented to the owner of the winner a handsome silver cup. Twenty-three regular and two field books were in operation.

WEST POINT, Dec. 10. -- Prince Fushimi of Japan and his retinue visited the Military Academy to-day as the guests of the Government. The Prince with his party spent Practically the entire day at the National training school for army officers, and manifested the most lively interest in the diverse phases of the educational system in vogue there that came under his observation.

In NOTHING since the production of "Parsifal" has Mr. Conried come nearer to meeting the ideals he professed and justifying the promises he made on taking the directorship of the Metropolitan than in the remarkable performance of "Die Aeistersinger" which he has just added to the season's repertory.

Men of prominence in many walks of life -- city officials, politicians of all parties, members of the bench and bar and of the Legislature, church officers, and business men -- thronged the Roman Catholic Pro-Cathedral, in Jay Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, at the funeral services for Hugh McLaughlin, for forty years the leader of the local Democracy.

The results of a sojourn of three years in China on the part of a young collector sent out by the Museum of Natural History are shown in part, so far room permits, in one of the galleries of the Museum in the west wng. Dr. Berthold Laufer has returned from Central China and the Amur country with an extraordinary variety of the modern products of China and a certain number of ancient articles.

" Lohengrin" was given at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening for the first time this season. Mr. Conried again brought out an important production at one of these Saturday evening performances which bid fair to take on a "popular" character not only in the half prices that prevail for them, but also through the fact that the casts are practically the same as those that are presented on the regular subscription nights.

It is extremely encouraging to know that in the recent conference between members of the Child Labor Committee and Governor-elect HIGGINS the suggestion that all the work of the State connected with the administration of reform laws should be taken out of politics was received in the most friendly spirit.

IT was really a very serious matter, though of course the Mere Man had laughed and pooh-poohed the suggestion that it would be. Had he not rubbed elbows with Fashion night after night at the opera? And was his not a familiar figure at symphony concerts and afternoon recitals, projected for the purpose of launching long-haired foreign genius on the silvery -- not to say golden and greenback -- sea of American favor?

CHARLESTON, West Va., Dec. 10. -- For a month armed guards have been keeping watch over the ballots cast in Kanawha County in the election held in November. The guard is being maintained by John Melton, the Democratic candidate for Sheriff.

Whatever duty the Government collects upon imported products the Government receives. The additional price that that duty enables the domestic producer to collect from the domestic consumer goes to the producer, and the Government receives none of it.

The collapse on the curb last Thursday of the Montreal and Boston Consolidated Copper Mining Company's stock is believed to have been responsible for the sudden death yesterday of Joseph C. Morris, one of the best known brokers on the curb market in Broad Street, and generally referred to by the younger generation as "Pop Morris."
TOKIO, Dec. 11. -- The battering of the Port Arthur fleet continues, and there is little ground for expecting that the Russian warships will ever again engage the Japanese.

Every friend of the Russian people must hope that it is true that the uncle of the Czar, the Grand Duke SERGIUS, Governor General of Moscow, has resigned his office in despair of being able to oppose successfully the new Minister of the Interior, Prince MIRSKY. If it be true, and if the Czar stands by his Minister, there will be a great advance for the cause of justice and decency in his realms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Commerce between the United States and China in the ten months ended with October last shows a larger total, both in imports and exports, than in the corresponding months of any earlier year.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 12. -- The Admiralty has issued a circular to all naval commanders explaining Lord Selborne's scheme, which becomes effective on Jan. 1, and detailing the organization of warships of the reserve.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Exports of mineral oils from the United States promise to exceed in value $75,000,000 in the calendar year 1904. Ten months' figures just presented by the Bureau of Statistics show a total value of mineral oil exported at $66,000,000, in round terms, which is a larger total in value than in the corresponding months of any preceding year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- There are several "machines" in different parts of the country, if the daily newspapers are to be relied upon; but one of the strongest, most ironclad of the lot is comparatively unknown except by name. Not Tammany Hall itself is such a close corporation as the House machine at Washington.

In the archives of the United States Weather Bureau in this city there is recorded no such Dec. 11 as yesterday. At 6 o'clock in the morning the thermometer registered the 9-degree mark, and it was not until well along toward noon that the city began to thaw out. New Yorkers had only one crumb of comfort -- there was but little wind.

After a careful inspection of half a dozen localities, the Automobile Club of France has selected the Bay of Arcachon for the international motor race next year. This event is better known, perhaps, as the Harmsworth Cup contest, as Sir Alfred Harmsworth presented the cup for an international motor boat race two years ago.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 11. -- Secretary Iri Reynolds of the Wade Park Bank declared to-night that his implicit belief in the statements made to him by Mrs. Chadwick in which she declared herself to be the daughter of Andrew Carnegie was the impelling cause of his financial dealing with her.

It is stated upon what is accepted as good authority that the number of the unemployed poor of New York needing relief is greater than was ever before known. The organized charities report that their resources are overtaxed. The number accommodated in the Municipal Lodging House during November was 7,787, or 40 per cent. more than during November last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Interesting information concerning the precious stones industry is made public in a pamphlet of the Department of Commerce and Labor covering reports extending over several years from United States Consuls in all parts of the world.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The official announcement of the scheme for the reorganization of the British Navy verifies fully the advance information relative thereto in my cablegram of Thursday.

Four belated transatlantic liners made port yesterday, after voyages that were as unpleasant as hurricanes, gales, snowstorms, and mountainous seas could make them. The vessels were the Cunarder Lucania, the American liner New York, the Hannover of the North German Lloyd, and the Hamburg-American liner Belgravia.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 11. -- Clad only in his underclothing and a raving maniac from an attack of typhoid fever James Delatto, an Italian thirty-two years of age, with an axe held seven policemen at bay for more than two hours in the Fifth Reformed Dutch Church shortly before the morning service to-day.

Services to commemorate the one hundred and sixtieth anniversary of the First Baptist Church, at Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, and the twentieth anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev. I.M. Haldeman, were held yesterday morning. The church was elaborately decorated for the occasion.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The Times in its financial supplement to-morrow will say:

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- The engagement of Miss Daisy Leiter, sister of Lady Curzon, to the Earl of Suffolk and Berkshire, of England, was announced to-night by Mrs. Leiter from the family residence in this city. The date of the wedding has not been decided on as yet, but will be in the near future.

The President, it appears, is about to win an important victory over the Senate in his long struggle to make CRUM, the negro, Collector of the Port of Charleston. Three times he has sent the appointment to the Senate, and three times confirmation has been refused. The name of CRUM has now gone to the Senate for the fourth time, and Washington dispatches announce that Senator TILLMAN gives up the fight.

PATERSON, Dec. 11. -- Two shots were fired in the lobby of the Bijou Theatre last night, and a man and a woman had narrow escapes. Both bullets lodged in the wall of the foyer, and in the confusion the man who did the shooting made his escape. A friend of the shooter was caught, and the police hope to force him to tell who his companion was.

The lawyer of one of the gentlemen who have been caught in the toils of the woman CHADWICK volunteers the suggestion that "if the newspapers had kept their hands off," the case would probably have been settled before this, and he ruefully complains that now he cannot tell whether it will be settled or not.

We are bound to assume that Dr. ANDREW D. WHITE, the eminent scholar and publicist, was well informed as to the facts when he criticized President ROOSEVELT for securing the commutation of the death penalty in the case of the son of a clergyman sentenced for murder. But we do not think that Mr. ROOSEVELT is likely to err on the side of "mawkish sentimentality" in such a matter.

A somewhat unequal and generally unsatisfactory distribution of travel in the Subway is effected by the abandonment of local trains at the Grand Central Station and the transfer of passengers to expresses, with the result that the locals from that point run nearly empty and the expresses are usually so crowded that only standing room can be had by those who do not push their way in rudely and often brutally.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- Philippe Bunau-Varilla, who, before being Minister of Panama to Washington, was the principal engineer of the Panama Canal, gives an authorized interview relative to the building of the canal at sea level.

Mr. Guiterman tells a charming story in poetry of the "Dog's Cold Nose," but I beg to assure you that he has been misinformed as to facts. The true story of the dog's cold nose has been handed down to us sailors from the log book of the Ark, and we generally get things pretty correct when the log book is the authority.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- J. Pierpont Morgan, who came to Washington yesterday to attend the Gridiron Club dinner, called at the White House to-night, and was with the President for a half hour. At midnight he left in his private car for New York. Secretary Shaw also saw the President, and later took a train for New York.

-- Discontent, apparently well justified, is expressed by The American Syren with the rate at which work on the Ambrose Channel into New York Harbor is progressing, and it inclines to the opinion that the cause of the delay lies in the Government's determination to get the dredging done too cheaply.

The Tribune, the principal supporter of the policies of the Republican Party in the East, and one whose editor is reported to have peculiarly intimate relations with the present Administration, stands firmly by the position it took immediately after the election in favor of practical revision of the extreme protective tariff.

If the quotation printed in THE TIMES of to-day, from Bishop Potter's address at Wellesley College on "The Relation of the Old Testament to Practical Modern Life" be correct, and if it was not modified by other statements not quoted, it may well be regarded as the most remarkable and significant assertion ever made by a recognized authority in the Christian Church.

ROME, Dec. 11. -- In the presence of 60,000 people assembled in St. Peter's, Pope Plus this morning canonized the Blessed Alessandro Sauli and the Blessed Gerardo Maiella, descendants of whom, including Marquises Ambrozio, Sauli, and Negrotto, assisted in the canonization, a ceremony so rare in recent times that this was only the second held since 1870.

PARIS, Dec. 3. -- One of the most brilliant and successful swindlers who has ever figured in the cosmopolitan society of Paris is undoubtedly the soi-disant "Don Casali, Prince del Drago," and pretended nephew of Pope Plus IX.

The Treasuries of the repudiating Southern States will not quake at the menacing decree of the Supreme Court against North Carolina, now pending fulfillment at Washington in favor of her prosecutor, South Dakota, because it is doubtful if like decrees will issue in the future.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 11. -- Coated with ice so thick that their clothing was as rigid as iron and rendered movement of their limbs almost -- in some eases wholly --impossible, their vessel awash and stranded on Pea Island, N.C., Capt. Booye of the three-masted schooner Montana and his crew of six men remained from 11 o'clock last night until 2 o'clock this afternoon lashed to the rigging.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 11. -- A popular anti-Government demonstration, the participants in which included large numbers of students of both sexes, began at midday in the Nevski Prospect and lasted about two hours.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 11. -- It all came about because John L. Young, an Arcola farmer, became sleepy yesterday before he disposed of the load of potatoes he had hauled to this city to sell. He curled up in his wagon using his sacks of potatoes as a couch.

LINCOLN PARK, N.J., Dec. 11. -- As Jennie Vreeland, fourteen years of age, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Milton Vreeland, was returning to her home from the village late yesterday afternoon she was attacked by two weasels. Only with great difficulty did she succeed in beating them off.

Agitation over the signing of city light-contracts by Commissioner John T. Oakley was renewed yesterday by the action of Controller Grout and the Citizens' Union. Each issued statements disapproving of the commissioner's action.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 11. -- Judson K. Gunn of South Newton has a flock of stationary hens, the delight of his heart and the wonder of all who have seen them. He proposes to rear a race of chickens which, instead of being armed with claws attached to legs, with which they will scratch in the neighbors' gardens, will be mounted on neat pedestals, so that they will "stay sot."

Nobody needs to be reminded what sort of a week last week was. The Lochinvar from the East raided our market for the benefit of himself or of somebody unknown, and carried away a lot of swag that he was not entitled to. Amalgamated was his stalking horse, and despite the remembered rise at the week-end it lost 10 3/4.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 11. -- Most young men consider poverty an insurmountable obstacle to getting an education, but E. Ray, a North Carolina boy studying in the graduate department of Harvard University, is not only poor, but blind as well.

As the climax of an all-night drinking bout in a hall on East Sixteenth Street, James Buchanan, the bartender of the Dagmar, a Raines law hotel at 213 Third Avenue, was shot and killed early yesterday morning. A group of five men, after having indulged rather liberally at the hall, entered the Dagnar, and were still in the place at 5 o'clock.

By order of Henry Gilsey, the old hotel at the corner of Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street, bearing his family name, is to be opened again to the public to-day. Business will begin with the serving of luncheon at noon, or as near that hour as possible, when the proceeding in the Sixth Municipal District Court, making positive the dispossess proceedings brought against Albert R. Keen and F.G. Lancaster of the Seaboard Hotel Company are completed.
Magistrate Crane, in the Harlem Court, yesterday gave a prisoner another chance, because he said that under similir circumstances he might have done the same thing himself.

In defiance of popular opinion, the fourteen men who composed the seven teams that finished for the six days' bicycle race in Madison Square Garden Saturday night all were out yesterday, taking the air in the open for the first time since the long contest was started a week ago. All were cheerful and strong, and none of them suffered in the least from disability caused by the supposedly cruel strain of the struggle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Secretary Metcalf in his annual report of the Department of Commerce and Labor, made public yesterday, expresses the view that the rapid development of insurance business, its extent, the enormous amount of money, and the diversity of interests involved, and the present business methods suggest that under existing conditions insurance is commerce, and may be subjected to Federal regulation through the affirmative action of Congress.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Capt. Mills of the American liner Philadelphia has entered a protest against reckless target practice carried on off Plymouth.

Expertship is the only preventive against such deplorable mistakes as appear to have been made in buying the Velasquez for Boston. But Mr. Ross is not an expert, although otherwise an able man. He teaches as professor of art painting at Harvard University. He teaches especially a color scheme of his own.

ALBANY, Dec. 12. -- Gov. Odell this afternoon received the committee of the Albany County Bar Association which came to urge the appointment of an Albany County attorney as Justice of the Supreme Court in place of D Cady Herrick, who resigned to accept the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Our dispatches this morning indicate that the troubles in St. Petersburg on Sunday were part of a more or less general series of demonstrations organized by the radical, or Socialist, Party, with, doubtless, some aid and instigation from the ultra-conservative or "Grand Ducal" clique near the person of the Czar.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12. -- Sais, Blute's good three-year-old, made his first appearance to-day in the fourth race, and, coupled with Tim Payne in the betting, was made a strong favorite. He won handily from his stable mate, with Judge Denton third. Aside from this race there was not much feature to the card. Summary:

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 12. -- Proclamations have been issued calling for a demonstration outside the law courts to-morrow at the opening of the trial of Sasoneff, the assassin of Minister of the Interior de Plelive. The demonstrators have been instructed to come armed.

By a unanimous vote in the First Presbyterian Church of Jamaica, L.I., the Presbytery of Nassau yesterday invited the Rev. Dr. Samuel T. Carter, who recently renounced certain fundamental dogmas of the Westminster Confession of the Presbyterian Church, to remain in the Church.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- "Sleep well to-night, by order of the Emperor," said Emperor William laughingly to Leoncavallo, at the conclusion of the final dress rehearsal this evening of "Der Roland von Berlin," alluding to the fact that the composer for several nights had been unable to sleep on account of anxiety over the success of the opera, and thereby expressing his satisfaction with Leoncavallo's work in its finished form.

The Charity Organization Society appeals for $100 to pay rent for one year for an American widow with four children under thirteen years of age, and a mother nearly eighty years old. The husband committed suicide when the younger child was an infant, seven years ago, and the woman has done her utmost to support the family by washing. The oldest boy will soon be able to earn something.

Under the eyes of William Penn, who looked down upon them from a portrait, more than 600 sons of Pennsylvania dined last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, the occasion being the sixth annual dinner of the Pennsylvania Society, and the guest of honor being Pennsylvania's new representative in the United States Senate, Philander C. Knox.

The imminent fire hazard inseparable from the lighting of Christmas trees with wax candles in church entertainments and other public or semi-public functions has been illustrated so often that it does not need to be emphasized by argument. Evergreen trees and their decorations are in the highest degree inflammable, and with the best of care the accident of starting a fire is almost unavoidable.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 12. -- The name of ex-Judge W.M.K. Olcott of New York, law partner of ex-Gov. Black, was brought into the Chadwick case to-day by Iri Reynolds, Secretary and Treasurer of the Wade Park Bank, at a hearing before Referee in Bankruptcy Remington.

Robert B. Mantell appeared last night at the Princess Theatre in "Othello." Despite the heavy snow an audience of some size and more enthusiasm greeted the popular actor. The performance, though by no means free from defects, was smooth and well sustained, some of the most important scenes being strikingly well done. Mr. Mantell was effective, though he showed a tendency toward exaggeration in facial expression.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 12. -- Contrary to the general impression here, Mrs. Lawrence C. Phipps and A. Hart McKee have not continued to be friends since Mr. Phipps brought his divorce suit, and it came to light to-day that McKee has threatened her with legal proceedings, because of her delay in paying him about $83,000 which, he said, she had borrowed from him.

The stock market suffered another violent break in prices yesterday. Simultaneously Lawson of Boston came out with another scare advertisement, while all day long a steady stream of Lawson-grams floated into the Street.

In the Class B amateur billiard championship tournament yesterday, at Maurice Daly's Academy, Albert Lowenberg continued his accurate cue work and came through with a victory over Louis A. Servatius, and W.A. Whitehead defeated James Vantine. It was the third victory for Lowenberg and he leads the six competitors for the title and trophy without the loss of a match.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day decided the case of the Western Union Telegraph Company vs. the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, involving the right of the railroad company to remove the telegraph company's poles from its right of way, in favor of the railroad company. The opinion was handed down by Justice McKenna.

As soon as possible after the first of the new year Controller Grout says he will take steps to compel all the corporations of the city to make good their obligations under the special franchise tax law for the calendar years 1900 and 1901 or else have their property advertised for sale at the general tax sale, which the Controller expects to hold some time in the Spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Mr. Hill of Connecticut got his Currency Reform bill before the House to-day and had it made a continuing order. It is a gold standard, pro-bank bill, and its discussion in the next few days will give the first measure of just how much there is in the talk of reorganizing the Democratic Party on radical lines.
OAKLAND, Cal., Dec. 12 -- Favorites fared badly at the Oakland track to-day, Pelham being the only first choice to win. Muddy going prevailed. Summary:

SOUTH McALESTER, I.T., Dec. 12. -- In the Choctaw-Chickasaw Citizenship Court to-day the compensation for Mansfield, McMurray, and Cornish, counsel for the two Indian tribes in citizenship litigation extending over the last five years, was fixed at $750,000. This is believed to be the largest fee ever paid west of the Mississippi River.

We seem to be back in last year's troublous times. Stocks are falling and there is nothing but conjecture as to why they fall. Intrinsic considerations afford no reason. The Monday traffic talks were filled with laments over car shortages, and that these are not fairy tales appear from as good a set of traffic reports as could be desired.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Representative Morrell of Pennsylvania introduced in the House to-day a bill embodying the suggestions contained in the President's message for subjecting insurance companies to Federal supervision.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Secretary Shaw conferred with the President to-day about the Dodge jewel case. He was accompanied by Edward Lauterbach of New York, counsel for Mrs. Dodge.

At the recent meeting of the Citizens' Industrial Association in this city Mr. C.W. POST of Battle Creek, Mich., read an instructive paper on the subject of industrial peace, which contained some pertinent suggestions to those for whom the open shop assumes the character of an issue.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- The election of J. Pierpont Morgan to be President of the Board of Trustees of the New York Metropolitan Museum of Art has caused Siegfried Lilienthal, one of the best-known art critics in Berlin, to see in this increased danger of the United States stripping Europe of her art treasures, and he has begun an agitation for international action to prevent art objects going to the United States.

Fire Commissioner Nicholas J. Hayes had the time of his life last night at the Star Lyceum, on East One Hundred and Seventh Street, where 5,000 of his friends assembled to attend a beef-and-beans smoker of the Pocasset Club, the Tammany organization of the Thirty-third Assembly District.
MADRID, Dec. 12. -- The Feast of the Virgin was marked by a riotous scene at Valencia.

-- Prof. CARL STUMPF, who is described as "the eminent psychologist of Berlin University," has reported in behalf of the scientific commission that has laboriously investigated the achievements of Hans, the equine mathematician, that the animal is not a mathematician at all, but answers the questions addressed to him by observing and acting upon some movement or change of expression made by his interrogators.

Since the Pennsylvania Railroad has commenced to build its new terminal, in the heart of the busiest section of New York, it has occurred to me as an old-time passenger and constant user of the New York Central Railroad that it would further the interests of both roads if the latter could connect with the tunnel for passenger transportation.

Now that all the mystery in connection with the financial operations of Mrs. CHADWICK is dispelled and the matter resolves itself into a commonplace swindle of forged securities and specious misrepresentations, the wonder grows that bank officers and shrewd financiers were so readily imposed upon.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12. -- Though drying rapidly the Crescent City Jockey Club's track was lumpy and slow to-day. The beaten favorites were Fallona, Dan McKenna, and Garnish. Spencerian again showed her quality by winning the handicap, with top weight, and in spite of serious interference for the greater part of the distance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Senators Cullom and Ankney held brief conferences with the President to-day, during which reference was made to the proposition to amend the inter-State commerce law as recommended in the annual message. The President is earnest in the desire to have the law so amended as to give the commission authority to fix rates in cases where exorbitant charges may be established after inquiry by that body.

Mr. W.J. BRYAN is very well content with the President's programme for the Government regulation of railroad freight rates. He quotes with approval in his Commoner this passage from Mr. ROOSEVELT'S message:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- President Roosevelt announced to-day that Secretary Morton, at his earnest request, had consented to remain in the Cabinet after March 4 as Secretary of the Navy.

Mayor McClellan gave renewed impetus yesterday to the agitation for a municipal lighting plant, saying that, if the Corporation Counsel upon examination found that the city had the necessary power to issue bonds for this purpose under the section discovered by the Citizens' Union, the Board of Estimate would proceed immediately to provide for such an undertaking.

Undoubtedly Controller GROUT has done well in changing his mind as to the payment of the claims against the city for lighting. The promise he made verbally to settle with the companies -- or, practically, with the company -- was clearly made without adequate consideration for the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Three witnesses were heard to-day in the case of Senator Reed Smoot before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections, the committee resuming its investigation after a long recess. The first witness was the Rev. J.M. Buckley, editor of The Christian Advocate, of New York, who told of a Mormon meeting he attended in Salt Lake, Utah, last Summer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A somewhat difficult situation is presented by the fact that the House Committee on Judiciary, which has been investigating the case of Judge Swayne of Florida, unanimously recommends his impeachment. Either Swayne, who is charged with being a tyrant, a corrupt Judge, and unfit for his office in every way, must be allowed to hold office for another year, or there must be an extra session of Congress to try him.

TOKIO, Dec. 12. -- A dispatch from Port Arthur says the battleship Sevastopol, which is lying outside the harbor, apparently is adopting defensive measures, therefore a naval attack is impossible pending discovery of the nature of the Russian precautions and the condition of the covering forts.

Jacob Wertheim, President of the United Cigar Manufacturers' Company, who lives at 763 Fifth Avenue, it was discovered yesterday, is the owner of the big red automobile which figured in the Pelham Avenue accident on Sunday, when John Murphy, sixty-five years old, of One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street and Eighth Avenue, who is confined in Fordham Hospital, received a severe scalp wound.

Charles F. Murphy, leader of Tammany Hall, yesterday announced that he would not take the Democratic State leadership if it were offered to him. At the same time it was declared by high authority in Tammany Hall that Tammany would never agree to the designation of William F. Sheehan as State leader.

Mr. John Pierpont Morgan, who may well be called "the uncrowned King of the realm of Finance," was invited to be a guest at the coming celebration in Charleston of Forefathers' Day. Mr. Morgan has responded to the letter of the President of our New England Society in a letter so warm and kind that The News and Courier has requested the privilege of publishing extracts from it.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13. -- Birch Rod and Gas Lighter were the beaten favorites to-day, and, though both were well supported, the losses on the remaining four events on the card brought the books out losers on the day. M.J. Shannon ran Alcom R. up to $600 and bought him at that price. Summary:

The recent remarkable performances in the stock market have not only placed the speculator on the anxious seat; they have also given a severe shock to public confidence in the sincerity of the big men, the leaders in financial affairs, the men who owing to their position have the broadest view of conditions.

The offer of Mr. MCADOO'S New Jersey Company to construct and operate without cost to the city a subway under Sixth Avenue from Tenth Street to Thirty-fourth Street will be considered again by the Rapid Transit Commission this week. Chief Engineer PARSONS of the Commission, it is known, has made a report favorable to the undertaking.

Assistant District Attorney Rand, who is conducting the prosecution of Nan Patterson, threw a bombshell into the camp of the defense yesterday afternoon, when he laid bare the theory of the State as to the murder of Caesar Yong. This step followed an attempt to prove that J. Morgan Smith, brother-in-law of the defendant, had fled from the jurisdiction of the court.

BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 13. -- A treaty of peace between the Government of Paraguay and the revolutionists was signed last night on board the Argentine warship La Plata by President Escurra and Gen. Ferreira.

The Surety Realty Company has bought 414 Broadway, adjoining the southeast corner of Canal Street, a lot 27 by 85, upon which there is now a five-story building. The company will erect on the site a fireproof store and loft structure, probably six stories in height.

THE TIMES'S editorial this morning relative to the ultimate removal of the elevated railway structures from the streets and also referring to the desirability of a subway along the line of Sixth Avenue is most opportune. Sixth Avenue, from Tenth Street to Thirty-fourth Street, is now one of the most congested parts of the city.

Although Col. Robert Grier Monroe and Attorney Clarence J. Shearn have not yet joined in Controller Grout's movement to investigate the general lighting situation and the held-up bills of the gas and electric lighting companies, Mr. Grout is arranging to go ahead with the proceedings in his office.

With 2,311 sacks of ordinary mail and 35,190 registered packages stored away in the compartments reserved for the American and European mails, the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm II. sailed for Bremen, Germany, via Plymouth, England, and Cherbourg, France, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Much of the ordinary mail and practically all of the registered packages contained Christmas presents.

The third concert of the Kneisel Quartet, given last evening in Mendelssohn Hall, afforded a keen artistic pleasure to the large audience that always greets this admirable organization. Mr. Kneisel's programme contained, as so many of his programmes do, a new composition, one by a young American composer.

Judging by the deliberations of the delegates to the annual meeting of the National League at the Hotel Victoria yesterday, measures will be taken to provide for more friendly relations with the American League in the shape of a post-season series of games between the winners of the respective championships and to avoid as much as possible a conflict of dates.

It has been seven years since "Die Goldne Eva" of von Schonthau and Koppell-Ellfeld was last seen in this city. That fact seems surprising in the light of its reception at the Irving Place Theatre last evening, where almost incessant laughter prevailed from the rising of the first curtain to the final picture.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 13. -- With a roar that could be heard ten miles away, subterranean forces which announced their presence at the first development of the newly discovered oil fields at Humble, Texas, seventeen miles northeast of here, to-day burst through the earth's crust sending clouds of vapor and great stones thousands of feet into the air.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 13. -- In a futile search in this city for Dr. Leroy S. Chadwick the Etoile Belge asserts that it has discovered that his wife left debts in Brussels, notably $18,000 due to a jeweler and $12,000 owing to a lace merchant.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- Charles N. Bulger, Deputy Attorney General, of this city, has announced his retirement from politics, and after Jan. 1 will take up his residence in New York, where he has decided to practice law. It is reported that he will form a partnership with David B. Hill, but Mr. Bulger will not confirm this report.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 14. -- Probably the worst fire that the city of Minneapolis has ever known is now raging here. Already at 12:30 o'clock, three million dollars worth of property has been destroyed, with prospects that the total loss will reach at least five millions.

BOSTON, Dec. 13. -- If Col. Greene had appeared here to-day he would have had a sorry time trying to get near Mr. Lawson. He would have had to pass numerous sentinels and guardians before he got to Mr. Lawson's office, and if he reached the inner sanctum he would have been disappointed.

Braving all the charges heaped up against her in Ohio, confident of her ability to escape punishment before the courts of her home city, and still intimating that every obligation she had contracted would be paid, Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick waived examination here and started for Cleveland at 8 o'clock last night, guarded by two United States Deputy Marshals and trailed by three Federal Secret Service men.
OAKLAND, Cal., Dec. 13. -- The following were the results at the Oakland track to-day:

PARIS, Dec. 13. -- The American Embassy is making urgent representations to the Foreign Office on behalf of American insurance companies against certain features of the Insurance Revision bill, passed by the Chamber and about to pass the Senate.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- Extraordinary precautions were taken by United States Marshal Henkel before he left Mrs. Chadwick in the hands of his Deputy Marshals at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, New York. All her baggage was overhauled and two flasks were taken from a bag carried by her maid as well as a pair of scissors.

Thomas W. Lawson and Col. W.C. Greene yesterday furnished Wall Street a short comedy as an afterpiece to the more or less serious business of the stock market of the last few days. They continued a long-distance duel in which each used some picturesque and emphatic language. But they made no attempt to get at any closer range than the distance between State Street, Boston, and Broad Street, New York.

Subway air was the point of discussion at a meeting of the Advisory Board of the Health Department yesterday afternoon. Those present were Commissioner Darlington, Dr. Edward C. Janeway, who was Chairman; Dr. Bates, Dr. Francis P. Kinnicut, Dr. Abraham Jacobi, Dr. L. Emmett Holt, Dr. Henry P. Loomis, Dr. John A. McCorkle, Dr. T. Mitchell Prudden, Dr. J. Winters Brannan, and Dr. Simon Baruch.

When the Rapid Transit Commissioners meet on Thursday of this week they will receive the report of Albert B. Boardman and George L. Rives, counsel for the commission, who have been at work for some weeks preparing rapid transit bills for introduction in the Legislature at its coming session.

Gradually the decisions of the courts are giving us a body of law defining more clearly than ever before the relations growing out of the new conditions created by organized labor. The latest decision of this character of which we have record was handed down a few days ago by Judge HEBBARD of the Supreme Court of California, in which the legal aspects of a boycott are thus presented:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 13. -- The discovery by Assistant Astronomer J.D. Perrine of the Lick Observatory, California, of a crack or rill which extends lengthwise on the face of the moon through the valley of the Alps for a distance of eighty miles is, according to Assistant Professor W.H. Pickering, Harvard's well-known authority on the moon, "old news."

It is peculiarly unfortunate that Mr. WILLIAMS of Mississippi, the Democratic leader in the House of Representatives, should take the present time, when his party is badly discredited, for proclaiming his belief in some sort of "influence at work to displace Government-provided money by bank-provided money in order to enable the banks to make a profit."

There is the Camera Club of New York and there is the organization of the Photo-Secession, but amateur photographers exist in such abundance that a third society has been formed to appease photographers of the upper part of Manhattan. It bears the formidable title of Metropolitan Camera Club, and boasts that it "occupies 6,000 sq. feet of space in a modern office building in the centre of the residence district of the city."

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 13. -- F.N. Hoffstot, President of the Pressed Steel Car Company, through a representative, denied to-day reports that the Pressed Steel Car Company had been instrumental in loaning money to Mrs. C.L. Chadwick. The denial was as follows:

OBERLIN, Ohio, Dec. 13. -- When the interview had with Dr. Chadwick in Paris was shown to President Beckwith of the wrecked Oberlin bank to-day he scouted the idea that the doctor did not know all about the Carnegie notes.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 13. -- A sensation was created here to-day by the institution of legal proceedings against W.S. Fielding, Finance Minister in the Dominion Cabinet; Sir Frederick W. Borden, Minister of Militia Defense, and eight other leading Liberal members of Parliament from Nova Scotia.

The harsh judgment on the easy complaisance of the bankers who supplied Mrs. CHADWICK with money on shadowy security which would not materialize when it was expected to do so must be tempered by more kindly consideration when her performances in loan negotiation are considered as a whole.

An unusually large number of members of the Automobile Club of America was before City Magistrate Leroy B. Crane last night. They were not there as offenders before the law, making excuses for excessive speeding, but as interested listeners to what the Judge had to say to them on obeying the law and winning the confidence of the Public.

YORKTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- The Palmer House, the most noted hotel in Northern Westchester, is to close its doors next Saturday. The hotel is at the old Croton Dam, and was erected about seventy-five years ago. It has been a famous meeting place of the Westchester Republicans since the party was organized, in 1856.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- In the Smoot inquiry to-day, two members of the Faculty of the Brigham Young University testified that they have sustained polygamous relations since the manifesto of 1890, and a teacher in the public schools asserted that the Mormon Church had its religion taught in such schools.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- The Imperial Commission of consumption experts appointed by the German Government some time ago to investigate the relations between bovine and human tuberculosis bacilli held an important meeting to-day at the Imperial Health Department. Dr. Weber, one of the most eminent members of the commission, reported on the work which that body has already done.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- The stage of the Royal Opera House was piled with wreaths of laurel as Ruggiero Leoncavallo was recalled for the last time to-night after the production of "Der Roland von Berlin." Emperor William stood up in his box and the brilliant audience cried "Bravo!"

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- In a resolution accusing him of "high crimes and misdemeanors" the House of Representatives to-day, setting as a Grand Jury, voted for the impeachment of Judge Charles Swayne of the Northern District of Florida. Five members were appointed by the Speaker to notify the Senate of the action taken by the House, and provision was also made for a committee of seven to present the case to the Senate.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 13. -- Three favorites, two second choices, and an outsider were winners at Ascot to-day. The outsider furnished the sensation of the day. Summary:
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 13. -- The annual meeting of the General Paper Company, which controls sixteen paper mills in Wisconsin and two in Michigan, was held to-day at the office of the company.

BOSTON, Dec. 13. -- The Democrats carried Boston by 20,000 in the off-year municipal election to-day, electing twelve of the thirteen Aldermen and a large majority of the Common Council and School Committee. No Mayor was to be chosen this year.

The dismissal from the Federal service by the Postmaster General of FRANK H. CUNNINGHAM, President of the National Association of Rural Carriers, and JAMES C. KELLER, President of the National Association of Letter Carriers, raises at once questions which involve the rights of Government employes and the scope of the Executive authority.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Postmaster General Wynne to-day announced at the Cabinet meeting the dismissal from the service of President J.C. Keller of the National Association of Letter Carriers, and President Frank Cunningham of the National Association of Rural Free Delivery Carriers. Cunningham submitted his resignation yesterday, but the department declined to accept it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- John D. Rockefeller has presented between $2,000,000 and $3,000,000 as a Christmas gift to the University of Chicago. This statement was made to-day by a member of the Advisory Committee of the Baptist Theological Union. The money, it is understood, is to be used for the creation of a school of engineering at the university.

The Directors of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe announced yesterday that after consultation with large stockholders they had decided to provide for future capital requirements by creating an issue of bonds, convertible into common stock, the total authorized issue of such bonds to be limited to $50,000,000.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 13. -- In the hemicycle of the Hungarian Chamber lies a heap of debris composed of red-cushioned Ministerial chairs, portions of the Presidential tribune, what is left of the Presidential and Secretarial chairs, broken fragments of Deputies' benches, with a few ordinary Austrian bent-wood chairs thrown in.

The militant department of the Professional Women's League went into action yesterday, and for five minutes gave hot chase to a young man fleeing along West Forty-fifth Street. A large and sympathetic company of amateur women looked on from apartment house front windows, emitting pianissimo shrieks of horror, because they thought that the fleeing young man was a baby snatcher. The young man thought so, too -- for a time.

Your editorial of this morning calls attention to the logical results of our National attitude toward our natural wards -- the descendants of our own Southern slaves. But the conclusion which you present in your closing sentence should arouse the most callous of us to the necessity for a prompt and generous attempt to educate and industrially train the mass of our colored citizens.

The interest shown in Berlin in LEON-CAVALLO'S new opera of "Roland" is not likely to be lessened by the fact that the dress rehearsal was conducted by his Imperial Majesty, the Emperor. It is quite conceivable that the composer would prefer his own tempo to that of the Emperor, and may even have views of his own as to expression.

The memorable performance of "Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg," which so stirred the frequenters of the Metropolitan Opera House at its first disclosure at the Saturday matinee a week ago, was repeated there last evening. There was a very large audience that was evidently in a mood to enjoy and to appreciate the remarkable qualities that raise this representation so far above what is usually presented as Wagner's great comedy.
BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- Telegrams received here are to the effect that the agitation in Warsaw continues and that anti-Government street demonstrations occur daily.

Mrs. Caesar Young, widow of the bookmaker who was shot and killed last June, was called to the witness stand yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Rand, who is conducting the case against Nan Patterson, the chorus girl accused of the bookmaker's murder. When the name was called the defendant was plainly disconcerted. She nervous until Mrs. Young appeared, and when the examination was under way avoided looking in the direction of the witness.

While your editorial in to-day's TIMES pointing out the advisability of building subways to take the place of the obsolete elevated roads will receive the indorsement of many of our citizens who have the best interests of the city at heart, it is probable that many years will elapse before the stockholders and the general public will take the same view of the matter.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 14. -- There is no longer any doubt that the Government intends to commit itself to very extensive reforms as a result of the liberal agitation begun when Prince Sviatopolk-Mirsky made his advent as Minister of the Interior.

In your issue of Dec. 7 appears an interview of Mr. Beck, counsel for the Mutual Life Insurance Company, favorably commenting on the suggestion of the President's message that Congress consider the propriety of extending the powers of the Department of Commerce and Labor to insurance, as a large item of inter-State commerce.

The Committee on Contracts will report to the Rapid Transit Commission at today's meeting in favor of granting a perpetual franchise to the New York and Jersey Tunnel Company to build a tube under Ninth and Christopher Streets to Fourth Avenue, and a twenty-five-year franchise for the subway under Sixth Avenue to Herald Square.

The career of L. CLARKE DAVIS was a fine and noble example of a life modestly and unassumingly spent in the public service, but out of the public view. Since 1893 Mr. DAVIS has been the editor of The Philadelphia Public Ledger. He died in Philadelphia yesterday after an illness prolonged through several months.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 14. -- Totness and Aladdin were the only winning favorites to-day. Crimmins, who had the mount on St. Sever, favorite in the last race, was thrown off as the horses left the post, but was not injured. Summary:
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 14. -- President Arthur T. Hadley of Yale, after a rough-and-tumble fight with a beggar to-day, got the better of the man and subsequently caused his arrest.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- The information which I cabled to you on Saturday that the sensational death of M. Syveton, the Nationalist leader, was a case of suicide and not due either to accident or assassination, is now admitted by the family of the dead man.

,.Articles o'f incorporation have been filed with the Clerk of Hudson County at Jersey City/by the North Jersey 'Electric Heat.' .k Light and Power Company tile local offic( being at 15 Excllange Place. The capital stock is $500,000. of which $100,000 hs been paid In. The incorporators are Benjamin F. Treaey, F. J. mtth, ad John O'Regal.

Authorized denial follows swiftly upon the heels of the report that President ROOSEVELT had "agreed to accept railroad rate legislation in the form of a court of inter-State commerce" to consist of one Justice appointed for that service in each of the nine Federal circuits.

Announcement was made yesterday that H.B. Hollins Co. had exercised an option which they had held on a controlling interest in the stock of the Cincinnati. Hamilton and Dayton Railroad. This banking firm was actively identified with the formation of the present system, a property of some 4,000 miles of road, which includes the old Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton and by lease the Pere Marquette system.
TOKIO, Dec. 14, 4 P.M. -- The report of Admiral Togo was received Tuesday night. It is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Judge William W. Morrow of the United States Circuit Court of San Francisco was among the callers on the President to-day. Nothing would be said at the White House about matters discussed by the President and Judge Morrow, but it is inferred that proposed legislation amendatory of the Inter-State Commerce law was the main topic.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 14. -- The Rev. Dr. A.H. Jolly, who married Dr. Leroy S. Chadwick to Mrs. Cassie L. Hoover here, is a cousin of Dr. Chadwick, and says he knows all about the trouble into which Mrs. Chadwick has gotten. He says he does not believe the signatures to the notes and securities given by the woman are forgeries.

The delegates to the National League had a busy day yesterday and completed all the business which was called for at the annual meeting at the Hotel Victoria. As indicated by the opinions of a number of the prominent club owners and others connected with the organization, the delegates voted unanimously for a series of games between the winners of the championship of the National and American Leagues for the world's championship.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 14. -- It was a day for favorites at Ascot, five of them finishing first. Dug Martin, a 100 to 1 chance, came to life suddenly and was only beaten out half a length in the fifth race. Maggie Mackey finished third in the second race, but was disqualified for fouling Ralph Reese, and the latter was placed third. Summary:

-- Being itself a "journal" -- "of civilization," according to its own modest admission -- Harper's Weekly has the right of a near relative to criticise the daily papers, and it does it, occasionally, with the skill and frankness which near relatives are wont to use in expressing their opinions of each other.

Robert Brash, the manager of the estate of C. Poyet Co., candy manufacturers at 414-430 West Thirty-eighth Street, was held for trial in $300 bail yesterday by Magistrate Cornell, in the Jefferson Market Court, for alleged violations of the labor law. At the same time, William Reed, senior member of the firm of Reed Keller, wire designers, of 132 West Twenty-fifth Street, was held in $100 bail on a similar charge.

Both Controller Grout and Commissioner Oakley issued statements last night in regard to the city lighting contracts, the Controller telling of his preparations for investigating the situation and the Commissioner defending his action in making the contracts.

We think that the Committee of Ways and Means, as well as other members of Congress, would do well to consider carefully the statement of Mr. E.W. BLOOMINGDALE as to tariff revision, made in an interview published yesterday in The World. Mr. BLOOMINGDALE is a Republican, a protectionist.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 14. -- Mme. Adelina Patti gave a concert here to-night for the benefit of the Red Cross Society, under the auspices of the Grand Duchess Maria Pavlovna. The concert was a brilliant success, netting over $37,000. Seats were sold at immense prices.

Warren Skillin, in conjunction with L.J. Phillips Co., have sold for Henry Lilly and others two lots on the north side of One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street, 250 feet east of Seventh Avenue, to Joseph Rosenthal, who will improve this plot in connection with the six lots adjoining to the west which he bought a few weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The scene in the Senate this noon, when the House committee to notify that body of the impeachment of Judge Charles Swayne of high crimes and misdemeanors appeared and performed its duty, has made on those who beheld it an impression in which various elements were blended.
OAKLAND, Cal., Dec. 14. -- The results of the races at the Oakland track to-day were:

The establishment of a bank which will be open by night as well as by day is likely to be hailed with joy by those who find it difficult enough to get their breakfast at noon, and usually find 3 o'clock upon them, the usual hour for banks to close, before they are thoroughly launched for the day.

When brilliantly gowned and bejeweled women were alighting from their carriages and tiptoeing across the sidewalk into the Metropolitan Opera House last night, the Broadway pedestrians heard a sudden exclamation from one of the operagoers:

Columbia's fencing handicap meet commenced yesterday and will end this afternoon. Much more interest has been shown this year than ever before. Special medals will be given to the first three men, and F. Lage, 1907, Science, Captain of the team, has offered a pair of foils to the freshman scoring the greatest number of points.

Mrs. Vanderbilt gave a small cotillion at her residence, Fifty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, last evening for her daughter, Miss Vanderbilt. The dance, which lasted until midnight, was proceeded by a dinner, and a seated supper, served at small tables in the ballroom, followed it. After supper came the cotillion, which, in turn, was followed by a buffet supper. Worthington Whitehouse led the cotillion, and the favors were staffs tipped with flowers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Strong evidence to show that polygamy has been countenanced by the Mormon Church since its pretended abandonment in 1890 was offered before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day. Mrs. Fred Ellis of Salt Lake City declared that Abraham H. Cannon, whose plural wife she was, married a Miss Lillian Hamlin as a fourth wife in 1896.

BOSTON, Dec. 14. -- The Clyde Line coasting steamer New York, which arrived here to-day, brought with her Capt. Reemie, his wife, and seven seamen, who were rescued Sunday noon after they had drifted for fifteen hours on a piece of wreckage from the New York bark Emita, which was wrecked Saturday night on Diamond Shoal, off Cape Hatteras.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- United States Consul General Evans at London, in a recent report, discusses British railways as follows:

That Thomas W. Lawson as a factor in the market is still to be reckoned with was shown yesterday when, after ruling strong until the very last hour, prices broke sharply on the report that Lawson would this morning come out with an attack on United States Steel and the Rock Island Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Russia has submitted to the American Government a new form of arbitration treaty which she is willing to negotiate. The Russian draft differs radically from that suggested by Secretary Hay.

I am really grateful to you for your editorial this morning upholding the delightful old custom of "Santa Claus" for children. The idea of its rankling in their minds in after life when the deception has been detected seems to me perfectly absurd. When I look back to my childhood's Christmas faith in "Santa Claus" and his midnight visits, I feel that it is one of the sweetest memories of those days.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 14. -- Reclining on a couch in the wide corridor of the Cuyahoga County jail, and looking the picture of content, Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick was seen by a press representative to-night.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 14. -- Two firemen were killed, three others painfully burned, and property valued at $727,000 was destroyed by a fire which began late last night and was not under control until this morning. The dead are: Jacob F. Miller, insurance patrolman, and John Fellow's, pipeman.

RUSSIAN HEADQUARTERS AT MUKDEN, Dec. 14. -- The dugouts along the front, which in reality are underground barracks, are splendidly constructed, and even bathrooms are furnished. Gen. Linevitch is beloved of all the army on account of his constant solicitude for the welfare of the men. Whenever he finds a soldier without warm clothing he insists upon an investigation on the spot.

Mrs. Rosa Di Pietro, the Italian woman who had been on trial for three days for the murder of her brother-in-law, Michael Rago, who she says threatened to kill her if she didn't leave her husband and run away with Rago, was acquitted yesterday by a jury before Recorder Goff, in General Sessions.

The police say that a man named Davis, a millionaire living in Cleveland, Ohio, lost $24,000 in checks, which were recovered, and $16,000 in cash in a Forty-sixth Street gambling house. A Pittsburg man, at the same time, it is reported, lost $20,000 in checks, which were returned to him, and $8,000 in cash.

According to the Post Office authorities, Christmas contributions to the New Thought Magazine, edited by Sydney Flower, will not reach their destination at 27 East Twenty-sixth Street. The mail for the New Thought Magazine recently was of large proportions, carrying in it many Post Office orders that will not be cashed.

Yale gave a magnificent exhibition of hockey last night at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, West Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue, and by defeating the strong New York Athletic Club team by the score of 4 goals to 3, furnished a decided surprise. It was Yale's first hockey game of the year, and even the friends of the collegians had hardly looked for such admirable team play so early in the season.

Referring to the letter printed in your columns this morning, under the heading, "Dr. Potter on the Old Testament," in which the writer asks, "How, then, can the Bible differ essentially from the sacred books of other great religions?" may I quote a few lines from a sermon by Dr. Momerie of England, to be found in a volume of his sermons, entitled, "Inspiration and Other Sermons"?
LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Commenting on a long special article concerning the condition of the British artillery, The Times will say to-morrow:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- At the request of Secretary Shaw representatives of a number of the leading flour milling interests of the country were at the Treasury Department to-day in conference with the Secretary on the subject of the regulations now in preparation to allow drawback on exported flour made in part from imported wheat.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 14. -- If Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick expected a friendly reception on her arrival in Cleveland, she was doomed to a most bitter disappointment. It is true that a vast crowd, estimated at 10,000 persons, assembled to meet her when her train drew in at 2:15 this afternoon, but it was not a friendly throng.

The "Whole Monarchy" of AustriaHungary strongly resembles the late BARNUM'S "Happy Family" of naturally antagonistic animals, precariously kept in superficial peace by the presence of the keeper. The amiable and now venerable FRANCIS JOSEPH is upon the whole a pathetic figure, since his kingdom has been shrinking in comparative importance ever since he came to it, as for long before.

Yesterday afternoon the Professional Woman's League opened the doors of its annual bazaar in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf. A "give away" bazaar the members call it, for they say there is not much of anything a reasonable man or woman could ask for which is not to be had for next to nothing.

A family living in Vermont removed from their long-time residence to another village, some forty miles away. They took with them a Scotch collie of unusual intelligence, but left behind the family cat. The collie and the cat had been warm friends for several years, and had fought each other's battles with courage and impartiality.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 15. -- A fatal street duel occurred this morning at the little town of Magee, about thirty miles south of here. The combatants were Edward Mangum, a livery stable proprietor, and Mr. Woodward, Principal of the Magee High School. Mangum was instantly killed, while Woodward received wounds from which he may not recover.

ALIBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- Roosevelt's plurality in the State of New York at the last election was 175,552, as shown by the official returns, certified to-day by the Board of State Canvassers. This is 36 less than the plurality given him in THE TIMES'S canvass published last Monday.

Robert Barry won the handicap fourteen-inch balk-line billiard tournament yesterday at the weekly meeting of the Amateur Billiard Club of New York, Seventy-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue. Barry was one of the low-mark competitors, only playing 15 points. He was also the winner in the handicap pool tournament of the club last week.

BOSTON, Dec. 15. -- Col. W.C. Greene of the Greene Consolidated Mining Company, who has been considerably in the public eye this week because of his threats against Thomas W. Lawson, arrived in Boston to-night and took a room at the Hotel Touraine. He denied himself to all newspaper men, and therefore it is not possible to say whether his intentions toward Mr. Lawson are as bellicose as have been represented.

DUBLIN, Dec. 15. -- A meeting of the Irish Parliamentary party to discuss the distress in the west of Ireland and consider means to "force the Government to provide for the immediate necessities of the case and put the Land act in operation in Connaught and other poor districts" was held here to-day under the Presidency of John Redmond.

Tucker, Speyers Co. have sold for Jesse C. Woodhull, to an investor, the new six-story building 574 Fifth Avenue, west side, 50 feet south of Forty-seventh Street, on lot 25 by 100. The price was $350,000. The property is opposite the Windsor Arcade.

A number of proposed changes in the rules of racing now before The Jockey Club, and requiring only the lapse of time provided under the constitution of the organization to be enacted, have been made public. Of those which will affect horsemen generally, the most important are alterations of the rules governing entries, the licensing of trainers and jockeys, and covering cases of error in the running of races.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15. -- A report of the General Athletic Treasurer of Princeton University, made public to-day, shows the receipts and disbursements of the baseball and track associations from Jan. 1 to July 1, 1904. The baseball managers show a net gain of $5,906.41, while the disbursements and receipts of the track association just balanced each other.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Dec. 14. -- Customs officers at Old Point are reported to have seized on board the United States cruiser San Francisco a rich store of smuggled goods, including silks, cigars, china, and ostrich feathers.

The New York Association of Credit Men gave a dinner at the St. Denis Hotel last night at which the guests of honor and chief speakers were Judge George C. Holt of the United States Court for the Southern District of New York; Macgrane Coxe, a referee in bankruptcy for the same district, and William H. Hotchkiss of Buffalo, President of the National Association of Referees in Bankruptcy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- John Nicholson, Chief Recorder of the Mormon Temple, who testified to-day, was the most reluctant witness that has yet appeared before the Smoot committee. He said the records of all marriages in the temple were kept by him, and he could give information on demand, but that unless the person requesting it was entitled to it he would not give it to him.
