In considering the very unsatisfactory arrangements under which this city is now purchasing light for its streets and public buildings, the student of municipal affairs finds himself confronted with another and equally exigent problem, the satisfactory solution of which will also solve that of economical municipal lighting, and which must be dealt with whether that of lighting is or not.
PARIS, Dec. 15. -- It is reported that in addition to the domestic scandal with which he was threatened the late M. Syveton was accused of financial irregularities of a grave character.

The frigate Constellation, oldest of American war vessels -- she celebrated her one hundred and seventh birthday Sept. 7 last went back into commission at the New York Navy Yard yesterday morning. The ceremonies that attended the recommissioning of the old craft were as simple as those that marked her plunge into the waters of the Chesapeake at Baltimore more than a century ago.

More than 200 members of the New York Yacht Club attended the annual meeting last night in the clubhouse, West Fortyfourth Street. Commodore Frederick G. Bourne, Vice Commodore Henry Walters, and Rear Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt were re-elected, and most of the other officials were also chosen for another term.

If the prosecution sustained reverses in the Nan Patterson case on Wednesday it recovered its lost ground yesterday when Assistant District Attorney Rand, who is conducting the case for the State, scored two important points. In the first place he succeeded in placing in evidence the letter written by Mrs. J. Morgan Smith to Caesar Young, which was ruled out by Justice Vernom M. Davis before court adjourned on Wednesday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 15. -- A high personage who attended the trial of Sasoneff, the assassin of Minister of the Interior de Plehve, has communicated the substance of the prisoner's speech, in which he strove to justify his act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- President Roosevelt attended the prayer meeting at the Grace Reformed Church to-night, and at the conclusion of the service made a short address and held an informal reception, shaking hands with his fellow members of the congregation.

The District Attorney began an investigation yesterday of the charge made by James Boyle, a prisoner in the Tombs, in a letter to Mr. Jerome that a policeman of the Tenderloin Station divided the spoils with women who robbed men in the back rooms of saloons. Boyle is charged with robbing a woman known as Dora Havens of $700 worth of jewelry and also a Greenwich Street tailor.

The second annual convention of the National Mosquito Extermination Society got under way yesterday morning in the Aquarium. The evening session was in the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, and there are two more days to come. The first thing the society did was to adopt a new constitution, changing its name by the substitution of the word "American" for "National."

Mr. JACOB H. SCHIFF is obviously as good authority on the interest of railroads in the policy suggested by the President in his annual message as any one in the country could be. In an interview with him published in The World Wednesday morning the following passage occurs:
LONDON, Dec. 15. -- Eleanor Robson's farewell performance in "Merely Mary Ann" at the Duke of York's Theatre tonight was the occasion of a remarkable ovation to the American actress.

William Halpin, leader of the Ninth District, was elected unanimously President of the Republican County Committee, to succeed Charles H. Murray, last night at the Murray Hill Lyceum, George W. Wanmaker took the chair and entertained the nomination of Mr. Halpin by retiring President Murray. Mr. Halpin will also serve as Chairman of the Executive Committee, something unprecedented in the history of the County Committee.

Police Commissioner MCADOO'S plan of relieving the traffic congestion on Fifth Avenue by condemning the stoop line and adding a strip of each sidewalk to the breadth of the street is open to at least two objections: It would deface and degrade the only avenue to which a citizen of New York is now able to point with pride, and the relief afforded would be but temporary.
August Belmont was elected to succeed Marcus A. Hanna as the President of the National Civic Federation at the annual dinner of that organization last night at the Park Avenue Hotel.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15. -- Gus Heidorn and Rankin were the only beaten favorites to-day. Cheatham, who had the mount on Shock the Talent, was severely bruised by the horse falling at the half-mile post. The track showed some improvement, but was lumpy and slow. Summary:

The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday granted to the New York and Jersey Railroad Company, the McAdoo enterprise, a franchise of 25 years' duration to build a tunnel up Sixth Avenue from the terminus of its Hudson River tunnel at Christopher and Greenwich Streets to Thirty-third Street, and a perpetual franchise to build a cross-town tunnel across the city under Christopher and Ninth Streets to Second Avenue.

Figures compiled for The Outlook from what are probably the best sources available show that between Jan. 1, 1902, and June 30, 1904 -- thirty months -- there were killed in strikes 180 persons; injured, 1,651, and arrested for violence or breaches of the peace, 5,533. How these totals were apportioned is shown in the following table:

The suit of Campbell against the City of New York, which has occupied the attention of the courts for more than twenty-five years, has been decided in favor of the city by Judges Wallace. Townsend, and Cox of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.
TOKIO, Dec. 15. -- The commander of the Third Japanese Squadron, reporting at 10:35 o'clock yesterday morning, said:
LONDON, Dec. 15. -- The Times's insurance correspondent says:

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- At a special meeting of the Prohibition National Committee today, Chairman Oliver W. Stewart faced his accusers and replied to their charges made during the last Presidential campaign. He denied every charge and in return attacked John G. Woolley, who led the fight against him.

The Stewards of the Grand Circuit in annual session at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday considered applications for dates in the Grand Circuit schedule of light harness racing from so many tracks that after two sessions the Stewards decided to postpone action until about the middle of January with the view of gaining time in which to look into the claims of some of the applicants.

Gas from a leak in the general supply main at Nassau and Spruce Streets filled the pressroom of THE TIMES, in the basement of the building at 41 Park Row early yesterday morning. Eight pressmen were overcome at their posts before they realized their danger and were carried into the open air by their comrades. Three immediately revived and returned to work.

A woman who said she was Mrs. Clara J. Hibbler Cooke, forty-four years old, of 1,737 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested on a charge of grand larceny in a Sixth Avenue department store yesterday afternoon with what the detectives said was one of the largest collections of assorted merchandise on her person that they had ever seen similarly disposed of.

Miss Maria L. Lagune told Magistrate Ommen in the Tombs Court yesterday that her friend, Miss Cora C. Wilson, who was a prisoner on a larceny charge, had persuaded her to leave her $1,200 jewels at the Wilson apartment over night a few weeks ago, and had kept them ever since. Miss Lagune became tired of waiting, and had appealed to Assistant District Attorney Kresel.

It was learned yesterday that the Washington Life Insurance Company had placed itself in position to satisfactorily adjust such differences as have existed between it and the State Insurance Department, which is now carrying on an examination of its affairs.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 15. -- Mrs. L.M. Kissinger and Mrs. Flora Kissinger, who were formerly employed in the Ohio penitentiary at Columbus, to-day visited Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick in her cell in the county jail and identified her as the woman who thirteen years ago served a term for forgery under the name of Mme. Devere.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15. -- William L. Elkins, the street railway and gas operator and financier, who died in November, 1903, left an estate worth $31,578,268.44. These figures are gleaned from the first account of the executors, Louise B. Elkins, George W. Elkins, John G. Johnson, and Sidney F. Tyler, filed with the Register of Wills at Norristown by Lawyer E.G. Hamerslay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

The opera-loving public turned out in great numbers last evening to welcome Mme. Melba back to the Metropolitan Opera House. She returned after an absence of four years. She began her short engagement there -- four performances being the sum total of her appearances this Winter -- as the heroine of Puccini's "La Boheme," a part which she assumed at the first performances of the opera at the Metropolitan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Philippine Promotion bill passed the Senate to-day by 44 to 23, Mr. McCumber being the only Republican to vote with the Democrats against its final passage.

Senator Depew was becalmed yesterday. He had met Governor-Chairman Odell the night before at the dinner given by Hamilton Fish in honor of Governor-elect Higgins at the Metropolitan Club, and the Governor-Chairman had given him the official version of what occurred at the conference on the Senatorship at the Republican Club Thursday morning.

CALENDARS of this season are remarkable for their freshness, ideas, and their general usefulness and ornamentation, which, in many cases, go far beyond the twelve months through which they are supposed to be worthy of preservation.

This practically is the question raised and discussed by the Hon. John W. Foster in a little volume on "Arbitration and The Hague Court." It is worth noting at the outset that the author is in no sense a "dreamer," a "theorist,'' or a "crank," which are the easy epithets with which it is tempting for practical men to dismiss those who urge upon them the consideration of novel and difficult questions.

"Jackies" from the Brooklyn Navy Yard and a big contingent of Columbia University "rooters" vied with each other last night in an effort to shake loose the roof of the Clermont Avenue Rink with their cheers. The occasion was the first of the Winter ice carnivals of the Brooklyn rink, the sailor boys being scheduled for a championship race, while the Columbia hockey seven faced the Crescent Athletic Club team.

Before the author of "Inner Jerusalem" went to the Holy City some one said: "Do tell people what they want to know. Never mind where Absalom's tomb isn't." You may ignore the sacred influences which pervade Jerusalem and yet there are many vital questions which await an answer. "Is the climate good?

Perhaps it is the intention of the author, expressed in the preface, to make the narrative "strictly veracious, if no more," that accounts for a paucity of incident in the opening chapter, "My First Stag -- And Some Others," which is consequently rather dull. The second chapter, "The Island of Hitteren," is an improvement on the first, and afterward the writer, striking his gait, so to speak, becomes interesting.
MADRID, Dec. 16. -- King Alfonso has approved the new Cabinet as follows:

Referring to Mrs. Elizabeth Custer's comments regarding my forthcoming book "Indian Fights and Fighters," published in your issue of last week, I desire to call attention to the fact that Mrs. Custer's zeal in defense of her husband, which I respect and admire, has led her into error.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- President Cassatt of the Pennsylvania Railroad had a brief conference with the President to-day. He came to Washington to attend a social function, and explained that his call at the White House was simply to pay respects.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Richard Donovan of 2,253 Ogden Avenue told Judge Mack to-day that they had abandoned their baby to the care of St. Vincent Orphan Asylum because they "did not want it."

This is a new edition, in attractive form, of Mr. Mabie's essays dealing with certain writers, with a special eye to their geographical setting, and the effect this setting has upon their work. In each case Mr. Mabie presents his author as in some sort the expression of his environment, and then dwells with a sort of gentle enthusiasm upon that environment as well as upon the merits and virtues of the author.

Justice Jenks of the Appellate Division, Second Department, has just handed down a decision in which he holds that labor unions may, within lawful limits, boycott, strike, and picket. The decision is concurred in by Presiding Justice Hirschberg and Justices Bartiett, Woodward, and Hooker.

One of the most agreeable of our Christmas visitors is a Persian kitten of most attractive personality. It is introduced by Oliver Herford, and its views of life, which are rational, are set forth in quatrains of the form employed by Edward FitzGerald in his version of the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam.

The New York Central Railroad has added to the site of its proposed terminal the two blocks bounded by Lexington Avenue and Depew Place and Forty-third and Forty-fifth Streets, the southerly one of which is covered by the Grand Central Palace. Announcement of the purchases was made yesterday by John N. Golding, who has acted for the railroad company in the buying of all the property for the terminal.
BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- Ruggiero Leoncavallo to-day received the following cablegram from a New York manager:

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 16. -- An adjourned meeting of the St. Petersburg City Council was held to-night for the purpose of discussing the advisability of indorsing the demand of the Moscow Municipality for constitutional reforms.

PERHAPS the title of the volume, "The Adventures of King James II. of England," is a trifle misguiding. The author informs readers that the subject he professes to devote his attention to "is the consideration of the question of the conversion of James Duke of York to the Catholic religion and the many complications which necessarily arose from the change of faith on the part of the heir apparent to the crown."

After laying aside this book one realizes that its principal intention is the worthy one of amusing its readers, and since it is by our motives we should be judged rather than by our deeds, it would be unkind, perhaps, to condemn either Mr. Hamilton or his book, for it is not so unusual, after all, for our best intentions to miscarry.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- The State Civil Service Commission to-day denied the application of the New York City Civil Service Board to place on the exempt list the following positions the creation of which is contemplated, but not officially approved by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment of that city:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- The committee of University of Pennsylvania alumni that has had in charge the building of a gymnasium and the improvement of Franklin Field, in addition to transferring to the university authorities for educational and athletic purposes a plant that has cost nearly $600,000 announces also the erection of a training house and dormitory for university teams and crews, to cost from $40,000 to $30,000.

WE REALLY know very little of that country in Africa called Nigeria. It is something like 700 miles across and about the same in the opposite direction, with the Niger flowing through it. To the right of it the Germans hold the territory, and beyond that is the French claim.

In an editorial on tariff revision in your issue of to-day I find a statement on linen manufacture in this country to which I must take exception, for I am acquainted with the facts. You say that in an interview with a World reporter, Mr. E.W. Bloomingdale (a gentleman for whom I have a high respect) made the following remark: "Previous to 1897 there was no linen huck toweling made in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Associated Press announces the rules for the international yacht race to be sailed off the Sandy Hook course next May for the Ocean Cup offered by his Imperial Majesty the German Emperor. The rules were drawn up yesterday in New York by the sub-committee of the Imperial Yacht Club, consisting of Commander Heibbinghause, the German naval attache at Washington; C.L.F. Robinson, and Allison V. Armour of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Yves Guyot, ex-Minister of Public Works of France, and Theodore Stanton of the American Chamber of Commerce of Paris, called on the President to-day and told him they had succeeded in doing something definite toward establishing in Paris an American commercial centre.

Mayor McClellan took a hand in the lighting situation yesterday when he had the Board of Estimate adopt a resolution asking the Corporation Counsel for an opinion as to the city's power to build an electric lighting plant under the present charter.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The Oxford University Press's publication of the collotype fac simile of the autograph manuscript of Keats's "Hyperion" has been postponed until January in order to allow another manuscript, which came to light recently, to appear as an appendix.

One of the common, every-day errors which is taught in the grammar and common every-day schools in America is that which relates to the introduction into the Western Hemisphere of the African and African slavery. The school histories which the school girl and school boy study say that it dates from 1620 or 1619, when a Dutch sea Captain sold the English settlers the first African.

"How to Know Pictures" might be the name of the new series of primers compiled by Frances Elizabeth Chutter and Eulalie Osgood Grover that they call "The Art Literature Readers," (Chicago: Atkinson, Menzer Grover.) Mrs. Grover has compiled several other similar series -- the "Sunbonnet Babies' Primer" and the "Folk-Lore Series which have had their due meed of praise in these columns.
"The time has come," the walrus said, "To talk of many things; Of slices and ships and sealing wax. And cabbages and kings."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Senator Cookrell has decided to accept a place on the Inter-State Commerce Commission after the 4th of March, when his service as a Senator will end by reason of the unexpected transfer of is State from the Democratic to the Republican column. President Roosevelt offered him the choice of an appointment to the Panama Canal Commission or the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

Those who, two or three years ago, read Miss Gilder's "Autobiography of a Tomboy" will doubtless be glad to read her continuance of that story in "The Tomboy at Work." After her father died Nell was obliged to look for means of earning her own living. She was only fifteen, but possessed of a beautiful self-confidence.

Two judgments have been obtained in this city against the George Bechtel Brewing Company of Stapleton, S.I., one for $1,542 in favor of the New Amsterdam National Bank and the other for 4,647 in favor of Rudolph Schneider on a note of the company dated June 4 and payable four months after date.

This posthumous work of the late Mr Carryl is, like all of his books, a lively tale. Indeed, almost every page has its pun, and for good people who like that style of writing this is just the style of book they will like. But aside from literary gymnastics Mr. Carryl has given in this book a story which, although possessing no unusual qualities, is, nevertheless, readable.

Mr. Belloc's text, with Mr. Chesterton's remarkable sketches, makes a book calculated to give people of cynical tastes much malicious satisfaction. Mr. Belloc relates in a tone of mock complacency the history of a British merchant of the most British old school, and how he was led into the larger ways of high imperial finance, and incidentally into ruin.
BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- "Each gentleman has a perfect understanding of the other's position, and there is nothing further to state of public interest."

The State Historical Society's museum has just received from the Misses Rebecca Lewis Potter and Fanny Potter of Lake Beulah some exceedingly interesting relics of their father, the late John F. Potter, who in war times was known the country over as "Bowie Knife" Potter. In 1860 Mr. Potter was a member of Congress from the First District of Wisconsin. A fellow member was Roger A. Pryor of Virginia.

Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes having died and come to life again, and then retired from view, behold, for a new "sensation," a revival of She Who Must be Obeyed. Yes, Rider Haggard's wonderful heroine, she of the many incarnations, of the prodigious experience, of the stupendous beauty, has broken out in a new place. The sequel to "She" begins as a serial in the January number of The Popular Magazine.

Magazines, particularly those with a restricted field, are frequently hard put to it for "original" features, "something distinctive," as the advertising agents express it. Periodicals devoted to architecture and interior decoration have followed the practice, for many years, of picturing and describing the dwellings (mansions and palaces) of comparatively few lucky human beings which their editors have considered models of taste and beauty.

Several interesting questions touching the relations of neutral nations to the war in the Far East have either actually arisen or are clearly impending. The question of the Black Sea Fleet is the most conspicuous of these. It is quite true that this question has not been formally raised by the Russian Government, but it has been so freely agitated by the Russian press that it can hardly be dismissed as academic.

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- Emperor William's advisers deemed it better that the transatlantic yacht race should be entirely under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Yacht Club of Kiel than have either the New York Yacht Club or the Atlantic Yacht Club participate because of the unpleasant feeling between them.

THE French invention and the English perfecting of a thin, almost opaque paper has enabled publishers to issue long classical novels in little 16mo volumes, often reaching 1,000 pages, but never more than one inch in thickness. What for years have been known as the "Dent Classics" have been offered through this medium.

The tone of the market yesterday was decidedly encouraging to the bulls. There was pronounced strength in the standard issues, and, while activity was not great, it was evident from the character of the trading that the big interests were once more interested in advancing the market. Union Pacific, which has led every real advance in prices for some months, was conspicuous.

The Central Realty Bond and Trust Company has sold, through L.J. Phillips Co., to the Fleischmann Realty Company the block bounded by Wilkins Place, Boston Road, Charlotte Street and One Hundred and Seventy-first Street, part of the Bathgate Beck property, recently purchased by the Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company.
Whether Mr. DEPEW or Mr. BLACK will go to the Senate after March 4 is the question with which the "organization" wrestled at its conference with the Boss-Governor on Thursday.

It xvill be entitled Tile Garden Magazine, and will relate the things done each month In reference to gardening, and will be sent to subscribers two weeks before the first of the month.

It might seem disrespectfully paradexical, on the eve of the centenary of Lord Beaconsfield, to assert that had he not loved a peacock waistcoat he would never have shone in literature. Yet it need imply no lack of appreciation of Disraeli's genius. It is a fact that iridescence, both in coloring and in expression, pleased him.

The latest work published under the direction of the State Historian is "New York and the War with Spain." Mr. Hugh Hastings gives a most interesting history of the Empire State regiments. As guardian of the sacred relics of the past he recommends greater care in the preservation of our State battle flags.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Senator Platt did not seem to think that the conference of Republican leaders yesterday, at which a large majority favored Black for Senator, gave any decisive indication of the result.

There are at hand revisions of these of Baedeker's guidebooks -- United States, Paris, and Italy, (Scribner's.) No guidebook of Italy can be written without being overshadowed by the huge bulk, historically and architecturally, of Rome. So though one of Baedeker's four handbooks on Italy treats almost exclusively of the ancient city, yet even this volume, "Italy from the Alps to Naples," is largely taken up by the seven hills of Rome.

John Lane is issuing a new novel by the Earl of Iddesleigh, author of "Luck o' Lassendale," which bears the title, "Charms; or an Old World Sensation." The story runs during the time of George II., and the King plays a considerable part in it. It gives picture of the King's life at court, and in the country strongholds of the Stuart of position.

Is it practicable to insure all the deposits in all the banks under the National Banking law without cost to the depositors, and with no greater cost to the shareholders of the banks than would be offset, or more than offset, by the increased stability of business and by the insurance against panicky withdrawals?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Representative Livingston of Georgia introduced a resolution to-day requesting the Secretary of Agriculture to forward to the House all data upon which the last report on cotton acreage and production was made.

THE Christmas season is at hand, and how fortunate will be both the giver and the receiver of books which enchant the home and fascinate the imagination with exalted and beautiful suggestion and vision.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Mrs. Thomas C. Platt, wife of Senator Platt, entertained this afternoon at a tea at the New Willard. The guests were welcomed in the large parlor on the second floor, which, with an adjoining apartment serving as a tearoom, was gorgeously decorated with American Beauty roses and chrysanthemums, with a background of tropical green.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16. -- J.W. O'Neill was the only beaten favorite to-day, and the fact that the colt showed soreness going to the post and that Gannon took him through the worst of the going, accounted satisfactorily for his defeat. J.W. Schorr bought Lady Fonse from H. Martin at private sale for $1,000. Lady Fonse was run up $600 and Aladdin $300 after their races today.

Many, if not most, of those who have ventured an interpretation of Rudyard Kipling's beautiful story have linked it with the "Brushwood Boy" and "The Finest Story in the World," by its fancied mysticism.

WE LEARN that the fifteenth volume of the Library Edition of "The Works of John Ruskin," edited by E.T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn, (New York: Longmans, Green Co., subscription issue,) will be ready for distribution between now and Christmas.

TWO nice little books which have the extra attraction that they come in a box together are "The Story of Little Jack Sprat," pictured by Frank Adams, and "Christmas at the Zoo," illustrated by Harry B. Neilson, with verses by William Boyle, (A.C. Armstrong Son.)

A woman known to the police as "Suicide Kitty" visited Roosevelt Hospital yesterday, but not as a patient, as three physicians in the operating rooms soon discovered. She first met Dr. Peabody. The woman said she wanted to see a certain patient, but didn't wait for a reply. She let fly with her fist, and Dr. Peabody went down.

THE Century Magazine for January will have a leading article from the pen of Randall Blackshaw, in which the author will attempt to prove that the recent architectural development of London, although not so conspicuous as that of New York, is none the less significant.

This is a pleasing little story, as readable as it is improbable. A young man, after resigning from his regiment in the West, travels abroad to see the world. What he sees of most importance, however, is a beautiful young woman on the return steamer, and, although he never speaks to her en route, he worships from afar.

Herr Bilse, formerly a Lieutenant in the Prussian Army, who may be remembered as the author of the book criticising German militarism, the title of which is "Auf Einer Kleiner Garrison," has just completed another novel. It was principally written last Summer while he was the guest of Mr. John Lane of Bodley Head.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 16. -- From now until the time of Mrs. Chadwick's arraignment in court all visitors will be excluded from her cell by order of Judge Wing. Even her son, Emil Hoover, and her maid, Freda, will be denied access to her except when armed with a written order from United States Marshal Chandler.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- At the concluding session of the fourth annual conference of State sanitary officers this evening, Dr. H.W. Wiley, Chief of the Bureau of Chemistry, United States Department of Agriculture, denounced the use of coal-tar dyes for coloring butter, saying that, while many of them have no direct poisonous effect, their continued consumption overburdens the kidneys.

CHE-FOO, Dec. 16. -- Seven Russians in civilian garb, but obviously military men, arrived to-day in an open sailboat. They brought a large number of dispatches. They were unwilling to talk, and went immediately to the Russian Consulate. A high wind enabled them to make a quick passage from Port Arthur.

"Peace for all Nations" is the motto inscribed on the American flag, bordered with white, which is the emblem of the American Conference on International Arbitration. At the meeting held last night at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of its New York Executive Committee for the purpose of urging the ratification of arbitration treaties recently negotiated between the United States and other powers, and now pending before the Senate, that sentiment furnished the leading thought.

My previous letter, in which I pointed out the fact that the heroine of "The Eagle's Shadow" had no particular claim to toleration, much less respect, seems to have aroused a hornets' nest. I stick to my colors, and I would leave the decision to any fair-minded person were it possible to quote here a few specimens of Miss Hugonin's language in her moments of irritation.
RUSSIAN HEADQUARTERS, Mukden, Dec. 16. -- There was considerable desultory firing on both sides to-day. The Japanese made an advance, but it proved to be only a demonstration.

Despite the enthusiasm aroused in American automobile circles in connection with the Vanderbilt Cup road race, and notwithstanding the assertion confidently made at that time that the entries from this country for the Gordon Bennett race would be at east double the number received last year, only three entries have been made, showing no advance in numbers over those of a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- A hearing on woman suffrage was given to-day by the House Committee on Election of President and Vice President. It was on the French bill providing for woman suffrage in elections for members of Congress, and Mrs. C.B. Colby of Portland, Oregon, made an argument for it, in the course of which she said:

The old house at 23 Bond Street, which figured in the romantic life of Eliza Ann Partridge, was sold at auction yesterday in the County Court House, the sale having been ordered by Francis N. Burdick, Special Master in Chancery, in a partition suit brought in the United States Circuit Court. The house was purchased by the defendants in the suit, who bid $44, 600 for it.

That the Rapid Transit Commission should grant the application of the New York and New Jersey Railroad Company to build and operate a subway in Sixth Avenue was well-high inevitable. No municipality would refuse an offer fraught with such visible public advantage, and which encountered substantially no objection from any disinterested source.
By the universal approval of marriage in the first instance, it is conceded that the married state is best for the individual and for society at large.

No doubt many of your subscribers besides myself have read with interest your review of Anthony Hope Hawkins's new book. And this leads me to suggest to them the perusal of "Quisante," one of his earlier works, in which surely he shows as "subtle and refined" an art as regards "psychological analysis" as any lover of character drawing could desire.

The unanimous and even enthusiastic election of Mr. AUGUST BELMONT to the Presidency of the National Civic Federation, an office made vacant by the death of Senator MARCUS A. HANNA, is a gratifying indication that the work of that body commends itself to the approval of men of affairs who are much too busy to have leisure for dilettante trifling with economic and social problems.

I have been greatly interested in "The Castaway" and its growth into popular favor. It seems to me, however, that it is high time to point out its limitations as a document of Byroniana. There is a tendency to take its side of accuracy far too seriously.

PRETORIA, Dec. 16. -- Two thousand burghers attended an impressive religious service this morning prior to the burial of Mr. Kruger. Several ministers of the Dutch Church spoke, all eulogizing the ex-President for his exemplary religious life and as a lover of his people and exhorting the Boers, while remaining loyal to the new flag, never to forget the principles of their late leader or their own language.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The appeal of the United States against the decision of the Justice of the Crown at Quebec in the case of Greene and Gaynor came up before the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The first witness in the Senator Smoot inquiry to-day was Mrs. Annie Elliott of Price, Utah. She is an elderly woman who went from Denmark to Utah in 1872 and left the Mormon Church in 1896. She was asked concerning the obligations taken in the temple and was requested to repeat as much of the ceremonies as she could remember.

In the discussion of Central Park not enough consideration appears to have been given to the fact that it is now, and in the future is destined to be in still higher degree, an obstacle to the free development of important sections of the east and west sides, which it practically cuts off from intercommunication.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- By purchase from the State of New Jersey the United States has acquired an extensive plot of ground just north of Ellis Island, New York Bay, on which a new island will be constructed and utilized as a part of the Ellis Island immigration station.

Clifford L. Miller, through his attorneys, Miller, Miller Storm, is waging a fight against the city in an effort to make the city restore Cromwell's Creek to its original depth of thirteen feet and make it a real waterway again. Cromwell's Creek to-day at low tide is navigable only by rowboats, and is making all sorts of trouble for passengers on the New York Central.

Abraham Levy, leading counsel for Nan Patterson, with Henry Unger and Daniel J O'Reilly, his assistants, yesterday had a long conference with their client in her cell in the Tombs relative to the course to be pursued by them when the case is called again to-morrow. A decision was reached, which, it is understood, will result in the placing of defense witnesses upon the stand, including the defendant herself.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 17. -- Everything is in readiness for the beginning of the ice-yachting season on the North Shrewsbury River. The Ice Yacht Club has been busy for a week getting the boats ready for the coming contests, and the indications are that the coming season will be the liveliest in the history of the sport here.

THE holiday times bring to those of us whose memories go back a half century or more thoughts of the days before the civil war, when life was so different from that in the hurrying world of the present. I was born in the South. My father, Mr. Devereux, owned a large plantation on the banks of the Roanoke River, in North Carolina.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- The Railroad Gazette, in its current issue, says:

I WAS walking down town the other day. My mind was free from care, and my heart was really very light -- for me. You see, I had not seen Hopkins for nearly a week, and I was getting to feel quite emancipated. It was as though somebody had removed a ton weight from off the region of my chest -- you knew the feeling. I dare say.

Within the last month the Rev. Dr. William T. Manning, vicar of St. Agnes's Chapel in West Ninety-second Street, has refused twice to become a Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, preferring to become assistant of Trinity Parish under the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, with the certainty of two centuries of precedent that he will succeed to the rectorship of the parish.

The announcement of a 4 per cent. interest rate by nine savings banks, with the authoritative expression of opinion that the majority would follow the example, was the event of last week of largest permanent importance. Its interest is far from being confined to the depositors of the institutions concerned.

In a recent issue appeared a communication signed "Safety," in relation to the danger to pedestrians by the rapid driving of vehicles around the corners. The writer states that they have an ordinance in San Francisco requiring vehicles to slow down to a walking gait in turning corners, and suggests that it would be well to have a similar ordinance in New York.
BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- The composer Leoncavallo to-day asked me to deny empratically the reports in foreign papers that Emperor William was responsible for some of the scenes in "Roland of Berlin."

A good many newspapers, among them our neighbor The Tribune, are quite unable to accept our view that the President has exceeded his authority in the order of Jan. 31, 1903, forbidding employes of the Federal Government to solicit the influence and the votes of members of Congress in support of measures giving them higher pay. The Tribune says:

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 17. -- A conference lasting for over four hours was held in this city to-day between representatives of the cotton manufacturers and their striking operatives, but no agreement was reached, and a settlement of the great strike, involving 26,000 mill hands, appears as distant as ever.
TOKIO, Dec. 17. -- The following dispatch was received to-day from the Jaupanese army before Port Arthur:

MALONE, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- Eighteen cents was a verdict awarded by the County Court this evening to William G. Rockefeller of the Standard Oil Company. This tiny sum, however, represented a very considerable victory for him, as it established a case of trespass against Oliver La Mara, an aged Adirondacks guide, who for years has claimed a right to fish upon Mr. Rockefeller's great park in the Adirondacks.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 17. -- Guests at the Hotel Rudolf in future will be entertained by daily concerts, arrangements for which have been completed between Proprietor Charles R. Myers and Signor Oreste Vessella, Director of the Royal Italian Band, which for the past two years has played on the Steel Pier.

The season of outdoor speed skating was opened yesterday in heroic style on Woodland Lake, at Woodland, by the Ardsley Skating Club, when in the face of untoward conditions, the full introductory programme of the organization was decided, on a course that was absolutely new to public competition.

Patrick Curran, thirty-six years old, a chauffeur, living at Eighth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, was held in $500 bail for good behavior for six months by Magistrate Cornell, in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning, on a charge of disorderly conduct. The prisoner was arrested Friday night by Policeman Forbes of the East Thirtieth Street Station after a chase on Thirty-fifth Street near Broadway.

Inclosed herewith please find a copy of the report of Mr. Albert E. Little, a well-known competent accountant of this city, on the financial condition of the company, which is self-explanatory, and which I submit for your information. Yours truly, GEORGE W. DUNN, President.
IS the United States destined to become the greatest maritime power in the world?

When Harry Wellington Wack of London and New York heard that District Attorney Jerome would not be able to discuss indicting Thomas W. Lawson until to-morrow morning, he took another whack at Lawson through his lawyer, Charles Maitland Beattie of 116 Nassau Street. Whack said, per Beattie, that he would get out a warrant for Lawson in case Mr. Jerome wouldn't arrange for an indictment.

UNGRACIOUS, indeed, would be the spirit of the reviewer who failed to find some cause for satisfaction in the success achieved by Mr. C.M.S. McLellan's "Leah Kleschna." Nor is it likely that any one who has the good of the native drama sincerely at heart will begrudge Mr. McLellan his good fortune.

In a decision written by General Appraiser McClelland, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by Poneet Neeser of New York against the assessment of duty at the rate of $2.50 a dozen pieces as "partly manufactured women's gloves of lambskin" on certain merchandise which the importers claimed to be dutiable as gloves tranks at $1.875 a dozen pairs.

Three persons were killed and seven injured in a fire that started at 6 o'clock yesterday morning in a three-story furnished-room house, at 184 South Ninth Street, Williamsburg. The house was owned by Mrs. Sarah Paynter. The dining room and kitchen were in the basement, and the parlor floor was occupied by Dr. Mortimer G. Burford as an office and sleeping apartment.

Christopher Fagan, among the last of the old-time squatters on the up-town rocks, was evicted yesterday. Fagan's home was on St. Nicholas Terrace, Manhattanville, where he lived with Spruce, his Newfoundland dog. His home was as neat and clean as a lady's parlor, although it was made of odds and ends, chiefly sheets of tin, carefully soldered together so that it was waterproof and warm in the most severe weather.

"Die Walkure" was produced for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon before one of the largest matinee audiences that have so far been seen this Winter. The first reproductions of the later Wagnerian dramas, and especially of the "Nibelung" dramas, are always an occasion of eager expectation and of some solicitude to the great public for which they are the highest and greatest sources of musical enjoyment.

Twelve of the most skillful trap shooters in the country visited Bay Ridge yesterday by invitation of the Crescent Athletic Club's shooting contingent and participated in several events, chief of which was a competition at 100 targets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- More important testimony was brought out to-day in the investigation of protests against Senator Reed Smoot than at any time in the present session of Congress. The witnesses were: John Nicholson, Chief Recorder in the Mormon Temple at Salt Lake City: Charles H. Jackson.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- Sir Chentung Liang-Cheng, Chinese Minister to the United States, to-night addressed the American Academy of Political and Social Sciences on "China's Traditional Policy." He said in part:
THE largest public school in the world was opened Dec. 12 -- a school so large that it covers the greater part of Manhattan Island.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Some questions relating to the construction of the Panama Canal were brought to the attention of President Roosevelt to-day. Representatives Humphrey and Jones of Washington called at the White House to lodge a protest with the President against the shipping of lumber from the Puget Sound territory to the canal zone in German vessels.

ROME, Dec. 17. -- Manfredi, the architect, author of the report on the condition of the Basilica of St. Mark's, Venice, is now in Rome, and has written to the Italia, saying that the measures proposed in the report are sufficient to prevent the damage becoming worse, adding that urgent and indispensable work has been going on with great activity and care since last June. The funds on hand are almost sufficient to complete it.

With the advent of Winter the fencers have begun practice for their season of competition, which will begin early next month and will last until the end of April. Busy scenes are to be witnessed on "club might" at any of the local fencing organizations, when the veterans gather to measure their skill and to get into condition for the many inter-club contests which are such a feature of the sport.

DENVER, Dec. 17. -- Chief Justice Gabbert to-day announced the decision of the Supreme Court to throw out the entire vote of three precincts of Ward Five and one precinct of Ward Seven at the late election on the ground that gross frauds were committed in direct violation of the injunction served upon the election officials.

"The Pike" was snowbound on its trip from St. Louis to this city. So it was not put on view at the Madison Square Garden yesterday as had been expected. Such visitors as braved the storm to see its curios found instead a barred door, and no notice that the opening was postponed until Monday, and went away growling.

A.W. McEwen, a paper manufacturer of Whippany, N.J., went to the West Thirtieth Street Station last night and told the police that he would pay $5,000 to know how two thieves got away with his wallet on a Sixth Avenue car.

According to a statement given out yesterday by Commissioner William Harman Black for the Commissioners of Accounts, C.I. Robert Grier Monroe, while the head of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity under the Low administration, certified to bills of an electric lighting company twice, and Controller Grout paid them twice as well as omitting to deduct the percentage of reduction due to the city.

MODERN fashion in pictures has deserted the paintings which tell some story and has turned its favors and face toward those from which all anecdote is absent, landscapes that express by color and composition an intangible beauty akin to music, figure pieces in which the human form is employed for decorative effect, while the color scheme affects the nerves like subtle odors.

The United States naval supply steamship Culgoa, at present in West Indian waters, is in the midst of one of the strangest voyages ever undertaken by an American war vessel. The mission of the Culgoa is the transportation and delivery to every naval vessel in the South Atlantic of Christmas supplies sufficient to furnish for every officer and man a substantial repast next Sunday.

Protests have been received by city officials in the last few days against a "proposed city ordinance" requiring all disorderly women to wear stuffed birds or feathers on their hats. This culminated yesterday when a letter reached the City Hall from Mrs. Frances W. Graham of Lockport, President of the Women's Christian Temperance Union of the State of New York.

GALVESTON, Texas, Dec. 17. -- Charles F. Dodge, over whose requisition there has been much litigation and numberless entanglements, left for New York to-day. He went on board the Mallory Line steamer in charge of United States Marshal Hanson and three deputies.

It is doubtful if THE NEW YORK TIMES, with all the glory of its old regime, has ever been so conspicuously an exponent of the conservative, substantial forces of New York as it is to-day. By leaps and bounds, almost by a flight instead of by steps, it has more than regained all the previous prestige that attached to its name.

ROME, Dec. 4, 1904. THE season has begun in earnest Parliament was opened by the King, who drove in gala to the Senate House, which is called Palazzo Madonna. Grenadiers lined the streets, and the Royal Horse Guards surrounded the King's carriage. Every man of this superb corps is six feet tall or over, and the uniform is beautiful with the richness and taste that Italians understand so well.
THE American woman has made a new conquest. This time it is no less a person than Alfredo Edel, who stands in the very front rank of the costumers of the Continent.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 17. -- While riding with the foremost of thirty members of the Watchung Hunt Club, who were following the hounds near this city here this afternoon, William D. Phillips of Glen Brook, Conn., suddenly threw up his hands and fell from his horse. The pace was lively, and the horses of several men and women riders who had been following close upon him trampled on the prostrate form of Mr. Phillips.

Students from a dozen High Schools and a number of athletes from the College of the City of New York for the special events competed last night at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, in the second annual championship indoor meet for High Schools, held under the auspices of the Public Schools Athletic League.

We have not shared the alarm which the Debs vote has produced in the minds of some of our contemporaries. In the first place, the vote of Mr. DEBS'S Socialistic Party was not 600,000, as first reported. THE TIMES'S figures of the total vote published last week show 392,857 votes for DEBS. The Rev. Mr. SWALLOW, the Prohibitionist candidate, polled 248,411.

That the abuses introduced in the foreign exchange brokerage business by the small speculators who have entered that market has reached serious proportions is evidenced by the fact that plans have recently been discussed by some of the most influential bankers in the city to put an end to the activities of this undesirable element.

The destruction of the steamboat Glen Island, in the night, on her trip from New York to New Haven, emphasizes the lessons of the Slocum disaster from which it differed essentially only because the Glen Island was not crowded with excursionists. It had only ten passengers, and most of these were saved by the lifeboats, thanks to the timely help of craft which picked them up.

Real estate men, mechanical and electrical engineers, and construction representatives assembled at Forty-third Street and Sixth Avenue yesterday afternoon and watched with keen interest the setting of the first of what are said to be the four largest trusses ever placed in a building in the United States. The truss was hoisted to its position in the New York Hippodrome.

THE protected cruiser Tacoma, one of the five trim sister-ships of the second-class cruiser type that have recently been added to the American Navy, is in New York, after one of the most remarkable voyages ever made by a man-of-war of any nation. Since she went into commission last Spring, this natty-looking, double-funneled little fighter has traveled over 20,000 miles.

Chatting over their after-dinner cigars and laughing at each other's jokes as though friendship were a thing apart from political animosity, Senator Chauncey M. Depew and Gov. Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., transformed into at least a temporary love-feast the dinner held last night to celebrate the twenty-fifth year of the Republican Club of New York.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- The Troy Times, which is the recognized exponent of the views and intention of ex-Gov. Black, published in its last edition this afternoon a double-leaded editorial one column in length declaring that Mr. Black would be a candidate for election by the State Legislature to the United States Senate. The editorial starts thus:
When your readers have read my appeal, I am bold to assert they will conclude you have not done amiss in granting me a brief space in your valuable paper.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, which yesterday began hearing the appeal of the United States against the decision of the Justice of the Crown at Quebec in the case of Greene and Gaynor, adjourned at the conclusion of the arguments to-day. Judgment will be rendered on Monday.

MR. COLONNE had his own way and conducted music of which he is an ardent admirer, in Brahms's Fourth Symphony that appeared upon his second Philharmonic programme yesterday and the day before. His reading showed not only love for the work, but a keen sense of its beauties and a very definite and carefully studied conception of it.

The Board of Governors of the recently formed Junior League of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum is reaching out for a large membership. The league has been formed for the purpose of aiding the Hebrew Benevolent and Orphan Asylum in this city, and more particularly to assist in caring for the children after they leave that institution. Any unmarried person is eligible for membership. The annual dues are $5.
The coming week promises to be as gay as that just past. There are several dbutante receptions, while dances and theatre partl2s %%-ill be a feature. f..
We are glad to note the progress made in Washington toward the passage of the bill better to define and protect the rights of authors in foreign languages in the translation of their works.
LONDON, Dec. 17. -- There was no great demand for money in the market to-day. Rates would have been easier, but the outflow to the provinces maintained quotations. Discounts were firm.

PARIS, Dec. 17. -- Great activity is manifested in official and diplomatic quarters in connection with the opening next Tuesday of the sessions at the International Commission which is to inquire into the North Sea incident.

The announcement last week that the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe would issue $50,000,000 in convertible bonds was received with mixed feelings by the financial community. It had been expected that some further capital issues would be made by the company, for in the annual report intimation of such requirements had been frankly made, and it was there set forth that the road had only some $5,600,000 in bonds left for purposes of improvements.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- Miss Mabel Clarke, the pretty twenty-year-old daughter of Mayor Henry S. Clarke of New Rochelle, a popular society girl and accomplished musician, is to become a trained nurse, according to an announcement here to-day. She will enter St. Luke's Hospital on Jan. 1 next for a probationary course.
I beg to call the attention of philanthropic people to the fact that the League of American Sportsmen is in need of funds properly to carry on its work of game protection.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 17 -- To avoid the crowd that would have assembled at the Government Building on Monday, the day fixed for Mrs. Chadwick's arraignment, President Beckwith and Cashier Spear of the Oberlin bank and the woman were taken before united States Judge Wing today.

It was only by the barest chance that large gold shipments to Europe were not made on yesterday's steamer, and the outlook is that the coming week will see large shipments of the precious metal. In fact, the exchange market is above the gold shipping point and all that is needed to allow gold to go is proper shipping facilities.
LONDON, Dec. 17. -- After three weeks' trial a jury in the Central Criminal Court to-day found Ernest Terah Hooley not guilty and Henry J. Lawson guilty of obtaining money under false pretenses.

E.M. Tobias won the handicap pool tournament that was finished at the Amateur Billiard Club of New York yesterday. There were twenty-two competitors in the tournament, and Tobias played in every round, as he was never fortunate enough to draw the bye. Baron Lothar von Koppen, a German nobleman and a skillful wielder of the cue, finished second to Tobias, whom he met in the final round.
In a recent issue "Observer," after commenting with approval upon a sermon on manners by the Rev. Dr. McConnell, adds:

Referring to your editorial on the President's order of Jan. 31, 1902, prohibiting Government employes from soliciting aid from Congress to legislate in behalf of their welfare, except through the heads of their respective departments, I would like to state that this order would be more reasonable and just if both parties (employes and the executive departments) would hold good faith to it.

The sharp fall in the stock market in the price of the shares of the United States Leather Company which followed the announcement of the plan for a complete financial reorganization of the concern reflects the opinion of the speculative element regarding that plan. It was hoped that on closer examination the plan would prove more acceptable than the stock market's judgment would indicate.

BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- The British steamer Gordon Castle, which arrived from Ceylon to-day, had one of the worst passages in the experience of her officers. Gales from southwest, northwest, east, and northeast, with fearful seas, were encountered, and last Sunday the steamer was struck by a hurricane, and for twenty-four hours was hove to with the seas raking her decks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- United States Commercial Agent Price at Jeres de la Frontera, Spain, sends some interesting figures in the sherry trade. He says:

AFTER one has whipped the Beaverkill for trout or angled in the rolling and breaking surf for striped bass other piscatorial sport seems tame, so when a friend recently asked me to go with him to the fishing banks outside of Sandy Hook, I was inclined to refuse.

In the list of awards in the fine art department of the World's Fair at St. Louis there is no mention of Great Britain in her usual place alphabetically between Germany and Holland. Prizes have gone to Canadian artists, but none to British, except "commemorative honors" to the managers of the British exhibit, some of whom happen to be painters.

THE TIMES of the 10th inst. reported that a movement will be launched to raise a fund for the relief of destitution in Japan caused by the war by the reading of an appeal in the Sunday schools throughout the country.

UPPER BROADWAY and Fifth Avenue stores catering to fine retail trade are offering exceptionally interesting collections of merchandise adapted as presents for the sterner sex during the Christmas season. These displays are characterized by elegance, richness and exclusiveness, appealing to the artistic sense as well as to luxurious purse.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17. -- The Crocker Selling Stake was the feature of a good card at Oakland to-day. Letola and Gold Money, from the Jennings stable, were the favorites. Ananias set the pace, but three furlongs from home Letola assumed the lead, winning by a nose from Military Man. The race had a value of $3,190, the winner's share being $2,590. Summary:

The necessity of compulsory, and not merely voluntary, international arbitration was urged by the Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, pastor of the Synagogue Shearith Israel, at Seventieth Street and Central Park West, yesterday, before a large congregation.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 17. -- El Tiempo, the leading clerical newspaper of Mexico, has made a bitter attack on Gen Powell Clayton, the American Ambassador, because in a recent public address he congratulated President Diaz on the impending monetary reform in Mexico. The Clerical organ calls Gen. Clayton's remarks "officious," and declares that he committed a breach of international etiquette in making them. Continuing, it says:

The official fielding averages of the American League for the season of 1904 place the Chicago team in the lead with a percentage of .965. New York, Boston, and St. Louis are a tie, with .961, and then follow Detroit, with .960; Cleveland, .959: Philadelphia, .958, and Washington, .951. La Chance of the champion Bostons leads the first basemen, making but 16 errors in 157 games and having an average of .991.

The remarkable developments of the last year and a half along Fifth Avenue between Thirty-fourth and Forty-second Streets, as well as the fact that operators have begun recently to do considerable buying in the side streets in that neighborhood, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, have served to attract a greatly increased amount of attention to the block just south of the new Public Library site.

PARIS, Dec. 17. -- Great precautions continue to be taken in Poland to prevent the real situation provoked there by the Russo-Japanese war from becoming known to the outside world, and nothing has been made public through official channels, but according to trustworthy correspondence received here by prominent members of the Polish colony the situation is an awful one.

There was two buying movements upon the Stock Exchange yesterday. One of them was brought over from Friday, and was sufficient to tempt profit taking until the bank statement appeared, when there was more strength, followed by later softness. It may have been more profit taking, or perhaps a bear raid upon a yarn regarding Mr. Harriman's decease.

A WIFE WITHOUT A SMILE," Pinero's new comedy, will be presented to-morrow evening at the Criterion Theatre. Mr. Charles Frohman, under whose direction the play is to be produced here, announced a day or two ago that the so-called "mechanical doll incident," which has created no end of comment in London, will be omitted.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17. -- Spencerian's inability to shoulder top weight in the heavy going tells the story of the running of the Crescent City Handicap to-day. The game mare with a record of twenty-four wins this season was always favorite in the betting with Luralighter, to whom she was conceding 18 pounds, second choice.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17. -- Two favorites, Capitanzo in the second race, and Schoharie in the sixth race, were the only ones that won at Ascot to-day. Summary:

Immediately after the first of the new year, acting under the directions of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, Bridge Commissioner Best will have the department engineers draw up plans and specifications and make borings for the proposed Hendrik Hudson Memorial Bridge over the Harlem River from Inwood to Spuyten Duyvil.

Fog and snow in the harbor and snow on land made yesterday one of the dreariest and most uncomfortable days that New York has experienced this Winter. The day dawned clear, and until a little before 2 o'clock in the afternoon conditions were pleasant. Then the skies became overcast, and soon a blinding snow was upon the city.

It is quite natural to feel, as Mayor McCLELLAN declared at the arbitration meeting on Friday evening, that there are some questions which cannot be arbitrated, while it is important to do all we can to secure arbitration for as many questions as possible. But it is obvious that what we accomplish will depend a good deal on the point from which we approach the matter.

The market has shown during the week most substantial signs of increasing strength. If there has been a very decided and greatly to be desired decline in the volume of Washington Heights and Bronx speculation, there has been a corresponding increase in operations affecting high-class properties, which aside from its immediate importance augurs well for business of a similar class after Jan. 1 and throughout the early Spring.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- There has been a remarkable spread in the religious revivals which were started at Bolton, Lancashire, on Sept. 4 of this year by the Rev. Reuben A. Torrey and Charles M. Alexander, both of whom are from Chicago.

A few days ago there was held in this city an important conference of financial men interested in the business of large corporations, among them being the President of a prominent railroad with Eastern and Far Western connections, for the purpose of discussing the possible evils in the handling of enormous amounts of money for corporation purposes in the hands of a limited number of individuals.
London, Nov. 24. HAVE you ever been to America?" demanded a little man, who, along with fifty or sixty others, was listening to a free trade speech in Hyde Park yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Joseph F. Proffit, Consul at Pretoria, in a recent report gives figures on the population of the Transvaal. He says:

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- Testimony by laboratory experts in the United States Commissioner's Court to-day in a hearing on criminal charges brought out the assertion that certain drugs sent about the country by alleged fraudulent mall order men endanger public life and health.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Japan's tobacco monopoly is dealt with in the annual report of United States Vice Consul Sharp at Kobe, recently received. The law relating to the monopoly of leaf tobacco, he says, was promulgated in March, 1896. This law provided that all leaf tobacco grown was to be bought by the Government and in turn sold to the manufacturers by the Government at a fixed rate of profit.

RESIDENTS near Broadway and Fifty-eighth Street have for some time past been attracted each Sabbath morning by a kaleidoscopic procession of many complexions and persuasions wending toward a demure brownstone building at 226 West Fifty-eighth Street, which is down on the city map as Genealogical Hall.

A varied and interesting array of programmes has been announced at the Metropolitan Opera House. There will be two performances of the favorite prima donna, Mme. Melba. "Parsifal" will, as usual, be a feature of the week, and "Faust" will, for the first time during the present season, be interpreted; to the classical, the revival of Beethoven's "Fidelio" will probably outshine in significance all that has preceded it this season.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 17. -- Lakewood, as usual, will be crowded with visitors over the holidays. Christmas at Lakewood is an outdoor festival. For the golfers there are the usual Christmas competitions at the links of the Pine Forest Golf Club and the Country Club of Lakewood. The sportsmen betake themselves to the Country Club traps for the regular Christmas sweepstakes, an event which always draws a field of crack marksmen.

IT IS the week before Christmas, but New York is by no means as quiet as the house in the traditional nursery poem. There are a number of important events on the calendar, including some large private dances and dinners, and there are yet a few debutantes who are to be brought out.

" Forefathers' Day" was observed by the New England Society of New York by attendance at the Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, last evening. A tribute to the Puritans was paid by the minister of the old church, the Rev. Dr. Donald Sage Mackay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Prof. Graham Bell has lodged with the State Department a protest against the action of certain hotel keepers in Cape Breton, Canada, in refusing to entertain his valet during the professor's travels in Canada last Summer. The valet is a negro named Thompson. While at Sydney last Summer Thompson applied to several hotels before he could secure accommodations.

Senator Platt arrived from Washington yesterday to plan with his followers to accomplish the re-election of Senator Depew if possible. He went to the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where he expects to confer with the men favorable to the Depew candidacy. Senator Platt intends to meet Gov. Odell, also, but it is said that whether the Governor will go to him or he will have to go to the Governor has not developed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Secret Service detectives are at work on clues that seem to show that Mrs. Chadwick has been a smuggler of diamonds. Treasury authorities say they have received authentic tips that she brought in large quantities of diamonds on which she evaded payment of duties.

Your report of the late City Club meeting where Col. Monroe made a set attack upon the lighting companies and I made a short reply, was unjust to me in stating a half truth which, as is so often the case, was an error.

When the city awoke yesterday morning it was arrayed in a new and pretty thick suit of white. The snow that began falling shortly after 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon kept on without interruption until early yesterday. The fall was 7.8 inches, making it the heaviest so far tills season, and bringing the total up to 21.9 inches, according to the Weather Bureau records.

Mr. LINN BRUCE'S suggestion at the meeting on Friday in favor of arbitration that the best guarantee of peace is the power of the combined British and American Navies is perhaps not so paradoxical as at first sight it seems. It is at any rate true that the recent dispositions of the British Navy indicate that the British authorities fear no trouble in the near future from America or from France.

Twelve-Bore McTavlsh, the Kipling of the battleship Texas, now at the navy yard, boarded the office of THE TIMES at eight bells last evening and spun this web of maritime history to the ship news man:

The funeral of PAUL KRUGER naturally and almost necessarily became the occasion for an impressive statement of the problem of South Africa from the point of view of the Afrikanders. This result was precipitated by the publication for the occasion of what may be called the ex-President's political testament There was no matter for surprise in this document.

The bill of Senator GALLINGER, which was introduced a year ago and has just been favorably reported without amendment, to secure a forest reserve in the White Mountains of New Hampshire, seems to be a careful and well-considered measure, and certainly has an excellent object.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- In the opinion of John F. Wallace, Chief Engineer of the Isthmian Canal Commission, a sea-level waterway across Panama, although it would cost far more and take a much longer time to complete than the three other canal projects, would in the end be the best.
Policeman Fannon of the Bedford Avenue Station, Williamsburg, may find himself called up for clubbing William Whitman, a bookbinder, twenty-nine years old, of 596 Manhattan Avenue, yesterday morning.
For the benefit of an impartial judgment and "altera pars" you will be certainly fair enough to give space for a few little remarks in reference to your article headed "The Hungarian Bear Garden."
ST. PITERSBURG, Dee. 18. -- The dispatches from Gen. Stoessel to the Emperor which were received on Friday night were given out to-day.

With the Harlem River filled with ice almost from bank to bank not a single crew ventured from any of the local rowing club houses yejsterday, and the attention of the oarsmen turned to handball and to bowling, the two indoor sports upon which they rely to keep in condition during the Winter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- " Why don't you write poetry any more."

Carl Schurz made all address to the twelfth annual meeting of the Educational Alliance last night in which he advised the Jews to be less clannish. If this advice were followed, he said, the pretext -- there was no reason -- for anti-Semitic feeling would be lessened.

The snow-covered drives of Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday furnished opportunity for a gala occasion to horsemen, and the streets and roads were crowded from early until late with sleighing parties. In the morning the Harlem River Speedway was the centre of attraction, the roadracing brigade turning out in full force with fast steppers hooked to featherweight speed cutters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Under a recent decision as to the Government wireless telegraph system all reports of observers of coastwise phenomena in currents and winds are made to the Weather Bureau.

Athletes at Harvard University are much interested in the dinner to be given to all holders of the 'Varsity "H" in the Union, at Cambridge, to-night. Fifty-seven undergraduates and a large number of prominent graduates have been invited, and an informal organization, like the University Club of several years ago, will be formed.

NEW WROCHELLE, Dec. 18. -- The Winter session of the People's Forum was opened here to-day with a debate on the subject, "Should Religious Instruction Be Given in the Public Schools?" W. Bourke Cockran took the affirmative and President J.G. Schurman of Cornell spoke for the negative. President Finley of the College of the City of New York presided.

I was interested and enlightened by the comment on T.W. Lawson that appeared in Tuesday's issue. It had been a matter of wonder to me why THE TIMES had ceased its comments on Lawson's articles, also why the flamboyant, though interesting, advertisements that appeared in other newspapers were not to be found in its columns.

The Socialists in the Central Federated Union found a new weapon against the non-Socialist delegates at yesterday's meeting of the central body in the fact that the dinner of the Civic Federation last week was attended by a large number of union officials, including President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor.

Half a dozen detonating caps containing a powerful explosive, such as are employed in blasting operations for exploding dynamite, a quartet of small boys, and a nail figured in an experiment on Saturday evening which caused a panic in the apartment house at 302 East Seventy-third Street. Three of the boys are in bed badly hurt.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Dec. 18. -- The four-masted schooner Lizzie H. Brayton, from Lambert's Point, Norfolk, Va., for New Haven, laden with coal, lost her way in the snowstorm early this morning and came ashore at 2 o'clock south of the Stratford Hotel in Point Pleasant. The vessel is thirteen years old, and was in excellent condition.

President ROOSEVELT and all Republicans of light and leading have repeatedly declared that the tariff, if it is ever revised, must be revised by its friends. The Hon. GEORGE RAINES, author of the odious vice-compelling law which bears his name, declares that if it is to be amended the work must be done by its friends.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- The Times in its financial supplement to-morrow will say:
MOSCOW, Dec. 18. -- This city was the scene of a revolutionary demonstration to-day from noon till nearly evening. Probably five thousand people actually participated in it.

Over a course ankle deep in untrodden snow sixteen members of the Mohawk Athletic Club of the Bronx competed in the monthly handicap cross country run of that organization yesterday afternoon. The course was from the clubhouse at One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Street and Walton Avenue, up Walton and Girard Avenues to One Hundred and Eighty-fifth Street and return, finishing at One Hundred and Sixty-first Street and Girard Avenue, a distance of about five miles.
ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 18. -- The disturbances so far reported to-day were confined to Moscow.

Robert Baeckelein, a Swede, twenty-six years old, of 149 East Fifty-fourth Street, was held in $2,000 bail for examination tomorrow by Magistrate Barlow, in the Jefferson Market Court, yesterday morning, as a fugitive from New Jersey.

Harry Taylor, a colored chauffeur, who was up before Magistrate Hogan in the Harlem. Court yesterday for speeding, blamed the snow. He was arrested at Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Fiftieth Street by Bicycle Policeman Kennison, who said that Taylor had been running his machine at the rate of twenty miles an hour.

Max Jacoby, who said that he was a shipping clerk for a Broadway house, and lived at 817 Fifth Street, appeared in the Yorkville Court yesterday morning as complainant against William Brown, a clerk at the Puritan Hotel, Bowery and Houston Street, whom he charged with grand larceny.

Robert Hunter, President of the Child Labor Committee, and head worker of the University Settlement, received the privilege of the floor at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union to talk on the alleged failure of State Labor Commissioner John McMackin to enforce child labor and factory inspection laws.

While hundreds were flocking yesterday to the Long Island shore, near Glen Cove, to see what little was above water of the hulk of the steamboat Glen Island, which was burned on Saturday morning with a loss of nine lives, there were made public at Washington a number of important changes in the rules of the steamboat inspection service.

In to-day's "Topics of the Times" of comment upon the fact that the tendency, of the public in general is to regard the financial methods of the remarkable Mrs. Chadwick as an "enormous joke," while her victims receive no sympathy; which you consider "a bad state of affairs."

BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- A storm which nearly reached the proportions of a hurricane swept over Southeastern New England to-day. The snowfall, especially along the coast from New London, Conn., to Cape Cod, was unusually heavy, while a wind velocity of sixty miles an hour was reported at Block Island, R.I.

CHE-FOO, Dec. 18. -- Commander Mizzeneoff, who was Executive Officer of the Russian battleship Poltava until that vessel v. as disarmed, and who on Dec. 15 headed the party of seven Russians who left Port Arthur in a sailboat and arrived here Friday with dispatches, said to-night in an interview that Port Arthur was a desolate and, save for the firing of guns, a silent place.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 18. -- Expert hydrographers are attempting to solve the problem of the Gulf Stream current, which practically holds up ships bound south in passing Hatteras, and hurries on their way all vessels bound north.

There is undoubtedly a good deal of truth in the plea for the city as against the country made by President FINLEY in his address of Saturday at the Cooper Union. It may be a rather strong statement, that.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 18. -- It has been known here for some days that the Secret Service men were investigating, at the instance of the United States Treasury Department, to discover If the duty was paid on jewelry, especially diamonds, that Mrs. Cassie k. Chadwick brought over with her on her many trips to Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Determined opposition to the proposed reduction of the duty on sugar and tobacco imported from the Philippines has developed among those interested in the production of these commodities in the United States. It is known that President Roosevelt and Secretary Taft are anxious that Congress at this session shall pass an act to abolish the duties on all products imported from the Philippines with the exception of sugar and tobacco.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 18. -- " There are ten potatoes which cost me $120, and you will find them in this box," said Reuben Martin to Capt. Harmon at Police Headquarters to-day as he dropped a paper shoe box on the Captain's desk. Martin, who is a negro, was accosted on Thursday by another negro, who asked him if he knew Charles Johnson, also colored.

An old couple, Bridget and Michael McGuire, aged sixty-six and sixty-eight, respectively, appeared before Magistrate Mayo in the Yorkville Court yesterday morning charged with vagrancy. For a long time the aged woman said she and her husband had been living comfortably in a little room at 318 East Seventieth Street.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 18. -- The Textile Council voted to-day to submit an arbitration proposition for the settlement of the strike in the cotton mills to the individual unions, and in case of their approval, by a vote on Tuesday, to ask the Civic Federation to choose a board of arbitration.

In this column were recorded last week the results of the philanthropic effort of a gentleman in Boston to save the community from loss in the stock market. The result was the most serious fall in prices witnessed this year, and it continued through a second week. Last Week 113 stocks moved a point or more, and only 23 of them rose.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 18 -- Miss M. Norma Clarke, an actress with the Alvin Stock Company here, had a narrow escape from death to-day. T. Edward King of 412 Hanover Street, Baltimore, who says he is her husband, tried to shoot her in the parlor of the Bachelor Hotel, where she is stopping, but was foiled by a detective, who knocked him down when he pulled his revolver.
