VVEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 18. -- An ingenious cadet in the United States Military Academy recently tapped a telephone wire running past his window, and for some weeks carried on daily conversations with his sweetheart in a far-away city. Of course, he had to have a secret arrangement with the "Central" operator here, and the money for long-distance calls was supplied from home, contrary to the rules of the academy.

LOGANSPORT, Ind., Dec. 18. -- The shortage in the accounts of Elder Frank Obenchain, Treasurer of Cass County, has proved so much more extensive than at first supposed that it now threatens not only the bankruptcy of his dozen bondsmen, but the financial ruin of three or four business firms.

The Children's Aid Society appeals to the men and women of this city for substantial assistance to enable it to bestow Christmas comforts upon the needy children who are under its care. The enrollment in the industrial schools of the society is nearly fourteen thousand. Among these the society hopes to satisfy, in some degree at least, a craving which at this season is well-nigh universal.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18. -- After a year's visit to the land of the Eskimos, Capt. Christian Jensen of the cryolite bark Silicon arrived last night at his home here. The homeward trip from Ivigtut Bay, Greenland, began on Oct. 4.

Douglas Robinson, Charles S. Brown Co., have sold for the Presbyterian Hospital the northwest corner of Park Avenue and Seventy-first Street, 86 feet on the street by 102.2 on the avenue. The buyer will erect high-class dwellings-on the plot.

Agreeing with "Caesar" that a couple having demonstrated that they are unable to live together in peace and happiness should separate, I contend the point that it should be made less difficult to procure a divorce. The very idea that a divorce is easily procured increases the unsettled conditions of married life and makes man and wife restive under the restrictions that come to all married people.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 19. -- One of the financial novelties of Aiken, the Winter resort of many New Yorkers, is the Union Trust and Safe Deposit Company. This institution was chartered about five months ago, and shortly afterward the office was fitted out with most elaborate banking fixtures. Behind the institution is said to be Mrs. Cora Wilson, who is believed to be the woman now in trouble in New York.

The Christmas holidays are at hand, and from 10,000 apartment and tenement houses hordes of children will again this year be forced from sheer necessity into our already overcrowded avenues to indulge in games and sports natural to their age.

The City Committee of the Citizens' Union, adopted resolutions last night favoring an extension of municipal control of public utilities, a municipal lighting plant, purchase of electrical conduits in Manhattan and the Bronx, the building of pipe galleries in connection with extensions of existing subway routes, and with future routes, and the granting of power by the Legislature to the city to build and operate lighting plants, gas, and electric.
PITTSBURG, Dec. 19. -- According to John B. Cunningham, National Bank Examiner for Western Pennsylvania, the National banks here hold no Chadwick paper. In a statement to-day Mr. Cunningham said:

It is gratifying to read of the efforts of the Health Department to secure a better control of the milk supply of our city. The plan of inspection of dairies, shipping stations, and other sources of milk supply is the proper step toward checking the evil of impure and adulterated milk.

Senator Platt has issued over fifty invitations to his friends up State to meet him in conference to-morrow at 11 o'clock to discuss the election of a United States Senator to succeed Senator Depew. He said last night that Governor-Chairman Odell had not yet obtained a majority of the Republican members of the Legislature for Black, and that Senator Depew's friends would go into the caucus if they only had two votes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- In its annual report, transmitted to Congress to-day, the Inter-State Commerce Commission refers to the two principal objects of the act to regulate commerce, the publication and observance of tariff rates, and the correction, on complaint, of established tariff rates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The powers given the Commissioner of Corporations under what is known as the Publicity clause of the act establishing the Department of Commerce and Labor are to be put to the test first against the Beef Trust.

ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- Governor-elect Higgins arrived here early this morning from his home in Olean and, besides announcing the composition of his military staff and completing arrangements for his inauguration, he held conferences with several State officers, with whom he discussed, prospective legislation to be recommended in his message to the Legislature.

Mr. HENRY H. ROGERS has caused the American News Company to be notified that that company and its officers will be held liable for the circulation of the January number of Everybody's Magazine, in which, according to the letter of Mr. ROGERS'S lawyers, "is included an article by THOMAS W. LAWSON, entitled 'Frenzied Finance,' containing grossly libelous statements concerning Mr. ROGERS amounting * * * to criminal libel."

From Metropolitan sources of information yesterday it was learned that the Metropolitan interests, under the advice of John B. McDonald, will favor the running of the proposed east side Subway up Third Avenue instead of Lexington, as had been considered by the Rapid Transit Commission.

We feel some hesitancy in commenting upon such passages as are sent by press correspondents as representative of a long and elaborate address upon any subject, especially upon a theological subject. For the correspondent naturally and rightly seizes upon the most striking and sensational passages of the address, of which the context might show that it is not really representative.

Mayer Cohen, thirty-five years of age, a theatrical man, who said that he is living with relatives at 321 St. Nicholas Avenue, walked into the West Thirtieth Street station last night and told Capt. Cottrell that he understood that there was a warrant for his arrest.

Coach Yost of the University of Michigan favors changes in the football rules, and has devised a working plan for Walter Camp's suggestion of ten yards to a first down. He contends that the rule might be made effective provided the rules governing the attack were changed so as to make it possible to gain the necessary distance for a first down.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The inaugural ball ran against a snag in the House to-day. Mr. Morrell of Pennsylvania asked for the adoption of a substitute for the Senate resolution, allowing the use of the Capitol Building for the ball. The Senate resolution provides that it shall be held in the Congressional Library.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 19. -- Four witnesses were heard to-day in the bankruptcy proceedings against Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick, after which the hearing was continued until to-morrow, when Receiver Nathan Loeser hopes to have the woman present. Mrs. Chadwick's appearance will depend on a report to Referee in Bankruptcy Remington as to her physical condition.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Eugene G. Hay, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by Meyer Lange of New York against the classification as non-enumerated manufactured articles, at 20 per cent., of certain meat and vegetable tablets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The President has nominated the following principals and alternates for examination to fill the two vacancies for midshipman at large, which occur in 1905:

E.J. Ridgway of the Ridgway-Thayer Company, publishers of Everybody's Magazine, made public yesterday this communication, which, he said, had been forwarded to his company by The American News Company:

That the demand for gold for export is not likely to cease very soon is evidenced by the fact that reservation was made yesterday at the Assay Office by Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co. of all the gold bars that may be prepared next week, Lazard Freres having already engaged the output of the present week.

Four, and perhaps five, men lost their lives on the Standard Oil barge No. 91, which burned off Lonog Branch Sunday afternoon. The news that the barge had been burned up was brought to port Sunday night by the steamship Baker, but the fact that lives had been lost was not known until yesterday, when the report of the Captain of the towing tug Standard was made public by the Standard Oil Lighterage Department.
TOKIO, Dec. 19. -- The Japanese fired an immense mine under portions of the north fort of East Keek-Wan Mountain yesterday afternoon.

If by any possible arrangement the last act of Arthur Wing Pinero's comedy, "A Wife Without a Smile," could have been played first, the audience at the Criterion Theatre would no doubt have found it far more entertaining than was the case last night. That third act is deliciously funny. It is compounded of farce, burlesque, and satire in about equal measures.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19. -- Two out of six favorites won at Ascot to-day, the other races going to second choices or well-played outsiders. Kenilworth showed a sudden recovery of form in the third race and led his field a merry chase from start to finish, covering the six furlongs in 1:13 3/4. Weather clear; track fast. Summary:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections today, during the Smoot investigation, evinced interest in statements by A.C. Nelson, Superintendent of Public Instruction for Utah, concerning the use of school buildings for the teaching of the Mormon religion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- A scramble for traction shares almost obscured the trading in Industrials on the Chicago Stock Exchange to-day and resulted in an advance of 9 points in West Chicago Street Railway. North Chicago cerificates advanced from 82 to 87 1/2.

The new code of rules relative to steamboat inspection must be judged with relation to the fact that there cannot be an immediate and sweeping condemnation of wooden steamboats without putting the public to an inconvenience greater than would be approved by public opinion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Government made a step forward to-day in its long fight to get George W. Beavers to Washington. On motion of Solicitor General Hoyt the case was advanced by the Supreme Court and set down for Feb. 20, after the hearing of the causes regularly set down for that day.

Hermann Sudermann's "Sodom's Ende" was presented at the Irving Place Theatre last evening by Mr. Conried's stock company. The play has been seen here a number of times before. In "Sodom's Ende" one finds a not altogether convincing study in which the beatific conditions of home life are contrasted with those which prevail where there is merely a seeking after worldly pleasure.

-- A correspondent very solemnly takes us to task because we called attention -it was very, very gently, by the way -- to the fact that the letter of another correspondent was not a model of expression. "Your sarcastic remarks," he says, "aimed at what you evidently considered poor composition, do not seem to me to be either explicit or courteous.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19. -- But for Pawtucket's stumble at the post in the first race, which unseated Jockey Phillips, and the latter's bungling role on Trapper in the third race, the favorites would have had much the best of it to-day. Swift Wing, the third beaten favorite, had the worst racing luck, meeting interference at every stage of the journey. Summary:
Red tape on Ellis Island will bring an unhappy and miserable Christmas to a lonely Scotch lassie, Sarah Agnes MacGill, who came over to this country on the Lucania a week ago last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The strange omission of the name of Representative Gaines of Tennessee in the House reports thus far this session is not due to any change in that gentleman's habits. It is due to the fact that Gaines has been sick.

About ten thousand New Yorkers, most of them young women, attended the Maniature World's Fair Show at Madison Square Garden last night, and "did the Pike," as they called it in St. Louis. It was a good-natured crowd that guyed the Filipinos who had been loaned to the show managers by the Government, joshed the Eskimos, and had a heap of fun with the Japanese acrobats.
It is a pretty mean show the tobacco raising and tobacco manufacturing organizations are making of themselves in their opposition to the reduction of duty on tobacco from the Philippines.

TOKIO, Dec. 19. -- Although accustomed to hearing of acts of bravery on the part of their soldiers and sailors, the people of Japan have been thrilled by the details of the desperate torpedo attacks against the Russian battleship Sevastopol and other craft driven outside of the Harbor of Port Arthur by the fire of the Japanese land batteries.

The work of removing the snow from the City's streets was continued uninterruptedly yesterday, and late last night Superintendent of Snow Removal Mortimer D. Bouton said that excellent progress had been made. All of the principal thoroughfares, he said, were practically clean, and traffic on them was not noticeably delayed.

George W. Kirschoffer made his third and successful attempt to kill himself yesterday in his rooms at the home of Mrs. Margaret Greene, 30 East Third Street. He would have been seventy-one years old to-day. Within the past year he had told his friends that a man ought not to live over the Biblical period of threescore years and ten.

The week's business did not open with a continuance of Saturday's late drive at the market. On the contrary, the opening was rather more cheerful than the close, the earlier business being motived by the denial of Saturday's canard regarding Mr. Harriman's health, and the failure of the attack upon Steel from Boston.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- A conference was held to-day in the office of the Secretary of Commerce and Labor on the question of changes in the Steamboat Inspection Service. The participants were Secretary Metcalf and steamship men from different parts of the country. It is said that there was nothing in the nature of a protest by the steamboat men. They will have until Jan. 16 to file suggestions or objections.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 20. -- According to correspondents with the Japanese, the capture of the Keek-Wan fort was a complete surprise to the Russian garrison, there having been no preparatory bombardment.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 19. -- Contrary to general expectation, Emperor Nicholas's name day was not signalized by the issue of a manifesto on the subject of reforms. The manifesto is now expected to-morrow.

TOKIO, Dec. 19. -- Hannah, daughter of Viscount Aoki, ex-Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Count Alexander von Hatzfeldt-Traehenberg, an attache of the German Legation here, were married to-day in the Catholic Cathedral, which was crowded with prominent Japanese and members of the Diplomatic Corps.
BOSTON, Dec. 19. -- Samuel Untermyer, who arrived in Boston late to-night, said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- James W. Buck of Portland, Me., was presented to-day to the President by Representative Allen of that Slate. Mr. Buck is 75 years old. He knew Speaker Reed when the latter was a boy, and always remained his fast friend.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20. -- Mansard won the handicap at Oakland to-day from Venator in an exciting finish. In the first race The Cure easily outfooted Dora I, to the wire. The Cure opened at 4 to 1 and was played into favoritism. W.R. Condon, at even money, made a poor showing in the second race, and finished among the tail-enders.

Dog owners of the Bronx opened their first bench show yesterday under the auspices of the newly organized Bronx Kennel Club in Zeitner's Morrisania Park, Third Avenue and One Hundred and Seventieth Street, where it will continue until Friday. Some 200 dogs were shown, almost every breed being represented, while in some of the larger classes the competition was very keen.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 20. -- The delay in the issuance of the imperial manifesto outlining reforms has led to the wildest rumors, according to which Emperor Nicholas has turned back on the idea of making any concessions, the immediate downfall of Interior Minister Sviatopolk-Mirsky is imminent, and the prospective nomination of Lieut. Gen. Kleigels, Governor General of Kieff, as his successor, may be looked for.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 20. -- Attorney F.A. Schofield of Hannibal, Mo., appointed to take depositions in the suit of a life insurance company of New York to cancel the $200,000 policy held by the late James L. Blair of St. Louis, former general counsel of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition Company, began the taking of testimony at the Federal Building to-day.

Prior to the conferring of Statehood on Utah, and as a condition of its admission to the Union, a prohibition of polygamy was adopted into the Constitution of the new State, and the Mormon Church forbade further plural marriages or a continuance of the polygamous relation. That the compact made with the Nation by Utah and the Mormons has been flagrantly violated is notorious.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 20. -- "Jimmy" Britt of this city defeated Battling Nelson of Chicago on points to-night after twenty rounds of the hardest and fastest fighting that has been seen here for a long time. The boys battled for what was regarded as the lightweight championship, and the condition of each was superb.

BROOK HAVEN, Miss., Dec. 20. -- Lincoln County Whitecappers, in the cases that have attracted attention all over the country, lined up in the Circuit Court to-day and received sentence from Judge Wilkinson, whose severity surprised the whole of Mississippi. The Judge imposed one life sentence, five of fifty years, one of twenty-five, and several of twenty years' imprisonment.
The first plan for the reorganization of United States Leather was a failure, and the new plan has yet to receive approval.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 20. -- A general meeting of the hardyarn spinners of the South has been called to be held in Charlotte Jan. 5, when matters of vital interest to the trade will be considered.

The very amusing account which we printed yesterday of the tribulations of Mr. WARE in trying to get a fair day's work for a day's wages out of his subordinates in the Pension Office carries a serious moral. The moral is that in the capital of the United States there obtains precisely the lowest and meanest standard of public service which is to be reckoned with in any American community.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 20. -- J.H. Wilson, who was a member of the Republican National Committee in 1896, to- day said regarding Thomas W. Lawson's charge:

President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard University, in an address on the subject of "The University and the Ethical Problem for Our Time," at the dinner of the Quill Club, last night at the Hotel Manhattan, declared that while the forces for good in the world are constantly overcoming the forces for evil, new evils are continually arising in a new form.

Because, it is thought, he did not receive money to buy Christmas presents from the executors of his father's estate in Germany, to which he would have fallen heir within a few months, Leo Bubel, who is said to have been a cadet in Germany, twenty-three years old, shot himself in the right temple last night at his home, 330 East Seventy-second Street.

So far from preventing the circulation of the January number of Everybody's Magazine, H.H. Rogers's warning to the American News Company seemed only to stimulate its sale yesterday, everybody being curious to read the installment of Thomas W. Lawson's "Frenzied Finance" which had at last stirred Mr. Rogers to action.

Business upon the Stock Exchange continues to lose in volume and gain in quality. There is less pressure for either account, and more evidence of business based upon current facts than upon current literature. As literature, whether of fiction or the drama, appreciation of yesterday's installment should be upon no grudging scale.

International Mining, Smelting, Refining and Development shares were floated in the curb market yesterday, and though the boom in the security and the pricking of the bubble came all in a day, there was but one victim of the vast speculation. He was a new-comer on the curb, Isaac Siegle, a brother-in-law of a curb broker with some experience, but no heart.

Nan Patterson, the chorus girl accused of the murder of Caesar Young, bore herself bravely on cross-examination yesterday and did not falter a single time under the fire of Assistant District Attorney Rand's pitiless questioning. She was on the stand for two hours and a quarter.
Your editorial of Dec. 10 on "Subway and Manhattan" has attracted great attention among real property owners.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission, as was to be expected, puts in an emphatic claim for the power to revise and fix railroad rates, subject to review by the courts, but obligatory until reversed by the courts. There will be a strong movement, sustained by several extensive organizations of shippers, to secure the passage of a bill to this effect this session.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 20. -- The finish of Diamente, the winner of the last race, was the stirring feature of the racing at Ascot to-day. From a position behind a field of seven into the stretch Diamente made the greatest finish ever seen on the local track, and won the race from Heather Honey, the favorite, which had a lead of two lengths over the field at the head of the stretch.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Sitting cozily in her flat in Washington this afternoon, Mrs. H.L. Van Matre attended the Baltimore wedding of her daughter, Martha Louise Van Matre, to Harry Underhill Walton of Washington. Mrs. Van Matre was confined to her room by illness and could not go to Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The luxuries of American civilization extended to him through the solicitude of the American Government have not tended to increase the usefulness of the Filipino as a soldier, according to the annual report of Gen. Wood, commanding the Department of Mindanao, just made public by the War Department.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 20. -- Denis Donohue, reputed author of several articles in The New York Commercial attacking some of Mr. Lawson's mining properties, has so stirred Mr. Lawson to anger that to-night Mr. Lawson prepared an advertisement defending his properties and addressing Mr. Donohue in most vituperative terms. This advertisement was telegraphed to New York newspapers for insertion in the morning.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20. -- Telescope and High Wind were the only winning favorites at the Crescent City Jockey Club's track to-day. The card was ordinary and the sport rather tame. Summary:

Labor unions in the building trades have united to bring a test case in the courts as to the right of the Building Trades Employers' Association to demand that as the price of their employment they shall join unions which have the sanction of the association and that they shall sign the arbitration plan.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 20. -- Capt. Wessels of the schooner Mary Champion, recently engaged in the oyster trade in Maryland and Virginia waters, was arrested at Onancock, Va., on the charge of cruelty to members of his crew, received a hearing at Norfolk to-day, and was held for trial.

Sheriff Erlanger opened the first game of the Amateur Hockey League championship series last night at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, West Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue. He made a brief speech from the balcony to a crowd that occupied every seat and made available standing room scarce, and then threw the puck down upon the ice.

The Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday handed down a decision sustaining protests by O.G. Hempstead Sons of Philadelphia and defining clearly the rights of importers in the matter of countervailing duties in cases where the duty of the exporting country has been changed during the time between exportation and arrival in this country.

The following passage is taken from the letter of a business correspondent to business man in this city. It is from one of the cities of the upper tier of Southern States, a centre of a large internal commerce with that section and the home of a considerable variety of manufactures, a fairly representative type of the business interests of the region:

TOKIO, Dec. 20. -- All Japan is to-day ringing with praises of Gen. Samejima as the hero of the assault on Keek-Wan Mountain Port. It is conceded that his heroism inspired his men and turned a threatened disaster into a splendid victory. Gen. Samejima is an old Samurai veteran of the war of the restoration and the Satsuma rebellion.

Policeman Joseph Lang of the Charles Street Station was arrested yesterday on an indictment for grand larceny and held in $5,000 bail for trial by Recorder Golf in General Sessions. District Attorney Jerome appeared before the Recorder when Lang was brought in yesterday afternoon, and said:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20. -- Officers of the Pennsylvania Railroad say that never in that road's history has a water shortage assumed such serious proportions as the one now affecting the central and western portions of this State. Because of the general scarcity of water the company's shops at Altoona are running but part time, and freight traffic is tied up at many points between Greensburg and Tyrone on the main mine division.

It may be well to bear in mind that the City Committee of the Citizens' Union, which on Monday evening adopted resolutions favoring a somewhat large venture in municipal ownership and operation of public service plants, is not the Citizens' Union itself. The committee could start night dogs in chase of all sorts of deer, which the main body of the Union at the earliest opportunity might recall to their kennels.

The crew of the United States battleship Illinois made merry last night on the occasion of their first annual banquet and ball, hold at the Terrace Garden. Capt. John Rogers and his staff, with sweethearts and wives," as they say in the navy, occupied boxes until the grand march started.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 20. -- Eight persons lost their lives early to-day in the Crocker Hotel through the falling of the high east wall of the O.H. Peck building, which was damaged by fire last Tuesday night.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 20. -- Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick was brought into the bankruptcy court here to-day, but was excused from testifying because of illness. Whether she will again be summoned will depend on the counsel for Receiver Nathan Loeser, whose attorneys are expected to take up the matter.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- President Loubet this morning received at the Elysee Palace the members of the International Commission which is to inquire into the North Sea incident, but the non-arrival of Rear Admiral

J.W. Ritchie of the former firm of Yates, Ritchie Pope was expelled yesterday from the New York Stock Exchange. The firm of which he was a member was one of those whose telephones were removed by order of the Committee of Arrangements last June because of certain alleged irregularities.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 20. -- Unless the drought from which Western Pennsylvania is suffering is broken by a heavy rainfall within ten days, workmen familiar with the situation believe that the United States Steel Corporation will be forced to order every one of its mills and furnaces closed. Disquieting news to the same effect comes from every manufacturing centre in this part of the State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A marble bust of Major Gen. Kilpatrick of civil war fame has been placed in the reception room of the Secretary of War. That action was taken with the approval of Secretary Taft at the request of the widow of Gen. Kilpatrick, now residing at Lucerne, Switzerland.

Greater New York's bankers, or, more accurately, that section of the New York State Bankers' Association known as Group VIII., had their annual banquet last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, and, including guests, 460 sat at the long tables. For once the bankers left Wall Street behind them, and no serious economic problem or abstruse financial question figured in the speechmaking.

In stock market circles yesterday almost everything else was talked of except the market. That presented few features of interest. There was no outside public in the market, and whatever movements were shown by prices were due to professionals.

Electric propulsion will be considered only in connection with the proposed barge canal by the State Legislative Commission appointed to investigate the subject, according to a decisison reached by a vote of 9 to 4, at a meeting at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. The vote was on the acceptance of the report of the Committee on Plan and Scope.

-- In discussing at New Rochelle this week the question -- the long since and finally answered question -- as to the propriety of giving religious instruction in the public schools, Mr. BOURKE COCKRAN accidentally touched upon what really is a living problem. It was when he said that these schools are tending more and more to become distinctively the schools for the poor man's children.

A challenge has been issued by the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis to Columbia University for a race between the Annapolis crew and Columbia's second 'Varsity, to take place at Annapolis on May 20. It is proposed also that the Columbia freshmen race the second navy crew on the same day.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 20. -- Advices from Mazatian, Mexico, say that the Seri Indians, inhabiting Tiburon Island, off the coast of Sonora, are on the warpath. Within the last few days Mexican fishermen from the island have arrived at Guaymas and report that several fishermen were captured and taken into the interior of the island by the Indians.

There was nothing about the appearance or demeanor of Mme. Catherine Breshkovskya to indicate a character so dangerous as to compel the Czar's Government to keep her imprisoned or exiled for more than twenty-two years. Nor did she have the looks of one accustomed to brave the indescribable hardships of Siberian Winters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Attorneys for the protestants in the Smoot investigation to-day concluded the examination of witnesses. At the request of Mr. Worthington, counsel for Senator Smoot, the committee then adjourned until Jan. 10, when the Senator's side will be presented and witnesses called.

Certainly President ELIOT is entirely within bounds in describing one of the essential functions of the university to teach freedom as opposed to monopoly, and he is correct in saying that monopolies may in some measure grow up under the regime of free association. But we think that he goes further than the facts warrant in declaring that the "hatefulness of the monopoly is just as great as it was four centuries ago."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21. -- Powers Weightman and Rosengarten Sons, Incorporated, two of the oldest and largest chemical manufacturing concerns in the United States, have been consolidated. The merger involves many millions of dollars. After Dec. 31 the combined organization will be known as the Powers-Weightman-Rosengarten Company, and general offices will be maintained at Ninth and Parrish Streets, the present offices of Powers Weightman.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- The mystery of the death of M. Syveton, the Nationalist leader, is still the cause of intense excitement here and is the principal topic of conversation in Parisian circles. Owing to the contradictory statements of some of the witnesses at the inquiry the theory of murder is now more generally entertained, but information I have received from a specially well-informed source confirms the explanation I previously sent to you.

The New York Road Drivers' Association last night issued a defiance to Park Commissioner Pallas, whose action in closing the Fifty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue entrance to Central Park to vehicles, was the chief cause of a special meeting held at the Hotel Cadillac, the meeting unanimously voting to go over the head of Mr. Pallas in an appeal direct to Mayor McClellan.

George H. Munroe, senior member of the firm of Munroe Munroe, brokers in outside securities, which was recently thrown into involuntary bankruptcy after a bad crash in the stock of the Montreal and Boston Copper Company, which happened when the stock market had trouble two weeks ago, had forgotten lots of things yesterday when he was placed on the witness stand on examination in bankruptcy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The Administration's plan for dealing with the trusts, referred to in THE NEW YORK TIMES some days ago, was to-day made public in all its details in the first annual report of Commissioner James R. Garfield of the Bureau of Corporations.

Congress appropriated $40,000 for a post exchange at Governors Island. The enlisted men, the privates, first rank and rear rank, expected this to be for their benefit. Now, they say, the officers have made it their clubhouse and the enlisted man can't pass the door to the real club part of the clubhouse.

-- A Southern widow with sons to educate reveals in a letter to Harper's Weekly that there has arisen in her mind a serious doubt whether, as she says, "we parents are called upon to make sacrifices to give our boys higher education, when it is proved beyond the shadow of a doubt that the professions are crowded and little money made in them."

Gov. Odell and Senator Depew sat down together at the annual banquet of the New England Society in Brooklyn last night, which took place in the Pouch mansion, on Clinton Avenue. The Governor was the special guest of the society, while Senator Depew came on from Washington, on twenty-four hours' notice, to take the place of Senator J.P. Dolliver, who was expected to respond to the toast "American Patriotism."

Welcoming Judge Parker on his return to the ranks of legal practitioners, members of the bench and bar to the number of more than 300 last night acted as his hosts at a dinner held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WANTED. -- By the Tammany General Committee of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District, suggestions as to how to spend $2,100 surplus in the organization treasury. Address Thomas E. Rush, district leader.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 21. -- The dual life of James L. Blair, late counselor of the World's Fair and leader of the reform movement in St. Louis, was laid bare at the hearing to-day before Special Master F.A. Scofield of the suit of the Mutual Life Insurance Company to annul the policy on Mr. Blair's life for $200,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Dec. 21. -- The registration figures in Harvard's catalogue, published to-day, shows that the university's enrollment has fallen off within the last year. In all departments of the university there are at present 5,500 students, against 6,040 last year, a loss of 540. The college loss is 34, the scientific school 18, the divinity 9, the law 20, the medical 76, and the dental 9.
"Odell thought the old guard was dead. We have sent a committee to tone him down."

The latest marvel in telegraphy, an instrument that can transmit messages at the rate of more than 40,000 words a minute, and deliver them at the other end of the wire written out in plain schoolboy handwriting, was exhibited at the Carlton Hotel the other day before a gathering that included Count Mensdorff, the Austro-Hungarian Ambassador.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 21 -- Pittsburg is to have a mineral collection rivaling the Bement collection of New York Dr. W.J. Holland, Director of the Carnegie Museum, returned to-day from New York and announced that Mr. Carnegie had authorized him to purchase the Jefferis collection of minerals, now held by the aged mineralogist at West Chester Penn.

The Mallory Line steamship Sabine arrived in port yesterday afternoon, two days late, and towing behind her the lumber schooner Edith L. Allen, badly waterlogged, and having among her passengers ten persons whom her crew had taken from the disabled schooner near Cape Hatteras. The persons rescued included Capt. Paul Le Blanc and his sixteen-year-old daughter, Marie, and nine of the schooner's crew, to say nothing of the schooner's mascot cat Tom.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 21. -- Harvard's hockey team proved a big disappointment to its supporters to-day when it barely succeeded in defeating the weak Andover seven by the score of 3 to 0 on the Soldiers Field rink. Knowing that her defense was very weak, Harvard played a shooting game, making the wildest tries for goal.

Increased activity accompanied a bad break in the market yesterday. Total sales approximated 900,000 shares, and all the activity was on the decline. When the market rallied it at once became dull. This is exactly the opposite of what was the rule during the late bull movement, and the most ardent bulls dislike to be asked to explain it.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21. -- Nearly 1,000 men and women fled from the Bon Ton -- formerly the Star -- Theatre, in Eighth Street, near Vine, to-night when the electric switchboard on the stage suddenly burst into flames. The asbestos curtain was lowered and the fire was extinguished quickly.
PANAMA, Dec. 21. -- Earthquake shocks were felt within a radius of 150 miles of Panama and Colon last night.

William Barclay Parsons at the fiftieth anniversary dinner of the American Geographical Society at Delmonico's last night, in speaking to the toast, "The Panama Canal," took the stand that it was premature and even impossible to state with any degree of definiteness what a sea-level canal would cost both in time and money.

The whole South, with the North as well, should tender its respectful and grateful appreciation to Judge WILKINSON of the Circuit Court of Lincoln County, Mississippi, for his firmness in sentencing prisoners convicted of murderous violence toward negroes. And this appreciation is equally due to the juries who convicted the offenders and to the law and order league which so formed and expressed sound public opinion that justice for the offenders became possible.

The police of Broadway and the upper west side are much exercised just now over what Xenodocius, the Classic Cop, says ough to be, and thereby is, named "The Mystery of the Wonderfully Winsome Woman and the Midnight Mastiff."

Prince SVLATOPOLK-MIRSKY has the best right of anybody at present much in view to implore to be saved from his friends. No sooner does he come forward with what seems a very moderate and circumspect plan of gradually assimilating the outworn conditions of Russian life to the life of the modern world than a number of wild Socialists, dreaming students, and misguided "intellectuals" in general seize the occasion for rioting after their kind.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21. -- Green B. Morris's two-year-old filly Gold Rose started again today and scored her fifth successive victory at Ascot. The distance was over the Slauson course, and Gold Rose was held at 6 to 5 throughout the betting. Sais was looked upon to take the fast filly's measure and was heavily played at 5 to 2, while E1 Chihuahua found numerous backers at 5 to 1.

I gather from your article in to-day's paper, under the heading "Topics of the Times" in re the efforts of the Cornell University to rid themselves, and the town of Ithaca of the mosquito pest, that you believe that these nuisances do not breed on high, dry ground. Therein I am sure you are mistaken.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- Rear Admiral Charles H. Davis, U.S.N., arrived here at 5:30 P.M. Lieutenant Commander Smith, United States Naval Attache, met the Admiral and his party at the Northern Railroad Station and conducted them to the Hotel Brighton.
OAKLAND, Cal., Dec. 21. -- The feature of the racing at the Oakland track to-day was the riding of Davis, who piloted the winners of the third, fourth, and fifth events. Summary:

The fate of Nan Patterson will be put in the hands of the jury to-day. The attorneys for the prosecution and the defense summed up yesterday, and Justice Vernon M. Davis will begin his charge this morning at 10:45 o'clock.
Two eminent men who had rendered the world distinguished service in widely different fields of usefulness call for passing mention in the comments upon the memorable events of the day.

Running down the list of changes in yesterday's prices there appears a numerous list of declines exceeding a point in active and representative properties, and a few small scattering advances among inactive stocks. First in time among the depressing influences was the break in Consolidated Gas, which has present troubles of its own in connection with the local Legislature, and which usually marks the approach of the meeting of the State Legislature by some softness.
TOKIO, Dec. 21. -- The Japanese Army besieging Port Arthur reported to-day as follows regarding the trophies captured by the Japanese in the North Fort of East Keek-Wan Mountain:
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21. -- The first dividend on Reading common stock since January, 1876, was declared to-day. It is 1 1/2 per cent., payable Feb. 1, 1905, to stockholders of record Jan. 14, 1905.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 21. -- Ram's Horn was the only winning favorite at the Crescent City Jockey Club track to-day. Homestead should have won easily, but Schilling's poor ride not only beat the colt for first place, but procured his disqualification for the second. Summary:

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Lieut. Gov. Higgins parried all questions put to him about the Platt conference in New York to-day. He said that it was a conference of gentlemen invited to meet together and discuss a stated matter.

The "Community of Freight Traffic Interests." an organization whose membership embraces the freight traffic officials of all the railroads east of the Mississippi River, has elected the following officers for 1905: President -- Henry L. Joyce, General Manager of the Manhattan Lighterage Company; Secretary -- M.G. Vandergaw, Freight Agent of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company; Treasurer -- Louis M. Allen, General Eastern Agent of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad.

Word has been received from Everett C. Brown, Chairman of the Athletic Committee of the Chicago Athletic Association, that James D. Lightbody, who proved during the Olympic games held recently at St. Louis that he is the greatest middle distance and steeplechase runner in America to-day, will be a competitor in the Pastime Athletic Club games to be held at Madison Square Garden on New Year's Eve.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 21. -- Still another satchel, one thought by Receiver Nathan Loeser to contain valuables belonging to Mrs. Chadwick, was to-day found to be missing.
ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 21. -- Emperor Nicholas is holding councils daily at Tsarskoe-Selo, at which, it is understood, the internal situation in Russia is being thoroughly discussed.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Fred Jones, a clerk in a store at Newfane, shot and killed Mrs. Abbie Goodrich and Constable William C. Gray this afternoon and then shot himself dead.

The annual report of the Seaboard Air Line was made public yesterday. The statement of earnings shows an increase in gross earnings of $604,881 and a decrease in net of $139,991, owing to increases in operating expenses. The surplus showed a decrease of $449,656. The income account was as follows:

Faculty intervention in the Kingdon Gould affair at Columbia began yesterday when it became known that an investigation was being made with a view to suspending the hazers of the young freshman. This fact, however, did not seem to dampen the spirits of the second-year men, for they had a fierce battle with the freshmen yesterday, and last night they dined merrily at Bretton Hall, Broadway and Eighty-sixth Street.

The United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest by Albert Lorsch Co. of New York against the classification at 50 per cent. as manufactures of agate, of agate keystones, unmounted, and small pieces of agate, all similar in form but differing slightly in dimensions, which had been cut, polished, and ground, thus fitting them for use as bearings for high grade scales.
To the Editor of The New York Times:I note the communication of "W.K." in your issue of yesterday relating to my note on the subject of "Dr. Potter on the Old Testament."

The Department of Commerce and Labor at Washington, through its Bureau of Statistics, has just published a statement regarding savings deposits in different countries, which, so far as Canada is conceded, is very misleading. The figures given for Canada are as follows:

PEKING, Dec. 21. -- I telegraphed to you on Nov. 11 that China had yielded to the wishes of the majority of the powers and had consented to pay the Boxer indemnity in gold. A note from the Chinese Government was presented to the Foreign Ministers on Oct. 26, submitting proposals for gold payments, but no reply has been received, although the payments are due on Dec. 31.

The sale of the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-second Street by James Henry Smith and the deal for three apartment hotels owned by Irons Todd and valued at $4,150,000, are referred to in more detail in another column.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Postmaster General Wynne to-day removed two more rural carriers for alleged efforts to influence legislation, the men being H.F. Nivin of Berthoud, Col., and J.W. Whitehead of Medina, Ohio. Nivin is Chairman of the Executive Board of the National Rural Carriers' Association.
LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The Times's insurance correspondent says:

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- Judge Tuley to-day decided that Montville Waldo Howard has been seeking for five years to establish title by means of a forged deed to $125,000 worth of property left by John McCaffery, an eccentric capitalist, now deceased. Howard is the husband of a woman formerly in the employ of McCaffery.

We take pleasure in expressing lay appreciation of the decision of Judge DICKEY, in Brooklyn, in refusing an injunction to restrain the Board of Estimate and Apportionment from awarding the contract for the book shelving in the Public Library to a firm not the lowest bidder, but, in the judgment of those charged with responsibility in the awarding of the contract, best fitted to do the work intelligently and to the public satisfaction.

The desire to save for its rightful, unknown owner what he temporarily believed to be a considerable sum of money caused Alderman Moritz Tolk, during the session of the board last Tuesday afternoon, to become the victim of a little joke, the author of which was his colleague and friend, Alderman Dowling.

A short and easy way to full approval of Commissioner GARFIELD'S plan of regulating the corporations of the country by a Federal franchise or license is to assume that his proposed law, if enacted, would never be executed and enforced by any but men eminently just and supremely wise. There is never the slightest danger in placing power in the hands of the inerrant and infallible.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 22. -- Major John M. Bailey, aged sixty-six, a veteran of the One Hundred and Seventy-seventh New York Volunteers, and Fannie Harding, aged thirty-three, daughter of Capt. John Harding, a Confederate veteran, were married in this city last evening. The Rev. W.S. Herbert officiated, and the bride's parents witnessed the quiet ceremony.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 22. -- At the anniversary banquet of the New England Society here to-night a letter from J. Pierpont Morgan was read, in the course of which Mr. Morgan said:

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 22. -- D.P. Atwood, who has caused so big a flutter by bringing suits against violators of the law requiring administrators and trustees of estates to file inventories, has written an open letter to the members of the Connecticut Legislature, defendinf himself from the attacks made upon him and protesting against the proposal to call a special session of the Legislature to repeal the laws under which his suits were brought.

The sort of article seasonable before the Fourth of July is adapted now to the current market. There is about as much current as in a millpond. There is no initiative, and the sale of a moderate quantity of stocks puts shares clown as easily as purchases put them up. The arbitragers telegraphed from London that on account of the fog they could not see to trade.
PARIS, Dec. 22. -- The international commission appointed to inquire into the North Sea incident met in one of the beautiful salons of the Foreign Office this morning.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- Mrs. Mary Guinan, who conducts a boarding house in Main Street, New Rochelle, received two new boarders this afternoon, and a few minutes later had a premonition that they were not honest. Telephoning to the police, Mrs. Guinan told the Sergeant: "I have just received two new boarders, but something tells me that they are not just right."

Unable to agree on a verdict the jury in the Nan Patterson case was ordered locked up at 11:25 o'clock last night, after having deliberated eleven hours. It was the general opinion about the Criminal Court Building, as the evening wore away without a verdict that the chances were largely in favor of a mistrial.

A franchise for the cross-town subway, connecting the tunnel of the New York and Jersey Railroad Company with the business section of the city, was formally granted at the meeting of the Board of Rapid Transit Commission yesterday, all the members voting in favor of it except Mr. Starin, who asked to be excused from voting.

Yesterday was the dullest day's trading that the stock market has seen since early last Summer. Less than 400,000 shares were traded in, and the ticker, which a few weeks ago had been unable to record the transactions, was silent for long minutes at a time. The general tendency was downward, and at the close prices were at the very lowest for the day.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The publication in St. Petersburg of a statement that Hull fishermen have voluntarily deposed that foreign torpedo boats were among the trawlers on Dogger Bank when the latter were fired upon by ships of the Russian Baltic Squadron follows similar statements emanating from Hull.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 22. -- A fire in the apartment house of John J. Barry, at 365 Main Street, shortly before daylight this morning nearly caused the death of the occupants of the building. It originated in the basement of the building, and had extended to the street floor and the hardware store of Charles F. Werner, Jr., before it was discovered.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 22. -- Nicol's riding was a feature of to-day's racing. The boy had four mounts and landed three winners, finishing second with his last mount. Fox Mead and Reliance were the only winning favorites. The former was run up $500 after his race. Summaries:

Ex-Judge Henry E. Howland was responsible for the single sensation at the ninety-ninth dinner of the New England Society, at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening. He was responding to the toast "Forefathers' Day," in which he had poetically pictured New England life and the trials and triumphs of the fathers who had left their native land to find freedom here.

Lazard Freres yesterday took from the Assay Office $530,000 in gold bars, which they had previously engaged, for shipment to Paris by yesterday's steamer. In addition to this shipment announcement was made of several shipments to be made to Argentina by to-morrow's steamer. The National City Bank is to ship $500,000, and other shipments may bring the total up to about $2,000,000.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 23. -- There is as yet no sign of the lifting of the fog which envelops the Kingdom. The absence of wind throughout Great Britain is almost unprecedented, and meteorologists do not expect any change in conditions for another twenty-four hours.

" Socialism for the Upper Classes" was the title of an address recently delivered by George Bernard Shaw at Holy Trinity parish hall, Sloane Square, London. The audience, consisting mostly of women, crowded the hall.
BORDEAUX, Dec. 22. -- Four Russian naval officers, bearing dispatches from Vice Admiral Rojestvensky, have arrived here on board a Messageries Maritimes packet.

Convinced that he is about to unearth one of the biggest pieces of graft in the city, District Attorney Jerome asked Judge Cowing yesterday that the Grand Jury now in session, and which ordinarily would be dismissed to-day, be held over until next week.

A nurse in the City Hospital at the south end of Blackwell's Island telephoned to Police Headquarters at 12:49 o'clock this morning that a fire had just started in the laundry, near the boiler room, and asking for help.
ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 22. -- The announcement that Japanese warships are proceeding west from Singapore is received here with much interest.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 22. -- Dr. Leroy S. Chadwick and his wife, Mrs. Cassie L. Chadwick, were jointly indicted by the County Grand Jury this afternoon on the charge of having forged and uttered a $5,000,000 note signed "Andrew Carnegie."

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 22 -- The old De Wolfe mansion, known as "The Mount," on the east side of the city, and one of the finest types of Colonial architecture in the State, was destroyed by fire to-night.

Sensational bribery charges against the State and county organizations of the Wine, Liquor and Beer Dealers' Association, generally known as the Liquor Dealers' Association, were contained in a presentment which the Grand Jury handed to Judge Cowing in the Special Sessions Court yesterday.

Speedy skating, combined with concerted team work, resulted in the Irving School's hockey team last night defeating the seven of St. Paul's Cathedral School of Garden City, L.I., by a score of 3 goals to 0. As a contest it was filled with that spicy condiment, play of "the do-or-die" order, and was one of the fastest schoolboy matches ever contested on the ice of the St. Nicholas Rink.

That which Xenodocius, the classic cop. calls "The Mystery of the Wonderfully Winsome Woman and the Midnight Mastiff," is still unsolved, despite the efforts of Detective McIvor of the Tenderloin to discover why the veiled woman with the ferocious, chained mastiff nightly trails an unknown something down Broadway.

The payment of the dividend upon the common stock of the Reading Railroad, the first paid in twenty-eight years, is an event of no little importance to the public as well as to the owners of Reading stock. It is a sign and a perfectly unmistakable one, of the country's prosperity.

A new society designed to promote the welfare of the people of New York and to engender a lively sense of civic obligation, regardless of political affiliations and social conditions, was organized last night at the Hotel Regent, at Broadway and Seventieth Street, under the name of The Association for Public Duty.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22. -- Governor-elect Joseph W. Folk was the first witness to-day in the hearing of the suit of a New York life insurance company to cancel the $200,000 policy on the life of the late James L. Blair before F. L. Schofield of Hannibal, special master in chancery.
TOKIO, Dec. 22. -- A dispatch received by telegraph to-day from the Japanese Army before Port Arthur says:

Charging that H. H. Rogers in the Spring and Summer of 1901 unloaded not only the $22,000.000 of Amalgamated stock that James R. Keene has told of selling, but his entire holdings upon the public, Thomas W. Lawson sent out from Boston last night a new letter, anticipating, in part, the account which he promises in further installments of his story of the great copper flotation.

The first shot in the local open shop campaign following on the open shop convention of the Citizens' Industrial Association in the Hotel Astor a week or two ago, was fired yesterday by the Cap Manufacturers' Association. The employes of its members were notified yesterday that the open shop would go into effect in all their shops on the day after Christmas.
DRESDEN, Dec. 22. -- The ex-Crown Princess Louise, who now bears the title of Countess Montignoso, arrived here unexpectedly from Vienna last night.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 22. -- Fire did $60,000 worth of damage to-night in the centre of the city. The flames started apparently in the basement of the paint store of Arnold Textor, at 145 First Street, and before they could be stayed swept through the entire four-story building and did considerable damage to surrounding property.

Seeking to prove that a partnership existed between the brokerage firm of Munroe Munroe on the one side, and Archibald G. Loomis and A.B. Leach on the other, Samuel Untermyer, counsel for the creditors of the suspended brokerage firm, yesterday resumed his rapid inquiry in the hearing before United States Commissioner Alexander in the Federal Building.

Schoolgirls are about to have their turn at athletics as well as the schoolboys. This fact was brought out by Gen. George W. Wingate, President of the Public Schools Athletic League, in his speech at the annual meeting of the organization, and the plans of the league for the girls of New York have since been outlined.
Your editorial this morning on "City Ownership" was badly needed.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 22. -- Emperor Nicholas wrote the following endorsement on the resolutions telegraphed by the Chernigoff Zemstvo Dec. 20, begging his Majesty in the most loyal manner to convoke legally elected members of the Zemstvos to present a programme of reforms for his consideration:

The current fatalities attributable to gas, in fires, explosions, and asphyxiations, cannot have failed to impress the careful student of the news of the day with wonder that so great a danger is still so lightly regarded by the public, and that anything so fatal as a fluid which kills or puts life and property in jeopardy even before its presence is recognized needs much better regulation than illuminating gas has yet received.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 22. -- Rain upset the calculations at Ascot to-day, and but one favorite on the card was successful. The other five races went to well-played horses at liberal odds, the longest chances being Cincinnatus at 8 to 1 and Effervescence at 10 to 1. Summary:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Vice Chancellor Pitney heard testimony to-day and reserved decision in the suit brought by Benjamin Searies of Jersey City to compel Mrs. Margeret Graham of the same city to live up to a contract. The contract consisted of the conveyance of a tenement house by the defendant to the plaintiff.
I beg leave to ask what is to prevent corporations from being placed under the control of the Internal Revenue Department?

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Passengers on a train on the Caldwell Branch of the Erie Railroad, leaving Caldwell at 7:36 o'clock this morning, got a bad scare and ten of them were more or less injured when the train was derailed in Verona, near the Newark City Home. The train contained fully 200 passengers, almost all of them commuters on their way to New York.

James B. Dill takes issue with Commissioner Garfield's plan of Federal control of corporations, and although he favors Federal incorporation he does not agree with Mr. Garfield when he says that there must be a positive prohibition against engaging in corporate inter-State commerce without a Federal franchise in order to make the system effective.

After reading your editorial "By Executive Order," under date of Dec. 14, I am led to ask, Have Government employes any rights? Are they not by the President's order reduced to the position of Government paupers?

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 22. -- Manager H.D. Brown of the New Orleans Jockey Club made an official statement to-night that the club's entire management had been turned over to Edward Corrigan, who has received all proxies to vote the stock according to his judgment.
BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- The Lokal Anzeiger, in a dispatch from Kiel, says that the Imperial Yacht Club announces the following American entries for the transatlantic racing:

DENVER, Dec. 22. -- A mystery, features of which seem to point to the commission of a crime surrounds the disappearance of W.M. Carlton, a young man from Brooklyn, N.Y., who, since Dec. 16, has been missing from his Denver address. The fact that Carlton's personal effects were left in his room is thought to indicate that he contemplated returning, and it is feared that he met with foul play.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- There is keen interest in the land fraud cases in Oregon, which are now before the United States Grand Jury at Portland. The finding of a new series of indictments this week encourages the officials of the Interior Department who have been at work on the case for over a year to believe they will succeed in convicting the guilty parties.

Now that most of the ships composing what has hitherto been known as Russia's Baltic fleet have entered the waters lying east of the Continent of Africa, navy men are discussing the probabilities of an attack upon this squadron by the Japanese before the detachment that went around the Cape of Good Hope shall unite with the one that passed through the Suez Canal.

Lax conditions on the Starin Line steamboat Glen Island, which burned in the Sound with the loss of nine lives on Saturday morning last, were disclosed by the testimony of Iron Larsen, the mate, at the opening of the investigation by the local Board of Steamboat Inspection at the Whitehall Building yesterday.

We still think that the country is a trading concern; that our imports are our purchases and our exports our sales; that to make a profit our exports must exceed our imports, and that this can be effected by taxing imports and subsidizing exports. Every one of these suppositions is fallacious, but they will die hard, because certain interests desire to keep them alive.

The title of the Library of Congress is not a happy one. It gives the notion to the general public of a library for the use of the members of Congress only, which naturally would involve a collection of a special and rather limited sort, of no great interest to the wide world of readers and students.
May I address you with reference to the letter of "S.N.M." about the United States Leather reorganization, printed upon your editorial page on the 21st inst.?
R. Humphrey Roberts of Pittsburg killed himself in his room in the Hotel Savoy early last evening. There was an attempt made to conceal the fact from the Coroner.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23. -- Carrying top weight, Honiton toyed with her field in the handicap at Oakland to-day, and her jockey won as far as he pleased. There was a spirited finish between the second and third horses, and Magrane just got up in time to get the place from Judge in the last jump. The others were strung out. McBride was suspended for one week for rough riding on Sea Air.

AMONG the interesting books of serious purpose for young people this year is the "American Boys' Life of Theodore Roosevelt," by Edward Stratemeyer, illustrated from photographs and with a frontispiece showing Col. Roosevelt at San Juan Hill, by Charles Copeland, (Lee Shepard.)

The Macmillan Company is issuing in its series on The Great Masters in Painting and Sculpture, edited by G.C. Williamson, a reduced edition of Gerald S. Davies's larger book on "Frans Hals." The present volume hag also been revised, owing to the "communications from many quarters which have enabled the author to add, to after, to omit."

It does not look now as if the utmost labor to which Senator PLATT and Senator DEPEW himself can devote their holiday week will avail to defeat the purpose of the "organization" to elect Mr. BLACK to Mr. DEPEW'S seat.

IN the past the incentives of discovery and exploration were for gold, spices, and peltries. Agnes C. Laut, in her "Pathfinders of the West," writes: "It was the fur trade that found the West. It was the fur trade that explored the West. It was the fur trade that wrested the West from savagery."

THE author of "Denovan" and "We Two," though those stories belong to a school of sentiment no longer as popular as it used to be, has had so many readers that an account of her life should posses considerable interest.

Four members of the sophomore class at Columbia were suspended yesterday by the Faculty because of the attempted hazing of Kingdon Gould. College sentiment seemed to be that the sentence was unjust, and the sophomore class was for leaving the university if their classmates were not at once reinstated.

The Board of Education came in for a gentle rap yesterday afternoon at the hands of the senior class of the New York Training School for Teachers, at One Hundred and Nineteenth Street and Second Avenue. The class gave "Everygirl," a morality play in two acts, a parody on the "Everyman," which Ben Green and Edith Wynne Matthison revived two seasons ago in New York.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 3. -- The gross earnings of the steam roads of Connecticut in the year ending June 30, 1904, were the greatest in the history of the State. They amounted to $50,188,984.87, showing an increase of $1,200, 299.15 over the previous year. This statement is made in the fifty-second annual report of the Railroad Commissioners, which was Submitted to Gov. Chamberlain to-day.

Among the books promised for the near future by the Charter House Bookshop is one dealing with Tuscany. It is entitled "The Medici Balls." The authors, Emma R. Sheldon and Moyca Newell, spent five years traveling in Italy. They explored romantic Tuscany, and devoted much time to unfrequented paths.

CURIOUS item of news is being commented on in certain exclusive local literary circles, if not in book-selling circles of the same character. It is that Henry James's most recent novel, published only a few weeks ago with the title, "The Golden Bowl," is in its third edition.

FOR the frontispiece of "In the Days of Shakespeare," by Tudor Jenks, which is published this week by A.S. Barnes Co. in their Lives of Great Writers Series, a reproduction has been made of Frederick MacMonnies's striking statue of Shakespeare in the Congressional Library at Washington.

We publish this week a final installment, the eighth in number, of our notes of comment on the new books for children of the Winter of 1904-5. Many columns have been given up to these notes, but even with this space at our disposal, and the best of intentions, it has been found necessary to dismiss many books for children with no further notice than the acknowledgment of their receipt.

Yachtsmen are wondering if some one has perpetrated a hoax on the Imperial Yacht Club of Kiel in the matter of the alleged American entries for the ocean race for the German Emperor's Cup, which were cabled from Berlin on Thursday night. Five of the nine owners said to have entered their yachts emphatically deny that they have done so.

The 350 women employed by the members of the Cap Manufacturers' Association joined in the strike against the open shop declaration of the association yesterday. In all about 1,800 or 1,900 workers are now on strike, and the factories will remain idle until Monday, when capmakers will be employed individually on the open-shop plan.

ALBANY, Dec. 23. -- Governor-elect Higgins has declined to declare himself in favor of either Black or Depew for United States Senator, although Gov. Odell had a private conference with him to-day in the inner office of the Executive Chamber, and he later received a visit from State Chairman William Barnes, Jr.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- That the further interchange of views preparatory to the formulating of a programme for another peace conference at The Hague be effected through the International Bureau under the control of the permanent Administrative Council of The Hague is the suggestion offered by Secretary Hay in a second circular note to the powers, made public at the State Department to-day.

The Hudson Realty Company has resold to Lowenfeld Prager the twenty-three lots on the south side of One Hundred and Fortieth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, 575 by 99.11, being the entire block front, with the exception of the two avenue corners.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 23. -- The North German Lloyd steamship Prinzess Irene, from Naples for New York, arrived here this afternoon short of fuel. She will take on 500 tons of coal and proceed to New York to-morrow.

You have most truly said that your readers will feel Mr. Chadwick's death as a personal loss. One who looks forward each week to the coming of your valuable paper echoes your words. Mr. Chadwick's latest reviews of books were of unusual interest and seemed most sound and just. They were most welcome to your readers, especially those dealing with Mr. Conway's and Mrs. Pryor's books.

Here's a story in which Mme. de Maintenon plays guardian angel and even Louis XIV. himself, disguised as a friar, plays a sort of good genius part, too. The persons thus powerfully protected are a young gentleman who is called Count Francois de Mowbray and a young gentlewoman who is called Marguerite de la Vergne.

MUCH has already been written of the present conflict between Russia and Japan, and much more probably will be written. But so far no book has appeared which contains, in an explicit and dispassionate manner, a succinct statement of the causes which have led to one of the fiercest struggles in history, and of the issues directly involved in it.

Often in the lives of great men undue prominence is given to some particular incident; for instance, many readers picture Thoreau as "a hermit," owing to the importance given by writers to his two years' sojourn at Walden. This is a thought which we find in the preface to "De Quincey," which is being issued by the Macmillan Company.

In the preface of the new two-volume pocket edition of Cervantes's "Don Quixote," which the Macmillan Company is bringing out, the editor, E. Bell, states that the book aims "to preserve the merits of Motteux, and to get rid of his faults." This version, published by Peter Anthony Motteux, appeared about a century after Shelton's translation was published.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The Times in an editorial article to-morrow will say that Elihu Root is right in declaring that there will be no frontal attack on the Monroe Doctrine, but in the opinion of The Times the United States may become involved in a quarrel with some nation over the concrete application of the doctrine. By way of illustrating this possibility The Times says:

THE title of the volume written by Capt. Mark Sykes is "Dar-Ul-Islam," which translated means "The Home of Islam." E.G. Browne, Professor of Arabic at Cambridge, who writes the introduction, says that the title is specially appropriate to the Turkish Empire. Mr. Sykes and the Cambridge professor

The affidavits which certain of the Dogger Bank fishermen have made at the instance of the Russian Consul at Hull explain the incident of the smashing of the fishing fleet in the North Sea by the Russian warships on their way to the East. The affidavits referred to set forth that the deponents saw foreign torpedo boats among the fishing vessels.

THE criticism of "The Eagle's Shadow" by "Old Fashioned" shows conclusively ignorance of the habits, ideas, and refinements of the girls of 1904. It does not do to look backward for our types of what a female should now be, since progress in everything is the watchword and to lose sight of sex the fashion.

" The Last Letters of Aubrey Beardsley," which Longmans, Green Co. are about to bring out in this country, cover the last two years and nine months of the artist's life. They are addressed to a Catholic priest, the Rev. John Gray, who edits the volumes. Throughout the book the writer is cheerful, although at times he expresses himself as "beginning to be really depressed and frightened" about his condition.

" Captain Amyas" displays a thorough knowledge of the mercantile marine of Great Britain and an intense sympathy with its peculiar and unenviable position. It is a strong story and an illuminating one in regard to that branch of the British service without which, as Frank Bullen tells us, "its navy is useless."
AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 23. -- The Mexican Government has just granted a concession to Col. W.C. Greene, the mining man, for the erection and operation of a large smelter at Dedrick, Mexico.

Abraham Chapkowsky, who four years ago was sent to an asylum after the death of his wife and was released about a year ago, shot five times at his brother, Louis, yesterday morning and probably fatally wounded him. The brothers live at 259 Division Street, and the shooting occurred at the breakfast table.

MR. CHARLES G. HARPER, author of a pleasant book on "The Ingoldsby Country," describing the storied Kentish coast and hop country and the towns and villages associated with the Ingoldsby legends, has now performed a similar service for the readers of Thomas Hardy, who outnumber by many thousands in these days, we fancy, the readers of the Rev. Mr. Barham, who called himself Ingoldsby.

SO MANY times within a few years has the last word from the hand of a beloved author been precisely the fitting utterance, that readers of the January Atlantic will turn with a little thrill of expectancy to the page whereon the table of contents tells them to look for "Defiance.

One of your Boston readers who has been "greatly interested in 'The Castaway' and its growth into popular favor" calls attention in last week's issue of THE BOOK REVIEW to its limitations as "a document of Byroniana."

Taken from an earlier edition under the editorship of her niece, Charlotte Barrett, the "Diary and Letters of Mme. D'Arblay" will appear in six volumes. The first volume of this work is being published by the Macmillan Company. A preface and some notes are included by Austin Dobson, author of "Life of Fanny Burney," and the writer of an introduction to Fanny Burney's "Evelina; or, The History of a Young Lady's Entrance."

Ex-Justice William M.K. Olcott, counsel for the Standard Manufacturing Company, appeared in Part I., Special Term of the Supreme Court yesterday to ask for an injunction restraining the Board of Health from awarding the city's offal contract to the syndicate that has had it for the past twenty years, consisting of McKeever Brothers and Frank White.

Through the skill of Arthur Aigeltinger, Columbia's sophomores were enabled to draw with the freshmen in the annual interclass cane sprees, held in the gymnasium yesterday. Aigeltinger was quite a hero, as in the morning he had been suspended from Columbia for participation in the Kingdon Gould hazing episode of Tuesday.

By two consecutive falls Fred Narganes became the holder of the special diamond medal for wrestling last night at the New York Athletic Club. Narganes, who last season won the welter-weight championship of the club, defeated D.C. Newton in last night's bout, which was actually a challenge match.
PEKING, Dec. 23. -- Chinese to-day seized at Fen-Tai, near Peking, 3,000,000 rounds of Russian rifle ammunition consigned to a Russian firm at Tien-Tsin, and evidently destined for Port Arthur.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23. -- Secretary Hess's statement of the world's visible supply of cotton, issued to-day, shows the total to be 4,566,127 bales, against 3,941,853 last year. Of this the total of American cotton is 3,843,127, against 3,331,853 last par, and of all other kinds, including Egypt, Brazil, India, , 723,000, against 0,000 last year.

The volume containing "The Story of Art Throughout the Ages." by S. Reinach, a Member of the Institute of France, and translated by Florence Simmonds, is a critical encyclopedia of the history of art beginning with the achievements of the savage and going "throughout the ages" up to to-day.

The Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday denied an application by counsel for the American Sugar Refining Company, that it continue to carry the 18,000 protests, on the sugar test question, on the suspended files, pending the outcome of the new attempt of the importers to secure a ruling by the Supreme Court in their favor.

Many of these little stories touch off very happily in the vein of serio-comic sentiment add bits of common or vulgar life in the City of New York. The words "vulgar" and "common," be it understood, are used in their better and not in their offensive sense. All the stories are of Cupid in one or other of his myriad cosmopolitan incarnations.

I have read with much interest the controversy being waged in your valuable columns over the heroine of Mr. Cabell's novel "The Eagle's Shadow," and I should like to join the protest against the somewhat harsh criticism of Margaret Hugonin. I am inclined to say that Margaret might make a man use some profanity, but she would never make him yawn.

The Countess of Warwick, who writes of "Warwick Castle and Its Earls, from Saxon Times to the Present Day," now out in a new edition, presents two volumes, which are elegant specimens of typographical art. Many of the Warwicks played a part in the dramas of English history.

A volume of no little curious interest this, and an almost unbelievable medley. It consists of letters from and to Nathan Appleton, interspersed with all manner of odd reminiscences. Just after the civil war this Nathan Appleton, with his cousin Charles Appleton Longfellow, the poet's son, went abroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Republicans are exhibiting special interest in the reorganization of their party in the Southern States, and encouraged by the evident purpose of the President to redeem that section from its solidarity, have been giving the matter attention from the standpoint of winning the South by appealing to the material interest of that section.

In his earlier works on pottery subjects, Mr. Barber has familiarized his readers with the various forms of American pottery products. He has assembled and published many new facts, not only regarding American pottery, but he has also written most entertainingly as to American potters themselves.

COUNTESS ON NOVELS OF ENGLISH SOCIETY. -- It is perhaps hardly fair to compare the so-called society novels of the day with those of an earlier period, for the latter have undergone the winnowing process of the elimination by time of the dull and effete among their number, whereas second and third class productions still circulate, like anaemic blood in the veins of an invalid, through the arteries provided by the circulating libraries.
BOSTON, Dec. 23. -- J. Edward O'Sullivan Addicks, the Delaware gas man, was in Boston several hours to-day and then went back without having seen Lawson.
LONDON, Dec. 23, 1904. -- Rider Haggard's sequel to "She" will not be published in book form until the Autumn.

ROANOKE, Va., Dec. 23. -- The leaders of the Republican Party in Virginia were in conference all last night to outline a plan of action to place the party on a stronger and more aggressive footing throughout the State and to devise a more satisfactory method of making recommendations to the President for appointments for Federal offices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The President will devote the holidays to rest and enjoyment with his family. He will make no engagements for the holiday week except when so required by the exigencies of the public service. Much of the time will be spent in outdoor exercises with members of his family and personal friends.

Justice Jonathan Dixon at Jersey City yesterday freely expressed his opinion as to the manner in which petit jurors are selected for the trial of cases in the county courts.
