The Justice's ire has been aroused several times recently by the failure of jurors to appear. As a result he instructed Sheriff Zeller to serve peremptory notice on all absentee jurors to appear before him. The first to respond was Joseph Crowley.

FROM the coarse twisting of osiers came, in time, the weaving of the more delicate grasses. As Mr. Otis Tufton Mason expresses it in his "Indian Basketry," "basketry is the mother of all loom and bead work.

Mr. Spearman, who has written so much about railways and railway men, sets forth in his "postscript" that the author of this little volume is a graduate of West Point, who, in the beginning of his railway career, exchanged the commission of Lieutenant in the United States Army for the post of brakeman on the Big Four.
" This volume is dedicated to Noah, who probably originated the idea 'Water, water everywhere, nor any drop to drink.'" And Thomas Ingoldsby is quoted hard after:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23. -- Pat Sheedy, gambler, art connoisseur, and philosopher, who is in St. Louis to prosecute his suit for $25,000 for an alleged gambling debt against Vincent Kerens, son of R.C. Kerens, candidate for the Senate, to-night entertained a crowd in the Southern Hotel lobby with a dissertation on Thomas W. Lawson and his methods of attacking "Frenzied Financiers."

On Dec. 20 you published an article in which you ascribe the deportation of Sarah Agnes MacGill to "red tape on Ellis Island,'' and you quote Mr. Grier, attorney for the Legal Aid Society, as stating that "he considers the action of the immigration officials unjust and high-handed." Mr. Otter denies having made any such statement.

THE life of the Duke of Wellington which is now before us is concerned almost exclusively with the public aspects of the great soldier's career. It is, as the title of the volume declares, "the soldier and the statesman" who is considered.

The jury in the Nan Patterson case after trying vainly for more than twenty-four hours to break the deadlock which continued from the first ballot when the members stood six for conviction and six for acquittal was discharged at 12:52 o'clock yesterday. Justice Vernon M. Davis announced that the defendant was remanded to the Tombs without bail, and the chorus girl was carried from the courtroom in a hysterical condition.

" K in Korea," a "patriotic pot pourri" in two acts, by George Parmly Day, was the title of the play performed before a stag company at Delmonico's last night in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of Company K, Seventh Regiment. Gen. A.L. Mills, Superintendent at West Point, and other military men were present.

" Quantitative Chemical Analysis" is the title of a textbook by Dr. J.C. Olsen, (Van Nostrand; $4) Professor of Analytical Chemistry in the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. It takes up each of the four chief methods used in his science -- the gravimetric, electrolytic, volumetric, and gasometric.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23. -- Fruit, Aurumaster, and Ahola were the beaten favorites to-day. The card was only ordinary and the sport fair. Weather cloudy; track fast. Summary:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Up to the time of the closing of the War Department to-day nothing had been received from Gen. Corbin, commanding the Philippine Division, regarding the affair at Dolores. It is expected that an official report from Gen. Corbin will be received at the Department to-morrow morning.

There are, it seems, certain caves in the Sierra de Monchique Mountains in Portugal where may be found the remains of primitive man, not counting the bones of the mastodon or the woolly rhinoceros. Fired with scientific zeal, a party was formed for the exploration of these caverns.

Mrs. Wilson has written a thoughtful and suggestive little book; one, moreover, so rich in apt quotation, so sparkling, and so original that the reader cannot fail to be fascinated, even though he be unhappy enough to know nothing of "the luxury of children," either as pedagogue or as parent.

An unusually lively and spirited game of hockey was played last night at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, West Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue. The Quebec hockey team, the champions of Canada, made its first appearance here this season, and met the Wanderers, champions of the Amateur Hockey League.

The first book of a two-volume work is about to be issued by the Macmillan Company. It is entitled "A Dictionary of Saintly Women," and is by Agnes B.C. Dunbar. The author has spent a large portion of her time in collecting legends and accounts concerning women venerated as saints.

Does not all this discussion of the merits and demerits of "The Eagle's Shadow" flavor of the tempestuous teapot? [Ah! Peggy, where is that peace of mind you hoped to discover in self-renunciation?] Alas! it is as if a few words of one syllable had unlocked the floodgates of that notoriety in adulation or vituperation which she thought would disappear with the relinquishment of riches.

It is rather the picturesque, the playtime college girl, to whom this book is devoted, in witness whereof the pictures mostly present this most interesting of educational phenomena in cap and gown, or else in May-pole or hoop-rolling ceremonies, in the garb proper for playing basket ball, or the stage finery of the play in the "original Greek."

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Dec. 23. -- A fire, which started shortly before 9 o'clock to-night in the Pelletier department store, had up to 11:30 o'clock, when it was under control, destroyed property valued at more than $1,000,000. The entire territory between Jackson and Pierce, and Third and Fourth Streets, was destroyed and one fireman was killed.

There is no doubt that the American people at large should have a very clear and definite notion of a "doctrine" in behalf of which they are exhorted to be prepared, and are in fact prepared, to go to war with any or all comers. Accordingly Mr. ROOT cannot be accused of wasting his opportunity at the New England dinner in undertaking to define and clarify the Monroe Doctrine.

A suit in which the Dutch Reformed Church of this city, the owners of a twenty-story building and the man who says he is the lessee of an eight-inch splinter of land are concerned, is the latest of these queer real estate disputes to get into court.

LADY GEORGIANA BURNE-JONES has taken six years to complete the life of her distinguished husband, following therein the practice of the latter when working on his paintings. He had been an artist of some note within a restricted circle of admirers and friends when he wrote: "I work daily at Cophetua and his Maid.

Not since August last has there been such a dull day on Change as was that of yesterday. The total sales were 289,382. Whatever business there was was created right on the floor of the Exchange, as there was absolutely no commission business. No one made any attempt to create any movement in anything, and those who tried to discover some feature to the market had a bard time of it.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- George C. Greene, general counsel for the Lake Shore Railroad, made an attack to-night on the plan of Federal control of freight charges, Mr. Greene said:

I have just read with profound astonishment your leading editorial of this morning entitled "To Abolish tile States." In substance you say that it is the purpose of Mr. Garfield, Federal Commissioner of Corporations, and, by implication, of the President, "to strip the States of the power to create corporations and to usurp for the Federal Government the sole authority to confer the right to do corporate business.

" Who's Who, 1905," the yearly biographical dictionary, which is appearing from the Macmillan Company, is now in the fifty-seventh year of its publication. In this volume event which happened later than Aug. 30, 1904, are not included. In order to make the book what it professes to be, each year names have been withdrawn and others are included.

In the innumerable throng of fiction writers Miss Anne Warner is among those distinguished by sufficient versatility to follow up a first success with a second of entirely different character and quality. Furthermore, she is able to give in both the impression that her humor is of the natural and unforced variety that is lasting because it is inspired by happy chance, and could never by any possibility become hackneyed or stereotyped.

Elaborate plans for a new Grand Central Station were placed before the Board of Estimate yesterday by Ira A. Place, General Counsel for the New York Central Railroad, and by George H. Daniels, its General Passenger Agent, both of whom appeared before the board. The plans involve the tearing down of the present structure and the erecting of a magnificent building in its stead, extending much further north than the present building.

There is doubtless more soft coal consumed -- or not wholly consumed, which makes all the difference -- in Greater London than in any other equal area upon the surface of the planet. The London "blacks" resulting from the imperfect combustion are commonly assumed to be the main cause of the London fogs, which from time to time simply paralyze the business of the greatest aggregation of human beings on earth.

WITH whatever enthusiasm the lovers of Thackeray may have followed the issue of this admirable edition as the various installments have come from the press, a joy over the possession of new things must have come to them when they held in their hands the final volume.

In the diary of the Rev. E.J. Peck this entry may be found: "Nov. 3. A whale has been caught to-day. Thank God for it. This monster of the deep will more than supply the needs of a l." That event happened at Blacklead Island, the headquarters of the mission among the Eskimo.

Here is a book devoted to the correct usage of such small words as "and," "who," "to," "also," and "about." James C. Fernald, editor of "The Students' Standard Dictionary" and "English Synonyms and Antonyms," wrote it, and the title is "Connectives of English Speech," (Funk Wagnalls Company, $1.50.) In the introduction the author endeavors to show the absolute necessity of such words, which he calls thought-connectives.

With two books devoted to "Virgin Son" where but one was contemplated, "The Novels and Stories of Ivan Turgenieff," translated from the Russian by Isabel F. Hapgood, have been stretched from fifteen to sixteen volumes, the final four of which having just come to hand, "Ghosts," "The Brigadier," "Spring Freshets," and "A Reckless," each volume so designated also bearing other short stories and sketches.

The announcement of the reappointment of Edward M. Morgan as Assistant Postmaster was announced just before closing time yesterday afternoon by William R. Willcox, the newly appointed Postmaster Mr. Morgan has been connected with the service for over a quarter of a century, having begun as a carrier 31 years ago.
We can hardly imagine that any one who has followed the testimony in the trial of the woman PATTERSON for the murder of the bookmaker YOUNG is surprised that the jury have disagreed as to a verdict.
" The Diary of a Church-Goer" is the title of an anonymous book which the Macmillan Company is bringing out here. In explaining the anonymity of the "diary," the author writes in his preface:

Prof. Trent's little volume on American literature is intended for schools and appears to be well adapted for the purpose. It is complete enough to give the teacher an outline and the pupil a general notion of the subject, and at the same time devotes to certain writers a proportion of attention which serves to relieve the catalogue-like effect which these handbooks of literature can hardly avoid.

Mr. Paine's story of what Thomas Nast did, taken with the immense collection of Nast's pictures he has gathered, makes at all events a volume of great interest. Whether or not Nast's influence upon the history of the country was quite as large as Mr. Paine thinks, it was certainly not small.
The Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke was the guest of honor of the Lotos Club last night, and for two hours sat and listened to tribute from men who like himself have won distinction in the literary world.

" A bird in hand is worth two in the bush. -- Cervantes. But this is not the opinion of the bird." Thus, after an alphabetical list of common sayings, begins the characteristic part of this compilation. Below on the same page one finds other suggestions relating to these celebrated birds from such diverse sources as Opie Read and Plutarch, with three sets of verses on the same theme.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 24. -- Mrs. Mary Shepard of this city is looking forward with pleasure to the celebration to-morrow of her one hundred and fourth birthday. She will begin the day by attending early mass at St. Peter's Catholic Church.

For the first time in the history of the New York Central and its allied railroads, the management seems to have had a realizing sense of what the traffic they control demands in the way of terminal facilities at New York. From its inception the Grand Central Station has been an inadequate makeshift.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 24. -- Dr. W.H. Davis, Mayor of Albany, Ore., appeared before the Federal Grand Jury to-day to explain his connection with the land frauds. The Grand Jury has adjourned until Tuesday morning, and it is not known when Senator Mitchell and Representative Hermann will appear before the body. Senator Mitchell to-day declared in emphatic terms his entire innocence of any part in the land frauds.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- The crisis in Morocco is assuming a warlike aspect, leading the Government to consider all eventualities, including the possibility and even the probability of the occupation of six or seven of the most important ports, giving France control of the Moroccan customs and communication with the outer world.
Athletics in schools for girls and young women may receive a great impetus from the action of the student body of Highcliffe Hall, Miss Anne Brown's School for Girls, at Park Hill on the Hudson.

The market continued to make an excellent showing in various directions last week, and produced more business than it has in any corresponding period since the decline in Washington Heights and Bronx. Speculation. There was marked improvement in the demand for high-class residential properties: lively trading was witnessed in Harlem in both lots and apartment houses.

THERE is perhaps no question of greater import to the American people today than that of the dangers of railway travel. From the very commencement of railroading in this country, or, for that matter, in any other part of the world, accidents have seemed to be inseparable from the operation of steam trains.

Except for a few changes in the material of the acts the International Theatre's programme, at the "St. Louis Fair," in Madison Square Garden, will remain the same as last week. Shungapavi, the Moke Indian, gives a quaint performance in Indian magic; he will have some new tricks this week with a medicine ball.

TWO or three persons having at different times intimated that if I would write an autobiography they would read it when they got leisure, I yield at last to this frenzied public demand, and herewith tender my history.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 24. -- All the hotels have made special arrangements for the holiday throngs which have been arriving for several days. There will be any number of dances and other social features to make the week a merry one. At the Hotel Rudolf Oreste Vessella and his band will give concerts afternoon and evening.

Commissioner of Licenses Frederick L.C. Keating, who was thrown out of the lobby of the Haymarket dance hall, at Thirtieth Street and Sixth Avenue, early Friday morning, and then arrested by Policeman McInerney of the Tenderloin Station at the request of the Haymarket bouncer, yesterday preferred charges against the policeman, accusing him of interference with a Commissioner in the discharge of his duties, assault, and of being in league with the proprietors of the Haymarket.

It is rather a happy phrase that Mr. JAMES M. BECK has invented for the morbid sentiment of hostility toward the possessors and manipulators of great means which always exists in any large community, which occasionally breaks out with sudden force, but which, as he ingeniously cited history to show, is less general and less intense at present than at any previous period.

Katie Maloney, a fifteen-year-old girl, who asserted that she had robbed a neighbor's flat at the bidding of a man, confessed yesterday that the story was made out of whole cloth. Had she adhered to it, as she had already done before two Magistrates, her testimony might have sent Thomas Comiskey and William Barrett to State Prison.

With the lull in vacant property speculation, after a period during which operators and brokers slept with telephones within reach and with maps under their pillows, the excellent demand for business properties has assumed a position of greater importance in the real estate market. The opinion is expressed in the offices of several large brokerage firms that this demand has seldom been better than it is at present.

THE list of this season's debutantes in New York is an unusually large one, over fifty, not all of whom have had formal presentations. Most of the girls are decidedly pretty, if not handsome; there is a large proportion of blondes and a number of decided brunettes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The children of the President will have no Christmas tree. This has been the rule of former seasons as well as now. In fact, there has not been a Christmas tree in the White House since the Cleveland Administration, when the little daughters of that President and their friends always made merry in the library on Christmas afternoon.

So many cases have been received in Bellevue Hospital in the last few days that the institution has been obliged to transfer many patients to the Metropolitan and City Hospitals on Blackwell's Island. As a result these hospitals have been filled to overflowing. One hundred extra cots have been installed in the Metropolitan, and as many in the City Hospital, and no more patients can be received in either place.

The most interesting if not the most important discovery made in recent times in arctic journeyings is recounted by Capt. JENSEN of the cryolite bark Silicon, whose home port is Philadelphia, and who has just returned from a cruise in Greenland waters. He tells of a race of giants seven, eight, and even nine feet tall, having their habitat in those far northern and practically inaccessible regions.

Facing another severe snowstorm, the conditions being even worse than those that prevailed on the previous Saturday, the largest field of target shooters of the Crescent Athletic Club that has turned out this season stood in front of the Bay Ridge traps for three hours yesterday and shot for trophies consisting of pigs, live ducks, turkeys, and roosters.

" Under the circumstances, I will oppose the release of Nan Patterson on bail in any amount," said District Attorney Jerome yesterday. This assertion was taken as pointing positively to a new trial of Miss Patterson on the charge of killing Caesar Young, the bookmaker. If the District Attorney intended to oppose an early date for the trial it would be natural for him to assent to Nan Patterson's release on bail meanwhile.

When the Atlantic Transport Line steamship Minnetonka arrived here from London yesterday George Woodger, the young fourth officer, was removed to Bellevue Hospital and was put in the psychopathic ward.

With the minor differences which threatened a few days ago to breed trouble in the successful management of the automobile speed races next month, on the Ormond-Daytona Beach, Fla., entirely cleared away, automobilists of all sorts, whether speed enthusiasts or not, are looking forward to the results of that week's meet with the keenest interest.

IT IS said of President Arthur T. Hadley of Yale that he was a scholar in his cradle; that he lisped in Latin when other babies only prattled, and cried in Greek on occasions when the ordinary youngster yelled lustily in Volapuk.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Fischer, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by K. Sugawa of St. Louis against the classification as printed books at 25 per cent, of bound books containing pictures and reading matter, in English and Japanese, descriptive of the Russo-Japanese war.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 24. -- Christmas finds a large and congenial company assembled here, and informal pleasures, both in doors and out, are filling in the social calendar, while delightful weather is contributing to the enjoyment of all.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- The relations of the Republican leaders of Westchester County are strained almost to the breaking point over the Senatorship. It became known to-day that the Republican County Committee, after holding a meeting and considering the question, left the entire matter in the hands of National Committeeman William L. Ward.

The recent selection of the course in France for the international motor boat race next year for the Harmsworth Cup, and the fact that some new and high-powered boats are being constructed in England for that event, recall attention to the possibilities of the sport in this country next season.
A woman is seldom as pretty as she thinks she is, nor as homely as other women think her.

Your columns contain a letter this morning signed "Citizens' Unionist," criticising rather savagely the action of the City Committee of the Citizens' Union on Monday night. The communication would be more valuable if the writer had attached his name; still I think it demands an answer, and I beg you will permit me to reply.

The four-story double frame tenement house at 45 Withers Street, Williamsburg, which contained sixteen families, comprising more than sixty persons, was wrecked yesterday morning by an explosion of bombs and other explosives. Several persons were hurt, and one probably mortally. The explosion was in the fourth-floor apartments of Stephen Montano, who, although his neighbors didn't know it, made fireworks, including bombs such as are used in Italian celebrations.

UNLESS he is gifted with an altogether abnormal and unpardonable sense of humor, Arthur Wing Pinero must be, at the present time, a far wiser if much sadder playwright than he was two months ago. The only wonder is that he had to learn his lesson so very late in life.
PARIS, Dec. 24. -- The Russian defense before the international commission which is to inquire into the North Sea incident is practically completed. The main features are:
BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- Mr. Lawson is with his family to-night and will not talk business. His secretary says he knows nothing of a Mexican trip or investigation.

No review of any play engaging the services of Lillian Russell would be complete without at least a reference to the fact that the lady in question would seem to have drunk from the fountain of perpetual youth. That matter, therefore, may as well be disposed of at the outset. It is to be doubted if Miss Russell ever looked more beautiful than she did last evening.

Leslie Hannan, twenty-nine years old, a musician, who for the last six years has conducted a lodging house at 131 Third Avenue, was taken to Bellevue Hospital yesterday in charge of Detective Sergt. W.S. Day, and placed in the psychopathic ward.

Canada's champion hockey team from Quebec lined up against the New York Athletic Club team last night in the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, West Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue, and after a lively match won by 7 goals to 3. All the points were scored in the second half, the first half being somewhat tame and devoid of clever team work.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24. -- At Oakland to-day fifteen selling platers lined up for the seven furlongs scramble, and there was no pronounced favorite. The shortest priced horse in the race was Sugden, closing at 5 to 1. The start was a very good one for such a large field. Military went to the front in the beginning and made a runaway race.

IF you go into the shopping district or if you come out of a church or step down from one of the elevated railway stations during this holiday season you are likely to be confronted by a beggar. Unless you are careful perhaps you will stumble over him, if he chances to be what is known in the vernacular as a "flopper."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The War Department was officially advised to-day by Gen. Corbin, commanding the Department of the Philippines, of the uprising in Samar, in which one Lieutenant and a number of enlisted men of the Philippine Scouts were killed. The cablegram is as follows:

In all churches to-day the annual hospital collection will be taken up. The fund will be distributed by the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association of the City of New York among forty hospitals, covering every branch of medical and surgical science on the basis of the free work performed during the preceding year.

BROCKTON, Mass., Dec. 24. -- A rearrangement of the most important positions on the staff of Governor-elect William L. Douglas was decided upon to-day. Lieut. Gen. Nelson A. Miles, (retired,) instead of being made Adjutant General, will be appointed Inspector General, and will act as the military advisor of the Governor, in effect holding the position of Chief of Staff. The Adjutant General will be Lieut. Col. William Stopford of Beverly.

If many days of preparations, as strenuous as any on record, may serve as an indication, the Merry Christmas ushered in to-day should be as merry as Father Knickerbocker ever enjoyed. When the ante-Christmas buying was brought to an end with the closing of the stores late last night the storekeepers went to their homes rejoicing over the heaviest holiday sales on record.
TOKIO, Dec. 24. -- A dispatch from the Japanese Army before Port Arthur, timed last midnight, says:

E.H. Gary, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday gave out an interview in which he charged that the Inter-State Commerce Commission, in ruling that the division of rates between the Steel Corporation's connecting railroad at Chicago and the other connecting roads were unjustifiable, had violated a tacit agreement with the railroad people in not allowing them to put in evidence in defense at the recent hearings.

I FIRST saw Disraeli in his brougham turning out of Hyde Park into Piccadilly in the Winter of 1858-9. He was then Chancellor of the Exchequer: Lord Derby, Prime Minister; Lord Stanley, the latter's son, long since succeeded to the title. Secretary of State for India; the country and the administration much exercised over the current discussion of Indian affairs in Parliament.

HOPKINS had sent me rather a nice gift, and, of course, I had bought one for Hopkins -- a fellow can do no less than that. I bought him a box of cigars -- a very good brand and expensive, if I do say so. (Hopkins's doctor doesn't allow him to smoke, but I am fond of a good cigar myself.)
LONDON, Dec. 24. -- The lower Thames to-night presents an extraordinary and unprecedented spectacle.
TOKIO, Dec. 24. -- Admiral Togo, telegraphing under date of Dec. 22, says:

ALBANY, Dec. 24. -- J. Warner Bott is President of the Albany Card and Paper Manufacturing Company of 315 Hamilton Street and a member of the Fort Orange Club and the Country Club. Mr. and Mrs. Bott have been well known in Albany society for the last seven years, and had a handsome home in Willett Street and a country home at Mount Hope, Kenwood.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 24. -- It can be announced that Russia is on the eve of abolishing the passport system. The matter has already been decided in principle by the commission which is investigating the passport question.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24. -- Cloudy, threatening weather, with a light rain in the afternoon, were the conditions as Ascot to-day, and the heavy track upset all the calculations of the form players except in the case of Bragg in the third race. With 116 pounds up Bragg again led his field from start to finish over a mile and a sixteenth. This is the only race that fell to the favorite.

STAINED windows at one time were very near to the hearts of the clergy because they furnished a series of lessons in the history of the church which were understood by the simplest minds of the congregation, those who could not read, or, if they could, were not to be trusted with the Scriptures.

CHAIRMAN TAGGART of the Democratic National Committee was discussing the results of the election with a Republican friend who ventured the remark that the Democratic Party would never elect another President on account of the infusion and injection of Bryanism.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24. -- Floral King scored a victory in the Christmas Handicap for which he was a strong second choice. The race was at a mile and was worth $1,455 to the winner. The Hayman pair, De Reszke and Orthodox, the latter ridden by Winnie O'Connor, were decided favorites at 5 to 2, while 9 to 2 or better could be had against Floral King.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Each incoming train yesterday and to-day poured out its loads of happy-looking people on the station platform, and waiting omnibuses, automobiles, and carriages have taken them to the hotels and cottages where they are to spend the Christmas holidays. Lakewood has never before entertained so many Christmas visitors.
ATLANTA, Dec. 24. -- Thomas F. Watson, the candidate for the Presidency on the People's Party ticket, to-day made the following statement on the political situation:

Toward the year's end events in Wall Street are making new history in a way peculiarly suited to the rise in prices which for months has been discounting a favorable future. It is strange that the activity of the market throughout its great rise but the accompaniment of but little real was and that in the weeks of decline and of the activity increased dividend announcement should become frequent.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Dec. 24. -- The total loss by last night's fire in the business section of this city is $2,500,000, and the insurance is about $1,600,000. Kenohah Brockway, who jumped from the fourth story of the Massachusetts Building, missed the life net and was instantly killed. As far as known, there were no other fatalities.

Dealers in American drugs are much alarmed at the scarcity and high price of most of the vegetable drugs indigenous to this country, which have developed during the present year. Many of the drugs in chief demand have advanced from 100 to 300 per cent. in price, and the supply of all is said to be very small.

PEDRO MARLANO was liked by all of the boys about Mulberry Bend. He shared his candy with his companions whenever he got a cent. No seven-year-old boy ever loved a mother more affectionately than Pedro loved his mother. When his father, Antonio Marlano, was killed in a rock blast in the tunnel, Pedro comforted his mother by telling her she would not be compelled to work hard when he got to be a man.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Col. Hepburn, the Chairman of the House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce, called on the President to-day and talked with him about the attack which is to be made on the Panama Commission when Congress reassembles.

Nicholas Murray Butler, President of Columbia University, in his report for the past year has gone deeply into the details of college sport as it now prevails at American institutions of learning. He points out the reforms needed, and comments on Columbia's success in accomplishing these reforms.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Supreme Court Judge Heisley granted an order to-day directing the Sheriff of Bergen County to sell all the personal effects of the late Mrs. Juliet C. Henderson of Hohokus, bring the money into open court, and divide it among her creditors.

HELSINGFORES. Dec. 24. -- The majority of the special committee of the Finnish Diet appointed to report on the petition hat steps be taken to re-establish the Finnish Constitution has reported in its favor, leaving it to Emperor Nicholas to . initiate the measures "necessary to the re-establishment of the constitutional administration and legal order ou thinks In 'lnland."

BEMIDJI, Minn., Dec. 24. -- A big bulldog guarding its master's camp was found in the northern wilds of Minnesota by members of the surveying party just returned from several weeks' work along the northern boundary line.

WE see them all stacked along the sidewalk in front of the florists' and grocers' shops, seemingly by the hundred, and then a day or two after Christmas they have disappeared. Where do they all go to? They are disposed of in more than one way, but the greater part of the left-over trees are sold to the very poor.

Some of those who went to hear the Fourth Symphony of Brahms played at the last Philharmonic concert may have gone there with the memory, still fresh in their minds, of a performance of the same symphony at one of the Wetzler concerts two years ago.

NEVER has the American metropolis, full, as it is, of poverty and pride, seen itself as in the condemnatory mirror which the Rev. S.D. McConnell is holding up to its very selfish and self-satisfied self.
TANGIER, Dec. 24. -- The British Minister has instructed the British Consul and all British subjects to leave Fez.

IN these later days of statistical information, when everything is reduced to decimal, how few grasp the fact that the same "tide" exists on the race track as in the harbor, or in the duplication and reduplication of the seasons?

FATHER IGNATIUS, the English monk who, with a subordinate friar of Raphael-like face two secretaries, and Sister Anne, visited this country fourteen years ago, now stalks boldly through the pages of a biography written by the Baroness de Bertouch and about ready for publication by E.P. Dutton Co. It is called "The Monk of Llanthony."

THE three days' holiday has taken many of the fashionable set from town, and the celebration of Christmas yesterday, to-day, and to-morrow was, is, and will be principally in the country. Even Newport, which of late years has been classed as a Summer resort, is quite crowded over the holidays.

WHILE the Earl of Suffolk was in this city, last week, awaiting the arrival of his wedding togs from English tailors, and looking after the last little details of bachelordon, he did a number of things besides watch the Nan Patterson trial and visit Bellevue.

Detective McIvor of the Tenderloin Station has been unnaturally reticent as to what happened on Friday night when he trailed with a bloodhound the Wonderfully Winsome Woman and the Midnight Mastiff who, for nearly a week now, have been haunting the midnight Rialto on the trail of an unknown something.

TROY, Dec. 24 -- Following the quashing of the indictment for larceny against him, John Schwarzkopf, an attorney of New York, obtained a warrant this afternoon for ex-Judge Edgar L. Fursman of this city on a charge of perjury. The two men were formerly law partners.

There are more people in New York than the Federal census takers ever showed, according to the Federation of Churches and Christian Organizations in New York City, which, through its Secretary, the Rev. Walter Laidlaw, has just completed a census of its own. According to the Federation of Churches, the population of New York on June 1, 1904, was not less than 3,945,907.
FRANK M. CHAPMAN, Assistant Curator of the Department of Ornithology at the American Museum of Natural History, has had many curious glimpses into the private life of birdland.

City Marshal Irvine, aided by four or five husky Tenderloin policemen, made a raid on the box office of the Pike Show at Madison Square Garden last night and collected $200 on an attachment in favor of Francis Aubrey, a lithographer of 128 Fourth Avenue. When the Marshal first demanded the money he was told in plain terms to go way back and find a seat.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Whether one railroad company can by condemnation proceedings under the act of 1890, acquire land that was bought by another railroad company for its own uses, is a legal question that was raised before Supreme Court Justice J. Franklin Fort in Chancery Chambers here to-day.

The fanaticism of the well-intentioned and ill-behaved members of the W.C.T.U. would be amazing if there were not so many instances of the same spirit in past and in current history. We do not ourselves profess any more expert knowledge of the workings of the canteen and of the abolition of the canteen than that which is possessed by the members of the W.C.T.U. themselves.

While the snow was still falling the gallery of the Century Club was being hung with the canvases of one of the most convinced painters of snowscapes we have, Mr. Birge Harrison, whilom of Philadelphia, but latterly of New England passim, than whom not even Mr. Walter Launt Palmer is a more enthusiastic devotee to the charms of the North American Winter.

A foreign banker associated with one of the best-known banking houses in Wall Street last week expressed the opinion that it was extremely hard to find an explanation of the willingness of investors to place their funds in various industrial issues at prices which yield a relatively low income, in some cases 4 per cent. or even less.

The world's Exchanges were closed yesterday, so that there were no dealings in securities or commodities. But the day not being a legal holiday here, our banks were open for routine business, although there was no money market. The bank statement was issued as usual, and it leaves the situation unaltered except in detail.

Young GOULD, the undergraduate of the School of Mines, Columbia University, who by firing a pistol repelled the attack of sophomores intent upon his capture and detention to make sport at the sophomore banquet, has been the subject of a good deal of harsh criticism for not "playing the game according to the rules."
In the current issue of The Manufacturers' Record of Baltimore is published an article from its New York correspondent on New York's street transportation facilities as follows:

Last week the market fell asleep as naturally as possible. Torpor always follows such unnatural excitement as the lashing of the Amalgamated market into exhausting fury. And the assembling of the National Legislature is always soothing to the activities of those who like to see the markets rise. When these influences fall in with a holiday season the effect is as soporific as a Summer sermon.

London, Dec. 5. A STORY is current about a couple of prominent Liberals that illustrates very prettily the political situation in Great Britain as the Liberals see it. One of the two men went to call on the other, and found him, with scowling face, viciously jabbing a meek and lowly grate fire with a big iron poker.

It was announced in the local cigar trade yesterday that the Cuban cigar manufacturers had worked out a plan to evercome the effect of the recent decision of the Treasury Department abolishing the large customs stamp on imported cigar boxes, which has been looked on by consumers as a guarantee by the United States Government of the quality of the cigars contained in them.
How is it possible, as Mr. Lawson asserts, that a few persons plunder the people of America?
Senator Depew, in announcing yesterday that there had been no developments in the Senatorship situation so far as he knew, said:

Charles Foster Dodge, one of the principals in the Dodge-Morse divorce tangle, who was brought to this city from Texas Friday night to answer to a charge of perjury, was discharged from custody yesterday and passed last night a free man in his rooms at the Broadway Central Hotel

The third and final round of the intercollegiate chess tournament in which Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton contested at the West Side Republican Club in this city, was concluded at 7 o'clock last night, the result being another victory for Harvard's champion team, the Crimson's players breaking even with Columbia in the last match and winning out with a grand total of 8 1/2 points, as against 6 for Princeton, which finished in second place.

THE Chicago Orchestra has finally occupied its new music hall, built especially for it by the subscriptions of Chicago millionaires, bankers, lawyers, clerks, stenographers, janitors, scrubwomen, and others who have an interest in music and the work that Mr. Thomas has been doing with the orchestra.

Several of the amateur billiard players were considerably stirred up yesterday over the news that had come from Chicago that those in charge of the National championship tournament had expressed themselves as not caring whether or not any of the Eastern players entered the tournament. Edward Gardner, an ex-champion and former holder of the Gold Cup, expressed himself in no unmeasured terms when seen in Maurice Daly's academy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Occasionally it grinds the very soul of a member of the House to know that by long effort he has won his way to a place in the House aristocracy and that there is no way of making his people at home see the significance of the great event. They do not even know that there is a House aristocracy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- A local newspaper says that the Pennsylvania Railroad Company is prepared to spend $30,000,000 in the construction of a new railway station in Chicago. Twenty millions of this sum will be spent in acquiring land adjoining the present Union Depot and $10,000,000 will be spent in buildings.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- Three men were killed and three were seriously hurt in a crash of two ice-boats speeding before a gale of wind at the rate of fifty miles an hour on Onondaga Lake this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Writing of the sale of American-made goods in Nottingham, England, United States Consul Malim says that while no figures are obtainable there is apparently an increase in imports this year over last year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 25. -- Harvard's oarsmen are preparing for the coming season with a spirit and enthusiasm which have seldom been seen here before. The appointment of Wray as head coach has greatly encouraged the undergraduates, who now hope to break the long series of victories which Yale has been winning upon the Thames.

Two women lost their lives early this morning in a fire which burned out the attic of the two-story-and-attic brick house at 201 Allen Street. Owen McGrath and his wife, living in the place, were taken to Gouverneur Hospital in a precarious condition from smoke asphyxiation.

The educational awakening throughout China is a matter for profound attention to all thoughtful persons. Reform in education is in the air. The great mandarins in Peking are taking it up, and edicts favoring it have been sent throughout the empire. Some of the great Viceroys are warmly and enthusiastically in favor of it.
LONDON, Dec. 25. -- The Times's Tokio correspondent sends the following letter on the naval fight of Aug. 10:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- In a report on "Miners' Consumption in England," Mr. Halstead, Consul at Birmingham, says:

The American liner St. Louis, due here on Saturday, reached New York early yesterday morning. Although she brought over seven hundred steerage passengers the St. Louis had in her cabins less than a hundred persons, the total in the saloon apartments being only thirty-one. The liner arrived outside Sandy Hook late on Saturday night, but owing to weather conditions anchored and did not pass the bar until daylight.

Charles F. Dodge, whose return from Texas last Friday to stand trial on a charge of perjury was so suddenly followed a day later by his discharge in court, spent Christmas Day at the Broadway Central Hotel in a confinement closely resembling that of a prisoner. Not only did he not stir away from the hotel, but he was kept constantly under surveillance by County Detective Hammond and Roundsman Beery of the District Attorney's office.

A very large memorial window designed by Miss Mary E. Tillinghast is on exhibition at the stained glass shops 46 South Washington Square. It is a decoration for the flat apse of the First Congregational Church in Attleborough, Mass., and is adapted to three tall and two shorter, narrow lancets in an interior of modern ecclesiastical Gothic.

There was less business done and almost no movement shown in Stock Exchange transactions last week. Only eighty-six issues moved as much as a point, and the advances numbered thirty-nine, to forty-six declines. Selecting the dozen active stocks which supplied two-thirds of the total 2,729,099 shares, there were among them six advances, four declines, and two unaltered quotations.

" Sk-r-r-r-a-t-t-s-k -- Hello, St. Louis -- Bill, I have a good Christmas story for you -- no British joke, you know. Congratulations of th cseason first, though. Merry Christmas, even if your old boat did get in late. Same old excuse, I suppose. Now for that story. It's about a goat -- Sk-r-r-r-atsk."

Chickens and Remorse. It was only a few days ago that a reader of African descent expostulated with us at some length for showing levity in a discussion of the unhallowed bond which by common and unkindly report so often associates the members of his race with domestic fowls belonging to people of lighter complexions.

Radical police regulations will shortly be introduced in Bellevue Hospital to curb the long-condoned evil of caring for the several thousand habitual and occasional drunkards who every years seek this institution to sleep off their sprees. Arrest instead of comfortable cots will be their fate.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25. -- Capt. Baldwin's airship California Arrow, driven by Roy Knabenshue of Toledo, Ohio, who made several successful flights in the same machine from the World's Fair grounds at St. Louis, had its first trial in California to-day and was successful with the single exception of its failure to land at the starting point.

Continued loss of membership in the League of American Wheelmen has resulted in the abandonment of all but three State divisions -- New York, Massachusetts, and Pennsylvania, and the grouping of the abandoned divisions into four districts, each of which will have but two votes in the National Assembly in place of over one hundred and fifty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The day of miracles has not passed, according to the firm belief of a hundred or more poor people in Washington. Yesterday Almas Temple of Shriners gave its annual dinner to the poor. It was a well-planned affair, generously contributed to, and turned out a big success. But the most notable thing about it was not on the programme and made the hit of the occasion.

New York had a real old-fashioned Christmas yesterday, with snow enough to insure good attendance at home festivities and to sharpen the appetites of the youngsters to try new sleds, but not too much to interfere with the elaborate services arranged by the churches. The churches, decorated for the occasion with holly, palms, and evergreens of all sorts, were crowded.

Christmas is past. With every fibre of our being pulsating with sincerity you have spoken of Love, Peace, and Good Will. With true hearts you have voiced Faith, Hope, and Charity. These thoughts are our thoughts; these ideals are our ideals. Can we not unite to weave them into the web of human conduct?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- To Stettin belongs the distinction of erecting the first imitation sandstone or beton building in Northern Germany, says United States Consul John E. Kehl, writing from Stettin.ent."

BLACKSHEAR, Ga., Dec. 25. -- T.B. Altman, a prominent farmer, dead, his son, Darling Altman, charged with involuntary manslaughter, and City Marshal McMillan badly cut, is the result of a Christmas Eve row here.

New York druggists do not know where it will end. What with golden seal at $1.75 a pound, an advance of almost 150 per cent. since Jan. 1, 1904; camphor 10 cents a pound higher than it was a week ago, and senega root, ginseng, wild cherry bark, white pine bark, elder flowers, sarsaparilla root, and sassafras all scarcer and dearer than ever known, they are beginning to figure on the future with considerable doubt.

In spite of a snowstorm and the fact that it was Christmas Day there was an unusually large attendance at the Central Federated Union meeting yesterday to hear what State Labor Commissioner John McMackin had to say in reply to the charges made by Robert Hunter, Chairman of the Child Labor Committee on the previous Sunday.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- The most notable feature of Christmas Day in the United Kingdom was the large amount of charity distributed as the result of the generous sums collected for this purpose through the newspapers and other channels.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25. -- Four men were suffocated and eight other persons were rescued from fire in three different parts of the city early to-day. At a boarding house at 1545 Wood Street, Charles McCusker, aged forty-four years; James Merry, forty-eight years, and Joseph McGill, twenty-four years, died in a trap made by themselves.

James W.S. Langerman, formerly United States Vice Consul General at Tangier, Morocco, is in New York on his way to report to the Sultan of Morocco, whose personal representative he was at the St. Louis Exposition. He talked of Morocco and its desire for American trade at the Waldorf last night.

Just as Mrs. Lillian Bullerton's boarders took their seats in the dining room of her establishment at 380 St. Nicholas Avenue for Christmas dinner yesterday a crash sounded in the kitchen, and the guests started as if to flee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Workingmen's gardens in France are discussed in a recent report by United States Consul Atwell of Roubaix. The evil of intemperance has so undermined the health and usefulness of workmen that this means is sought of interesting them in such healthful employment outside of mill hours as shall bring them increased comfort and attach them to the soil which they cultivate.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 25. -- If the fifteenth General Assembly of Colorado, which is to meet Wednesday, Jan. 4, shall effectuate the plans formulated by the managers of the Republican post-election campaign, Gov. James H. Peabody may serve as Chief Executive of this State for two years more, despite the fact that Alva Adams still has nearly 10,000 plurality.

The Hon. PAUL MORTON, Secretary of the Navy, avers that America, in order to build up a big shipping interest, "will be obliged to meet the competition of all nations." That is quite true. He predicts that we shall be forced "to recognize the mail contracts, the subsidies, and the premiums of Germany, and of England, and of other Governments" to effect this consummation.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Kemter of this city believe that the mutilated body of the young woman found Nov. 19 in North Cheyenne Canon, near Colorado Springs, is that of their daughter, Mrs. Bessie Boston.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 25. -- The passenger train which left St. Louis at 9 o'clock last night on the Southern Railway collided to-day head on near Mauds Station, Ill., with the passenger train which left Louisville about the same hour. One passenger and six employes were killed and two passengers and eight employes were slightly injured.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 25. -- Bishop John Scarborough of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey, who was named by Bishop Talbot as one of the seven Bishops fully knowing the character of the Rev. I.N.W. Irvine, who was unfrocked by Bishop Talbot, said to-night that he had no official relation with the case.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- From La Rochelle, France, United States Consul G.H. Jackson writes:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The members of the Russian Embassy conducted a raffle last night for the benefit of the Russian wounded in Manchuria.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25. -- By order of the Presiding Bishop of the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church a new chapter in the famous Irvine-Talbot controversy will be started in Reading on Jan. 10.

A great sensation has been caused in Italy by the charge made by Capt. Baccari, who was sent to the Congo Free State as the accredited representative of King Victor Emmanuel to report upon the possibility of starting an Italian emigration scheme for the Congo, that the Free State authorities attempted to have him poisoned, and that afterward the Governor General of the Congo tried to prove that he was insane.
LONDON, Dec. 25. -- The Times, in its financial supplement to-morrow, will say:

When the new Colonial Theatre at Sixty-second Street, Broadway, and Columbus Avenue opens its doors to the public on Jan. 15 the upper west side will have close at hand what no other portion of the city now has -- a regular London music hall, run on the same lines as the Alhambra and others that have become famous in the British capital.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 25. -- A young woman, who declined to tell her name, was run down by a trolley car at Main and Day Streets, Orange, about midnight last night, and escaped injury by an acrobatic feat which called forth the admiration of all who saw it. The woman had been shopping, and her arms were piled so high with bundles that it was with difficulty she could see where she was going.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25. -- Miss Voltairine De Cleyre, who calls herself an Anarchist, left her bed in the consumptive ward of the Medico-Chirurgical Hospital to-day, walked through the snow and attended a mass meeting of the Russian Socialist Revolutionist Party in the Casino, where 1,500 persons listened to the story of Mme. Kathrine Breschkovsky, who for more than twenty-two years was a Siberian exile.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 25. -- It was an exceedingly gloomy Christmas for Mrs. Chadwick, who remained alone in her cell most of the day, not taking advantage of the Christmas custom of allowing to the prisoners unusual freedom in the jail.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Henry Casson, Sergeant-at-Arms of the House, was connected with the Speaker's Bureau of the Republican Congressional Committee in the late campaign, and his friends out in his home district, the Second Iowa, ascribe to him all the credit for the Republican sweep in the Nation last month.
TOKIO, Dec. 25. -- Tokio is again a great military camp, and the scenes of last Spring, when the first armies were mobilized and dispatched, are being duplicated.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- According to the tax books of the cities and towns of Westchester County, filed yesterday with the Board of Supervisors, the total assessed valuation this year will be about $200,000,000, or $25,000,000 greater than the entire State of Nevada. The valuation last year was $198,702,924.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Dec. 25. -- In accordance with the verdict of the jury in the trial of the alleged fraudulent bond case, the court has pronounced judgment as follows:
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- Mrs. Mary Shepard of this city celebrated her 104th birthday to-day, having been born in Ireland Dec. 25, 1800.

ALBANY, Dec. 25. -- Complaints of the alleged pollution of the waters of Lake Champlain and of the Boquet and Au Sable Rivers by the refuse products of woodpulp mills at Willsborough and Au Sable Forks, Essex County, are corroborated apparently by the findings of the experts of the New York State Health Department, in its special report to Gov. Odell, by whose order the investigation was instituted.

Adolph Herschkopf, after serving eight years of a life sentence in Sing Sing, became a free man yesterday by pardon of Gov. Odell. Herschkopf was not the most miserable man in New York last night. He had been employed in the prison tailor shop, and had not felt the touch of snow on his face since entering the prison gates.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- An Italian correspondent, who was lately with the Russian headquarters in Manchuria, furnishes, in an article in The Times, some interesting illustrations of Russian methods.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 25. -- The drought which has been costing Western Pennsylvania industries $1,000,000 a day has been broken. On the crest of a rise in the Ohio River 15,000,000 bushels of coal will be shipped South.

The list of the telephone's utilities lengthens as time goes on and it is found subservient to the most various and unexpected uses. It is only lately that it has been employed for conducting religious services, when for any reason the congregation could not come together, but it is found on trial to do the business acceptably and to the edification of those to whom it is made to minister.

The cold wave from the Ohio Valley predicted by the Weather Bureau struck New York with full force yesterday morning. It came in sections, each section a fraction colder than its predecessor. This continued up to about 10 o'clock, when the temperature began to rise, the clouds became heavy, and the weather sharps knew that a snowstorm was imminent.

I notice in to-day's TIMES that Mr. A. Augustus Healy, a manager of the United States Leather Company, communicates a lengthy article arguing for the proposed "reorganization" plan of the Leather Company. Why should such arguments by a manager of the company in public print for the plan of reorganization be necessary?

District Attorney Jerome, it was learned yesterday, has a big surprise in store for the public in the case of Charles F. Dodge, who was brought from Texas last week to stand trial on the charge of perjury and unexpectedly discharged in court. Long tales have been printed on this subject, and some grains of truth have been among their contents.

George S. Evans, broker and promoter, who for years has occupied offices at 63 Wall Street, and was, until recently, reckoned a man of means, shot himself in the head early yesterday morning in a room in a small hotel opposite the Pennsylvania station in Jersey City. He died instantly.

In to-day's issue of THE TIMES I notice a letter from a navy yard clerk with reference to the "Rights of Government Employes." The only right about which he seemed anxious was a longer vacation. Government clerks are amply protected under the civil service laws and regulations, and if the rights of letter carriers, navy yard clerks, , are infringed upon, they have their recourse to the courts and numerous civil service commissions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Representative Robert Baker of Brooklyn was asked to discourse on how it feels to be regarded as "the kicker of the House." He has maintained his reputation in this respect in this session, as he did in the last, and just as Congress adjourned for the holidays he succeeded in defeating by well timed objections the proposition to turn over the Pension Office to the inaugural ball.

TOKIO, Dec. 26. -- Foreign correspondents just returned from Port Arthur declare that fortress to be the strongest place ever besieged. They say the things accomplished by the Japanese almost stagger belief, even when seen. They do not think any other army in the world would have made such progress under such conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Senor Quesada, the Cuban Minister, in view of reports that yellow fever was again obtaining a foothold in Cuba, and that the Cuban Government was not vigorously enforcing sanitary precautions, to-night gave out a statement which is in part as follows:

The opponents of any change in the tariff -- and they are more active and determined than they were at the opening of the session of Congress -- insist that the country is prosperous and therefore no change should be undertaken. It is true that the country is prosperous, but we do not know of any of its citizens who would object to a little more prosperity.

"In Newport," a musical burlesque on fashionable society, was presented at the Liberty Theatre last night by the Klaw Erlanger Comedy Company, an organization which includes several popular favorites -- Fay Templeton, Peter Dailey, Virginia Earle, Joe Coyne, and Lee Harrison. These were the reasons why "In Newport" will probably be a success.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 26. -- Miss Ida Conquest appeared at the Hyperion Theatre to-night as the star in George Rollitt's three-act comedy, "The Money Makers," under the management of "Tom" W. Ryley. It was the first production of the piece in this country, although in London "The Money Makers" has had a successful run at the Royalty Theatre.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 26. -- Reports leaking out in Pittsburg within the last ten days and developments of the last twenty-four hours point to trouble in the armor plate business within the next three weeks. The Naval Board at Washington will open bids on Jan. 12 for armor plate for the battleship New Hampshire and cruisers, aggregating in all about 8,000 tons of armor, which at the present price of plate would cost something like $3,340,000.

Into the biography of the goat Babe, mascot of the battleship Kentucky, now at the navy yard, there went another chapter yesterday. This was headed "The Goat Becomes an Automobile, and Why." The author is one "Toddy" Jones, able seaman. Here is his tale, which is accompanied by no affidavits:

In a revival in which sincerity of purpose and good taste are so manifest as in the case of "The Winter's Tale." in which Miss Viola Allen was seen at the Knickerbocker Theatre last evening, the spirit of carping criticism may well be stilled and the efforts of the players received with some degree of thankfulness by those persons who still find pleasure in the acted versions of William Shakespeare's plays.

Removing the snow on Christmas Day was a rather sad affair for Commissioner Woodbury as well as the 4,000 men who actually handled it. In the first place, the 4,000 men were about one-third of the number engaged usually in cleaning the city's streets when the snow is as deep as it was yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 26. -- There seems to be no evidence of a cessation of the agitation in different parts of the country in favor of liberal reforms. The situation is most acute in Moscow, where the university is closed, and the students and the pedagogic and other societies are in a constant state of ferment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Mrs. Leslie Carter scored a success to-night with "Adrea" at Convention Hall, which David Belasco has adopted as the place for his Washington presentations. In "Adrea" Mrs. Carter abandoned her accustomed class of plays and made her debut in tragedy.

Debutantes will be out in full force and in full glory to-night, for there are three private dances on the social programme, one to be given at Sherry's by Mrs. Howard Page for Miss Lily Lee Page; another at Dodworth's by Mrs. Amos Morrill for Miss Elsie Morrill, and a third by Mrs. John Claflin of Washington Square at her home for Miss Wilhelmine Claflin.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 26. -- Brooklyn, which scored in the fifth race, was the only winning favorite to-day. Kickshaw and Luralighter fell in the fourth race, but neither horses nor riders were hurt. Weather threatening; track fast. Summary:

Edward Terry, the English actor, who made his first appearance in this country yesterday afternoon, was received in a spirit of generous warmth that must have gone far toward reconciling him to the fact that the season of good cheer finds him far away from home. The audience that assembled in the Princess Theatre had obviously come in a fine holiday mood, and this fact was reflected in an abundance of laughter and applause.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 26. -- President Roosevelt could not have given a greater surprise to Congressman Frank Wachter and other leaders of the local Republican organization than he did by his choice to-day of W. Hall Harris as Postmaster of Baltimore to succeed S. Davies Warfield.

Eighteen Chinamen, charged with being common gamblers, were arraigned in the Tombs Court yesterday, but Magistrate Breen discharged all except one. On the promise of the police to produce more evidence against Sing Moh, said to be one of the proprietors of the place, the Magistrate held him in $1,000 for examination to-morrow.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 26. -- Mrs. Madeline MacKay Williams, wife of Charles Williams, District Superintendent of the Union News Company, killed herself at her home at 269 Essex Avenue to-night by drinking acid. A little while before Mrs. Williams had a slight tiff with her daughter Margaret, sixteen years old, about the dress which the girl was to wear this evening at a Christmas dance for young folks at the South Orange Field Club.

The interior and part of the exterior and much of the furnishings of the beautiful chapel in Sailors' Snug Harbor, which has been called the most magnificent structure of its kind in the world, were destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. The interior of the structure is almost an absolute wreck.

After a lapse of three years, the Seventh Regiment handicap and championship competitions in indoor tennis were revived yesterday afternoon, on the large floor of the armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. A number of the best players in the regiment turned out, and while the contests did not advance beyond the first rounds in the events, there were several lively and well-contested matches.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec 26. -- A portion of the Acadia Powder Company's works, at Waverly, ten miles from this city, blew up to-day and the concussion shook the country and broke windows for twenty miles around. No one was killed or even seriously injured, although about twenty of the employes who had just left the building, which was demolished, were thrown violently to the ground and stunned.

Replying to the request of the City Club for facts concerning the new lighting contracts Commissioner Oakley of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity announced last night that he had made a full report to Mayor McClellan in a letter to the Mayor in reply to one addressed to the Mayor by Lawrence Veillier, Secretary of the City Club.

With their trotters and pacers hooked to featherweight speeding cutters, road drivers held an impromptu sleighing carnival in the Park and on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday. The footing was all that could be desired, as the snow which fell Sunday just put a nice covering on the roads that have been ice bound for several days past, without making them too heavy for fast work.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26. -- The Zemstvo Congress of the Moscow Government opened to-day. Prince Trubetzkoi, the President, in his opening address, dwelt upon the serious condition of Russia and the regretable war with Japan, the end of which could not be anticipated in the near future, as well as the grave economical crisis through which the country was passing, and the internal disorganization of the empire.

The British freight steamship Drumelzier, which sailed from New York for Havre, Dunkirk, and Swansea on Sunday morning, went ashore on the Fire Island bar eight hours later. It was not until early yesterday morning, however, that her predicament was observed by the Oak and Fire Island Life Saving stations, the crews of both of which went to the assistance of the vessel.

Better proof of our Washington correspondent's recent statement that the papers of that city support the departmental clerks in their antagonism to any official who attempts to get from them the amount of work that would be demanded by a private employer could not be desired than a long "protest" made by The Washington Star against the article in which that statement was made.

The final exhibition game of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club's holiday season was played in the clubhouse, in West Forty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, when in a special match at racquets George Standing, the former English champion and instructor for the club, won from Edward Rodgers and David Gardner, the two most skillful of his assistants, after a close and hard-fought contest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Secretary Taft received to-day a cable message from Gov. Wright at Manila in response to his inquiry in regard to the recent uprising of the Pualjanes at Dolores, Samar, in which Lieut. Hoyt and thirty-seven men were killed. Gov. Wright's message is as follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- After President Roosevelt's inauguration will come a number of changes in the Diplomatic Corps. of which the most important have already been decided upon.

OAKLAND, Cal., Dec. 26. -- The special feature of the races to-day at the Oakland track was the mile and a quarter handicap, with Claude, carrying the top weight, 127 pounds, an odds-on favorite in the betting. The son of Lissak won, with Military Man second and Leila third. Davis rode the winners in the first two races and was second in the fourth and fifth. Summary:

ORANGE, Dec. 26. -- With his coat ablaze and half suffocated with smoke, Fireman George Eager of Hook and Ladder Company No. 1 of the Orange Fire Department rescued to-day from the third story of the residence of Samuel Brody, at 69 Essex Avenue, Mr. Brody's four-year-old daughter Gertrude. The rescue was one of the best in the history of the local Fire Department.

A representative crowd of speed skaters of the metropolitan clubs gathered on Verona Lake, near Montclair, N.J., for the regular racing programme of the Verona Lake Skating Club yesterday, and four events decided furnished an afternoon of the most exciting sport that the season has produced so far.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- Sheriff Barry of Cuyahoga County, Ohio, who expects to arrest Dr. Leroy S. Chadwick, husband of Mrs. Chadwick, when he lands in New York to-morrow, on the charge of forging the name of Andrew Carnegie, met a check in his plans to-day when he failed to obtain from Gov. Odell the requisition papers necessary to permit the transportation of Dr. Chadwick to Ohio for trial.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 26. -- The handsome residence of Col. and Mrs. Tracy B. Warren in Seaview Avenue, facing Long Island Sound, was burned to-day, a candle which was a part of the decoration of a Christmas tree starting the blaze. Col. and Mrs. Warren were entertaining a party of children at the time.

Patrick White, thirty-five years old, of 522 West Fifty-third Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon, charged with smuggling liquor on board the warship Alabama, which is lying off the foot of West Forty-second Street. White went to see a friend aboard the warship and took with him, it is said, a quart bottle of fine old whisky.
LONDON, Dec. 27. -- The Daily Telegraph's correspondent at Che-Foo, in a dispatch dated Dec. 26, says:

As President of a club which exists for the purpose of giving support and currency to the economic teachings of Henry George, I beg the courtesy of space to correct a misapprehension which may arise from a statement recently published in your editorial columns.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 26. -- When the four negroes who murderously assaulted three policemen in North Plainfield Saturday night were taken from their cells this afternoon to be removed to the Somerset County Jail, in Somerville, a mob surrounded the prisoners, who were escorted by Mayor Smalley, Chief Weiss, and a squad of North Plainfield police.

An impressive ceremony marked the blessing of the chimes presented by the Bohemian family of Maschek von Masburg at the Bohemian Catholic Church, Seventy-second Street and Second Avenue, yesterday at the 10 o'clock service. Mgr. Lavelle of St. Patrick's, representing Archbishop Farley, officiated, assisted by the rector, the Rev. Father John T. Prout, and other priests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The marriage of the third and last daughter of the late Levi Z. Leiter of this city and Chicago to a representative of the English nobility took place at noon to-day at the family residence on Dupont Circle, where Miss Marguerite Hyde Leiter, generally known as Miss Daisy Leiter, became the bride of Henry Molyneaux Paget Howard, the nineteenth Earl of Suffolk and twelfth Earl of Berkshire.

Oligarchy is a handy, if not strictly accurate, term for the relatively small number of men who practically govern the House of Representatives, who have great power in securing action there, an almost absolute power in obstructing such action as they may choose to oppose.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Attorney General Moody discussed with the President to-day certain phases of the railroad rate question. The Attorney General is giving special attention to the legal side of the proposition to enact a law providing for placing inter-State corporations under Federal law and regulation.

Domenico Faraone killed himself yesterday morning at his home, 331 East Seventy-fifth Street, by drinking oxalic acid. Domenico was known among the artists of the city as the "Greek god." Among his fellow-workingmen in the construction of the Subway he was known as "the man to be feared." His greatest pride was that he had been the model for one of the sailors in the navy group on the Dewey celebration monument.

Following out the plan instituted about two years ago by the Polo Club of Squadron A in holding polo competitions with the West Point cadets, the newly organized hockey team of the squadron is making arrangements to play the West Point hockey men. Theron R. Strong, manager of the squadron team, said yesterday that the match was practically assured, and the date of Feb. 25 has been provisionally set for the game.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 27. -- Attorney General Moody, for the United States, through United States District Attorney Haupt and Frank B. Kellogg and James M. Beck, Special Assistant Attorneys General of the United States, took action to-day against the Western Paper Trust.

QUINCY, Ill., Dec. 27. -- Bishop Edward Fawcett of the Quincy Diocese of the Episcopal Church was interviewed to-day in regard to the allegation that Bishop Talbot of Pennsylvania had declared that the Bishop of Quincy had told him that the Rev. Ingram Irvine had been guilty of serious offenses in Quincy. Bishop Fawcett made this statement for publication:

The policeman said that he found him steadying a fence on St. Paul's Avenue, Jersey City, yesterday. He was later arraigned in the Second Criminal Court, where he said that he was John Severance, painter, ventriloquist, and artist. Judge Manning suggested an exhibition of his skill as a ventriloquist.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- When ex-Supreme Court Justice Edgar L. Fursman appeared before Justice Jones to-day in answer to a warrant accusing him of perjury, counsel for the accused caused a postponement for a day by moving that the warrant be dismissed on the ground that the information was insufficient.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 27. -- The general opinion is that the Emperor's manifesto on the subject of reforms represents a victory for Interior Minister Sviatopolk-Mirsky and the Conservative Liberals over M. Pobiedonostzeff. Procurator General of the Holy Synod, and the Reactionaries, and that it practically places the strong combination of M. Witte and Prince Sviatopolk-Mirsky behind the Government's programme.

Mrs. Nettie Hoffmann of 893 Eighth Avenue heard some one moving in a room occupied by one of her lodgers yesterday afternoon, and as she believed that the tenant of the room would not be at home at that time she attempted to force the door.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 27. -- In an outspoken article in reply to the recent letter of Admiral Birileff appealing to the Russians not to criticise openly the condition of the navy, the Russ to-day declares the time has passed for silence. It says:

CINCINNATI, Dec. 27. -- The "King Dodo" company now appearing in this city will close its season at the end of the engagement here on Saturday. The company was placed on the road by Max Anderson. The season opened in Trenton, N.J. The cost of the production is given as the reason for disbanding.

PERU, Ind., Dec. 27. -- A fast train on the Wabash Railroad, east bound, came in collision with a freight train at 9 o'clock to-night at Fort Wayne, and it is believed that one man was killed, two persons fatally injured, and twelve or fourteen more or less seriously hurt. The collision occurred on a steep grade, and both engines and several cars were demolished.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Gen. and Mrs. Draper gave a dinner to-night in honor of Capt. Kaempff of the Deutschland, who is their guest. The company included the Russian Ambassador, the Ambassador from Austria-Hungary and Baroness Hengelmuller, the Belgian Minister and the Baroness Moncheur, Mrs. McCormick, wife of the Ambassador to Russia, Rear Admiral and Mrs. Higginson, and the Assistant Secretary of State and Mrs. Pierce.
LONDON, Dec. 27. -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day for month-end and settlement requirements, and there was much borrowing from the Bank of England. Discounts weakened slightly.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Dec. 27. -- Josiah Flournoy, a civil and mining engineer of this city, who for a number of years lived in Venezuela, has received a letter announcing that property which was acquired by himself and associates while he was in that country has been confiscated by the Venezuelan Government.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- The conditions which had prevailed among the shipping in the Thames for nearly a week were considerably improved to-day. Much of the produce intended for the London Christmas market was unloaded. The loss, however, through its late arrival aggregates several hundred thousand pounds.

Wall Street resumed business after its triple Christmas holiday in the cheerful temper which was anticipated. There had been no unfavorable developments, and resumption of business was accompanied by much routine news of a sustaining sort. The advance in the iron schedule has now proceeded far enough to warrant advancing wages, 2 per cent. being added to tin plate workers' pay.

Following is the presentment in the case against Bishop Ethelbert Talbot of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Central Pennsylvania on new charges growing out of his connection with the deposition of Dr. Ingram N.W. Irvine of Philadelphia from the priesthood:

George Macculloch Miller, Secretary of the Trustees of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, announced after the meeting of the Trustees yesterday that the sum of $600,000 had been subscribed by an anonymous donor for the completion of a choir. This is in addition to the sum of $100,000 and $50,000 previously announced, making $750,000 in all.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27. -- Two records were made at Ascot track to-day, Gold Rose going a mile in 1:38 3/4, which is equal to the California record, made by Divina at San Francisco, and Needful galloping the Brooks course, seventy-three yards less than a mile and a quarter, in 2:03. Besides these features, the day's card had a steeplechase in which two horses fell.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27. -- Royal White, at 30 to 1, brought woe to the talent at Oakland today. Weather showery; track slow. Summary:

Delegates from the seven universities and academies comprising the Intercollegiate Fencing Association attended the annual midwinter meeting yesterday, which was held at the Plaza Hotel. The New York Athletic Club, as in former years, was selected for the annual championship tournament, and the dates for the event were fixed for Friday and Saturday evenings, March 24 and 25.

Controller Grout went to work yesterday on the preparations for his coming investigation into the city's lighting situation. He expects to have the public sessions of his investigation under way before the close of the week, and may request witnesses to be present in his office to-morrow to answer questions concerning the positions and the claims of the companies.
