A great many conservative people who are not afflicted with "moneyphobia" have been anxiously awaiting some statement from business interests against whom various charges of a "frenzied" character have been made. I think that neither the address of James M. Beck nor your own editorial comments upon that address will afford much satisfaction to the public.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 27. -- Bishop Whitehead of Pittsburg said to-day he would appear before the commission appointed to investigate the presentment against Bishop Talbot, and would tell what he knows of Dr. Irvine, who is alleged to be back of the charges against Bishop Talbot, who unfrocked him. Bishop Whitehead refused to discuss the case further, and said:

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 27. -- Patrick Fortin, engineer of a Lackawanna Road freight train, was found, bleeding and scalded, in a snowbank near Waterloo early this morning. He told the track walker who found him that he had been blown out of his cab by a bursting steam pipe and that his engine, a big camelback, was running wild with the train at a forty-mile-anhour clip.

There are now before the Mayor certain amendments to the rules adopted by the Civil Service Commission which we believe will work a decided improvement in the system. As they have the unanimous approval of the commission, we assume that they are likely to be favorably regarded by the Mayor.

Deputy Sheriff Porges has received an attachment for $13,385 against Thomas M. Jaramillo y Hijos of Madellin, Colombia, in favor of G. Amsinck Co., for balance due on an account stated on July 1 last. The attachment was served on a commission merchant here.

The estimates of the churches and Christian organizations that the population of New York is now in excess of 4,000,000 will probably be verified by the State census of 1905. The Federal census of 1900 gave it as 3,437,202. This is claimed to be considerably below the fact.

Up before Magistrate Breen in the Tombs Court yesterday afternoon stood Thomas J. Hart of 7 South Elliott Place, Brooklyn, protesting. Thirty-seven years old, and a member of the commission firm of E. Everett Carlton, with offices in the Coffee Exchange Building, Hart was plenty angry when Detective Lynch of the Old Slip Station arrested him at noon time and took him in a cab to court to answer to his brother's charge of insanity.

B.B. Herbert, editor of The National Printer-Journalist, has prepared for the students of the Kansas State University an analytical lecture on "The Modern Newspaper," in which he does THE NEW YORK TIMES the honor of naming it first in a list of nine "model newspapers" which he advises aspiring newspaper workers to study.

VIENNA, Dec. 27. -- It is not unlikely that the Austrian Premier, Dr. von Korber, will tender his resignation to-morrow. The object for which his Cabinet was formed, to promote the restoration of normal parliamentary conditions, has not been attained, and the recent defeat of the Government by the Budget Commission of the Reichsrath shows that the Premier's influence over the principal parties is not on the increase.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- "There was no idea of controlling prices or restraining trade in the organization of the General Paper Company," said L.M. Alexander, Secretary and Treasurer of the General Paper Company, in discussing the Federal suit against that concern.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 27. -- George Howland of Mount Vernon, N.Y., conductor of the accommodation train from New Haven due to leave Stamford at 7:15 and arrive in the Grand Central Station at 8:35, was instantly killed in a collision at the Stamford station at 7:15 this evening while a dense fog prevailed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Attorney General Moody this evening issued the following statement in explanation of the suit brought to-day against the Paper Trust:

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27. -- Contrary to expectations, the inquiry in connection with the Chadwick receivership case was not resumed to-day. Receiver Loeser stated that nothing more would be done in the matter for several days.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Leroy K. Nesbit, a banker, committed suicide to-day in an undertaking establishment. Scribbled on a card in the banker's pocket was a note saying:

"The market," said one broker, "is like an old razor -- dull as a whole, but pretty sharp in some places." By that he meant that while the market showed no great outside interest, those stocks which did move at all went up sharply. Among these issues was Rock Island common, which advanced 2 1/4 points without any other explanation than "there is something up in Rockies."

The ancient homilies about the unwisdom of the newspaper man who forsakes his high calling to accept public office will scarcely bear re-exhibition in the case of Mr. WHITELAW REID, who is soon to be appointed by the President to the post of United States Ambassador at London.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 27. -- Vice President-elect Fairbanks was to-day made a full-fledged Mason in record time, having taken the Entered Apprentice degree at 10 o'clock this morning, the Fellow Craftsman's degree at 2 o'clock this afternoon, and the Master Mason's degree to-night.

In the editorial columns of Thursday's issue of THE TIMES, under the caption "Dr. Eliot on Monopolies," you say, "Let us fight it [monopoly] wherever it rears its hateful head." I am quite a regular reader of THE TIMES, and my chief grievance against you is that you do not "fight monopoly wherever it rears its hateful head."

W. Fellowes Morgan, Secretary of the United States Golf Association, issued to the clubs in the association yesterday the report of the special committee appointed at the annual meeting last February to consider the plan of placing all the clubs in the National body on an equality, both in the payment of dues and in voting power.
LONDON, Dec. 27. -- In opening the Winter season at the Duke of York's Theatre to-night with "Peter Pan; or, the Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up," Charles Frohman seems to have caught London's fancy.

It seems more than probable that next season there will be seen in this city an international football game under Association rules. G.O. Parker, manager of the famous Corinthians of London, and Jerome Flannery, Secretary of the New York Association Football League, have been in correspondence on the subject, and there is little doubt that their negotiations will lead to the arrangement of a game in New York.

The Manhattan Island Corporation (Flake Dowling) has sold to Mrs. Althea Rudd Ward, through Ogden Clarkson, 1,733, 1735, and 1,737 Broadway and 235 West Fifty-fifth Street. These properties form an "L" around the northwest corner of Broadway and Fifty-fifth Street, the frontage on the former being 77.4 feet and on the latter 25 feet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- The Chicago Subway Company, owned and controlled by large railroad and financial interests, made announcement to-day that among the prominent men in the Directory of the Illinois Tunnel Company, the operating company, will be the following:

At the meeting of the Graduates' Club of New York held at the Hotel Manhattan last night in honor of Chancellor MacCracken, the new President of the club, Dr. C.E. Meleney, Associate Superintendent of Schools, said the club had been growing rapidly in membership and at the meeting to be held at the Aldine Club on the evening of Jan. 9 announcement would be made of the location of the clubrooms.

A letter received from Mr. HENRY CLAY WEEKS, the Secretary of the American Mosquito Extermination Society, expresses warm agreement with the recent paragraph in this column in which we attacked the evidence of a soldier correspondent who thought that while serving in the Northwest he had been fiercely persecuted by mosquitos that couldn't have been bred in water.

SARANAC LAKE, Dec. 27. -- The case of William Rockefeller of the Standard Oil Company against Oliver Lamora, the old soldier who has been striving to maintain legal rights to fish in public waters in the Adirondacks, has just been trial again in the County Court at Malone, and decided technically against Lamora, for the sum of eighteen cents. Lamora probably will appeal.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- One of the severest snowstorms of recent years has raged through the territory lying between the Rocky Mountains and the Great Lakes since early this morning, and has caused much trouble to street car companies, railroads, and telegraph companies.

Fog, waves, fluffy, thick, soggy mountains of it, swept in upon this city yesterday morning. Pilots and the weather men agreed that it was the worst one that had been observed for many years. It hung in one immense, impenetrable bank along the coast from above Block Island to Washington. Primarily a coast fog, it reached just the same as far inland as Cincinnati.

A minority report favoring the reintroduction of corporal punishment in the public schools will be made this afternoon to the Board of Education by four of the nine members of the Committee on Elementary Schools. Several weeks ago the report of the majority opposing the reintroduction of the rod was made public.

It is not unlikely that at the beginning of Kingdon Gould's college career he has performed a useful public service in calling attention to the idiotic practice in vogue at Columbia and other colleges, known as "hazing."
NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 27. -- Overnight rains caused a muddy track and upset all calculations here to-day. Topic and Gregor K. were the only winning favorites. Summary:

Admitting that since the failure of Munroe Munroe, the brokerage firm of F.P. Ward Co. of New York and Philadelphia had taken 28,000 shares of Montreal and Boston Consolidated Mining at $1 a share off the hands of the syndicate of which the suspended concern were managers, Q.W. Bosee, Secretary and Treasurer of the Mining Company, yesterday proved quite the most interesting witness yet examined in the Munroe bankruptcy proceedings.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 27. -- The State Board of Pardons to-day granted a parole to Charles Westervelt, who in May, 1901, was sentenced to nine years in the penitentiary for embezzling about $38,000 of the funds of the Dime Savings Bank of this city. Westervelt was Secretary and Treasurer of the concern.

ROME, Dec. 28. -- Novelli, the Italian actor, who recently returned here from Argentina, expecting to start for the United States, announces that he is not going to America, as Liebler Co., the theatrical managers, of New York, have broken their contract with him.
The following is both comical and absolately true, it having just occurred to me:

After a futile attempt to take off the crew of the British freighter Drumelzier, which went ashore on Fire Island Bar in the dense fog of Sunday night, the United States revenue cutter Mohawk, which set out on her mission of mercy to the imperiled vessel early yesterday morning, returned to her anchorage off Tompkinsville, S.I., last night.

If any one form of words is better calculated than another to implant a homicidal impulse in the breast of the average man, it is the formula "Step lively!" which has gained a new vogue through its employment by the trainmen of the Subway system. As an injunction to those addressed it is the quintessence of inanity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Count Cassini, the Ambassador from Russia, and Dean of the Diplomatic Corps, was to-day the recipient of many congratulations on the fiftieth anniversary of his entrance into the diplomatic service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A new chapter in the work of purifying the foods used by Americans has been begun by the Bureau of Chemistry of the Department of Agriculture. The bureau will examine all sorts of well-known mineral waters now being sold, most of them domestic in origin, and some of them imported.

Martin Way, Sergeant Eight Infantry, United States Army, and Supervisor of Castle Williams, the military prison of the Department of the East on Governors Island, is a candidate, in the hands of his friends, for enrollment in Burke's Peerage. This leaked out of Castle Williams the other day, when a letter was received from Ireland addressed to "Paddy Ward, care of Lord Way, Castle Williams, New York, U.S.A."

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 28. -- In order to save the sight of the remaling eye, surgeons this morning removed the eye of Alfred I. Dupont, injured about two months ago in a gunning accident in Virginia.

The United States played Santa Claus to the world at large, according to reports secured from General Superintendent Joseph Elliott of the Money Order Division of the New York Post Office. From Dec. 1 to Dec. 24, the night before Christmas, no less than 334,084 international orders were forwarded to other lands from this city, and these orders called for $4,677,628.90.

NYACK, Dec. 28. -- In a starving condition, and half frozen for want of fire in her house, Mrs. Louisa Gastro, an aged widow, was taken from her home at Spring Valley to the Rockland County Almshouse yesterday.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- The motion for a dismissal of the warrant sworn out by John Schwarzkopf of New York, charging his former law partner, ex-Justice Fursman, with perjury, was denied to-day by Jolice Justice Jones.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 28. -- The Regatta Committee of the North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club announced to-night that in all probability the first race of the season would be called Saturday. The ice was never in better condition for ice boating. Ice with a comparatively rough surface makes the ideal sort for this kind of sport.

BUTTE, Mon., Dec. 28. -- F. Augustus Heinze in a proceeding for the taking of his deposition to be used in a suit for $1,500,000 damages brought against him and several of his companies by the Butte and Boston Mining Company, admitted to-day that he negotiated last June and July for a sale of his Montana mining properties to the Amalgamated Copper Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28. -- Jockey Davis won the first four events at Oakland to-day and was second in the remaining two. Four favorites won. Silverskin, the favorite in the second race, would have won if his rider's stirrup had not broken. Before the fifth race Ferryman threw Jockey W. Daly at the post. Daly's leg was broken. Summary:

An unusually large number of skaters entered the three events provided last night by the Clermont Skating Rink, Brooklyn. The races were a Class A, one mile; Class B, one mile, both being handicaps, and a half-mile novice, in which nearly twenty young skaters started from the scratch mark and made one of the most exciting contests seen on the ice in the Clermont Rink this season.

At the moment when the mind of the President is occupied and visibly agitated by the problem of effectual Federal control of trusts a case has arisen through the action of his own Attorney General that should suggest to him a policy more radically effective than any confined to the Department of Justice or that proposed by the Department of Commerce and Labor.

An autopsy performed by Dr. Weston yesterday upon the body of the young woman who was found unconscious in the snow at Riverside Drive and One Hundred and Twelfth Street on Monday morning, and who died soon after that, showed that death had resulted from a broken neck, and not from exposure, which had been ascribed as the cause.

There will be no less than four Amateur Athletic Union championship events held on Saturday evening at the games of the Pastime Athletic Club. The events to be decided are four of the standard Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships recognized annually by the union -- the 60-yard dash, the 1,000-yard run, throwing the 56 pound weight, and putting the 24-pound shot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Senator Elkins, Chairman of the Committee on Inter-State Commerce, is devoting considerable time to the formation of a bill designed to carry out the views expressed by the President in his annual message in relation to the abolition of rebates on railroads engaged in the inter-State trade.
BERLIN, Dec. 28. -- Prices on the Boerse to-day were irregular and business was light.

The Grand Jury held a brief session yesterday morning and adjourned again till this morning without having had a chance to take cognizance of the statement made by Charles F. Dodge. Nor will the matter be laid before the jury to-day, the last day of its existence. All action in the case will be deferred till next week, and perhaps longer.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 28. -- Luralighter was the only successful favorite to-day. The track was good and the weather clear. Munroe's ride on Joe Lesser, favorite in the last race, was not satisfactory to the stewards and will be investigated. Summary:

James Gray, head bookkeeper in the Money Order Division of the Post Office, died yesterday morning in the private office of his chief of heart disease. Mr. Gray had been in the postal service, with but a brief interim, since 1871, and was regarded as one of its most valuable men. He was 56 years of age and a bachelor.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Dec. 28. -- "I am afraid of the potentialities of Dr. Irvine, and this fear hinders me from discussing freely the controversy between Bishop Talbot and Dr. Irvine," so declared Mrs. Emma Desha Elliott, the woman in the recently revived Irvine-Talbot case, at her residence here to-day.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 28. -- It is evident from the reports received from the interior that the fairly good impression produced by the imperial manifesto on the subject of reforms may be more than offset in many places by the effect of the Government's note of warning to the Zemstvos.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Denial that the post exchange building at Governors Island has been appropriated for the exclusive use of the officers is made by the military authorities there, according to a report which Gen. Ainsworth, Military Secretary, has made to the Secretary of War. In this report Gen. Ainsworth says:

Once possessed of wealth, all of which he lost through business reverses, Thomas Dunn, aged sixty-two, for many years well known in Williamsburg, died an outcast early yesterday morning in a cell of the Clymer Street Police Station in Williamsburg. He had gone to the station for shelter from the storm late on Tuesday night.

Behind an attachment for $2,000 which Deputy Sheriff Porges received yesterday against Mendel Frucht of 82 Rivington Street, and in favor of Samuel Pfefferman, a dealer in dry goods of 183 East Second Street, is a story of "Frenzied Finance" on the east side. The story is pretty well told in papers and affidavits filed in connection with the attachment.

American readers are very likely to have been bewildered by the published accounts of the Czar's reform ukase, particularly when taken in connection with the Czar's published rebuke of the President of the Moscow Zemstvo for meddling in matters upon which his opinion had not been invited. Constitutional government, to people brought up under it, seems as necessary and essential to social and individual development as any other condition of that development.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- There will be no hearing of the charges against Bishop Ethelbert Talbot of the Diocese of Central Pennsylvania by the court recently appointed by Bishop Tuttle, is the statement made by churchmen who are well posted in the canonical laws of the Episcopal Church. A complication has developed which they say will put a stop effectually to the proceedings of the court of inquiry as now constituted.

TOKIO, Dec 2. -- It is understood that the Japanese dynamiting and paralleling against the eastern section of the main circle of forts around Port Arthur is progressing favorably. The right wing of the besiegers continues a heavy and effective shelling of the New Town previous to operations, the preparation of which is nearing completion.

Minor league baseball players of prominence will be generously scattered among the eight teams of the National League next year. Brooklyn has secured the greatest number, thirty-two, making fifty-four players in all reserved by the Washington Park Club. The list includes twenty-one pitchers, four catchers, twenty infielders, and nine outfielders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Quartermaster General Humphrey to-day received a telegram from the Superintendent of Construction at Chattanooga saying that Capt. Howard W. French, Quartermaster in charge of construction at Chickamauga, was found dead Tuesday evening near the border of the army post reservation. A subsequent telegram read: "French accidentally killed himself Monday."

The World publishes an abstract of the political and personal records of Mr. BLACK, Mr. PAYN'S candidate for the Senate, and of Mr. LOU PAYN, the leader of Mr. BLACK'S campaign. These records show the aspirant for the Senate as a skillful politician, greedy of power, ambitious for honors, personally honest in money matters, practically without scruple in the support of his supporters.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- "I fling the lie back into bishop Talbot's teeth, and were it not for the Church it would be my duty to horsewhip him for making the statement he did," said Dr. Ingram N.W. Irvine to-day.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- While numerous semi-official statements have been published here that Ambassador Choate is about to retire from doplomatic life, it can be stated that Mr. Choate has not sent his resignation or any communication on the subject to President Roosevelt or the State Department; nor has he received any inquiry either from the President or Secretary Hay concerning his future plans.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28. -- Racing at Ascot to- day was featureless. Two favorites won, the other events going either to second choices or well-played third choices, except the last race, which was won by Emily Oliver at 20 to 1. Hildebrand rode in his old form. He successfully piloted three winners. Summary:

Commissioner OAKLEY is making the very usual mistake of those in the wrong who realize that they have been filled out, of doing too much explaining. In trying to make it appear that his action in signing the lighting contracts was wise and well-considered, he is called upon to say a good many things which will not bear critical investigation.
LONDON, Dec. 28. -- Money was in much request in the market to-day on the approach of the year end. Discounts were quiet on the firmness of Continental exchanges.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 28. -- There is to-night pounding on the Inner Diamond Shoals, off the Cape of Hatteras, a three-masted, one-funnel steamer, whose name it is impossible to learn. Two life-saving crews stand powerless on the beach, as it means certain death to launch a boat in the heavy sea. The wind is blowing a gale and the waves are running, in marine parlance, "mountain high."

President Vreeland of the New York City Railway Company at 11 o'clock on Friday morning will face 100 angry residents of Washington Heights, who will demand that the street-car service in their section be restored to its former efficiency, especially north of one Hundred and Sixty-first Street.

There was increased activity in the stock market yesterday and prices all around scored substantial advances. The explanation most generally offered was that the investment demand anticipatory of the dividend and interest payments to be made on Jan. 1 was responsible. Inquiry among some of the big commission houses, however, disclosed the fact that a good deal of this buying had already been accomplished.

One F. BOCK of Badenhausen, in Hesse, who bears the title of professor, and therefore must be at least as important as a Kentucky Colonel, announces the discovery of a close connection between the humming of telegraph and telephone wires and the weather of the next few days after the quality and quantity of the humming is noted.

The Board of Education, at its December meeting yesterday, adopted by a vote of 22 to 15 the majority report of the Committee on Elementary Schools, which opposes the reintroduction of corporal punishment in the public schools of this city. Commissioner McGowan, speaking for the matter report, said:

Supporters of Senator Depew's candidacy for re-election declared last night that they regarded the Senatorship contest as practically settled, as the result of conferences held yesterday between Governor-Chairman Odell and friends and supporters of ex-Gov. Black, Mr. Depew's rival.

An amateur circus, in which surprising feats of equestrian ability were displayed by amateur riders of social and business prominence, was the feature of the annual Christmas ride at the Durland Riding Academy, on West Sixty-sixth Street, last night. The programme was a lengthy one, requiring until midnight for its completion, but a large and fashionable gathering enjoyed it from beginning to end.

Amazement, mingled with a certain amount of indignation, reigned throughout the ground floor of 308 East Thirty-first Street yesterday, when it was learned that Miss Anna Conway, an aged woman, who was found dead in bed earlier in the day, after months of apparent destitution, had left bank books showing deposits and accrued interest to the amount of $10,500.

Orestes A. Weed of Brookline, Mass., one of whose sisters is the wife of ex-Gov. Sprague of Rhode Island, and another the widow of Col. Gerritt S. Wheaton of Washington, and Benjmain J. Riley, also of Brookline, were found unconscious from morphine poisoning in their room at the Grand Union Hotel yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- That future generations in the United States will probably possess the largest and best brains of all mankind was the interesting suggestion made to-day before the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. Edward A. Spitzka, Fellow and anatomical demonstrator at Columbia University, New York. Dr. Spitzka said:

Mrs. Irvinea Bergin, wife of Dr. Thomas J. Bergin, a physician, of New Haven, Conn., who was arrested there on Tuesday charged with defrauding several persons in Jersey City by means of bad checks, voluntarily returned to Jersey City yesterday in custody of Detective Frank J. Bennett.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- As a result of storm conditions, the railway service of the entire Middle West is in a bad condition, and trains on nearly every railroad entering Chicago were from one to four hours behind schedule to-day. Great difficulty was experienced by railroad officials in securing telegraphic reports of the movement of trains.

The United States Express Company has bought from St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church the five-story building 101 Greenwich Street, 28 by 100.5 by 25 by 100. The parcel adjoins the large plot at Rector Street, Trinity Place and Greenwich Street, bought by the company last Spring.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 28. -- Fearing bankruptcy because of the tremendous slump in cotton, the farmers and merchants are taking a heroic measure to prevent a further fall and to advance the price. This measure is no less than the burning of a portion of the cotton which has not been marketed. It is proposed that 2,000,000 bales be destroyed, each State to burn its proper proportion.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- Warning of grave danger that New York Harbor will be closed to ocean trade by a huge sandbar was given by Prof. L.M. Haupt before the American Association for the Advancement of Science this afternoon. Prof. Haupt is a distiguished engineer and at present is a member of the Isthmian Canal Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 29. -- Capt. Oliver G. Filley of Harvard's 'Varsity crew believes that the Crimson university can well pattern after the English universities as far as her athletics are concerned.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Prof. Paul Reinch of the University of Wisconsin, made a plea for the better government of the Philippine Islands before the American Political Science Association to-day.

Andrew Gray Carter, 10-year old son of Andrew P. Carter and his wife, Pauline Gray Carter, was produced in Special Term of the Supreme Court in obedience to a writ of habeas corpus issued by Justice Leventritt, applied for by Franklin Bien, counsel for the mother, who charged that her son was being kept away from her by the father.

Municipal ownership of public lighting plants as a platform and William R. Hearst as the leader of a straight independent Democratic Mayoralty ticket comprised the demand of John T. Cronin, Chairman of the Greater New York Democracy's special reorganization committee at an executive committee meeting last night, when a plan of reorganization was adopted.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- "The Army as It Was and as It Is to Be," is the text under which Field Marshal Earl Roberts, in the January Nineteenth Century and After, reads Britons a noteworthy lecture on the duty of all classes if Great Britain would meet the demands of modern warfare. After frankly pointing out existing deficiencies, Lord Roberts writes:

Surrogate Thomas yesterday decided that the deathbed will of Mrs. Sarah J. Hassett Choate, in which an estate valued at $180,000 is disposed of, should not be admitted to probate, but that a previous will should be probated in its stead.

The shooting of William O'Brien, a Bowery character, whose testimony against Policeman Mallon was mainly instrumental in sending the latter to Sing Sing for twenty years for killing O'Brien's "partner," Brennan, has stirred the police of the Eldridge Street Station to unwonted activity.

Several important amendments to the constitution will be submitted to the members of the New York Athletic Club for consideration at the annual meeting, which will be held at the clubhouse, Sixth Avenue and Central Park South, on Tuesday evening, Jan. 10. Most important is an amendment for increasing the athletic members from 100 to 150, evidently implying that a greater active, interest will be shown in more branches of sport.

More than once attention has been called in and this column -- and shall be once more -- to a most irritating form of discourtesy which "came in" with the telephone and from present indications seems likely, unless its too patient victims rise in defense of their rights, their time, and their temper, to continue through a long future, to which it will add a wholly unnecessary gloom.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- Ten members of the Vesper Boat Club to be known as the Henley Committee, met at the Hotel Hanover to-night and formulated plans to have the Maroon and Gray represented at the great English rowing event next Summer.
MUKDEN, Dec. 29. -- Cossacks to-day brought in the body of Capt. Erldaroff, a noted scout, who was killed in an attack on the village of Tifanty.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29. -- Concerning the contention that the Board of Inquiry appointed by Bishop Tuttle of St. Louis to examine into the charges against Bishop Talbot of Central Pennsylvania will not have the right to officiate in January, on the ground that it was appointed under a canon which will be superseded by another on Jan. 1, Bishop Tuttle to-day said:

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 29. -- Isador Mautner of Fort Wayne, acting for himself and John Heenan of Terre Haute and John Ganzel and his partner, Philip Arnold of Louisville, failed to agree this afternoon on a purchase price for the Grand Rapids Central League baseball franchise. It is understood that there was about $1,000 between the final figures offered by each side.

James Tierney, thirty-five years old, of 116 Tenth Avenue, while at work on a pier at One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street yesterday, unloading sections of iron tubing to be used by the Subway in tunneling under the Harlem River, slipped on a piece of ice and fell overboard. Before a rope could be thrown to him he was carried more than fifty feet from the pier by the tide.

A foppish youth who sees his ideal in every woman he meets, a jealous husband badly in need of a lesson, and a pretty wife ready and willing to supply it -- these are the familiar figures that enter into the composition of Gustav von Moser and Otto Girndt's farce "Die Sternschnuppe," ("The Shooting Star,") seen for the first time in ten years at the Irving Place Theatre last night.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday said that no confession had been obtained, and none sought, from Charles F. Dodge, whose return from Texas about a week ago to stand trial on a charge of perjury was followed by an all-night session with Mr. Jerome at Police Headquarters and a discharge in court two days later.

BOSTON, Dec. 29. -- Officials of the State of Massachusetts and of the City of Boston were the guests of the Boston Transit Commission and the Boston Elevated Railway Company to-day upon an inspection trip through the new tunnel under the harbor which connects the business section of the city with East Boston.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 29. -- The American Embassy here, at the request of the Japanese Minister in Berlin, has made urgent representations to be allowed to send a representative of the embassy to visit the Japanese officers who are prisoners at Medvid.
CHE-FOO, Dec. 29. -- The Japanese line at Port Arthur is now, as a result of the attack begun on Dec. 25, much closer to Liao-Thie Mountain.

Senator Chauncey M. Depew will be reelected to the United States Senate without further opposition from within his own party. Governor-Chairman Odell announced yesterday that he thought the best interests of the Republican party would be subserved by the return of Senator Depew, and following the announcement of the Governor-Chairman, who has been the decisive factor in the situation all along, the friends of x-Gov. Frank S. Black gave up their fight for him.

The conclusion of Dr. EDWARD A. SPITZKA that the admixture of races is destined to give this Nation the best average brain equipment is interesting. No doubt it is true; but there be some who have cherished the conviction that the American brain is already a pretty fair sort of a machine, and quite capable of standing the test of comparison with the normal brain of any other nationality.

The total sales on the Stock Exchange yesterday once more exceeded the million-share mark, and this renewal of activity was accompanied by showing of great strength in every department. Amalgamated Copper was the leader, not only of the industrial group, but of the whole market.

Ben Epstein, the village blacksmith of Williamsburg, sat on the stone floor of a cold cell in the Federal Building, in Brooklyn, last night weeping. Gussie, the blacksmith's wife, sat in an adjoining cell, tearing her hair. Over at their home, at 145 Siegel Street, three United States Revenue officers sat in the parlor smoking Ben's best cigars and cracking mother-in-law jokes at the blacksmith's expense.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 29. -- Three midshipmen detected in an attempt to smuggle liquor into the Naval Academy during the holidays have been ordered to the prison ship Santee for the remainder of the academic year, and will lose their September vacation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- The friends of Dr. Irvine are much exercised by the contention of Dr. John Fulton in an editorial article published to-day in The Church Standard, in which it is declared that the proceedings against Bishop Talbot must fall to go further because they are opposed to a new canon adopted at the late General Convention.

The Crescent Athletic Club defeated a mixed team composed of members of the Brooklyn Skating Club last night in the Clermont Skating Rink, Brooklyn, by a score or 7 goals to 0. The victors practically had things their own way after the first few minutes of play and after scoring two goals in the first half, made five more without apparent difficulty in the last half.
G.E. Bauhahn has sold to Albert L. and Stanley Wolfson the new seven-story loft building at 30 West Twenty-first Street. Charles H. Posner was the broker in the deal.

PARIS, Dec. 29. -- Very sinister accounts, both public and private, of the effect produced by the Czar's decree continue to reach Paris. They show that the agitation for reform, far from subsiding, has materially increased and threatens to assume alarming proportions.
NEVV ORLEANS, Dec. 29. -- George K. and Baywoods were the only beaten favorites to-day. The track was fast and the weather clear and cool.

GENESEO, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Three members of a prominent Livingston County family lost their lives in a fire which destroyed the farm residence of Charles McMillan, at the head of Conesus Lake, early to-day.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29. -- The card at Oakland to-day had no special features. Three favorites finished first. Adirondack, at 10 to 1, won easily from Barney Dreyfus and Batidor.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Dec. 29. -- Cotton growers throughout the State have united in an effort to reduce the cotton acerage one-fourth for 1905 as compared with 1904. Merchants of the State are pledging their co-operation to the movement.

Beset as he was by a combination made up of a trolley car, an ambulance surgeon and an electric power house, John Murtha of 164 Butler Street, Brooklyn, succeeded, after a strenuous time yesterday afternoon in "saving his job and perhaps a leg or two," as he puts it.
THE NEW YORK TIMES will begin the year 1905 in its new home, in Times Square, and to celebrate the event the issue of the newspaper on Sunday next will be notable in many ways.

The stage Irishman has at last become the subject of judicial decision, and the subject of green whiskers and red whiskers and a general orang-outang make-up by those who seek to portray the Celt has come under the notice of the law. An opinion which Justice Fitzgerald rendered on Wednesday in the case of Dan McAvoy, the comedian, who sought to force J. Wesley Rosenquest to allow him to produce his play.
Mr. Lawson of Boston, who paints black the characters of Wall Street's chiefs of high finance, is probably no white-robed angel himself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Prof. Charles Waldstein is well pleased with his visit to Washington in the interest of the plan for the excavation of Herculaneum. He gave a lecture on Wednesday night at the home of Herbert Wadsworth, and repeated it last night at the White House at the request of the President.

Only the most difficult taste could fail to be pleased with yesterday's market, which was buoyant in temper, with few eccentricities, and without congestion of business in selected issues under cover of which others were sold. There was little bidding up, but a quiet acceptance of all offers, with the result of clearing away overhanging stock which lay in the way of further improvement.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- "It's all over," said State Committeeman William Barnes, Jr., referring to the Odell-Platt fight over the United States Senatorship. His newspaper in its leading editorial to-day says:

OMAHA, Dec. 29. -- At the first annual meeting of the Western Fruit Jobbers' Association here to-day a paper attacking Armour Co. was read by E.M. Ferguson of Duluth. Ferguson was then elected President of the organization.
ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- Governor-elect Higgins to-day announced that he would appoint Nicholas Van Vracken Franchot of Olean State Superintendent of Public Works to succeed Charles Spencer Boyd.

It is not very likely that the story of the burning of cotton to enhance the price thereof will have any serious effect upon the cotton market. Certainly there is no reason why it should. It is quite true that cotton seems to be plentiful, and that that seeming has made it cheap.

Fashionably dressed and showing marked unconcern about her predicament, Miss Emma Page, thirty-three years old, daughter of William C. Page, senior member of the firm of Page, Dennis Co., scale manufacturers of 341 Broadway, was locked in a cell in the West Thirtieth Street Station last night, charged with grand larceny in obtaining goods to the value of $265 in the name of others from a Sixth Avenue department store.

W C. Muschenheim, proprietor of the Hotel Astor, will have to pay 35 per cent. duty on nine great ornamental wine casks which are to form part of the fittings of the new hotel. The casks were imported in a "knocked-down" condition, for convenience in shipping. That is, the staves and ends were packed separately in bales and boxes.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 30. -- Jockey Munro, has been unable to furnish the Stewards a satisfactory explanation of his ride on Joe Lesser in the sixth race on Wednesday has been barred from riding here for the remainder of the meeting. This decision was reached by the Stewards this afternoon after a careful investigation of the case.

" Principles of Economics" grow out of the class lectures delivered by Prof Frank A. Fetter of the Department of Political Economy and Finance at Cornell University. The author has almost entirely omitted the critical discussions of controverted points in theory, believing the inherent difficulties of the subject great enough without these subtle controversies in classes of beginners.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- Hundreds of marines and sailors, buckets in hand, aided by the Navy Yard's fire department and the crew of the Government tug Modoc, fought two fires of mysterious origin at League Island to-night, sparks from which threatened to destroy the great dry dock in course of construction.

The life of the cowboy is adventurous, with pleaty of hard work. In "Bucking the Sagebrush" Mr. Charles J. Steedman presents the practical side of the cow puncher. He has, so the author tells us, his characteristics, and one of the most prominent is the bear of ridicule. "To have his neck broken by a horse is awkward; to get shot is unfortunate, but to appear ridiculous -- that breaks in heart.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- In response to the request that he outline his position regarding the Senatorial fight just ended, Senator Edgar T. Brackett this evening made the following statement:
The old colored man at his gate with a crutch under his arm had sent a boy of his color about ten years old to the Post Office for mail and the lad had returned empty-handed.

" A Short History of Germany," by Mrs. H.C. Hawtrey, is a mere outline of the annals of the Teutonic peoples. (New York; Longman's. $1.25.) But for that very reason it will be useful to the great number who have no time to indulge in extended study, and who nevertheless want to know the historical background which will help them to understand the art, architecture, and customs of the Germans.

While Senator Platt yesterday did not confirm the belief existing among many of the Republican politicians that the victory of Senator Depew over the forces which sought to deprive him of the Senatorship would lead to any change in the Republican organization, he plainly indicated that he intended to take a more active part in party management than he has since the election of Gov. Odell as State Chairman.

It is generally conceded that the sentimental novels of Disraeli are not his best literary work. Yet Mr. L.F. Austin, a London reviewer of very modern inclinations, goes far when he writes in The Book Monthly that "Henrietta Temple" is "pure bathos." It is, indeed, inferior in abiding interest to "Coningsby," "Sybil," and "Tancred," but its sentimentalism belonged precisely to the era in which it was written.

Short terms at night schools and trade schools often leave the boy with skillful fingers partly taught, when lack of time puts a stop to further lessons. For such beginners, people who have a knowledge of the rudiments of the handicrafts, "The Art Crafts for Beginners," was written.

Down-town men interested in railroad affairs had it yesterday that, in addition to the Interborough and New York City Railway interests, there would be soon another competitor to bid on the construction of further subways, in the shape of one of the companies having rights for tunnel construction under the Hudson River.

MR. CONRAD'S new story reveals its author's best qualities. It is noteworthy for good construction, good style, for the clearness and strength with which its many complex characters are developed, and particularly for the vivid reality of the scene and the comprehensive, intelligence, and masterly manner in which it reveals the true inwardness o the methods of government that prevail in that part of America that lies west and south of the Caribbean Sea.

THE Bishop of Oxford appreciates conditions when he writes concerning controversies that time dulls them; the world moves "quickly nowadays, * * * the point of view shifts, * * * the importance is notably diminished."

Is there a science of study? If so, upon what basis shall it be determined? These and similar questions Mr. James G. Moore has asked and answered in "Outline of the Science of Study" (New York: Hinds Noble, $1.00.) He believes that with the average teacher the educational process has consisted chiefly in furnishing his students instruction per capita.

After a trial before the Civil Service Commission yesterday afternoon on charges of "conduct unbecoming an examiner of the Municipal Civil Service Commission and conduct unbecoming a gentleman and prejudicial to good order and discipline," David H. Ray, an examiner, was dismissed.

After a hundred men had vainly beaten the Great Meadows, which lie between the Hackensack and Passaic Rivers, for traces of ten-year-old Charles Brantjen of Jersey City Heights, who was lost in the big waste Wednesday evening, two boatmen accidentally discovered the boy early yesterday morning in a clearing near Secaucus.

The chief significance which attaches to the news from London that heavy insurances have been issued on the life of the Czar of Russia at the very high rate of fifteen guineas per cent., is that the speculators are gambling somewhat recklessly on an eventuality which cannot by any chance be reckoned arithmetically or on any basis recognized by Actuaries.

This book, "Seven Years' Hard," is a human document. It professes to be no more; it claims to be no less. The persons who figure in it are living, breathing realities, not creations of pen and inkpot. The experiences recorded in it are history, not myth, and have been cast into mold piping hot from the memory.

Prof. PAUL REINSCH of the University of Wisconsin is a man who should be listened to when he speaks of our colonial dependencies. He is among the most careful, acute, candid, and patient students of the questions they involve, not a theorist, still less a partisan, but a practical, clear-headed man of unusual ability who has given a great deal of time and labor to the study of the subject.

The masquerade dance given last evening by Mrs. Arthur J. Moulton for her three children, the Misses May and Bessie Moulton and Arthur Moulton, was one of the gayest and most original of the holiday entertainments for young people. The girl guests came in costume, as did some of the young men, and even those of the latter who came in ordinary evening clothes wore masks.

THE American bookbuyer is an inconsiderate being; he knows that nobody reads Scott; that Scott is an author suited only to simple, uncritical boys, not to the complex, analytical, mature mind; that Scott has no atmosphere, no art, no critical faculty, no "human feeling" no over so many more things to be found in the works of the American critic-novelist, but what does the American bookbuyer care?

The second volume of the "Original Journals of Lewis and Clark," edited by Reuben Gold Thwaites, author of "The Colonies," "Historic Waterways," , is published this week by Dodd, Mead Co. It contains the journals and orderly book of Lewis and Clark, from Two-Thousand-Mile Creek to Shoshoni Camp on Lemhi River: May 6, 1805, to Aug. 20 of the same year.

THIS work has had a somewhat remarkable history, of which it bears traces. Since his first coming to America ten years ago Prof. Munsterberg has from time to time given expression to somewhat strenuous criticisms of certain aspects of American life which he thought did not come up to the German ideals. These he collected together a couple of years ago under the title "American Traits."

The appeal in abatement of judgment from Prof. William Estabrook Chancellor in the matter of his History of the United States, recently noticed in your columns, is natural and quite characteristic. As the author eloquently pleads, his work is to be of the nature of an achievement sui generis.
EASTPORT, L.I., Dec. 30. -- The Oak Island life saving crew this afternoon had to go to the rescue of the members of the Fire Island crew when the situation of the Fire Island men was desperate.

The Rapid Transit Commission has wisely and sensibly decided to print for general distribution and information the very interesting report of Chief Engineer PARSONS, embodying plans for the extension of the city's Subway system. Nobody would call in question the professional competence of the Commission's Chief Engineer to lay out and design a plan of Subway extension that would satisfactorily meet the primary demand for larger travel facilities.

J.P. Firth, an expert on Cromwellian strategy, writes a preface to his book on the "Life and Times of Constantine the Great," which G.P. Putnam's Sons will issue in January in their Heroes of the Nations Series. Concerning the author's impartiality in speaking of that first Roman Emperor who embraced Christianity, Mr. Firth says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Official commendation of the services rendered the men aboard the British steamer Drumelzier, which stranded off Fire Island last Monday, by the crews of three life-saving stations in that vicinity is made in letters dispatched by Secretary Shaw to-day to Keeper T.H. Patterson and men, at the Sandy Hook Station; Keeper Edgar Frost and men, at Oak Island Station, and Keeper Doxsee and men, at Fire Island.

" A Short History of Ancient Egypt," by Percy E. Newberry and John Garstang, covers the entire history of the Valley of the Nile, from the early tribal communities of archaic times, more than 3,000 years before the commencement of our era, to the conquest by Alexander the Great in the year 332 B.C.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- Herbert Noble of New York, one of the leading figures in the controversy between Bishop Talbot and Dr. I.N.W. Irvine, who held a secret conference here to-day on the case, said to-night that intimidation had been practiced in getting the Huntingdon signers to repudiate the presentment against the Bishop.

LONDON, Dec. 30, 1904. -- It seems to be the practical agreement on the part of publishers, booksellers, and others qualified to speak on the subject that 1904 has not been a remarkably good book year in Great Britain.

In the days when the Bowling Green was the heart of Manhattan was all the City of New York and more, and beaus and belles walked at eventide on the Battery, these in "spencers" and Dolly Vardens and those in tailcoats and tail hats of quaint design -- in such days lived Sapphira Bloommaert and Annette de Vries.

Four lectures by Mrs. Annie Besant are appearing in pamphlet form from the press of John Lane. The first, "When a Man Dies Shall He Live Again?" was delivered last May at Myddelton Hall, Islington. The author declares that, as a Theosophist, she should at once say that man never dies.

Thomas Jefferson was deeply interested in the great unknown lands beyond the Rocky Mountains. In 1783 he wrote to George Rogers Clark encouraging him to make a journey of exploration, the ultimate object of which was to acquire them for the United States. One of the results of Lewis and Clark's expedition was what is now the State of Oregon.

THE Macmillan Company is preparing to publish a new novel by Charles Egbert Craddock (Miss Murfree) early in the new year with the title "The Storm Centre.'' It is said to be a return to the manner of "The Prophet of the Great Smoky Mountain."

" Maxwell's Theory and Wireless Telegraphy" is one of the latest contributions to the rapidly growing library on this end-of-the-century subject. (New York: McGraw Publishing Company.) Frederick K. Vreeland has written the second section, "The Principles of Wireless Telegraphy," himself, and has translated from the French of H. Poincare: Maxwell's Theory and Hertzian Oscillations."

This, the seventh volume of the publications of the Buffalo Historical Society, is a very bulky affair. It contains, besides matter of routine belonging and to society, historical material of made in local and some water interest. Under the last head may be increased founded in letters of Thomas Jefferson, mostly in his own handwriting, addressed to Francis Adrian van der Kemp, and preserved by the society.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 30. -- Commander Hebbinghaus, Naval Attache at the German Embassy here, to-day received from the Imperial Yacht Club at Kiel the rules for the ocean yacht race next May, which were formulated by Commander Hebbinghaus and the New York Yacht Club, and sent to Kiel for approval by the Imperial Yacht Club.

SCARCELY one library of importance came into English and American auction rooms during 1904. We might possibly except the library of the late Bishop John F. Hurst, three sections of which were offered in this city in May, November, and December by the Anderson Auction Company; but this the dispersion of which will be concluded in 1905 is a miscellaneous collection of interesting books, containing several volumes of high quality.

In some fifteen years as a reader of THE TIMES I have found its editorials, with perhaps occasional exceptions, written with such fairness and evident freedom from disposition to consider any other opinion untenable as to be convincing. Naturally, there have been many subjects of which I have had only superficial knowledge, if any, and your views on such would be accepted as final unless disproved by other and expert testimony.

Walter C. Horsley, Lieutenant Colonel commanding the Twentieth Middlesex, (Artists,) R.V., has translated "The Chronicles of an Old Campaigner, M. de la Colonie, 1692-1717," which is about to be issued in this country by E.P. Dutton Co. The translation is offered "as an addition to the material bearing upon the war of the Spanish succession."

PITTSBURG, Pa., Dec. 30. -- Bishop Cortlandt Whitehead of the Pittsburg diocese said to-day that the gravest offense with which Bishop Talbot is charged is the commission of an indiscretion in writing letters concerning Mr. Irvine in a positive form where a more cautious or a more worldly man would have written more guardedly and would have prefaced his statements by the words "it is said."

Alexander Henschel and William R. Lowe Co. have sold for Mary G. Pinckney and others the triangular block bounded by Eighth Avenue. Macomb's Dam Road, and One Hundred and Fiftieth and One Hundred and Fifty-first Streets, to Klein Jackson. The block has frontages of 179 feet on Eighth Avenue, 203 feet on Macomb's Dam Road, and 97 and on One Hundred and Fifty-first Street.

Members of the Automobile Club of America, who visited the rooms Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday expressed general satisfaction at the selection of the circuit Auvergnat by the Automobile Club of France for the Gordon Bennett cup race next year. The contest will probably be held in June, as has been customary with former events of this kind.

The new biography by James Douglas, "Theodore Watts-Dunton, Poet, Novelist, Critic," is almost ready for publication. A glance over the advance sheets shows that it will surely justify all anticipations of its unique interest. It is a study of Watts-Dunton by an avowed and most enthusiastic admirer, and will serve as an interpretation of that friend and critic of Tennyson, Rossetti, Swinburne, George Borrow, Lowell, and William Morris.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- Father Corkemaz, who is a Maromte, owning allegiance to Rome, said this evening in his home:

Prof. Munsterberg has frequently explained, we believe, that the books he writes in the German language and publishes in Germany are intended only for German readers. For Americans he writes books in English. But a translation of his "Die Amerikaner" having appeared under unimpeachable auspices a serious review is demanded, and this we now publish, and cordially commend to the notice of our readers.

Are you only to plant cabbages and forget your sweet peas, or nasturtiums and hollyhocks? Is your sense of taste only to be gratified and the delights of flowers to be overlooked? Why cannot you have turnips and tulips? You certainly can, if you know how to go about it.

COUNTLESS are the fossils of the past, or as we designate them, "antiquities," but quite alive are our superstitions, for those mental aberrations are common to humanity. The study of old manners and customs is always engaging, and seems to us to be in a measure authoritative, because of inherent conservatism.

Ex-Gov. O'Ferrall began his official life when only fifteen years of age, at which time, owing to the sudden death of his father, for whom he had acted as a clerk, he was appointed deputy clerk of the Circuit Court of Morgan County, then a part of Virginia, but since made a part of the State of West Virginia.

" Saturday Night Sermons" first appeared from week to week on the editorial page of The Los Angeles Express. The author, the Rev. George T. Dowling, Rector of Christ Protestant Episcopal Parish, Los Angeles, went out there five years ago in an effort to save the life of his wife.
THE NEW YORK TIMES, to commemorate its removal to its new building in Times Square to-morrow, will publish one of the most notable newspaper editions on record.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 30. -- The sport at Ascot Park to-day began with the winning of a 40 to 1 shot Whitestone, but after that favorites won right down the line with the exception of the fourth race. The best that Jockey Hildebrand could do was to finish second in the fourth race and third in the final race of the afternoon. Summary:

An unusually fine lot of athletes, including a host of champions in different events, will appear to-night in Madison Square Garden in the big indoor meet held under the auspices of the Pastime Athletic Club. This will be the first of the season of what have come to be termed athletic carnivals, and, very fittingly, it will close the long line of successes with which the year 1904 has been filled.

A volume of lectures which were delivered at Harvard University in April of this year is being issued by the Macmillan Company under the title "Harvard Lectures on Greek Subjects," by S.H. Butcher, author of "Some Aspects of the Greek Genius," to which the new book is a companion.

Col. Younghusband in his preface to the second edition of "The Heart of a Continent" tells how the proof copies of his former travels were sent him from England for correction, and reached him "just before the Tibetan attack on his camp." Col. Younghusband has gained distinction during the present year (1904) by commanding the expedition which opened Tibet to Europe, and so the present work is certain to find many readers.

THE anthology issued under the editorship of Mr. Bliss Carman and his distinguished associates must be judged, of course, not only by the taste exhibited in selecting from American and English poetry and from translations into English of the poetry of the world, but by its method of arrangement, which is effective in making a poem of Whittler's succeed one of Shakespeare's, and a selection from Keats's "Endymion" follow a sonnet by Martial.

Sterling Green, a six-foot negro athlete, was arraigned in the West Side Court yesterday, charged with homicide. The police of the Wrest Thirty-seventh Street Station, who made the charge, also alleged an extraordinary series of misdeeds on the part of the prisoner.

GUY WETMORE CARRYL had the modern poetic touch, representative of the time in which he lived; negligently careful, certain, and light without frivolity. His manner was winning by its suggestion of deep sincerity beneath the sparkling surface.

The new book by Janet Ross, author of "Florentine Villas," "Leaves from Our Tuscan Kitchen; or, How to Cook Vegetables,'' , on "Old Florence and Modern Tuscany." is to be brought out here by E.P . Dutton Co. in about a fortnight. Several of the chapters have appeared as articles in English magazines.

ONE of our readers who, during a residence of four years in London, joined other Americans there in the graceful, reverential ceremony of Primrose Day, writes to express his astonishment at the celebration of the one hundredth anniversary of Lord Beaconsfield's birth on the 21st of December. He had always fancied that Primrose Day, April 19, was Disraeli's birthday.

ELIZABETH LEE, sister of Sidney Lee, the distinguished Shakespearean scholar, author, and critic, has edited a collection of poems by Elizabeth Barrett Browning, which appears as the latest volume in the Standard English Classics Series, published in this country by Ginn Co.

HAMMOND, Ind., Dec. 30. -- Forty or fifty revolver shots were exchanged to-night in a fight of steel workers at the Lake Shore Station, Indiana Harbor, in the presence of several hundred men, women, and children, who were waiting for a Lake Shore suburban train.
ROME, Dec. 30. -- An official communication is published regarding the statement by Prof. Waldstein of the University of Cambridge, England, with reference to excavations at Herculaneum.
TOKIO, Dec. 30. -- Admiral Togo and Vice Admiral Kamimura, with their staffs, arrived at the Shimbashi Station at 9:20 o'clock to-day. Their journey from Kure to TOKIO was a continuous ovation.

Definite steps toward the construction of a municipal electric lighting plant were taken at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on the receipt of concurring opinions from Corporation Counsel Delany and ex-Judge John Dillon, who held that the city has the power under the charter to establish and maintain such a plant.

The Macmillan Company is publishing a volume by Edward Fraser entitled "Famous Fighters of the Fleet." This is an account of the achievements of various English men-of-war. The text contains a number of illustrations, including the frontispiece, "The Enemy in Sight -- Full Speed Ahead."

In my isolation here the issue of Dec. 10 of THE BOOK REVIEW reached me twelve days after its date! After papers reach the dock here it takes two days for the postman and four days for the newsman to reach this hotel, a mile away. Fact!

AS I read various reviews of "The Golden Bowl," I am tempted to think that the critics are not infallible; that they are capable of making mistakes like the rest of us. It really seems as if some of the critics have not the intelligence to get at the work of an artist like Henry James.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- President Roosevelt is devoting some time at present to consideration of important appointments in the diplomatic and consular service of the Government to be made formally by him at the beginning of the new Administration, next March. Secretary Hay had a conference with the President to-day, and it is understood that diplomatic appointments were discussed.

With a historical background similar to that of Scott's "Talisman," and with a galloping sweep of incidents held fast by the rein of probability, the author of "She" has given us an absorbing tale into which enter the elemental virtues and vices, emotions, and actions of the Christian Crusader, the Saracen, and the Arab of the mountains.
BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 30. -- Thomas W. Lawson laughed to-night when asked about his alleged trip to Newark.

The stock market yesterday opened with the remnant of Thursday's good feeling, but soon developed a reactionary temper under influences of considerable importance regarding specific properties, although not of general significance. For example, Consolidated Gas fell upon the report favoring the legality of a city lighting plant, and the fall was logical, although its effect upon the rest of the list was purely sympathetic.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- Before the Section of Chemistry of the American Association for the Advancement of Science to-day, Dr. Leon L. Watters declared emphatically that the extent to which foods and medicines were adulterated in this country constituted a menace to the health of the public, the extent of which could scarcely be estimated.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Dec. 30. -- John Langdon and James Denithorne, two of the six Vestrymen of St. John's Church whose names were attached to the presentment against Bishop Talbot, declared today that, having been tricked into signing the document by a conspiracy on the part of Dr. Irvine and his friends, they would not only prosecute him, or whoever was responsible for the trick, but would take action under the canons of the Episcopal Church.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- The late decline in New York had an unsettling effect upon the local leaders and somewhat interfered with what would otherwise have been an excellent market. Lehigh Valley and Lehigh Navigation were distinctive features. The former advanced nearly a point on inside buying, but lost it nearly all later in the day.

BEST-SELLING BOOKS. -- It is unquestionably a fine thing to be ranked among the very highest in the literary world, yet a study of the "Best-Selling Books" of the past five years shows that the stars of the first magnitude have not nearly had things all their own way.

THE appearance of one of Mr. Rhodes's volumes on the history of the United States is an event of no small importance. In the year 1892 Mr. James Ford Rhodes began to publish his now famous "History of the United States from the Compromise of 1850."
AMONG the lawyers of Columbia County, New York have been numbered many of National reputation, and Mr. Miller has collected in his volume an exceedingly interesting group of sketches and portraits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Prof. Yamashita of Japan was presented to-day to the President by Commander Takashita, Naval Attache of the Japanese Legation. Prof. Yamashita, who is giving a course of instruction in jiu jitsu at Harvard University, met the President some weeks ago, and it is understood gave a few lessons in the science that is attracting so much attention among athletes.
Collector Stranahan yesterday received a letter addressed as follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Edward B. Whitney of New York declared to-day before the American Political Science and Economic Associations that Congress has the direct power to put an end to the United States Steel Corporation, the anthracite "coal pool," and similar corporations.
AMONG the lawyers of Columbia County, New York have been numbered many of National reputation, and Mr. Miller has collected in his volume an exceedingly interesting group of sketches and portraits.

Possibly the last piece of prose to come from the pen of the late poet Henley was written in extenuation of William Hazlitt and the place which should be his by all the tenets of literary expression, but, alas! is not. It is this piece of writing which opens the new, and, for all practical and educational and reference purposes, complete edition of Hazlitt's works.

The stock market had another Lawson spasm yesterday. Just as everybody had decided that the storm was over and that it would be safe to come out of the cyclone cellars, an angry growl from some unknown direction, but familiar in its tone, once more scared all the little people out of their wits and sent them scurrying for shelter.

This is the story of Jeems Brooks, colored, who from early youth was called Punch. The cabin of his nativity was in one of the south side counties of Virginia -- that is, in the territory south of the James River. You are introduced to Punch, age five, "tendin'" his younger brothers and sisters and eating dirt.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 30. -- The labor unions involved since last July in a strike against a 12 1/2 per cent. reduction in wages in the cotton mills of the city, to-day, by a vote of approximately three to one approved a continuance of the contest.

TOKIO, Dec. 30. -- The Navy Department published to-night a letter written by a man on the battleship Sevastopol which had fallen into the hands of the Japanese. The writer despairs of relief of the fortress and tells of the destruction wrought by Japanese shells. He says the Russians are resigned to their fate and are determined to fight to a finish rather than suffer the shame of surrender owing to starvation.

One may sympathize with Congressman FOOTE, Congressman LITTAUER, State Senator BRACKETT, and even with "LOU" PAYN, difficult as it is to sympathize with "LOU," on the manner in which they have been left outside the breastworks by their precipitate and premature tying up of their political fortunes with the Senatorial aspirations of ex-GOV. BLACK.

The Pendleton collection, described by Mr. Lockwood, has recently passed into the hands of the Rhode Island School of Design. It was assembled in thirty years of the most discriminating collecting. The late Mr. Pendleton was especially interested in chairs, tables, desks, bedsteads, and high and low chests of drawers, with ball and claw feet.

The funny fellows continue to write for publication, and doubtless they have their readers, even the least of them. It is the popular pose of the movement to pretend to need diversion. If the accepted dates are right it was 400 years ago this next twelvemonth that John Knox was born: the place, they say, was Hubbington, and the time is not more closely given than that it was in 1505. In 1522 one finds the reformer-to-be at the University of Glasgow, after which he is very nearly eclipsed for the next twenty-five years.

Backsliding Salvation Army soldiers are rare in the criminal courts, but the police believe they have two of them in Albert J. Neidinger and Charles H. Herbst, two young men who were captured yesterday while they were asleep in their room at 390 Eighth Avenue by Detectives Foster and McGee of the Oak Street Station.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31. -- Sais, first choice at Ascot to-day, for the main won principally on account of the good riding of Hildebrand. It was raining, consequently the track was very sloppy.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 31. -- Detective Rose left here for Richmond to-night to secure from Gov. Montague requisition papers for Philip McIntyre.

In a decision written by Gen. T.S. Sharretts, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by the Alfred H. Smith Company of New York against the classification as manufactures of rubber at 30 per cent. of so-called India rubber sponges. The importers contended that they were dutiable at 20 per cent. as sponges.

The new Anchor liner Caledonia, from Glasgow, finished her maiden voyage across the Atlantic late yesterday afternoon. Capt. Archie Baxter, her commander, after telling how smoothly the engines of the big ship worked and how easily the liner plowed her way through giant seas, told a story of a wonderful field of icebergs south of which the Caledonia passed last Thursday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 1. -- George Yepsen, a prominent resident of Perth Amboy, was arrested there this morning by Detective Peltier on a warrant issued yesterday by Justice Sedam of this city, in which he was charged by the officers of the Second People's Building and Loan Association of this city with forgery for the purpose of making a bogus transfer of stock.

In his last annual message President ROOSEVELT declared that "combination of capital, like combination of labor, is a necessary element of our present industrial system." He therefore thought it "unfortunate that our present laws should forbid all combinations, instead of sharply discriminating between those combinations which do good and those combinations which do evil."

When the big Cunard turbine steamer Lusitania arrives in this port about the middle of September it is probable she will come up to the city through the new Ambrose channel The matter of the vessel entrance has been a question which has been agitating the Cunard line, the engineers who have been working on the channel, and the War Department for some time.

ODESSA, Sept. 2. -- The Black Hundreds began rioting hers this afternoon, alleging that the Jews were responsible for the explosion of the bomb in the courtyard of the Central Police Station here on Saturday morning, which resulted in the killing of an artillery officer and four policemen, although it was stated at the time that the bomb was accidentally dropped by the officer.

WASHINGTON, May 6.--Little if any change was shown in the volume of cash and credit sales of various types of retail stores during the latter half of 1930, despite the business recession during that period, according to a survey of twenty-five representative cities made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Further declines on the Stock Exchanger yesterday indicated to Wall Street that the reactionary influences have not been eliminated altogether from the market. At any rate, the standard issues, notably United States Steel common, were under pressure for a good part of the day.

Plans and specifications for the second half of the city's new subway system, the key line of which in Manhattan will be the Second Avenue route, will be presented shortly to the Board of Estimate, it was said yesterday by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

Jack Emmett of Stuyvesant High School was chosen last night to represent the senior and evening public high schools of Manhattan in the regional championship of the National Oratorical Contest which will be held at Town Hall May 15 under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Large loose-footed mainsails may be used in the transatlantic race to Plymouth; Eng., which starts off Newport, R.I., on July 4, but there will be a penalty for them. Leaders in the city's philanthropic, political, religious and art fields ex pressed regret last night at the death of Robert W. de Forest.

Thomas Snell, a trustee of Cooper Union and house painter to old New York families for the last eighty-six years, died of pneumonia at his home at 323 Lexington Avenue on Tuesday night at the age of 94. He had been ill for ten days.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 6 (AP).-- Mortimer L. Schiff, New York banker, was elected president of the Na tional Council, Boy Scouts of America, at the close of its annual meeting here today. The council will meet next year in New York.

Butler in an address here tonight related how a Mexican President who had defied the United States signed an order, while under the influence of liquor, which gave a Marine Corps spy the power to enter every army barracks in Mexico City, count the soldiers, examine, the equipment and ascertain the number of guns in the fortresses.

LISBON, Portugal, May 6 (AP).-- The cruiser Carvalho Araujo and the former liner of the same name, now known as auxiliary cruiser "E," were ready tonight to sail with 600 men to put down the rebellion which broke out in Portuguese Guinea April 17.

CLEVELAND, May 6.--Louise Gaudig, 17 years old, died today from a bullet wound inflicted Monday night by a mysterious sniper as she was walking home with a girl cousin. Miss Gaudig was the fourth girl shot here in the same manner within a week.

The pamphlet report of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company for 1930 shows that as of Dec. 31 last total assets were $703,891,462, compared with $712,054,187 at the end of 1929. ITHACA, N.Y., May 6.--Behind Ray White's fine pitching, Columbia defeated Cornell by 5 to 0 on Hoy Field today in their second Eastern Intercollegiate League encounter of the season. The Lions took undisputed possession of third place with three victories and two defeats.

CATSKILL, N.Y., May 6.--Jack (Legs) Diamond will live to stand trial next month on the kidnapping and torture charges already pending against him and on possible new indictments which are expected to be handed up to Supreme Court Justice J. Walter Bliss here Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 6.--Moving steadily toward the billion-dollar mark, the treasury deficit on May 4, the latest figures available today, was $903,320,757. Total government ordinary receipts through that date were $2,694,682,531 and expenditures $3,598,003,288. Receipts showed a decline of $526,000,000 from the same period last year, while expenditures were $225,000,000 higher.
BERLIN, May 6.--Germany's unemployment problem cannot be solved without new extensive credits and since no domestic capital is available, the money must come from abroad.

The Public Service Commission, after hearing final argument yesterday on an application of the railroads of the State for an increase of intrastate class freight rates to conform with interstate schedules set by the Interstate Commerce Commission, reserved decision. The case was started in 1929.

Mrs. Sarah M. Goodhart, acting principal of Public School 154, in Brooklyn, told the police yesterday that she did not believe in turning schoolboys over to them and refused to surrender two of her pupils or point them out for arrest.

America, idealistic, rich in natural resources and pursuing the things of the spirit more keenly than any other nation, will find a new civilization "in which Europe will be reborn," Dr. Rabindranath Tagore, Indian poet and philosopher declares in his birthday message to this country, made public yesterday by The American Tagore Association. Dr. Tagore's seventieth birthday will be tomorrow according to the Western calendar, although according to the Bengali calendar it was yesterday.

More than 400 guests attended the annual luncheon given by Mrs. Dunlap Hopkins yesterday at the New York School of Applied Design for Women, 160 Lexington Avenue. The luncheon marked the opening of the students' exhibition and the awarding of $1,600 in cash prizes and scholarships.

Kiernan of the Forty-first District, Brooklyn.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 12. --Information reaching Montevideo from reliable sources in Buenos Aires indicates improvement in the Argentine situation, with a tendency on the part of political parties to await the outcome of the November elections.

Trading was extremely dull on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, with but few signs of strength in the list. Some issues managed to hold their own sufficiently to close at Monday's levels, but the majority was lower. Trading was characterized by frequent spells of almost complete inactivity.

COATESVILLE, Pa., May 12.-- Senator James J. Davis, during an address at dedicatory exercises for the new veteran's hospital here this afternoon, assailed what he described as the "mailed fist" of foreign powers attempting to force tariff reductions and war debt cancellations from this country through the meeting of the International Chamber of Commerce in Washington last week.
