LONDON, May 12.--Most sections of the stock market were quiet today, with a certain amount of forced liquidation still in evidence. In the gilt-edge market profit-taking continued, conversion 3 per cents dropping to 82 3-16.
DAYTON, Ohio, May 12 (AP).--Air and sea forces of the United States were on the move tonight for war against an unseen enemy.

John Constantine, stock broker, has bought a seven-room and threebath Norman type stone house at Charlotte Place and Andover Road, in the Manor Woods section of Hartsdale Fells. The dwelling was built by Michele Maluccio from plans by Herbert Johnson, architect. The Maurice S. Goodman Associates arranged the sale.
The American Commonwealths Power Corporation has been incorporated in Trenton, N.J., by the Corporation Trust Company of 120 Broadway with a capital of 1,000,000 shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--Plans of the stockholders' protective committee of the Chicago Alton Railroad to disclose certain alleged secret negotiations between Kuhn, Loeb Co., New York banking firm, and the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, leading up to the latter's purchase of the Alton, were rejected today by the Interstate Commerce Commission as irrelevant.

The Long Island Railroad Company filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission a petition asking to be relieved of the obligation to provide a substitute bus service before abandoning its Whitestone branch in Queens.

The annual meeting of the Board of Education yesterday, at which Dr. George J. Ryan was re-elected president for his tenth consecutive term, was transformed into a ceremony of tribute to Dr. Ryan as the builder of the greatest free education system in the world.

GENEVA, May 12.--The fact that the Austrian Government has had to advance 100,000,000 schillings ($14,070,000) to the Vienna Creditanstalt Bank will have direct practical repercussions on the discussions of the Austro-German customs union project beginning here Friday in the meetings of the European Union Commission and the international committee of control over the Austrian League loan.

The Board of Estimate, sitting yesterday in Committee of the Whole, approved an appropriation of $3,000,000 to augment the funds already voted under the State law for oldage relief. Earlier in the year the board had appropriated $2,500,000 for that purpose.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 12.-- With only two more days of practice for the Derby races Saturday, the seatings in the Princeton varsity heavyweight shells were radically revamped today, with no indications being given as to which combination Coach Chuck Logg will designate as the Tiger entry against the first Cornell and Yale varsities.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--A continuation of generally lax conditions of employment throughout the country in the first week of May, with further slight declines in the East, was shown in reports made public today by the President's Emergency Committee for Employment.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12.--Plans for the establishment within a year of transatlantic passenger-freight steamship service from Philadelphia, with three seven-day liners plying between this port and Liverpool and Manchester, were announced today by General W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Five police lieutenants, ten sergeants and fourteen patrolmen received orders yesterday to appear this morning at 9:30 at the office of the chief clerk of the department at Police Headquarters to receive promotion to higher grades. The men will receive the new badges from Commissioner Mulrooney in his office.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 12.--A declaration made by George A. Hastings, new secretarial aide to President Hoover, that "education plus action will conquer tuberculosis," and a discussion of B.C.G., an antituberculosis serum discovered five years ago by the French scientist, Calmette, but not yet universally adopted, were features of the second day's session of the National Tuberculosis Association.

PARIS, May 12.--Aristide Briand is not going to have anything like a walk-over at tomorrow's Presidential election. Despite his wishes and despite his past record as a collaborator with Raymond Poincare and Andre Tardieu, he is being run as a party candidate against Paul Doumer, president of the Senate, and every one expects that the vote will be very close. M. Briand tonight is only slightly the favorite.

Stearly, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Newark, declared today in an address at the opening of the fiftyseventh annual conference of the diocese at Grace Church here.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--The Federal Government's drought relief program, for which a total of $67,000,000 was appropriated after much controversy between the President and the Senate, has virtually been completed for an outlay of $47,000,000, President Hoover announced today.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 12.-- Horton Smith, Joe Turnesa and an Englishman, Len Holland, established a record for the Hesketh course today in the final qualifying round of the $7,500 golf tourney, each returning a 69 against the par, of 76.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 12.-- Republican prosperity was the byword at the tenth annual luncheon of the Westchester Women's Republican Club in the County Centre here today. ALBANY, May 12.--A judgment of $385,550.14 obtained by Walter G. Filer of California against the Creole Syndicate in the Appellate Division, First Department, was unanimously reversed today by the Court of Appeals. Stimson's recent speeches, in the opinion of several South American newspapers.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning received a succession of honors yesterday on the tenth anniversary of the Episcopate, the fortieth of his ordination and the sixty-fifth of his birth. The tributes included gifts, resolutions and telegrams.

LONDON, May 12.--A world-wide appeal for a memorial fund for the completion of the humanitarian work of Dr. Fridtjof Nansen will be made tomorrow, on the first anniversary of the death of the explorer and peace worker, by leading statesmen of seven nations.

BOSTON, May 12.--President Marsh and the trustees of Boston University announced today the creation of a new deanship of student health and physical education for the university and the appointment as dean of Dr. Frederick Rand Rogers of Albany, N.Y., Stanford and Columbia graduate, who will resign his post as director of the Division of Health and Physical Education in the New York State Education Department to enter upon his new duties in September.
The general investigation of the New York City Government by the Hofstadter legislative committee will be speeded up after the meeting of the committee tomorrow.

CHICAGO, May 12.--The Golden Gloves fighters of the United States tonight triumphed over representatives of France in an international amateur boxing tournament before a crowd of 40,000 at Soldier Field. The winners of the New York-Chicago fights defeated five of the national champions of France and lost to three others.

The unveiling of a bronze replica of Houdon's statue of George Washington, a gift of the class of 1880, will mark the annual charter day ceremonies today commemorating the eighty-fourth anniversary of the College of the City of New York.

MADRID, May 13.--Under cover of resentment against monarchist provocations Spain's provisional republic tonight dropped all semblance of good-will toward the exiled King, Alfonso and ordered the confiscation of his personal property throughout Spain.

WASHINGTON, May 13.--Emergency War Department plans for the mobilization of an army of 4,000,000 men through conscription and for the maximum operation of necessary industries under the guidance of civilians were described today by General Douglas MacArthur, Chief of Staff, to the War Policies Commission.

PARIS, May 13.--Although the people took no direct part in the voting for President today, there was a popular fete during the afternoon. Banks closed down, business houses let their employes out early and many gathered downtown or went to Versailles to hear the returns.

A resolution looking toward the appointment of an Episcopal commission to consider economic adjustments to protect workers against a recurrence of the hardships of business depressions was adopted after a lively debate yesterday by the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York at the second and last day of its 148th annual convention in Synod House of St. John the Divine.

VATICAN CITY, May 13 (AP).--Pope Pius XI will speak in Italian, French and German when he delivers his radio address Friday before 10,000 labor representatives celebrating the fortieth anniversary of the Rerum Novarum encyclical of Pope Leo XIII.

LONDON, May 13.--There was another debate on the everlasting Indian question in the House of Commons tonight. Last December in New York City the unemployed numbered close to 600,000, according to a study made for the Welfare Council by EDNA LONIGAN, formerly chief statistician of the State Labor Department. Mrs. Herbert S. Gay of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, was general chairman.

Sullivan announced eight transfers in the detective division.

WASHINGTON, May 13. National banks showed a reduction in resources of $673,217,000 between December 31 and March 25, but an increase of $777,969,000 since March 27, 1930, John W. Pole. Controller of the Currency, announced today.

Hoffman, in the current issue of The Spectator, an insurance periodical. Dr. Hoffman finds that the death rate per 100,000 population increased from 18.1 in 1929 to 20 in 1930. J., May 13.--As the last official act of the 1930-1931 undergraduate council of Princeton University, the retiring student governing body adopted a resolution last night urging "the need and advisability of an undergraduate centre. Munger, but the committee's inquiry into the Nebraska Republican Senatorial campaign of last year was held valid.

Preston F. Walsh, 38 years old, junior partner in the banking firm of Sutro Brothers Co., accidentally killed himself yesterday while cleaning an army automatic pistol in his office. He died in Beekman Street Hospital shortly before 2 o'clock, about two hours after the shooting.

PARIS, May 15.--Miss Helen Jacobs of California, Mrs. John Van Ryn, formerly Miss Marjorie Gladman, George Lott and John Van Ryn, members of the Davis Cup team, will be standard bearers for the. United States in the French international tennis championships, beginning Sunday.

With selling pressure concentrated against the best-rated industrial issues, prices continued to decline on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but not as rapidly as on the day before. United States Steel common, the recognized market leader, sold at the lowest price since July 26, 1924, and all the averages of THE NEW YORK ...

The world of the theatre, in which he had been a picturesque and important figure for many years, continued yesterday to pay its tribute to David Belasco, who died suddenly Thursday afternoon at the age of 76. Messages from all parts of this country and from many others were sent to his daughter, Mrs. Morris Gest.
A report that J.P. Morgan will be the next president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be published today in The Art News.
CATSKILL. N.Y. May 15.--Witnesses questioned today in the investigation by Attorney General John J. Bennett into activities of Jack (Legs) Diamond's gang supplied much information, it was said.

CHICAGO, May 15.--Conflicting influences tended today to hold wheat prices within a range of 1 cent on the Chicago Board of Trade. Continued dry weather in the Canadian Northwest, with rainfall in the last six weeks ranging around 25 per cent of that of the same time last year, ...

Samuel H. Hofstadter, chairman of the legislative committee to investigate the government of New York City, and Samuel Seabury, its counsel, made it clear yesterday that they intended to proceed with the inquiry without regard to any obstructive tactics by the Democratic members.

An indictment charging failure to file income tax returns and attempted evasion was handed up yesterday by a Federal grand jury against Henry Miro, Harlem policy banker, who also faces indictment by a county grand jury for perjury as a result of his testimony in the Appellate Division inquiry last Wednesday when he was shown to have banked $1,251,000 in four years.

BALTIMORE, May 15.--Soaring 1,500 feet over the Gunpowder River with eighteen passengers aboard, a tri-motored Richmond-New York transport plane caught fire late today near Aberdeen, Md. The pilot landed the ship in flames on the reservation at Fort Hoyle. All aboard were saved.

STOCKHOLM, May 15.--Labor disturbances, which led yesterday to a fight between the military and striking workers at the Kramfors sawmills, became more serious today. While the troops have succeeded in subduing the disturbances, sympathy strikes are spreading over the whole country.

A flood of applications for employment at sea, in greater volume than has marked the average mid-May season, has reached the offices of ship lines in the last few weeks from college students or their spokesmen. The business depression has closed many doors to students seeking Summer employment ashore, but since a similar depression has hit the shipping business the ship lines have notified such applicants that no positions are open.

LONDON, May 15.--In a speech to the National Liberal Federation at Buxton today, David Lloyd George said in justifying his support of the Labor Government that there was not the slightest trace of socialism in Premier MacDonald's Administration.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15.-- Hunters were the attraction that drew a large gathering of horse show enthusiasts to the arena this evening for the third session of the seventh annual New Haven Horse Show. Competition was close and as performances were excellent, conformation usually decided the way the ribbons went.
HAVANA, May 15.--Armed rebellion is reported to be imminent or perhaps even to have started in Oriente Province. Some rumors set midnight tonight as the time for a general revolt to begin.

Harold Russell Ryder, 35 years old, whose loose management of Woody Co., a brokerage firm he founded in 1929, led to its failure last Summer with liabilities of more than $2,000,000, was sentenced to three to ten years in Sing Sing by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday.
Tommy Loughran has qualified for recognition as a giant killer and a serious contender again for the world's heavyweight title.
VATICAN CITY, May 15.--The following is the text of a radio ad dress delivered today by Pope Pius XI, translated by The Associated Press as the Pontiff spoke:
NEWPORT, R.I., May 15.--Simplicity marked the marriage this morning of Miss Louise Astor Van Alen, daughter of Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen, and Prince Alexis Z. Mdivani of Paris.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 15 (AP).-- Butter Beans, which cost her owner, J.M. Reed, only $25 at Havana last Winter, clearly established herself as the best 2-year filly in the West when she easily accounted for the thirty-seventh running of the Debutante Stakes, feature of the Derby eve card.

The regional championship in the National Oratorical Contest on the Constitution, sponsored in this district by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was won last night by Jack Emmett of Stuyvesant High School, Manhattan. He was one of eight contestants who discussed the Constitution in prepared and extemporaneous speeches...

CAIRO, May 15.--The discovery of the first complete sanctuary with all annexes of the crocodile god Sekneb tunis of the ancient city of Tebtynis (Ummel Boreigat) is the chief result of the season's excavations in the district of Fayum, "lake of the crocodiles."

"If Booth Had Missed," a threeact play of the "reconstruction period" by Arthur Goodman, brought to the Morningside Players of Columbia University their second successive victory in the second National Long Play Tournament, according to the decision of the committee of five judges last night at the Craig Theatre.

A thrilling nose-and-nose finish in the Toboggan Handicap, with the first three horses only inches apart, was the vital touch which made yesterday's opening day program at Belmont Park one of the most mem orable in the history of America's Newmarket. Never in the long history of this six-furlong sprint has the Toboggan furnished so thrilling a result.

At the dedication of the bust of President MONROE in the Hall of Fame several Latin-American diplomatists were present. In what spirit did they listen to the reading of that letter in which Mr. ROOT declared that the Monroe Doctrine "neither ...

LONDON, May 15.--Samuel R. McKelvie, former Governor of Nebraska; Dr. Alonzo E. Taylor of Stanford University and Nils A. Olsen, chief of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, arrived here today to attend next week's conference of the wheat-exporting countries of the world, which will begin next Monday.

To send a solid "wet" delegation from this State to the House of Representatives in 1932 is part of the program of the New York State division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, as outlined yesterday by Mrs. John S. Sheppard, its chairman, at the annual meeting of the advisory committee of the organization, held at ...

HARRISONBURG, Va., May 15.-- Woodrow Wilson's prophecy of the blighting effects of high tariff walls upon world trade was held to have come true by Dr. William E. Dodd, Professor of American History, of the University of Chicago, in an address today dedicating the administrative building and auditorium at the Harrisonburg State Teachers College to...

LONDON, May 15.--Gilt-edge securities were again the centre of interest on the Stock Exchange today. Business at first was mostly of a selling nature, but in the afternoon renewed support appeared. The conversion 3 per cents advanced to 83. The few movements in the industrial group were favorable to the holders. More forced selling was reported.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 15.-- Directors "having little conception of their duties and responsibilities, or ignoring them," were blamed today for many of the bank failures throughout the country in the last two years by F.G. Awalt of Washington, D.C., Deputy Controller of the Currency.

Three meet records were broken and two C.C.N.Y. marks were bettered and another tied at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday as Manhattan College conquered the City College track and field team in their annual dual meet by a 66-to-60 score. The victory for the Jaspers brought to a halt a six-meet winning streak in dual competition which C.C.N.Y. had compiled since 1929.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 15.-- The possibility that the Garden City Golf Club trophy may spend the Summer up-State loomed today when J.B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., defeated Eddie Driggs, holder of the Long Island amateur championship, in a twenty-hole match that was intensely exciting even if loosely played.

Three raids upon factory payrolls, staged in widely separated parts of Manhattan and the Bronx by three groups of armed thugs, resulted yesterday in a loss of $10,700 to business men. In each case the robbers escaped.

VATICAN CITY, May 15.--A resume of an encyclical to be issued by Pope Pius XI on the social and labor question was given out here today. It is entitled, "An Encyclical Letter of Pope Pius XI on the Social and Labor Question, on the Fortieth Anniversary of the Encyclical 'Rerum Novarum,' May 15, 1931." The text follows:

SOUTHPORT, England, May 15.-- T. Henry Cotton, the young British golf professional who has passed over in the selection of England's Ryder Cup team which will meet the United States team at Scioto, Columbus, Ohio, because he wished to have a free hand to remain in America if he won the open championship there, today beat all comers for the most valuable money prize ever offered in European golf competition.

Sir ARTHUR QUILLER-COUCH has been giving some advice to young writers. Many of them have sat at his feet, when he was lecturing, and others have read and profited by his books. He takes a kindly interest in them all. He believes that they ought to be encouraged, but also that they should be warned against what he conceives to be a fault into which they easily fall.

NEW LONDON, May 15.--Secretary Mellon of the Treasury laid the cornerstone of the new Coast Guard Academy here this afternoon and watched Rear Admiral Billard as he gave commissions to the thirty-three cadets who were graduated as ensigns.

Development by General Theatres Equipment, Inc., of a motion picture projector which will handle a film of any width from the standard 35 millimeter to 70 millimeter, was announced in the annual report of the company issued yesterday by Harley L. Clarke, president. The development, which is now available for ...

More than seventy railroads which serve this port joined yesterday with the State and with the city of New York in opposing the application of New Jersey to the Interstate Commerce Commission to break up the unit freight rate now charged to all points in the port district and to replace it with a lower rate for the New Jersey side than for points in New York.

The Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly, at the request of Mayor Walker, referred yesterday to its committee or local laws the Mayor's bill transferring from the License Department to the Police Department the duty of licensing and regulating the conduct of cabarets, dance halls and night clubs.
The International Paper Company announced yesterday a reduction of $5 a ton in the price of newsprint, and made public its new price schedule for the period ending Dec. 31, 1936.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15.-- Twelve crews from four universities worked out on the Housatonic at Derby today for the last time before the start late tomorrow afternoon of the Carnegie Cup regatta, preceded by the Big Three lightweight race for the Goldthwaite Cup.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 15.-- Justice Arthur C. Salmon of Special Sessions Court, New York City, died at the Miramar Apartments here today at 2 P.M. after an illness of a little more than a month. Justice Salmon, who was on the bench for twenty-one years, was 78 years old.

WOODBURY, N.J., May 15.-- After a four-mile automobile chase, George Miller Jr., 42 years old, a World War veteran of Pitman, argued for fifteen minutes in the woods at Wright's Mills this afternoon over whether he would surrender Paul Cramme Jr., 10, to the child's father.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 15.--Mr. and Mrs. P.B. Postthwaite entertained Mr. and Mrs. C.L. Pierce Jr. with a dinner this evening in the Homestead. Samuel L. Nicholson had General Otto H. Falk and C.E. Searle as his guests. Mr. and Mrs. L.N. Wood entertained Mr. and Mrs. M.F. Tiernan. Mr. and Mrs. E.B. Lewis entertained Mr. and Mrs. A. E. McBride.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 15.-- The new Coolidge 900,000-volt X-ray tube, in which flying electrons are discharged at a speed of 184,000 miles per second, and equivalent to enormous amounts of radium, 99 per cent the speed of light, will be shipped from the General Electric Laboratories here next week to Memorial Hospital.

Continuing his defense of the State examinations given to 7,000 graduates of city elementary schools in 1929, Dr. John L. Tildsley, District Superintendent of Schools, who administered the tests, branded yesterday as "bunk" and "bluff" the assertions of Superintendent of Schools William J. O'Shea that the questions asked in the tests were not within the scope of the training the city pupils had received.

Indicative of the desire of State and municipal officials throughout the country to take advantage of the high prices now prevailing in the municipal bond market, next week's schedule of awards will be heavy. Forty-nine communities will be in the market with bonds and notes aggregating $46,641,048, compared with $63,832,922 this week, which included New York's $52,000,000 of corporate stock, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $39,319,819.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--William R. Castle Jr., Acting Secretary of State in the absence in New York of Secretary Stimson, stated today that the government will gladly participate in an international conference on silver, although unwilling to call one itself, since other countries are more directly concerned in restoring...

The resumption of the baseball season at the Polo Grounds yesterday found the players of both sides a bit stiff muscularly and mentally after their holidays. The Giants likewise had trouble finding the ball with their bats when there were runs to be driven home.

SAMUEL RUGGLES, who one hundred years ago deeded to trustees a part of his estate for a park, may be called a pioneer New York "city planner." Having purchased a portion of the old Duane farm, of upland (Bowery Hill) and morass, extending east from the "Old Bowery," he "tumbled" the hill into ...

MINEOLA, L.I., May 15.--A strange story of the forming of a suicide cult by thirty residents of Nassau and Suffolk Counties who believed themselves no longer of any use to humanity was told today by Miss Louise Schwartz of West Amityville and received some measure of credence when a check-up showed...

SHAANGHAI, May 15.--The Canton situation was further beclouded today by reports of mutinies against General Chan Chia-tang's rebel regime in addition to yesterday's defection is favor of Nanking of the forces holding the Whampao Military ...

Sunshine and victory came to Ebbets Field together yesterday and 10,000 baseball-hungry fans, who have been fasting since last Monday, found warmth and nourishment in both. The Robins defeated the Cubs, 6 to 4, and came from behind to do it.

John J. Girolamo, secretary of the loan and executive committee of the Bank of United States, was a witness yesterday in the trial of Bernard K. Marcus, president of the bank, and three associates. He refuted testimony given by several directors as to the responsibility of the defendants for the transaction which formed the basis of their indictment.

MADRID, May 15.--The Papal Nuncio filed an energetic protest with the Spanish Republican Government today on the burning of religious houses by rioters. The document is said to ask why the police failed to protect convents, churches and schools from the incendiary mobs.

GENEVA, May 15.--With the Foreign Ministers of Europe left hopelessly at sea by the defeat of Aristide Briand for the French Presidency in an already overclouded moment, Arthur Henderson at the very beginning of their meeting in the European Union Commission here this morning took the helm.

It was in 1923 that the Long Island Railroad Company began to consider abandoning the Whitestone branch, an unprofitable single-track electrically operated line running from Flushing to Whitestone Landing, with stations at College Point and Malba.

Mrs. Genevieve Potocki was recalled as one of the State's last witnesses yesterday at the trial of William B. Lewis and Edgar P. McFarland, ousted vice-squad patrolmen, charged with beating her in her apartment at 129 Cedar Street in a vice raid last September.

General business conditions changed only slightly in the past week, according to the mercantile agencies. Wholesalers and retailers reported territorial variations due almost entirely to the weather. Bradstreet's said in part:

DETROIT, May 15.--The vaunted offensive of the Yankees, which has been mowing down all opposition since invading the West, bogged down before the right arm of George Uhle today, and the result was something totally unforeseen by the forces of Joseph Y. McCarthy.

Rather than place itself in a possibly unfavorable position before the coming legislative investigation of the city administration, the Board of Estimate denied yesterday the usual request of the Department of Purchase for permission to destroy several tons of obsolete documents of 1927 and 1928.

THIS is the big day in the Blue Grass region. At Churchill Downs the thoroughbreds will be run ning in the Kentucky Derby, which started as a horse race in 1875 and developed into a national drama. There are Derbies at a dozen tracks around the coun try. There are older races than the feature event of the Kentucky racing calendar. There may be better races in the course of the year on the turf.

Bishop James Cannon Jr, of Virginia "will be subpoenaed and required to testify" when the Senate campaign fund committee resumes its publics hearings, Senator Gerald P. Nye, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday after a conference here with Senator Robert F. Wagner, one of the two other members of the committee.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 15.--A trombone choir in the ivy-covered tower of Packer Memorial Church intoned this afternoon the ancient chorale sung on Christmas Eve in 1741 when this Moravian settlement was named Bethlehem. This marked the opening of the twenty-fifth Bach Festival.

Despite the dismissal on Thursday of the search warrant on which the Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity was raided last April, Andrew McCampbell, Prohibition Administrator, said last night that again he would ask United States Attorney Medalie to sue to padlock the club.

The industrial depression is bringing back to east side tenements thousands of workers who had moved in the last ten years to better quarters, it was reported yesterday by Edward Corsi, head workers of Haarlem House, at a meeting of the officers and directors at the Downtown Association, 50 Pine Street.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 15.--The government said tonight that the death toll in Cairo yesterday was fifteen, with more than 100 wounded, while the writer learns from most reliable authority that the actual number of dead is now eighty-six, with more than 500 wounded. Four policemen are dead and thirty two seriously injured.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--Pennsylvania's first home regatta of the season tomorrow against Harvard and the Navy promises to attract a big turnout of alumni and followers of all three institutions to the Skuylkill course in Fairmount Park.

Members of the National Republican Club are upset over the latest episode involving Alan Fox, 1928 promoter of the pre-convention Hoover movement in this State, and his report as chairman of its committee on city affairs, in which was embodied an attack on the private life of Mayor Walker. By a vote at its April meeting the club deleted some sentences as objectionable.

The most favorable weather in the cotton belt in several weeks and the weakness in the stock market combined to drop prices on the Cotton Exchange again yesterday. New crop deliveries touched the lowest figures of the season and 65 points from the opening quotations of last Saturday.

STRATFORD, Conn., May 15.-- Memorial gates and tablets honoring Samuel Johnson, the first president of King's College, now Columbia University, and his son, William Samuel Johnson, the first president of Columbia College, were presented by Columbia to Christ Episcopal Church cemetery at dedicatory exercises this afternoon.

The Newfoundland Government has called for tenders on a new issue of $8,000,000 5 per cent bonds due on June 30, 1956, under the loan act of 1931. Peter J. Cashin, Minister of Finance and Customs, announces that the bids, which are to be opened on May 22, may specify payment in dollars or in pounds sterling.
WASHINGTON, May 15.--Heavy buying by Russia of American industrial machinery caused such exports, in 1930, to reach the highest level since the post-war year of 1920.
MONTEVIDEO, May 15.--Montevideo news papers are vigorously protesting against continuation of Argentina's alleged policy of making Montevideo the dumping ground for all of its undesirables.

Miss Ruth Nichols, holder of world records for women for speed and altitude, plans on her transatlantic flight to cross the ocean in less than thirteen hours. Miss Nichols in an interview yesterday discussed her preparations. She said she did not know just when she would start, but that it would certainly be before the end of June. If everything goes well she may start within two weeks.

While machine guns clattered and airplanes droned overhead, the annual military field day of the New York University Reserve Officers' Training Corps was held yesterday at Ohio Field, University Heights. More than 1,000 spectators viewed the manoeuvres of the 800 student members of the corps.
LONDON, May 15.--Britain's place in the European scheme was considered by Professor Andre Siegfried today in addressing the Oxford Luncheon Club on Anglo-French relations.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., May 15.-- Prohibition was debated here tonight by Pierre S. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., chairman of the executive committee of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, and O.G. Christgau, assistant to the general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League.

If the public is not aroused over the alleged threats to personal right and liberty inherent in Judge SEABURY'S plan to hold private hearings in the city-wide investigation by subcommittees of one, the Democratic committee members have only themselves to blame.

Johnny Balquist, diminutive Columbia second baseman, rose to thrilling heights yesterday at Baker Field by hoisting a single over second to enable John Siergiej to score from second with the run that defeated Colgate, 3 to 2.

PARIS, May 15.--While the decision of the Bank of England to lower its rate was received here as a hopeful sign, banking opinion is inclined to the view that making cheap money cheaper will not accomplish a great deal in the way of trade revival.

Twenty-six American cities which extended their hospitality to the French fliers COSTE and BELLONTE, heroes of the Paris-New York westward crossing, are now the recipients of the French people's appreciation. LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 15.--For the first time since Bubbling Over won in 1926, it looks like dry footing and sunshine for the fifty-seventh running of the Kentucky Derby tomorrow. Probably 60,000 persons will crowd into Churchill Downs to see the Blue Grass classic, and Louisville, bright with smart frocks and straw hats, buzzes with talk of Twenty Grand and Mate.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--Practically all immigration to the United States has been limited to "desirable" aliens as a result of President Hoover's order of last Summer to the State Department that consular officers should refuse visas to immigrants who might become "public charges," the President said today.

Foreign funds in this market for short term loans, which are estimated at $2,000,000,000 or more, found conditions made less attractive by two developments yesterday. LEXINGTON, K.Y., May 15.--The highest average of any of the major thoroughbred auctions held in the blue grass this week was realized today when thirtyfour lots sold at the disposal sale of the Gifford A. Cochran estate for a total of $104,575, an average of $3,075.

In a day of little activity in the markets, prices of stocks slipped down again, though with most of the changes small. Financial movements were mostly of a kind that reflected no very definite trend but a good deal of perplexity. It was an obviously depressed French Foreign Minister who appeared at Geneva yesterday after his defeat in the Presidential election. All his colleagues on the commission to study his projects of economic relief and European union hastened to assure him that he retained their fullest confidence and affection.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--A proposal for controlling the wheat surplus by a nation-wide agreement among farmers was held impractical today by Chairman James C. Stone of the Federal Farm Board in a letter to State Senator F.J. Wilmer of Washington.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 15.--Sniper captured the featured fifth race at Beulah Park track today, traveling the mile and a sixteenth in 1:53 1-5. The victor paid $7 in the mutuels. Heatherwine, an outsider, who took the place, paid $34.20, the top price of the day. Porto Bello G. was third in a field of ten.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--A sitting of the War Policies Commission was interrupted temporarily today by the physical coliapse of Senator Claude L. Swanson of Virginia, Democratic member ol the body, but the meeting was resumed when it was found that the 69-year-old Senator had suffered only an attack of indigestion.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--How to bring adequate medical care and treatment within the reach of all Americans is the problem the committee on the costs of medical care took up for consideration when its two days' session began here today.

There was a representative gathering yesterday at Belmont Park, for the opening of the Spring meet of the Westchester Racing Association, although it was evident that many of the regulars had gone to the derby in Kentucky.
PERSONS interested in the work of the Carroll Club at 120 Madison Avenue have arranged to hold the annual boat party of the organization on Tuesday on board the Lafayette.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 16.-- Lafayette defeated Army at golf today, 5 to 4, in a match played on the links of the Storm King Golf Club at Cornwell, N.Y.

LONDON, May 17.--Sir John Simon will represent Lord Kylsant when his summonses in connection with the Royal Mail Steamship Company's affairs are heard at Mansion House on June 2.

THERE are thirty-six magistrates' courts in Greater New York, presided over, on schedule, by forty-nine magistrates and one chief magistrate. Nearly every person charged with crime in New York City is first brought before these courts.

LATE Spring is the most favorable season for garden parties. On the afternoon of May 21, the an nual garden party given by the trustees and the ladies' auxiliary of the New York Zoological Society will be held at the Zoological Park.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 16.-- Three thousand library leaders from all of the States, Canada and Mexico will attend the annual conference of the American Library Association at Yale University June 22-27. Adam Strohm, president of the association, will preside and President Angell of Yale will welcome the delegates at the opening session.
THE antique story of Prometheus has teased more than one poet out of thought, and more than one a poet of great name. Miss Deutsch does not, as we see it, contribute much to the theme.

Financial events of the last two years show that no magic has yet been discovered which can prevent the recurrence of business cycles, says the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation of New York in its quarterly review.
Three gunmen held up a branch store of the Hilton Company, Inc., men's clothiers, at Broadway and Fourteenth Street, at 9 o'clock last night and escaped with $3,000.

A DANCE recital for the benefit of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children at 128 East 112th Street will be given on Wednesday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza, under the direction of Miss George Harris. Later in the afternoon tea will be served.

LONDON, May 16.--No solution is yet in sight for the thorny question of war debts, Roy Howard, American publisher, who is now in London, will be quoted as saying in an interview in The Sunday Times tomorrow.
BOGOTA, May 9.--The government of Colombia has employed William T. Roddy, American customs expert, to reorganize and supervise the national customs service under a threeyear contract.

Former Controller Charles L. Craig appealed yesterday from the judgment for $139,139 in his favor in the suit against the city of New York for $350,000 for services as counsel in the five-cent-fare litigation. The judgment was based on a verdict for $125,000 directed by Supreme Court Justice Glennon. The notice of appeal is based on the plaintiff's con tention that he is entitled to a larger sum.

BOSTON, May 16.(AP)--Although threatened several times with disqualification, Harry L. Clark of Boston won the National A.A.U. 50,000meter walking championship without great difficulty today at Franklin Field.

MONTIVIDEO, May 16.--A hundred or more members of an international white slave gang who are seeking to settle in Montevideo are to be intrened at the quarantine station on Flores Island, off the Uruguayan Coast, according to treliable reports in official circles, where it is said that President Terra will sign a decree to that effect early next week.

A TRANSATLANTIC liner on the journey from England to America strikes upon an ice berg. A slight grinding sound is almost unnoticed by the passengers, each absorbed in his own affairs. The engines are stopped.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Debits to individual accounts, as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ended May 13, aggregated $10,197,000,000, or 20 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 30 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

LONGVIEW, Texas, May 16 (AP).-- Nine new wells, adding an estimated daily potential production of 155,000 barrels of oil to the output of the Lathrop pool in East Texas, were brought in during the twenty-fourhour period ended at noon yesterday. Three other wells were near completion.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 16.-- When Chairman William L. Ward of the Westchester County Republican Committee returns in June from the trip to Europe for which he embarked on Wednesday, final decision will be made relative to the Republican candidates in the county election next Fall.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Employment in fifteen industrial groups throughout the nation showed an increase last month of two-tenths of 1 per cent, while the monthly payroll totals for the same groups declined 1.5 per cent, as compared with March; the Department of Labor announced today.

CLEVELAND, May 16.--John A. Novario, former assistant police prosecutor and member of the Republican County Executive Committee, died today in a hospital, where he underwent as operation for appendicitis nine days ago. Death was attributed to Bright's disease. He was 36 years old.

Formation of a Canadian committee, the first since the opening of the International Chamber of Commerce, to take its place in all deliberations of the chamber, has been approved by Canadian delegates who attended the sixth general congress of the chamber in Washington.
WASHINGTON, May 16.--The exhibition of a motion picture held to be derogatory to a South American republic hay raised the question as to what authority, if any, the Federal Government has over films.

Champion Vigow o' Valley Farm, a Russian wolfhound, yesterday charmed and thrilled a crowd of 3,000 spectators by his beautiful performance in the annual Queensboro Kennel Club show at the Aqueduct race track. Majestically striding through the sporting hounds groups, Vigow gave the first indications that the rest of the 700 dogs would have to beware.

BERLIN, May 16 (AP).--Aristide Briand's sharp reply to Foreign Minister Curtius in Geneva today was viewed with astonishment and uneasiness in official circles here. Press comments reflect general surprise at the turn taken by what was widely hoped would be a conciliatory meeting.
URBANA, Ill., May 16.--Dr. Samuel W. Parr, emeritus Professor of Applied Chemistry of the University of Illinois, died of heart disease here tonight. He was 74 years old.

New York University defeated Manhattan, 17 to 7, yesterday at Ohio Field in a free-hitting baseball game before a record Alumni Day gathering of more than 6,000. Bob McNamara was effective for the Violet for the most part.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 16. --Unless the open date on the Williams baseball schedule for one week from today is filled, the Purple nine will play three out-of-town games during the next two weeks before entertaining Amherst in the annual Memorial Day contest between the ancient foes here.

In an article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 12, entitled "The Chemical Make-Up of the Universe," it was erroneously stated that rhenium was the most recent chemical element to be discovered. This should have read "one of the most recent" chemical elements. Rhenium was discovered in Germany in 1925.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 16.-- Princeton put on a strong finish today but fell short of victory in the annual baseball game with Holy Cross, losing by 6 to 3.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The Navy Department awarded contracts today for 2,014,150 barrels of fuel oil at a cost of $1,750,063.25.for the requirements of navy yards and stations on the Atlantic Coast during the fiscal year 1932. Among the successful bidders were a number of domestic companies as well as the Shell Petroleum Company.

More than 10,000 boys are studying mechanical engineering in the United States, according to findings of Walter J. Greenleaf, specialist, of the Office of Education. A survey just made is embodied in a new circular, "Mechanical Education," issued by the office.

A group of twenty-two brick homes of English design has been completed by Frank Richards at 217th Street and Foch Boulevard, St. Albans, L. I., and the same builder has just started work on a new group of sixty-nine dwellings on adjacent property. The houses are a block east of Springfield Boulevard. Paved streets and a sewer system have been installed.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP).--National forests attracted 31,904,515 visitors last year, traveling by automobile, train and walking. There was a gain of 146,284 visitors, as compared with 1929, but the 1929 gain was 8,000,000 over 1928. Camping in Michigan forests gained 60 per cent. Arizona showed the largest gain in all types of recreational uses, with 1,225,000 more visitors than the previous year.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP).--The Navy Department was informed today that the submarine tender Canopus had been temporarily disabled by boiler trouble and was being towed into Shanghai by the mine sweeper Pigeon. The Canopus broke down yesterday 120 miles from Shanghai in bad weather.

Deposits in savings banks in New York State passed $5,000,000,000 for the first time in April, it was revealed in the monthly report of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, issued yesterday. The net gain was $41,413,183, bringing the total at the end of April to $5,000,270,647.
ANDOVER, Mass., May 16.--The new Addison Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy was dedicated with an informal private ceremony today, and will be opened to the public Monday.

SEATTLE, May 16 (AP).--Miss Helene Madison, Seattle's aquatic ace, created a new record in the Pacific Northwest A.A.U. indoor swimming championships last night. Miss Madison, picking up on her own world's mark for 220 yards, free style, won in 2:34.8, clipping off two-tenths of a second from her previous mark. The Washington Athletic Club team, headed by Miss Madison, easily won the two-day meet.

BERLIN, May 15.--A housewives' gas mask company has been organized in Berlin to see what profit can be made out of the fear of a coming poison gas war which has been created by recent propaganda in the Nationalist press. Eaton had been unfair to Continental. Mr. Eaton was chairman of Continental at the time of the transactions, but has resigned. Today's answers defended the deals as fair and reasonable.

Ten bushels of corn is generally regarded as the average amount of feed required to produce 100 pounds of pork. It takes 546 pounds of corn to make 100 pounds of live pork, says the Kansas State Board of Agriculture, or at the rate of 1,092 pounds for a 200-pound hog. The International Paper Company announced yesterday that its customers in New York City would receive a retroactive reduction of $5 a ton for newsprint purchased from Jan. 1, 1931, to April 1, 1931. Figures for other zones are being worked out.

CAIRO, May 18.--There were ten deaths today, the last of the three Egyptian Parliamentary election days, according to government figures. Two of the victims were women. No deaths occurred in Cairo, the ten persons being killed in the Dakhaliah District, where a crowd attempted to burn polling booths and stoned the police. Troops opened fire.

LONDON, May 18.--Paul Robeson, American Negro actor, who opened in Eugene O'Neill's "The Hairy Ape" a week ago, is now in a hospital here suffering from laryngitis as a result of the severe strain on his voice and the play has been withdrawn after only five performances.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--Any move on the part of industry to bring about reductions in wages will be considered by the administration as a violation of confidence, and as justifying organized labor in asking for increases, Secretary of Labor Doak declared today.

GENEVA, May 18.--The delegates of twenty-seven European capitalistic countries in the European Union Commission of the League of Nations today heard their economic difficulties diagnosed by their Soviet critic, Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff, who in an extraordinary discourse held their attention for more than an hour on the subject of the world crisis.

HONGKONG, May 13.--General Yung Ting-hui, who commanded the "Police Preservation Corps," which was defeated and surrendered at the Whampoa Military Academy, has succeeded in reaching Hongkong. He reports his force was outnumbered and overwhelmed and that the casuties on each side probably totaled 300.

LONDON, May 18.--In accordance with the Soviet Government's plans for this year's lumbering operations, as ascertained by The Times, London, there are now about 2,000,000 laborers working on the "timber front." The conditions under which they live are not and cannot be uniform.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP).--The closing of public lands to oil and gas prospectors under President Hoover's oil conservation policy was sustained as legal today by the Supreme Court.

GENEVA, May 18.--The League of Nations today had one of its greatest days from immediate and long range political, juridical and economic viewpoints.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding declined $44,714,928 in April, according to the survey as of April 30 published yesterday by the American Acceptance Council. This was a comparatively small decline for the season and left the outstanding total of bills at $1,422,021,675, or $8,304,397 higher than the volume on April 30, 1930.

BASLE, May 18.--The board of directors of the Bank for International Settlements today made one of the most significant decisions of its brief history when it informed the governor of the Austrian State Bank that it was prepared to arrange a 100,000,000-schilling ($14,000,000) credit to assist the country in its present financial crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--The contention that the trend in State legislatures in the last decade has been to strengthen, not to repeal prohibition laws, was made in a statement issued this afternoon by the National Women's Christian Temperance Union.
WARSAW, May 18.--All commercial motor traffic was suspended from 7 a.m. until midnight today as a mark of protest against the recently imposed taxes for the State road fund.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--A record in the world production of cane and beet sugar was established in the 1930-31 season, the Department of Agriculture declared today, with a crop estimated at 31,506,000 short tons, compared with the previous record world crop of 30,671,000 short tons in 1928-29.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--Commercial aviation marched steadily ahead during the past twelve months under the supervision of the aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce, and every phase of the industry gained so rapidly that now the Federal airway system is superior to the airways of any nation or group of nations in the world.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 18.--With the second rehearsal of the forthcoming manoeuvres of the 672 planes of the Army Air Corps terminating this morning, the general staff of command under Brig. Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois announced that the air armada was ready to advance on Chicago tomorrow for the first tactical demonstrations.

Reich, local Democratic leader, will issue a statement tomorrow which will have a bearing on the Gubernatorial election and which will include a demand for the share of county bus taxes, said to amount to about $100,000, which he contends is due this municipality, it was revealed here today.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--Senator Borah, replying to ex-President Coolidge's statement that "silver has been cheapened by the increased use of machinery in its production," insisted today that the present condition of silver is not due to overproduction, but "to the action of governments in a deliberate effort to debase silver."

WESTWARD HO! Devon, England, May 18.--George Voigt, most feared of the United States challengers, and Douglas Fairbanks, movie star, both enhanced their reputations as golfers in the British ameteur championship today.
ELDON, Iowa, May 18 (AP).-- George C. Crowley, a magazine broker of New York City, died on an eastbound Rock Island train today. The body was removed to a mortuary here.

RENO, Nev., May 18.--Mrs. Marcia Farrell Keresey, heiress to a quarter of the Nicholas Brady fortune in New York, received a divorce here today from John McPike Keresey on grounds of cruelty. Mr. Keresey is connected with an electrical manufacturing company in New York.

Many jurists and other men prominent in public life paid tribute to the late Justice Arthur C. Salmon of Special Sessions Court by their presence at funeral services held yesterday morning in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Vanderbilt Avenue and Pacific Street, Brooklyn.

ROME, May 18 (AP).--A further expansion of the Soviet-Italian trade agreement, together with an increased guaranty of the accounts by the Italian Government, is being discussed by trade expert, it was understood today.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--Banks of the country taken as a whole, having an abundance of funds released from trade and industry, have not kept them idle, but have employed them in the investment market, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its May bulletin.

Primary elections will be held in New Jersey today with the interest centred in county struggles for leadership, since David Baird Jr. and A. Harry Moore, Republican and Democratic candidates, respectively, for the gubernatorial nomination, are unopposed. There are also five minority candidates for Governor who are unopposed in their respective parties.

The decline in prices on the Cotton Exchange was accelerated yesterday by increased selling pressure induced by weakness in securities and excellent weather in cotton producing sections. Prices reached the lowest since 1915, all months breaking a quarter cent or more and ending not far from the bottom figures of the day, 25 to 27 points lower than on Saturday.

Jacobs of this city, president of the association.

The Montross Gallery opened yesterday one of its best group exhibitions of the season, devoted entirely to American artists. This follows a brief interlude in which the gallery brought forth modern French art.

Representative PARKER, farmer, Washington County, New York, is trying to raise a crop of dreams. The hope of electing a Republican Speaker may be a dream. If it is, he is cultivating a dream-in-a-dream.

As a result of the dismasting on Saturday of Winthrop W. Aldrich's sloop Valiant in a light breeze off Oyster Bay, the new lattice-construction duralumin sticks on the three Class M racing yachts will be rebuilt.

The annual exodus of Columbia oarsmen to the waters of the upper Hudson, where they will prepare for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta at Poughkeepsie on June 16, takes place today.

CATSKILL, N.Y., June .1.--Jack Diamond was arraigned before Justice F. Walter Bliss in Supreme Court here this morning on indictments returned during his convalescence in an Albany hospital from gunshot wounds. He pleaded not guilty to the new charges of coercion and violation of the Sullivan law.

Ivanoff, directed the construction of the Stalingrad tractor plant with Mr. Calder's assistance.

The remainder of the New York engagement of "The Wonder Bar," the Al Jolson starring vehicle which had been announced to close on June 13, was abruptly canceled yesterday by the Shuberts.

Public offerings of bonds, notes and stock, excluding domestic and Canadian municipals, aggregated $1,600,697,000 during the first five months of this year, according to a compilation made by Otto P. Schwarzschild, editor of American Underwriting Houses and Their Issues.

LONDON, June 1.--Six New Yorkers are among the American debutantes and matrons who will be presented by Mrs. Charles G. Dawes, wife of the American Ambassador, at the season's third and fourth courts next week.
Seven passenger steamships are arriving today from foreign countries and one is leaving for the West Indies.

The reduction in the price of crude petroleum recently made in east Texas spread to other points in the mid-continent field yesterday, while, unofficially, the price in the Texas flush area dropped again to the lowest level at which crude has sold anywhere in the country since 1918.

SIMLA, India, June 1.--Military operations on a larger scale against the Burma rebels are likely to begin in that disturbed country forthwith, according to information at headquarters of one government of India here.

The tentative draft of charges against several Queens officials, including John J. Halleran, Public Works Commissioner, was completed yesterday at a meeting of the executive committee of the City Affairs Committee. SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 1.--George W. Wickersham, chairman of the Hoover Commission on Law Observance and Law Enforcement, was the chief speaker at the sixtieth commencement at Syracuse University today. Senator Morrow also made an address to the 1,088 students. Chancellor Flint presided.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 1 (N.A.N.A.)--Rain beat down bitterly today at Carnoustie and on the neighboring links at Barry during the first round of the qualifying tests for the British open golf championship.

Surrounded by a special police guard of twenty-five men and several Secret Service agents from Washington, Nobile Giacomo de Martino, Italian Ambassador to the United States, returned from a visit to Italy yesterday on the Cosulich liner Saturnia, and left immediately for Washington.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, June 1 (AP).--Nearly 150 Americans, most of them scattered along the Atlantic seaboard, won consolation prizes of $500 each today in the drawing for the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes on the Derby to be run at Epsom Downs Wednesday.

GENEVA, June 1.--Two American anti-narcotic policies were strongly supported by Dimitri Bogomoloff, the delegate of Soviet Russia, in urging three things as "essential" for the Moscow conference on limitation of the manufacture of narcotics here today.

JERUSALEM, June 1.--Welcome relief is afforded Palestine farmers by the High Commissioner's measure reducing by 20 per cent the tithe tax on grain for the 1930 crop, which, with the 30 per cent reduction of last year, makes a 50 per cent cut. The measure also decreases the tax on the 1931 crop 50 per cent.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 1.-- A private police booth was erected this afternoon on the beach of Ormston House, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Aldred, following the holiday week-end, during which Mr. Aldred had difficulty in his attempt to keep crowds of bathers off his property.

Marc Connelly's Pulitzer Prize play, "The Green Pastures," will end a run of sixteen months on Saturday night, June 27, at the Mansfield Theatre, where it was presented on Feb. 26, 1930, by Rowland Stebbins. Largely, no doubt, on account of the reforms instituted by Chief Justice TAFT, the Supreme Court of the United States is able practically to keep abreast of its docket.
Fifty-five seniors received diplomas yesterday afternoon at the graduation exercises of the Horace Mann School for Boys, 243d Street and Broadway.

A group of thirty scientists, artists and photographers, to be known as the Tay-Lan Expedition, will leave New York on July 1 on a two-year cruise to various parts of the world to collect specimens for several of the smaller museums throughout the country which find it too expensive to equip expeditions of their own.

Twenty-four men were placed on trial in Brooklyn yesterday before Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston charged with conspiracy to smuggle liquor. The defendants are believed by the government to have been minor employes of a Canadian whisky ring.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--Missing the opportunity during the week-end to hold a departmental economy conference at the Rapidan Camp, President Hoover called in Secretary Hyde and other "key" officials of the Department of Agriculture today for a survey of expenditudes in that branch of the government.

MADRID, June 1.--The Constituent Assembly which will rewrite Spain's Constitution, formally making the country a Republic, will be convened on July 14, it was decided at a Cabinet meeting tonight.

NORTH PLATTE, Neb., June 1 (AP).--Amelia Earhart landed here at 6:50 P.M. tonight in her autogiro, in which she is enroute to the Pacific Coast. She said she planned to remain here tonight and hop off at 7 A.M. tomorrow for Cheyenne, Wyo.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--Italian Catholic Action is the new name, with a slight change in form and much change in vigor, for a long-existing Italian organization of Catholic lay federations. It used to be called the Italian Catholic People's Union.
